 The permanent members of the UN Security Council agree on a draft resolution to increase sanctions against North Korea . The full Security Council unanimously approves it on June 12 . The draft resolution was approved by the full council .

 Nobels in 2009 were AWARDED to eight men and a RECORDSETTING five women . Recipients included a sitting United States President for strengthening INTERNATIONAL DIPLOMacy .
 The Nobel Prize for Peace for 2009 was awarded to United States Pres. Barack Obama . Obama received the Peace Prize for 2009 .
 Obama became the third sitting U.S. president to receive the prize . Theodore Roosevelt in 1906 and Woodrow Wilson in 1919 received the award .
 Jimmy Carter received the prize in 2002, two decades after he had left office . Former president Jimmy Carter also received the award in 2002 .
 For several years, the boy lived with his mother and stepfather in Indonesia and then with his maternal grandparents in Hawaii . They subsequently divorced . The boy's maternal grandparents also live in Hawaii, where he was raised .
 Obama was elected to the Illinois Senate in 1996 and to the United States Senate in 2004 . Obama has served in the Senate since 2004 . He was elected in 1996 to Illinois Senate .
 In 2008, he won the Democratic nomination for the presidency, the first African American to be chosen by a major party . He won a decisive victory in the general election .
 The Nobel Prize, which came less than nine months after Obama’s inauguration as president, was a surprise . Many people were puzzled, even shocked, by the committee's decision, given that not enough time had elapsed for the president's major policies to come to fruition .
 President Obama had made a number of dramatic shifts in foreign policy from his immediate predecessor . While coping with a severe financial and economic crisis at home, he had nonetheless made significant changes .
 Obama indicated that the U.S. would rejoin international efforts against climate change . Obama also reached an agreement with Russia to reduce nuclear weapons, attempted to restart peace talks .
 Some observers saw the award as a recognition of this new atmosphere that Obama had created . Obama has created a new atmosphere in the world .
 The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences was awarded in 2009 to Americans Elinor Ostrom and Oliver E Williamson . They established economic governance as a field of research . The prize was awarded to the two Americans .
 This extended the traditional focus of the theory of the market and market prices . The theory was extended to include the concept of market prices in the 1930s .
 The results of Ostrom’s work challenged conventional thinking that common natural resources where use by one person reduces the amount available to others are badly managed unless regulated by a central authority or privatized . The results challenge conventional thinking .
 Williamson’s work offered a new theory to explain why firms exist and why some transactions are kept within firms rather than opened to the marketplace . Williamson's work offers a theory that explains why firms are kept in firms .
 She found that societies and people often devised sophisticated methods of governance to ensure that shared natural resources are not overexploited . She found these methods were often more appropriate and effective than rules imposed by a less-well-informed government .
 The Evolution of Institutions for Collective Action , 01strom used case studies to show that private associations often avoided the “tragedy of commons” by developing the efficient use of resources .
 She found that a flaw in the “tragedy"" was its failure to take account of the often repeated interaction of people sharing a resource, which made credible use of punishments .
 Williamson received his share of the award for his analysis of economic governance, especially the boundaries of the firm . Williamson's analysis broadened understanding of why large companies evolve in some industries .
 British-born economist Ronald Coase won the Nobel Prize in 1991 for his work in institutional economics . This advanced the 1937 theory of the 1937 Coase theory of institutional economics, Coase .
 Williamson realized that it did not necessarily cost more for a firm with adequate administrative infrastructure to expand its boundaries to bring more of its business activities inside the firm .
 Williamson argued that negotiating in the market was more difficult, given the greater scope for haggling and disagreement . In papers and books beginning in 1971, notably Markets and Hierarchies, he argued .
 The high cost of writing and enforcing contracts would make it more competitive to integrate activity into the firm, where conflicts could be resolved via the use of rules and hierarchy . In such cases, the high cost could be made more competitive .
 The greater the mutual dependence of the two parties, the stronger the likelihood of integration . A firm with several suppliers in close proximity might opt for the market but would choose greater integration if there was only one .
 At the time she was awarded the Nobel Prize, Ostrom was Arthur F Bentley Professor of Political Science and co-director of the Workshop in Political Theory and Policy Analysis . Ostrom co-founded with her husband and fellow political science professor, Vincent Ostrom .
 In 1988 he returned to the faculty in Berkeley, where in 2004 he was named Edgar F Kaiser Professor Emeritus of Business, Economics and Law . In 2004, he was awarded the Edgar F. Kaiser Prof. Emeritus .
 The 2009 Nobel Prize for Literature was awarded to Romanian-born German author Herta Muller . Muller was a voice of opposition against political oppression and the anguish of human existence .
 Known primarily as a novelist, Muller was also prolific as a short-story writer, poet, and essayist . Muller's works portrayed the harsh reality of life in Romania under the repressive dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu .
 Muller for much of her career was limited to a German-speaking audience . Muller was highly regarded by those who read her, but her reputation was largely limited to those in Germany . Muller died at the age of 92 on December 18, 2009 .
 She was the 12th woman to receive the literature prize and the first German writer to win since 1999 . Gunter Grass won the award for his work in 1999 .
 Outspoken in her criticism of all forms of totalitarian rule, she was drawn to those victimized by the abuse of authority . Women traumatized by emotional and sexual exploitation .
 Muller was born on Aug., 1953, in the village of Nitchidorf in the Banat region of Romania . He was born in the Germandominated Banat, Romania, in 1953 .
 Her father served in the Waffen SS during World War II; her mother was deported to the Soviet Union and spent five years in a labour camp in present-day Ukraine . Her mother, like members of other ethnic minorities in postwar Romania, was deported .
 She was dismissed for refusing to cooperate with the Securitate, the Romanian secret police . She then worked as a translator of trade materials and a private tutor . She found employment as a kindergarten teacher and private tutor after being dismissed .
 In 1982 she published her first book, Niederungen, a collection of stories that depicted ethnic intolerance and the hypocrisy of village life governed by corruption and exclusion . Her first book was published in 1982 .
 As a result of her public condemnation of the Ceausescu dictatorship, Muller was prohibited from publishing in her native Romania . Muller was forced to publish in Romania because of her criticism of the regime .
 Muller was permitted to leave Romania in 1987, when she was allowed to enter West Germany . In 1987, she immigrated to West Germany, where she now lives in Germany . Muller was the first Romanian woman to be allowed to leave the country .
 Muller explored the condition of exile and the difficulties of assimilation . Muller's next novel, Reisende auf einem Bein (1989; Traveling on One Leg, 1998), explored the conditions of exile . Muller: "Traveling On One Leg"
 Muller’s semiautobiographical novel is narrated by a female protagonist who escapes the brutality and harassment encountered in Romania by starting a new life as an emigre in Germany . The novel is one of Muller's most distinctive works .
 Muller explored humiliation and indignity suffered by another female narrator deemed by the state as subversive and parasitic . Muller's next novel, Heute war icli mir lieber nicht begegnet, explores the humiliation of another female . Muller explored the humiliation .
 In 2009 she published her novel Atemschaukel, a work set against the backdrop of the ethnic deportation to the Soviet Union . The novel was inspired in part by the experience of her mother .
 The selection of these three individuals illustrated vividly how the traditional lines between the sciences had blurred and virtually disappeared . The selection and contribution of these . individuals illustrated how the . traditional lines . between the . sciences had . blurred, virtually disappeared.
 The ribosome is the biological engine that reads the genetic information stored in DNA and builds the corresponding proteins from amino acids . Their research elucidated the structure and function of the ribosomes .
 The process of building proteins requires cells to translate DNA into an RNA molecule that moves from the cell nucleus to the cytoplasm, where it acts as a messenger . The messenger RNA carries the genetic information to the ribosome .
 Transfer RNA retrieves amino acids needed to build the specific protein to which the mRNA corresponds . A second kind of RNA, called transfer RNA, retrieves and carries the amino acids necessary for the protein to be built . Transfer RNA retrieved and carried amino acids to build a protein to match the
 The process of matching the sequence carried from the DNA to mRNA and . thence to tRNA is the job of the ribosome .
 The first big step toward achieving this understanding was uncovering the structure of the ribosome, scientists say . The ribosomes are a key part of the understanding of life's biology .
 The small subunit is made of one large RNA molecule and roughly 32 proteins . The subunits are made of roughly 32 protein molecules .
 The large subunit is made of three RNA molecules and about 46 proteins . It is the largest subunit of the large subunits . The subunits are made of about 46 protein molecules .
 Determining the structure of these pieces is accomplished by passing X-rays through a very nearly perfect crystal composed of ribosome units . The structure of the ribosomes is determined by passing the X-ray through a crystal .
 The pattern formed by the scattering of the X-rays when UPI/Landov Thomas A Steitz they travel through the ribosome crystal produces an image that contains information about where every atom in the entire structure lies .
 Generating a nearly perfect crystal, however, is by no means an easy task . Generating an almost perfect crystal is not always easy .
 After taking a position as a postdoctoral scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the late 1960s, she became interested in deciphering the atomic structure of ribosomes by using X-rays .
 By 2000 she had achieved her goal by working with ribosomes from a bacterium that survives at high temperatures . She was able to produce crystals of the large ribosomal subunit .
 In 1998, using high-resolution Xray crystallography techniques, Steitz revealed the location of the RNA molecules in the large ribosomal subunit .
 Steitz determined the full stmcture of the large subunit in 2000 . Finally achieving higher resolution in 2000, Steitz achieved higher resolution .
 Ramakrishnan’s background in physics and biology enabled him to study ribosome structure in Escherichia coli . He used a technique called neutron scattering to study the ribosomes .
 He later also used X-ray crystallography to elucidate the structure of several different cellular components, including ribosomes . He also used the technique to also elucidate structure of various cellular components .
 Steitz crystallized and determined structures of the large subunit in intermediate stages revealed the pathway for protein growth . Steitz's ability to crystallize and determine structures of large subunits revealed the protein growth pathway for proteins .
 The work of all three scientists also provided insight into the atomic structure of antibiotics and how these agents bind to ribosomes, opening the way to the design of new antibiotics .
 The 2009 Nobel Prize for Physics was awarded to three physicists who in separate ways made possible the worldwide information explosion . The prize was given to physicists who helped make possible the world's information revolution .
 Half of the prize money went to Charles K Kao for groundbreaking work on the use of optical fibres for information transmission . The other half went jointly to Willard S Boyle and George E Smith for the invention of the charge-coupled device .
 Kao worked as an engineer for Standard Telecommunication Laboratories (STL [later part of Nortel Networks], Harlow, Eng. Kao graduated with a degree in electrical engineering from Woolwich Polytechnic .
 He was awarded the Charles Stark Draper Prize of the U.S. National Academy of Engineering in 1999 .
 In 2000 he became chairman and chief executive officer of ITX Services . In 2000, he was chairman and CEO of ITx Services .
 At that time, existing telephone cables based on copper wires were reaching the limit of the speed at which they could transfer data . At the time, the speed of the data-transfering cables was reaching the limits of the cables .
 Systems using light in the visible or near-infrared region of the spectrum would enable data transfer at much higher rates . The technology could be used to send data to the next generation of data networks .
 At the time, it was generally believed that the intrinsic attenuation losses in optical fibres made it impossible for them to replace copper . It was generally thought that the loss of these losses made them impossible for copper .
 In 1966 Kao and Hockham published a paper demonstrating that these losses were far smaller than expected and that the main sources of loss were impurities in the glass itself .
 Kao predicted that such fibres could be made into optical waveguides for communications purposes . He also predicted that the fibre could be used as a waveguide for communications .
 Within a few years fibres of ultrapure silica were being produced that confirmed his analysis . The fibres were being used to create fibres that can be found in silica .
 The first fibre-optic telephone cables were installed in 1975, and the first transatlantic fibreoptic cable was laid in 1988 .
 Modernday global communication is based primarily on fibre-optic transmission systems . Global communications systems are based on fibre and optic networks .
 In 1962 he became director of Space Science and Exploratory Studies at Bell Labs subsidiary Bellcomm . In 1964 he returned to Bell Labs in 1964 and was executive director of research from 1975 until 1979 .
 Smith and Boyle played a significant part in the revolution in electronic technology that occurred over the past 50 years . They were pioneers of electronic technology .
 The first solid-state transistors of the 1950s were joined up into ""integrated circuits" The major advance came with large-scale integration when thousands of transistors could be manufactured together on a small sheet of silicon and then connected to make circuits .
 An individual transistor comprises a dot of metal on an insulating layer of silicon oxide deposited on a silicon substrate . The silicon oxide is deposited on the silicon substrate and deposited in silicon .
 In 1969 Smith and Boyle realized that such devices could be used for light detection . In 1969 such devices were used to detect light from light sources .
 A detector is composed of a matrix of such CCD cells (known as “pixels”), and the intensity of light falling on each cell is recorded and stored . A detector was created by combining the matrix of cells with a matrix known as a matrix .
 Their use revolutionized the storage and transmission of photographic images . They were used to transport and storage of photographic photographs . Their use of the technology revolutionized photography .
 The 2009 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine was awarded to three American scientists for their discovery of the enzyme telomerase and of how chromosomes are protected by telomeres . Three American scientists were awarded the prize for the discovery of telomerases .
 Telomeres are structures at the ends of chromosomes that help control when cells divide . Telomere are structures that are at the end of chromosomes and help control the cell divide .
 Szostak was independently studying telomeres when he met Blackburn at a conference in 1980 . He met Blackburn when he was working independently on the subject of research .
 Researchers began a collaborative investigation of telomere function in yeast and Tetrahymena yeast . They began to investigate the function of the yeast in yeast .
 In 1983 Greider joined Blackburn’s lab as a graduate student . Greider and Blackburn jointly discovered telomerase, an enzyme that appeared to control telomere behaviour . The enzyme is thought to control the growth of telomeres .
 Several of the repeated DNA segments of telomeres are lost each time a cell divides, shortening telomere length . Telomeres can be found in cells that divide in a cell .
 telomeres play an important role in determining cell life span . Telomeres are an important part of a cell's survival span, according to scientists .
 Szostak’s later work connected the loss of telomerase activity and cell death to cell death . Szostaks' later work also connected telomerases activity to cell deaths .
 This provided the initial link between telomeres and the aging process of cells . The link was established by the study of human cells .
 Greider and Blackburn also confirmed telomerase was the key to stopping telomeres from overshortening . Greider, Blackburn and Blackburn subsequently also confirmed Telomerase is key to preventing telomere shortening . The study was published in The Lancet, published in October .
 Dr. Greider suspected that abnormal telomerase regulation contributed to tumour development . He said telomerases regulate the production of tumour cells .
 Greider found blocking telomerase activity in cancer cells forces telomeres to shorten . Greider also found that blocking telomere activity forces telomerases to shorten in cancer patients .
 This process stops cells from surviving indefinitely and slows tumour growth . It stops cells dying indefinitely and stops tumour cells growing indefinitely .
 The findings brought a surge of new interest in developing anticancer drugs that target telomerase . These findings brought an interest in new anticancer drug development .

 Israeli entrepreneur Shai Agassi unveiled the prototype for a robot that could quickly remove the depleted battery from an electric car and replace it with a freshly charged battery in 2009 .
 The device was designed for battery-exchange stations, a key component of Agassi’s plan for an infrastructure that would spur the public to adopt more efficient all-electric vehicles .
 Such stations would allow the driver of an electric car to travel long distances without waiting to recharge the battery along the way . Such stations could be used to charge drivers of electric cars .
 Another key element of his plan was to set up a network of ubiquitous recharging spots in parking lots and other places for recharging electric cars whenever they're not being driven .
 Agassi’s business plan positioned Better Place as a service company to provide drivers of electric cars with batteries and an electric-charging infrastructure on a subscription basis .
 He also started several other businesses, including software companies Quicksoft and TopManage .
 In 2001 TopTier was bought by SAP, a leading German software company, for $400 million . SAP bought TopTier from TopTier in 2001 . SAP is now owned by TopTier .
 Agassi served on the SAP executive board and became president of SAP's Products and Technology Group . Agassi also served as SAP's president of its products and technology group. Agassi was a member of the executive board .
 Time magazine named him one of the most influential businesspeople in the world in 2003 . Time magazine considered him in line for the company’s CEO position .
 Agassi looked into climate change, especially in the area of transportation . Agassi spoke at an induction meeting in which participants were entreated to find ways to make the world a better place .
 Known as a persuasive visionary with a command of the facts, he soon had more than $200 million lined up from investors . Known as persuasive visionary, he was known as persuasive .
 By 2009 he had reached agreements to establish Better Place’s open recharging system in a number of countries, including Denmark and the United States . Renault had begun development on a mass-production electric vehicle suitable for the system .
 Blue LEDs had been previously considered impossible or impractical to make . Blue LEDs are now the first blue LEDs to emit red or green light .
 Blue LEDs became available commercially commercially in 1993 . They achieved importance in a range of applications, including electronic displays and indicators .
 Further work led to the development of blue semiconductor lasers, which proved useful for high-capacity optical-media devices, such as Blu-ray disc players .
 The availability of blue LEDs made possible the development of white LED lighting . White LED lighting combined light from red, green, and blue LEDs is a promising form of high-efficiency general-purpose lighting .
 A major breakthrough was the team’s discovery that a materials-forming technique called metalorganic vapour phase epitaxial growth could be used to create highquality GaN crystals on a sapphire substrate .
 Akasaki’s work in developing blue LEDs was the discovery that p-type GaN could be formed by doping GaN crystals with magnesium atoms and then irradiating them with electron beams .
 This p-type material was then used with existing ntype material to form GaN diodes . The material is then used to create GaN-Diodes using existing material .
 Akasaki continued research into GaN materials through the 1990s and early 2000s . His research helped lead to the development of blue semiconductor lasers and other electronics applications .
 In July 2009 Yukiya Amano was elected the director of the International Atomic Energy Agency . Amano is a Japanese veteran diplomat . He was elected to lead the agency's director in July 2009 .
 Concerns were heightened by the disclosure in September 2009 that Iran was operating a clandestine nuclear facility . Concerns have been heightened since the disclosure of Iran's clandestine nuclear program .
 Amano, an expert in nuclear disarmament and nonproliferation, had worked for more than 36 years in the Japanese foreign service . Amano was Japan's envoy to the IAEA and a member of the organization’s board of governors .
 Amano was elected director general on the sixth round of voting with the support of 23 member countries of the board of governors . The minimum twothirds majority required for Amano to be elected . Amano is the first director general to have been elected by 23 countries .
 Amano and South Africa's IAEA envoy, Abdul Samad Minty, voted for Amano . The vote was divided between Amano, Minty and Minty . Amano says Amano is the only member of the world's largest nuclear watchdog agency .
 The split reflected the multiple mandates of the IAEA, with Western industrialized countries more concerned about nuclear proliferation . LDCs generally gave higher priority to sharing nuclear technology among all countries for the generation of nuclear energy .
 Amano said he was ""resolute in opposing the spread of nuclear arms because I am from a country that experienced Hiroshima and Nagasaki” and that he supported the IAEA's 70 Biographies mandate of helping countries make safe use of nuclear energy and technology . Amano supported

 He was subsequently appointed director of the publications and information centre of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in Tokyo . He was also director of nuclear energy division of the Japanese Foreign Ministry .

 He then held positions in Japan’s Foreign Ministry as director general for arms control and scientific affairs and director general of disarmament, nonproliferation, and science department .

 Bryce was appointed governor-general by Prime Minister Kevin Rudd in 2008 . She became the first woman to hold the high-profile post of Queen Elizabeth IPs viceregal representative in Australia . Bryce is a noted lawyer, educator, and human rights activist .
 Bryce’s historic appointment was hailed by numerous Australian media outlets, as well as many government officials . Bryce was appointed by the Australian Prime Minister in 2011 .
 Bryce was to serve a five-year term, during which she intended to devote much of her attention to human rights issues . Bryce indicated that she would place “special emphasis” on promoting and protecting the rights of the country’s indigenous peoples .
 She married architect and graphic designer Michael Bryce in 1964 . The couple eventually had five children . She was admitted to the Queensland bar the following year .
 In the late 1980s and early 1990s, she worked for the Australian Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission . She worked as the commission’s Queensland director and then as a federal sex discrimination commissioner .
 Bryce became the founding chairperson and CEO of the National Childcare Accreditation Council in 1993 . She led efforts to ensure and improve the quality of child-care services in Australia . Bryce is the founder of the Australian Childcare Commission . She is also the founder and former chairperson of
 Bryce was appointed governor of Queensland in 2003 . She was made a Companion of the Order of Australia in the same year that she was made Companion of Australia .
 Her five-year appointment as Queensland’s governor was extended for an additional two years in January 2008 . It was only three months later that Rudd announced his selection of Bryce for the governor-general's post . Bryce has been in charge of Queensland since 2008 .
 Bryce maintained a busy travel schedule, visiting troops in Afghanistan, addressing the World Future Energy Summit in Abu Dhabi, U.A.E., and undertaking a diplomatic trip to nine African countries in March and April .
 After the deadliest bushfires in Australia’s history, Bryce toured both states and made a national televised address on February 10 . She urged her fellow Australians to “do whatever needs to be done” to help survivors of the disasters .

 Brazilian race-car driver Helio Castroneves capped a tumultuous year in triumphant fashion by winning the U.S. premier auto race in Indianapolis 500 . 2009 .
 His victory came just five weeks after a United States federal jury acquitted him on six counts of incometax evasion . Prosecutors dropped a remaining conspiracy charge against him two days after prosecutors had dropped a conspiracy charge .
 The 34-year-old Castroneves turned in a stirring performance before some 300,000 fans at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway . The Brazilian was finally able to put his monthslong legal battle behind him .
 Castroneves was involved in motor sports from a young age with the support of his father, an auto dealer in Sao Paulo who owned a stock-car-racing team . He was involved with his father's team, which he owns in Brazil .
 As a teenager, Castroneves won a national go-kart-racing title in Brazil before advancing in 1994 to Formula Three auto racing in Europe . As a teen, he went on to become a national champion in go kart racing in Brazil .
 He attracted the attention of Brazilian racing great Emerson Fittipaldi, who helped him get started on the Championship Auto Racing Teams IndyCar circuit in 1998 .
 Castroneves signed with Penske Racing in 2000 . He quickly became one of the team’s dominant drivers . The Brazilian has won the IndyCar Series since 2000 .
 He was the youngest driver ever to accomplish the back-to-back feat and the first to win the classic race in each of his two initial attempts . He was also the first driver to win in each race in the classic classic race .
 By this time the immensely affable Brazilian had become one of the Indy Racing League's most popular drivers . The Brazilian driver is known for his affable style of driving .
 In 2007 he appeared on the hit American television show Dancing with the Stars . He won the competition with professional dance partner, Julianne Hough .
 A federal indictment handed down in 2008 alleged that he had helped create a Panama-based shell company with the intention of avoiding paying taxes on some $5 million in income . The indictment was filed in 2008 .
 Following his acquittal, he tearfully expressed his relief at being able to return to racing . He tearfully said he was 'relieved' to be able to race again .
 Since the early 1990s, Cave had been immersed in fashioning the Soundsuits that qualified as fashion, sculpture, and performance art .
 Nick Cave's Soundsuits were fabricated through a complex layering of found materials . The wearable mixedmedia constructions are named for the sounds made when worn by performers .
 These hybrid objects referenced Cave’s ongoing interest in the construction and concealment of identity . Equally reminiscent of African religious ceremonial costumes and high fashion garments, these hybrid objects were created by the artist .
 Cave's Soundsuits won numerous awards, including the Joan Mitchell Foundation Award in 2008 . The Soundsuits were an interdisciplinary and transformative nature that won Cave numerous awards .
 He studied at Alvin Ailey’s modern dance company . During his time there he also studied with Alvin . Ailey's modern dance .
 He earned a master's in fine arts at the Cranbrook Academy of Art, Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and later became chairman of the Fashion Design program at the School of the Art Institute .
 Throughout his career, Cave made use of found and ready-made materials to reference cultural, political, and autobiographical issues . Cave's work is published by Simon Cowell, a self-taught author .
 He made his first Soundsuit out of twigs in the early 1990s by wiring cut and drilled sticks to a handmade cotton undergarment . He realized its performative potential only once it was completed .
 He later employed a myriad of techniques and traditions to create the Soundsuits . Soundsuits range from formfitting bodysuits composed of intricately sewn fabrics and beads to ceramic headdresses . The Soundsuits are made of amorphous suits made of woven hair .
 Soundsuits conceal and transform the identity, race, and gender of their wearer . When worn, the Soundsuits create sounds that correspond to their chosen materials and construction .
 The Soundsuits’ meanings shift and multiply with each exhibition and performance, set in places as varied as the theatre stage, fashion runway, and city street . The Soundsuit’s meanings shift .
 Cave used these contexts to emphasize his reliance on community to activate his work . Cave recruited skilled professionals and friends to assist him in the creation of the suits .
 Cave continued to borrow from a wide range of disciplines and cultures in an effort to examine and challenge notions of personal and cultural identity . With these objects and his Soundsuits, Cave continued .
 Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry resumed his duties as chief justice of the Pakistan Supreme Court more than a year after he was dismissed by the Pakistani Pres. Muhammad Khan . In March 2009, he resumed duties after being dismissed by Khan .
 Chief justice's entire tenure on the court had been filled with drama and eventdefining moments . Chaudhry’s reinstatement served as the focal point of sustained efforts to pressure Musharraf into vacating his role .
 He established a legal practice as an advocate in 1974 and became an advocate for the Balochistan High Court in 1976 . He established his practice as a lawyer in 1974 . He was also a member of the Supreme Court in Pakistan .
 Chaudhry was then named advocate general of the Balochistan High Court . He has held several other judiciary positions, including an advocate general .
 He was twice presiding officer of the Balochistan Local Council Bodies Authority . While serving simultaneously as chairman of the  Local Council Election Authority, he was also serving as chairman .
 Chaudhry played a key role in the establishment of the Circuit Bench of the Balochistan High Court at Sibi . After being appointed chief justice, he was the first chief justice of the High Court .
 He was named to the Pakistan Supreme Court in 2000 . He was elevated to chief justice in 2005 . He is Pakistan's most senior Supreme Court judge .
 Chaudhry presided over the court during much of the military dictatorship headed by Musharraf, who seized power in 1999 . Never one to avoid controversy, he presided over many controversies during the dictatorship .
 Chaudhry was removed from his post as chief justice in late 2007, ostensibly because he appeared to threaten Musharraf’s political authority . He became the lightning rod for sustained efforts by Pakistan's legal community to seek his reinstatement and also to drive the former president out
 Pres. Musharraf resigned in August 2008, and after elec77 Pakistani jurist Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry Aamir Qureshi was held .

 More than a year of unrelenting demonstrations followed Chaudhry’s dismissal . Demonstrators led by former prime minister Nawaz Sharif led by political leaders led by Musharraf .
 Zardari's hesitation in returning Chaudhry to the court caused a rift between himself and Sharif . The former prime minister was eventually restored to office after a rift with Sharif . Zardar finally relented and restored the former minister .
 In May 2009 the court, again led by Chief Justice Chaudhry, lifted the ban on Sharif’s ability to run for political office . The court appeared to lay the groundwork for yet another confrontation between Sharif and Zardari .

 Spanish cyclist Alberto Contador won the Tour de France in 2009 . Contador claimed the 23-day, 3,460-km race on July 26 in Paris . The Spaniard established himself as the greatest stage racer in the world .
 Contador dominated the 2009 Tour’s overall standings, finishing 4 minutes 11 seconds ahead of runner-up Andy Schleck of Luxembourg . Former champion Lance Armstrong of the U.S. placed third in the race .
 Contador won the Tour of Italy (Giro d’ltalia) and Tour of Spain (Vuelta a Espana) in 2008 . The win was his fourth victory at a major national national tour . Contador was just 26 years old .
 Followers of cycling marveled at the Spaniard’s versatility, regarding him as a ""complete rider” Many believed he had the potential to challenge Armstrong's record of seven Tour de France titles .
 Contador competed as an amateur from his mid-teens and made his professional debut in 2003 . Contador made his debut as a professional cyclist in 2004 .
 In 2004 his future was left in doubt after he suffered a fall during a race and underwent brain surgery to remove a blood clot . He showed early promise, winning a time trial that year at the Tour of Poland .
 He made a remarkable recovery in 2005, winning a stage of the Tour Down Under in Australia and earning his first overall victory as a professional rider at the Catalan Cycling Week . He won a stage in Australia, and won the overall overall victory in 2005 .
 His Discovery Channel team disbanded at the end of the 2007 season . His emergence as one of the elite figures of road cycling came in 2007, but he has since retired .
 Contador was the defending champion in the 2008 Tour de France . His new team, Astana, was excluded from the race for prior doping offenses . Contador won't be allowed to compete in 2008 Tour because his new team was excluded .
 During the 2009 Tour, reports surfaced of a rift between Contador and teammate Armstrong over the leadership of Astana . Armstrong and Contador were teammates at the Tour in 2009 .
 Spaniard produced the fastest climb in Tour history, making the final ascent to the Alpine village of Verbier, Switz., at an estimated rate of more than 1,850 m per hour . The Spaniard made the climb to Verbier at a rate of over 1,800 m
 Contador seized the leader’s yellow jersey on that stage and never relinquished it . Contador won't relinquish it .
 Armstrong left Astana at the end of the Tour, vowing to assemble his own team in 2010 . Armstrong left the Kazakh team after the Tour Tour ended in July .
 Contador, meanwhile, celebrated his victory and fielded offers from several other teams eager for his services . Contador won the Tour de Clasquer in the opening stages of this year's race .

 Dennard was credited with the invention in the late 1960s of the one-transistor cell for dynamic random-access memory . In the early 1970s, he pioneered the set of consistent scaling principles that underlie the improved performance of increasingly miniaturized integrated circuits .
 DRAM consists of an array of semiconductor memory cells that are integrated on a silicon chip . DRAM is a form of memory that can be stored in a chip that is integrated into a chip .
 Onetransistor-cell DRAM was extensively used in computers and other electronic devices . It was introduced in the 1970s .
 With miniaturization, it was possible to develop DRAM chips that contain billions of memory cells . The chip is now being developed in the form of DRAM memory chips .
 He joined IBM Research in 1958 as a staff engineer . He first worked on memory and logic circuits and the development of data communication techniques .
 In 1968 Dennard was granted a patent for the design of wire mesh and magnetic rings . The wire mesh-based memory system was then in development . It was then used in the development of computer memory .
 It was one of more than four dozen patents that he was eventually issued .
 Dennard was given the title of IBM fellow in 1979 . He held several positions over the length of his career of more than 50 years .

 D’Espagnat’s research into the philosophical foundations of quantum physics addressed the conflict between the realist and instrumentalist views of the results of quantum mechanics . The realist view is whether the results reflect underlying physical reality or are merely rules for predicting the outcomes of
 D'Espagnat's work on Bell’s theorem (which indicates that the realist interpretation is not viable) led him to reject conventional realism, but the fact that scientific theories remain falsifiable by experiment steered him to the idea that a veiled reality underlies the phenomena
 D’Espagnat was educated at the Lycee Condorcet and the Ecole Polytechnique in Paris . He was educated in France and at the University of Paris .
 Fosso transformed himself into people and characters drawn from popular culture and politics . In fact, these 14 images were "autoportraits," as Fososso created them from his work .
 Fosso’s work was regularly featured in solo and group exhibitions around the world, including the 2008 edition of the “Festival des rencontres de la photographique d’Arles’ in France .
 Fosso lived in Nigeria as a child, but was forced to flee to Bangui after the Biafran war forced his family to flee . He settled there after the war destroyed their Nigerian home .
 He discovered photography in his early teens while working as a shoemaker . After apprenticeship with a local photographer, he had opened his own studio .
 He lived and worked at the studio, creating portraits of the local residents by using studio lights fashioned from pots and backgrounds made from traditional African fabrics .
 At the end of the day, he would often step in front of the camera to finish a roll of film . At the day’s end he often stepped in to finish the film .
 Fosso used these images to communicate his wellbeing to his grandmother in Nigeria . The staged self-portraits became agents of transformation and expression for the artist .
 In many of his early images, Fosso borrowed elements from popular culture that he admired, even having local tailors replicate outfits worn by celebrities . In many early works, he borrowed elements of popular culture from his work .
 In 1993 these images were discovered by French photographer Bernard Deschamps, who was looking for photographers to be included in the first edition of ""Rencontres de la photographic africaine” in Bamako, Mali .
 The 1994 exhibition launched Fosso’s career as an artist . He later went on to win the Afrique en Creation award in 1995 .
 Fosso evolved and expanded the scope of his autoportraits, using these constructed images to critically narrate and reference cultural and political events . The autoportrait is a form of art that has been used in more than 50 years .
 In the Tati series, Fosso depicted himself as characters ranging from an African chief draped in gold jewelry and leopard skins to a glamorous African American woman . The series was commissioned by the Parisian department store Tati .
 Fosso continued to live and operate his photography studio in Bangui, where the local community remained largely unaware of his achievements .

 Mauricio Funes was elected president of El Salvador on March 15, 2009 . He was elected with a five-year term to begin on June 1 . Funes is the first president of the Salvadoran nation .
 There he was influenced by sociology professor Francis Miguel Hasbun, a leftist activist . He studied sociology at the University of San Francisco .
 The violent death of his older brother, who was killed by police during a student protest in August 1980, induced Funes to leave the university before completing his degree . Funes' older brother was shot dead by police at a student demonstration in 1980 .
 Despite leftist leanings, he did not join a political party or participate in guerrilla warfare . He did not participate in the ongoing guerrilla warfare in Afghanistan .
 He taught literature in Catholic schools, where he emphasized audiovisual methods of communication . Instead of teaching literature, he taught literature .
 In 1986 Funes became a reporter for the state educational channel, launching a highly successful career in television journalism . Funes has been married to his wife, Mariana, since 1988 .
 In 1987 he moved to Channel 12, where he became popular for his analytic coverage of Salvadoran politics . He was known for his analysis of the country's leftist and working class .
 He interviewed leaders of the FMLN and other leftist parties, as well as leftist leaders from abroad . He also interviewed leaders from outside of Colombia .
 He also was a longtime correspondent for CNN TV's Spanish-language telecasts . He was also a longtime CNN TV correspondent .
 Funes’s investigative reporting on Channel 12 won him several awards, including the prestigious Maria Moors Cabot Prize in inter-American journalism in 1994 . Funes's investigative reporting won him an award in 1994.
 He was promoted to news director at Channel 12 in 1997, but his harsh criticism of the ARENA government led to censorship and death threats . In 2005 Channel 12 fired him and several other journalists, including several journalists .
 Funes continued to appear on other channels, however, and remained a national celebrity among leftists . Funes appeared on several other channels .
 With Hasbun as his adviser, Funes exploited his popularity to become the FMLN candidate for the presidency in September 2007 . Funes was the first FMLN presidential candidate who had not been a guerrilla fighter in the 1980s .
 In the long electoral campaign, Funes criticized ARENA for doing nothing for the Salvadoran people in its nearly 20 years reign . Funes says ARENA has done nothing for Salvadorans in its 20 years .
 He promised social justice, economic reform, improved standards of living, universal health care, and better access to education, housing, and pensions . He promised to stem crime and gang violence, as well as policies to stem the rising crime .
 Once elected, he took a pragmatic and conciliatory tone toward the opposition . Once elected he took the position of taking a pragmatic approach to his opponents .
 El Salvador's Funes said he was not a Marxist or even a socialist . He pledged not to align the country’s foreign relations too closely with either Venezuela or the United States .  Timothy Geithner has been nominated to serve as secretary of the United States Department of the Treasury in the administration of Pres. Obama .
 As treasury secretary, he was tasked with leading the administration’s efforts toward financial recovery amid the ongoing global economic crisis . He has been in office since 2001 .
 In March he laid out a comprehensive plan to help free banks from bad housing loans and mortgage-related securities . The move ignited a stock-market rally .
 On December 9, Geithner announced that the $700 billion financial bailout program would be extended until October 2010 . Congress had approved the bailout program in the fall of 2008 . The extension of the program was announced in December 2009 .
 Geithner defended the 84 Biographies extension as necessary in order to assist homeowners and small businesses . Critics had argued for the program to be shut down . The extension was necessary to ensure that the government would be able to respond if financial conditions worsened .
 Geithner took a job as a research assistant at Kissinger Associates, an international consulting firm founded by Henry Kissinger . After completing his education, he took the job as an assistant to Kissinger Associates . The firm was founded by former U.S. secretary of state .
 Geithner joined the Treasury Department in 1988 . He has held a number of positions within the agency’s international affairs division .
 Geithner worked closely with Lawrence H Summers, who identified him as a gifted official with a deft political touch . Summers was a Treasury official at the time .
 In 1999 Geithner was promoted to undersecretary for international affairs . He represented the Treasury Department at meetings of the Group of Eight .
 While not formally trained as an economist, Geithner brought to the position extensive experience with international monetary policy . He became an advocate for greater transparency and increased government oversight .
 As the government’s unofficial liaison to Wall Street, Geithner was a key participant in the response to the credit crisis that began in 2007 . As the U.S. Treasury Secretary, he was the government's unofficial liaison with Wall Street .
 He oversaw JPMorgan Chase’s federally backed takeover of failed investment bank Bear Steams in March 2008 . He spent the rest of the year helping to craft the Federal Reserve's response to a series of corporate meltdowns .
 In 2009, a year after its publication, Amitav Ghosh’s epic novel Sea of Poppies continued to draw accolades . The novel was published in 1956 in Calcutta [now Kolkata], India .
 Among the books against which Ghosh’s novel was competing was The Enchantress of Florence by Salman Rushdie . Rushdie was another Indian-born writer to whose work Ghosh's had often been compared .
 As a child, Ghosh, whose father was a diplomat, lived in India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, and Iran . Ghosh's father was also a diplomat and he lived in Sri Lanka and India .
 Ghosh’s ambitious novels use complex narrative strategies to probe the nature of national and personal identity, particularly of the people of India and Southeast Asia . Ghosh's ambitious novels are published in India, Southeast Asia and India .
 His first novel, The Circle of Reason, follows an Indian protagonist who, suspected of being a terrorist, leaves India for northern Africa and the Middle East .
 Postcolonial in its marginalization of Europe and postmodern in its nonlinear structure and thick intertextuality . Blending elements of fable and picaresque fiction, it is distinctly postcolonial . It is a novel that is postmodern and postcolonial in terms of its structure and
 The Shadow Lines is a sweeping history of two families (one Indian and the other English) that are deeply shaped by events following the departure of the British from India in 1947 .
 The Circle of Reason and The Shadow Lines, both written in English, were widely translated and gained Ghosh an international readership . Ghosh was a prolific writer and published internationally .
 A Novel of Fevers, Delirium, and Discovery represented his foray into science fiction and earned him the Arthur C Clarke Award . This densely layered novel offers an alternate history of the discovery of malaria .
 Ghosh's subsequent novels include The Glass Palace and The Hungry Tide . Ghosh’s subsequent novels are set in Bengal and featuring American and Indian characters .
 Sea of Poppies shows Ghosh turning away from his earlier novels’ formal experimentation and toward a more traditional form of storytelling . Ghosh’s earlier novels have been experimental and experimental, but his new novel is a classic .
 This novel describes individuals who are on a ship in Southeast Asia carrying coolies (indentured labourers) and opium . The first book of a projected trilogy, this novel is the first of a trilogy .
 Ghosh straddles several genres: travel writing, autobiography memoir, memoir . Ghosh also wrote In an Antique Land .

 Saudi-born businessman and politician Saad al-Hariri was named prime minister of Lebanon in June 2009 . He is the son of former Lebanese prime minister Rafiq al-hariri, a former prime minister .
 With relatively little political experience, the younger Hariri had entered politics following his father’s assassination in February 2005 . The younger politician was faced with the task of forming a unity government in 88 Biographies one of the world's most complex political environments .
 Hariri received his elementary education at the school of Freres Maristes in Rmaila , Leb. (near Sidon), and completed his secondary education in France and Saudi Arabia . Hariri was born in Lebanon .
 Hariri helped orchestrate Saudi Oger’s acquisition of Turk Telekom . Hariri gained the position of general manager at age 26 . He also worked to extend the business into the telecommunications sector .
 After his fathers assassination in a Beirut car bombing, Hariri was selected by his family to follow in his father’s political footsteps . Hariri is the son of assassinated assassinated by his father in Beirut .
 The Future Movement was the largest contingent within the March 14 coalition (named to commemorate the date, in 2005, of massive anti-Syrian protests in Beirut), which opposed Syrian influence in Lebanon’s affairs .
 Hariri did not consider himself politically mature enough to serve as prime minister . Instead, he supported Fouad Siniora, a former finance minister and close ally of his father, for the position .
 During the next four years, Hariri worked to forge and refine his own political identity . Hariri was elected to the Senate in 2006 .
 His lobbying helped secure a sizable financial aid package from the U.S. to assist in Lebanese reconstruction . In late May 2007, the United Nations Security Council approved the establishment of a special court in which to try suspects linked to his father's assassination .
 In May 2008, Lebanon was in the midst of a dangerous political stalemate that had followed the departure of Pres. Bashar al-Assad . The country was in a dangerous state of instability .
 Hariri helped negotiate a unity government and navigate the country away from violent confrontation . Emile Lahoud was ousted from office in November 2007 . Hariri was the prime minister of Lebanon in 2007 .
 In June 2009, Hariri again led the March 14 coalition to victory in elections in June 2009 .

 Protect Protect highlighted her ongoing practice of utilizing original and borrowed text as a primary medium . Her works were alternately soothing and unsettling, meditative and confrontational, and seductive and frightening .
 Holzer emerged in the early 1980s as part of a generation of artists who gained recognition for employing and appropriating aspects of mass culture in an effort to explore and question contemporary issues .
 Her critical texts take form as objects ranging from ephemeral posters to stone benches . She is best known for flashing electronic LED sign sculptures that display carefully composed yet fleeting phrases .
 Holzer originally presented as phrases on anonymous posters and later on T-shirts, billboards, and electronic signs . The works, composed of seemingly familiar slogans such as “Abuse of power comes as no surprise,” were originally presented by Holzer .
 The Living series and Survival series were seamlessly integrated into various urban landscapes as plaques and signs . These texts, fraught with cynicism and political implications, were followed by the more structured and complex Inflammatory Essays series .
 In the mid-1980s, Holzer began inscribing her texts on stone benches, sarcophagi and floor tiles .
 Her LED signs accompanied her LED signs in numerous exhibitions and were installed independently as site-specific works .
 Holzer’s installation for the United States Pavilion at the 1990 Venice Biennale won the Golden Lion Award . The juxtaposition of texts set in austere marble tiles and benches and flashing across commercial LED signs .
 From 1996 Holzer expanded her installations to include large-scale outdoor light projections . She chose public locations that demanded viewer attention .
 Beginning in 2001, she started incorporating borrowed texts in her work, including poetry, literature, and bureaucratic documents .
 These paintings underscore the impossibility of fixed meaning and the multiple viewpoints always present in her work . Similar to her original texts, these paintings underscore her original meaning .
 Holzer continued to use words to question the relationship between the private and the public . With these projects and others, Holzer used words to ask questions about the relationship .

 On June 4, 2009, Randy Johnson recorded the 300th victory in his career as a Major League Baseball pitcher .

 The MLB National League Montreal Expos drafted him after his junior season, and he made his major league debut in Sept. 1988 . He was drafted by the Expos .
 Johnson quickly built a reputation as the pitcher major leaguers most feared facing . The physically imposing 2.08-m (6-ft 10-in) Johnson quickly became a star in the Major League Baseball .
 The novelty of his height at first overshadowed Johnson’s work on the mound, but as his pitching improved, the accolades increased . Johnson has been named the best pitcher in the Major League Baseball .

 Johnson led the AL in strikeouts for four consecutive years . In 1995 he won the Cy Young Award as the league’s best pitcher . Johnson won the AL Cy Young award in 1995 .
 Johnson and the Mariners management began to have contract disagreements on a regular basis . He was traded to the Houston Astros at the 1998 trading deadline .

 She helped support her growing family by sewing undergarments and shoes and selling them on the black market . She married at the age of 15 and subsequently helped to support her family .
 When she was 28, Kadeer founded a laundry business out of her home . She was motivated by her separation from her children, she founded the business .
 She invested some of her earnings in trading commodities, modestly at first and eventually on a larger and larger scale . After several months she closed that thriving business, she invested her earnings .

 In March 1987 she opened a women's bazaar in Urumqi, and in the 1990s she followed with a department store and an accompanying apartment complex .
 By 1993 she had become the wealthiest woman in China . Soon she had enlarged her operations to include subsidiaries throughout Central Asia .
 Kadeer capitalized on her business by employing and mentoring Uighur individuals . Long concerned with aiding and advancing her people, she is now a businesswoman .
 She was appointed to influential organizations and committees, including the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC) and the National People's Congress .
 In 1995, she served as a delegate to the UN Fourth World Conference on Women, held in Beijing .
 Kadeer utilized her increased financial means and social stature to continue campaigning on behalf of the Uighur population .
 She was detained in August 1999 en route to meeting a congressional delegation from the U.S. and was imprisoned . She was imprisoned and imprisoned in 1999 .

 Mervyn King was governor of the Bank of England in the summer of 2009 . Evidence was mounting that the U.K. might be the first of the world’s major economies to emerge from the global recession .
 King had insisted that his ambition was to make monetary policy boring . After he became governor in 2003, King insisted that he wanted to make policy boring.
 In 2007 and 2008, as the banks collapsed and the world recession started, King became a familiar fixture on British television . King's wry humour and perfectly formed sentences became a popular British television show .
 Cambridge graduate is one of the brightest economists of his generation . His intelligence and drive took him via Wolverhampton Grammar School to Cambridge .
 Through the 1970s and '80s, his academic career blossomed on both sides of the Atlantic . Through the '70s and 80s, he was a major success in Europe .
 King's special area of interest was taxation . He co-authored a book on the British tax system . He was professor of economics at the London School of Economics from 1984 .
 In 1990 King was appointed one of the BOE’s nonexecutive directors; the following year he became the bank’�s chief economist . King was also appointed as the bank's chief economist in 1994 .
 This gave him a platform for preaching in favour of placing the fight against inflation at the heart of economic policy . It gave him the platform to preach against inflation .
 He was deputy governor in 1998 and governor in 2003 . No one was surprised when he became BOE’s deputy governor .
 At first the U.K.’s economy grew steadily, and inflation remained under control . At first, inflation remained in control . But now, inflation is under control in the UK .
 In September 2007, one of Britain’s main mortgage lenders, the Northern Rock Bank, collapsed . Northern Rock collapsed .
 For the first time in more than a century, there was a run on a major British bank as anxious savers formed long lines to withdraw their money . Eventually, the government nationalized the bank .
 A year later King faced criticism for keeping interest rates too high for too long as the economy started to contract . King faced similar criticism for raising interest rates a year after the recession .
 In response, King and his colleagues on the BOE’s Monetary Policy Committee acted boldly . They expanded the money supply sharply and cut interest rates in successive months from 5% in October 2008 to 0.5% by March 2009 .

 Martinelli made his first bid for the five-year, one-term presidency in 2004 . He finished last among four candidates, receiving only 5.3% of the vote . Martinelli has been in office since 2004 .
 For his 2009 run, he led a coalition of right-wing parties and contributed significant funding to his own cause . He presented himself as an outsider vying for the office that had been held by traditional political powers since 1989 .
 Martinelli's message of change resonated among poor voters in Panama . PRDP candidate Balbina Herrera was considered the favourite .
 The early challenges of Martinelli’s presidency included fighting an escalating crime rate and stabilizing the economy . In 2008, the economy had grown at a 9.2% annual rate but was forecast to rise only 3.2 percent .
 He aimed to influence the initiation of a free-trade agreement that had already been signed with the United States but had stalled in the U.S. Congress .
 Martinelli was also relying on a $5.25 billion project to expand the Panama Canal to provide some short-term benefits to the economy . The Canal project was expected to create thousands of jobs .
 Northern Ireland Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness of Sinn Fein (the IRA’s political wing), a former IRA commander, worked harmoniously with his former enemies to run the province .
 McGuinness turned down offers of special police protection . McGuinness himself was considered a possible assassination target .
 In 1973 a Special Criminal Court in the Irish Republic sentenced him to six months in prison . He had been caught in a car containing large quantities of explosives and ammunition .
 McGuinness was one of the IRA's most important members during the 1970s, '80s, and '90s . The IRA kept secret the membership of its seven-man Army Council .
 McGuinness was involved in spasmodic secret talks with British government ministers and officials to end the conflict . He was reportedly planning attacks on civilians in Northern Ireland and the British mainland .
 In 1972 McGuinness, with fellow IRA leader Gerry Adams, privately negotiated with British Secretary of State for Northern Ireland William Whitelaw, but these and other talks over the next two decades came to nothing .
 McGuinness was the IRA's chief negotiator in the deliberations, also secret, that culminated in 1998 in the Good Friday Agreement . McGuinness has been a key figure in negotiations between the IRA and the British government .
 Sinn Fein joined a coalition government to rule Northern Ireland . This pact finally ended the conflict and brought Sinn Fein into a government . Sinn Fein was the party to end the Northern Ireland conflict .
 McGuinness was elected to the new Assembly and was appointed minister of education . McGuinness won the election to the Assembly in 2011 . He was also elected as the new Minister of Education in Northern Ireland .

 By age 21 Messi had achieved fame on two continents that had seemed impossible 10 years earlier . Messi has achieved fame by age 21 . Messi is now the world's No. 1 most famous footballer .
 He started playing soccer as a boy and in 1995 joined Newell’s Old Boys . He has been in the Premier League since 1995 and is now a professional footballer .
 Messi attracted the attention of the club River Plate, but he was diagnosed with growth hormone deficiency . For his working-class family it was impossible to find the money for his expensive medical treatment . Messi attracted interest from River Plate but was unable to afford treatment .
 Messi's potential was spotted on a scouting mission in South America . Carles Rexach, then the sporting director of FC Barcelona, recognized Messi’s potential and arranged for him to receive treatment if he was prepared to move to Europe .

 He scored 21 goals in 14 games for Barcelona's junior team . He quickly graduated through the C and B teams until given his informal debut with FC Barcelona at age 16 .
 Messi, then 17, became the youngest official player and goal scorer in the Spanish La Liga in 2004-05 season . Messi is now the world's top scorer and official official player in the La Liga .
 Though only 1.69 m tall and weighing 67 kg , he was strong, well balanced, and versatile on the field .
 Messi is a left-footed, quick, and precise in control of the ball . Messi displayed distribution and could thread his way through packed defenses . Messi showed distribution and ability to thread through packed defences .
 In 2005 he was granted Spanish citizenship by the Spanish government . The honour was greeted with mixed feelings by the Catalan supporters of Barcelona .

 Maya Arulpragasam, better known by her stage name M.I.A.A., helped raise awareness of the Tamil insurgency in Sri Lanka in 2009 .
 Her efforts to support humanitarian aid for civilians in the Tamil region of Sri Lanka were opposed by the Sri Lankan army . Critics claimed that her lyrics and music videos betrayed a veiled sympathy for the Tamil separatist movement .
 Arulpragasam was born in London, but spent much of her childhood in northern Sri Lanka . She was raised in Sri Lanka and spent most of her life in the north .
 When the civil war between the Tamil minority in the north and the Sinhalese government in the south intensified in the 1980s, her father joined the militant Tamil Tigers . The rest of her family fled the country, eventually returning to London .
 There Arulpragasam studied visual art, often creating works that were influenced by the conflict she had witnessed as a child .
 She received her first exposure to the music industry as the graphic designer for British pop punk group Elastica . She familiarized herself with the recording equipment used by producers .
 Anticipation of a full-length album intensified among her fans with the release of Piracy Funds Terrorism, a 2004 mix tape produced with American songwriter DJ Diplo .
 Parts of M.I.A.'s 2005 debut album had been circulating on the Internet for almost a year . Its release was still greeted with much critical interest .
 The album title, Arular, was the name her father adopted while a Tamil Tiger . The album cover featured Arulpragasam’s face surrounded by a collage of cartoon tanks and AK47s .
 The compilation was a huge success on the club circuit, based on the strength of singles such as ""Galang” and ""Bucky Done Gun" M.I.A.’s politics lent a new gravity to the dance music genre .

 John Evans Atta Mills was officially sworn in to succeed John Agyekum Kufuor as president of Ghana in 2009 . Mills was sworn in as president on Jan. 9, 2009 .
 The election marked the second time in Ghana’s history that one legitimately elected leader had handed over power to another .
 Democracy had been established and reinforced in the West African country, despite occasional eruptions of ethnic conflict and political tension . It demonstrated that after an era of coups and dictatorship , democracy had established .
 On his return to Ghana, he taught law at his alma mater, where he remained for some 25 years . He taught at the law school for 25 years before returning to Ghana .
 Mills eventually left academia to establish a distinguished career in public service . Mills eventually became a prominent public figure in the world of politics .
 He was appointed in 1988 as acting commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service . He eventually became substantive commissioner . He was the first person to become substantive commissioner of IRS .
 Jerry Rawlings's running mate in the 1996 elections was Jerry Rawling's vice president . He took office in 1997, as vice president, a post he held until 2001 .
 Mills was roundly criticized for statements that if elected he would consult with Rawlings, but in 2008 Mills distanced himself from his former mentor . During subsequent presidential campaigns, Mills was criticized for his comments .
 Mills embraced a political platform that was more comprehensive and less divisive than that of either Nkrumah or Rawlings . Mills was a social democrat who believed in the concept of social welfare espoused by Kwame Nkumah .
 Ghanaians ranked among the world’s poorest people, with an average daily income of $2.32, a 60% literacy rate, and 10% unemployment . After his inauguration he set about to improve the socioeconomic situation of ordinary Ghanaians .
 In his first state of the nation address on February 19, Mills announced an austerity program . Mills promised steep cuts in government spending, beginning with cutbacks in wages and the use of two presidential jets .
 He instituted policies to eliminate four cabinet ministries and reduce the size of the presidential convoy . He also instituted policies that eliminated four Cabinet ministries .

 His father was a headman of the Talaote, a Kalanga clan among the Ngwato . He was born in the Kalanga tribe of Ngwata .
 He joined the Development Planning (later the Finance and Development Planning) Ministry of newly independent Botswana, under Vice Pres. Mandela . He then joined the Ministry of Newly Independent Botswana .
 Ketumile Masire became a key figure in Botswana's remarkable rise to economic prosperity . He was the head of the ministry's permanent staff . Masire was Botswana’s most successful minister .

 He returned home to serve as governor of the central bank of Botswana and permanent secretary to Masire . Masire had become president in 1980 and became president in 1994 .

 Mogae continued the policies of his predecessor and successfully steered the BDP through the 1999 elections . Mogae succeeded in other respects .

 Stefan Persson held his position in 2009 as one of the wealthiest individuals in the world . Persson, Stefan, is a retailing executive in Sweden .
 Persson learned fashion retailing from his father, Erling Persson, who founded a women’s clothing store, Hennes, in Vasteras, Sweden in 1947 .
 The company added a store in Stockholm and soon became a fixture of fashion in the Swedish market . It has since extended its reach to other European countries .
 Persson, who joined the family firm in 1972, helped lead its European expansion . Persson was present when the first British store opened in London in 1976 .
 He assumed leadership as H&M’s managing director and CEO in 1982 when his father became chairman of the board . His father was chairman of board when he became chairman .
 By the late 1990s, H&M had become Europe’s largest retail clothing chain . The chain is now the world's largest clothing retailer .
 As it grew, H&M built its reputation on “fast fashion”—inexpensive trendy designs with wide appeal . In-house designers initially created in-house designs, which were quickly transformed into mass-market garments . The chain is based in Turkey, Bangladesh,
 Persson recognized the business potential of—as well as the cultural interest in— global fashion . H&M did not alter garment designs for specific national or regional markets .
 By 2009 H&M operated more than 1,800 stores in 34 countries, with some 73,000 employees . By 2009 the company had more than 70,000 stores .
 Most of the brands sold through H&M were in-house labels . Persson tapped star appeal by soliciting design lines from Karl Lagerfeld, Stella McCartney, and Jimmy Choo .
 Persson's son Karl-Johan was named H&M’s CEO in July 2009 . Persson remained chairman of the company until he was named CEO .

 In that position she worked closely with Finance Minister Trevor Manuel to strengthen the country’s economy by increasing exports and cutting debt . The two effectively guided South Africa toward a free-market economic model .
 She had devoted most of her career to fiscal policy and economic planning . Her move in 2004 to Transnet appeared to be an unlikely choice . Transnet is operator of ports and shipping operations, bus and other passenger transit systems .

 In 2009 best-selling American romance novelist Nora Roberts opened the Inn BoonsBoro, a cozy boutique hotel-bed and breakfast, in her home state of Maryland . Roberts has a penchant for creating charming settings not only for characters in her stories but for real-life couples .
 During renovations in 2008 to restore the structure to its former grandeur, a fire broke out in the hotel . Roberts and her contractors were forced to start from scratch .
 Roberts outfitted each room with furnishings theme-related to characters in great love stories with happy endings . The Shakespeare room is based on the lovers Oberon and Titania from A Midsummer Night’s Dream and the Pride and Prejudice suite .
 As a child, Roberts was an avid reader and frequently formulated her own stories . Roberts was also an avid writer and often formulated her stories .
 Her passion for creating fiction resulted in her extremely disciplined practice of writing up to eight hours, five days per week . Her passion was to create fiction and write for eight hours a week .
 She penned her first novel, Irish Thoroughbred, published in 1981 by Silhouette . Confined to her home with her two young sons during a blizzard in 1979 .

 Turkish-born American economist Nouriel Roubini was named to the "Power 50" list of influential people in finance .
 Roubini’s subscription Web site, RGE Monitor, began in 1997 as a single page of Web links . The site has become known as a central source for economic analysis of the ongoing global credit crisis .
 Dr. Doom was known for his dire economic predictions in 2006 . He convinced even those economists and pundits who had dismissed his pessimistic outlook that he had been right .
 Roubini was born to Iranian Jewish parents . He moved with his family to Iran and Israel before they settled in Italy in 1962 .
 Roubini began looking for the next national economy most likely to collapse . Out of curiosity, he began looking at the next country's most likely economic collapse .
 Many in the audience laughed when he predicted a deep, painful recession marked by the burst of a housing bubble, mortgage defaults, a collapse in real-estate values, and economic repercussions that would shock financial markets .
 Some say Roubini was a chronic pessimist who used any number of reasons over the years to predict and explain a market collapse . When his predictions came true beginning in 2007, some critics said it was a lucky call .
 Roubini's consulting firm and Web site benefited from the publicity . Meanwhile, he had a successful consulting firm . He says the publicity was good for him .
 By mid-2009 he had softened his worst-case scenario . He still criticized those who were predicting a recovery later in the year .
 Roubini expected more financial shocks, especially from bank insolvencies, to persist through 2009 . He said he expects more shocks to continue through 2009, especially in the coming years .
 He predicted that a somewhat normal, U-shaped economic recovery would begin in 2010 . More optimistically, he predicted that the economy would begin a normal recovery in 2011 .
 Wallace Shawn's first new play in more than 10 years premiered in 2009 at London's Royal Court Theatre . Grasses of a Thousand Colors premiered in the spring of 2009 at the Royal Court .
 Shawn Shawn had long been a critical darling in the British theatre . His oft-surreal, probing plays led some critics to call him America’s leading contemporary dramatist . Shawn is best known in his home country for his lengthy career as a character actor .
 His first produced work was Our Late Night, which premiered in 1975 . He won an Obie Award for playwriting for play .

 The Designated Mourner touched on similar ground, telling the story of educated and privileged people who grapple with their humanity during a chaotic civil war in an unnamed country .

 She quickly gained a reputation as an advocate for social justice . She has called for the strengthening of Iceland’s welfare system .
 She was named minister of social affairs in 1987 . She held a position until 1994, when she unsuccessfully campaigned for leadership of the Social Democrats .
 Icelandic Prime Minister Johanna Sigurdardottir formed her own party, Icelandic Ministry of Social Affairs and Social Security . The party captured four seats in the subsequent parliamentary election in Iceland . The election was the result of a split in the Icelandic parliament .
 The two parties eventually reconciled in 1999, when they joined with the Women's Alliance and the People's Alliance to contest that year's election . In 2000, the coalition formally became the Social Democratic Alliance .
 Sigurdardottir established a civil partnership with her companion, Jonina Leosdottir, a noted playwright and journalist, in 2002 .
 In public opinion surveys, she was consistently rated as Iceland's most popular politician . In Iceland, she has been Iceland's top politician since 2008 .
 The Social Democrats and the Left-Greens won 34 seats, capturing a slim majority in the 63-seat legislature . After she was sworn in as prime minister, she called for new parliamentary elections to be held .
 Iceland submitted its formal bid for EU entry on July 17 . Shortly thereafter Sigurdardottir announced that one of her top priorities as prime minister would be securing Iceland’s membership in the EU .

 Svindal won the title by a record-low two-point margin, with a record low winning-point total . Svindal's win was the lowest total of all-time winning points in the world ski racing . The Norwegian won the world championship by a two point margin .
 The narrow victory completed a triumphant comeback from a devastating crash in 2007 that had left him seriously injured and inactive for nearly a year . The win was a narrow victory for the Spaniard .
