 On Fearless she demonstrated a refined pop sensibility, managing to court the mainstream pop audience without losing sight of her country roots .
 In November 2009 Belgian Prime Minister Herman Van Rompuy was appointed the first permanent president of the European Council, the EU’s chief decision-making body .
 His twoand-a-half-year term of office (which could be renewed once) would officially begin on Jan. 2010 .
 In 1972 he began his career as an economist at the National Bank of Belgium . He has been in charge of the Belgian National Bank since 1972 .
 The following year he entered politics, serving as the vice president of the youth section of the centre-right Flemish Christian Democrat party .
 Van Rompuy left banking in 1975, and within three years he was working in the Christian Democrats’ national office . He was working for the party's national office in the 1970s .
 He left office after the Christian Democrats’ defeat in the 1999 general election . The Christian Democrats were defeated in 1999 general elections .
 In 2004 he was named minister of state . That year he entered the legislature as a member of the Chamber of Representatives .
 With the return of the Christian Democrats to the majority in July 2007, Van Rompuy was named leader of the Chamber of Representatives . With the re-election of the party in 2007, he became the leader of his party's majority .
 King Albert II designated a reluctant Van Rompuy to replace him . Yves Leterme resigned in 2008 amid allegations of improper conduct in the disposition of Belgian-owned shares in failed Fortis bank .
 Albert had previously entrusted Van Rompuy with brokering deals between Belgium's estranged Walloon (Frenchspeaking) and Flemish communities . The former prime minister's term as prime minister saw a lessening of tension between the regions .
 Van Rompuy's light diplomatic touch has been noticed by other European leaders . The former French president's light touch was noticed by others in the region .
 After ratification of the Lisbon Treaty in November 2009, he became the compromise choice for the European Council presidency . He earned the appointment despite bids for the post by several higher-profile candidates, including Tony Blair and Felipe Gonzalez .
 In 2004 he had openly declared his opposition to the possible EU membership of Turkey . Turkey gained EU candidate status in 1999, on the basis of what he perceived to be religious differences . In 2004, he openly declared opposition to Turkey's possible membership .
 Alice Waters is a chef, restaurateur, and food activist . She championed an overhaul of the public-school lunch system . Waters is known for her efforts to bring organically grown food to the mainstream .
 Waters was co-owner and chef of the famed Berkeley, Calif., restaurant Chez Panisse . Waters had long fought to overturn the elitist stereotypes surrounding the ""slow food” movement .
 She participated in the 1960s Free Speech Movement, and the idealism that was prevalent at Berkeley was reflected in her ideology .
 She studied abroad for a time in France, and it was there that her love of farm-to-plate dining took hold . She studied in France .
 Following graduation, she spent a year at the International Montessori School in London . She then returned to California to teach .
 In the 1970s the U.S. was still years away from the “foodie revolution,"" which by 2009 had brought farmers’ markets and organic foods to a larger audience . By 2009 organic foods were available at farmers' markets .
 Waters’s prescient passion for whole foods inspired her and her friend Lindsey Shere to found a market-inspired restaurant, despite having little capital and no experience as restaurateurs . Waters and Shere are the owners of the restaurant in New York .
 Waters wanted to create meals by using only locally grown seasonal ingredients . Waters said she wanted to forge relationships with the producers and suppliers . Waters says she wants to use locally grown ingredients to make meals .
 Waters's restaurant was in debt for its first eight years of business . It was frequently saved from bankruptcy by loans from Waters's friends . The restaurant was often in debt during its first 8 years .
 Waters had time to devote herself to other facets of food activism, such as the Garden Project . The Garden Project provided produce to the San Francisco county jail and work opportunities to former inmates .
 In 1996, to celebrate the restaurant’s 25th anniversary, Waters founded the Chez Panisse Foundation . The foundation funded programs that educated young people on responsible agriculture .
 The Edible Schoolyard was established in 1995 . The advocacy group was founded in 1995, and is best known for its advocacy work . She is also known for her advocacy work on the edible arts movement .
 Waters began the program by planting a garden in the yard of Berkeley’s Martin Luther King Jr. Waters planted the garden in a garden at the King's home .
 A cooking classroom was installed a few years later, and by 2009 the Edible Schoolyard was a thriving educational tool, though not a source of lunchroom produce . A cooking class was installed in 2009 .
 Waters's new cause is persuading the government to increase funding for school lunch programs . Waters hopes to increase the government's support for school lunches to improve the quality of school lunch .
 Waters' dedication to providing schoolchildren with more healthful eating options earned her fair share of detractors . Waters' detractors argued seasonal food was a luxury for already underfunded schools .
 Canadian environmental warrior Paul Watson and his crew sailed into the second season of their popular program Whale Wars on the Animal Planet cable television network .
 The Sea Shepherd Conservation Society’s expeditions to protect and defend marine wildlife from illegal poaching . The Canadian environmental warrior Paul Watson Chantal Henderson/Sea Shepherd Conservation society in Bebeto Matthews' book .
 Watson's direct-action approach to saving whales caused some whalers to label him as an ecoterrorist . Watson's ship, the Steve Irwin, was positioned between the whaling and a targeted pod of whales .
 At the age of nine he would seek out and destroy leghold traps that were set by beaver hunters, interfere with deer and duck hunters, and foil the attempts of other young boys to shoot birds .
 During the late 1960s he joined the Canadian Coast Guard . He gained sailing experience with the British, Canadian, Norwegian, and Swedish merchant marines .
 Watson often employed daring and innovative tactics to defend wildlife from hunters . Watson often positioned his inflatable Zodiac boat in between a pod of sperm whales and the harpoon of a large Soviet whaling vessel . Watson forced sealing ships to halt by standing on the ice in their path .
 He was also known to handcuff himself to a pile of seal pelts being hoisted up onto a sealing vessel .
 Watson left Greenpeace and established the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society . Owing to conflicts concerning such unconventional protest methods, Watson left the group . Watson established Sea Shepherd conservation Society .

 Vasily Pavlovich Aksyonov is a Russian novelist and short-story writer . He is also a Russian short storywriter . He was also a short story writer .
 Aksyonov was the son of parents who spent many years in Soviet prisons . He was raised in a state home and raised in the Soviet Union .
 He graduated from medical school in 1956 and worked as a doctor for a few years . He has been married for more than 60 years .
 In the cultural thaw of the late 1950s and early ’60s, he published a number of short stories and novels .
 Aksyonov excelled in fast-moving narratives dealing with youthful rebels who are attracted to Western culture even though they share the collectivist ideals of the previous generation .
 In 1980 he was forced into exile in the West because of his reputation and involvement in the attempted publication of Metropol, an uncensored literary journal, in 1980 . He was forced to flee to the West .
 Aksyonov’s citizenship was restored by decree in 1990, and he later lived in Moscow .

 Philippine political leader Corazon Aquino Val Rodriguez Val Rodriguez/AP province, Phil. Jan. 1933, Tarlac . Val Rodriguez: "Aquino was a great leader of the Philippines"
 President of the Philippines restored democratic rule in that country after the dictatorship of Ferdinand Marcos . Marcos was a dictator who ruled the Philippines during the dictatorship .
 She was born into a wealthy, politically prominent family . She graduated from the College of Mount St. St. in New York .
 She remained in the background during her husband’s subsequent career, rearing their five children at home . She remained the background of her husband's career .
 Her husband, who had become a prominent opposition leader, was jailed by Marcos for eight years . In 1980 Aquino accompanied him into exile in the United States . Her husband’s assassination upon his return to the Philippines in 1983 galvanized opposition to Marcos government .
 When Marcos called for presidential elections in February 1986, Aquino was the opposition’s candidate . Aquino became the unified opposition's candidate in 1986 elections . He is now the leader of the Philippines .
 Aquino and her supporters challenged the results, charging widespread voting fraud . Though she was officially reported to have lost to Marcos, Aquino's supporters said widespread fraud was widespread . The results were disputed .
 High officials in the military renounced Marcos and proclaimed Aquino the rightful president . Aquino was declared the president of the Philippines by the military .
 On Feb., 1986, both Aquino and Marcos were inaugurated as president, but that same day Marcos fled the country . Marcos fled that day .
 Aquino appointed a commission to write a new constitution, which restored the bicameral Congress . Aquino appoints a commission, which appointed a new commission .
 She broke up monopolies held by Marcos’s allies over the economy . She then held elections to the new Congress and broke up the monopolies . The economy experienced steady growth for several years .
 Aquino failed to undertake fundamental economic or social reforms, however . Her popularity steadily declined as she faced continual outcries over economic injustice and political corruption .
 She followed it with three more novels that established her as a literary star in Quebec and France . Her novels were published in Quebec, France and Canada .

 Norman Ernest Borlaug, Norman Ernest, was an American agricultural scientist and plant pathologist (b. Norman Ernest) Norman Ernest . Norman Ernest was an agricultural scientist in the United States . He was also an American .
 Nobel Prize for Peace in 1970 for his contributions in laying the groundwork of the so-called Green Revolution, the agricultural technological advance that promised to alleviate world hunger .
 His work was founded on earlier discoveries of ways to induce genetic mutations in plants .
 These methods led to modern plant breeding, with momentous results that included the tailoring of crop varieties for regions prone to climatic extremes . These methods were used in the creation of modern crop varieties .
 At a research station at Campo Atizapan, he developed strains of grain that dramatically increased crop yields . The strains were developed by scientists in the Philippines .
 Borlaug ultimately developed short-stemmed wheat, a key element in the Green Revolution in less-developed countries . Short-stressed wheat is a key ingredient in the green revolution .
 He served as director of Inter-American Food Crop Program and director of International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center, Mexico City .
 In 1986 Borlaug created the World Food Prize as a way to honour individuals who had contributed to improving the availability and quality of food worldwide . The prize is given to individuals who have contributed to improve the availability of food in the world .

 Merce Cunningham, Merce (MERCIER Philip CUNNINGHAM), American dancer and choreographer (b. Philip Cunningham) Cunningham was choreographer, choreographer and dancer . Cunningham was born Philip Cunningham in 1926 . Cunningham died at the age of 92 . Cunningham is credited with
 Cunningham began instruction in dance at age 12 . He studied for two years at Cornish School in Seattle . He also studied with Lester Horton at Mills College, Oakland, Calif. Martha Graham invited him to join her group .
 He also had already started collaborating with Cage and presented his first solo concert, with music by Cage .
 Cunningham developed ""choreography by chance," a technique in which selected isolated movements are assigned sequence by such random methods as tossing a coin . Cunningham developed the technique in the 1970s . Cunningham's technique is called "choreographic by chance"
 The sequential arrangement of the component dances in Sixteen Dances for Soloist and Company of Three was determined, and in Suite by Chance the movement patterns themselves were so constructed .
 Many of Cunningham's works were associated with Dadaist, Surrealist, and existentialist motifs . Cunningham's work was associated with the works of Dadaists and Surrealists . Cunningham was a prolific artist .
 In 1974 he abandoned the repertory that had been built over a 20year period for what he called ""Events,"" excerpts from old or new dances, sometimes two or more simultaneously . In 1974, he abandoned all his work over the next 20 years .
 Cunningham left the performance stage soon after Cage’s death in 1992 . Cunningham continued to lead his dance company after Cage's death .

 Amae no kozo was perhaps the first Japanese expert to analyze the Japanese idea of amae (""indulgent dependency"") and the first to exert wide influence on Western psychiatric thought .
 In 1950 he traveled to the United States to study psychiatry, and the culture shock he experienced prompted his investigation of the Japanese psyche . He traveled to Japan in 1950 to study the psychology of the country .
 Doi’s groundbreaking theory centred on the concept of amae, which he defined as a culturally ingrained dependence on authority figures that retained a pervasive influence on all social structures .

 Granger’s books cover such subjects as time series analysis and forecasting, statistical theory, and applied statistics . Granger's books cover subjects such as statistical theory and time-series analysis .
 In his seminal work, conducted in the 1970s and '80s, he developed concepts and analytic methods to establish meaningful relationships between nonstationary variables such as exchange rates and inflation rates .
 Fundamental to his methods was his discovery that a specific combination of two or more nonstationary time series could be stationary . He invented the term cointegration, which he invented for his methods .
 The dynamics in exchange rates and prices are driven by a tendency to smooth out deviations from the long-run equilibrium exchange rate and short-run fluctuations around the adjustment path .
 Granger was granted a knighthood in 2005 after spending most of his career in the U.S. He retained his British citizenship and was granted his knighthold in 2005 . Granger was knighted in 2005 for his services in the United States .

 He was one of the preeminent ethnologists of his time . He was a leading exponent of structuralism, the analysis of cultural systems in terms of their structural relations .

 Hossein Ali (HUSAYN-'ALI MUNTAZIRl), Iranian cleric (b.22, Najafabad, Iran—d.d. Montazeri) Hossein was Iranian cleric . He was a prominent cleric in Iran's Islamic Revolution .
 Ayatollah Montazeri was emphatic in his defense of human rights in Iran . He spent long periods under arrest during both the regime of Mohammad Reza Shah Pahlavi and the Islamic republic that he himself helped to establish .
 Montazeri was the son of a farmer who taught the Qur’an . He began studying Arabic grammar and Persian literature at age 7 . At 12 he enrolled in theological school in nearby Esfahan .
 At 19 he moved to Qom, were he studied under the future Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini . At 19, he studied in Qom and studied in Iran .
 Montazeri helped maintain his mentor’s antiregime message and campaigned for Khomeini's return . After the shah exiled him from Iran, he campaigned for his return to Iran .
 Montazeri was arrested a number of times and was often exiled within Iran . He was arrested several times and often exiled .
 After his arrest in 1974, he was imprisoned in solitary confinement for several months and tortured . He was tortured by police in the 1970s and imprisoned for months .
 Khomeini named him his deputy in Iran in 1978 . Released in 1978, he traveled to Paris, where he was named his deputy .
 Following the overthrow of the shah, Montazeri was instrumental in drafting of a new constitution . In 1985 he was designated as Khomeini's successor .
 Montazeri contended that human rights abuses persisted in Iran, however, and when Ali Khamenei—a junior cleric—succeeded Khomeini upon his death in 1989, he denounced Khamenei’s relatively low status .

 Wyeth was a wellknown illustrator who had studied under Howard Pyle . Wyeth, starting in 1932, served as his son’s only teacher .
 The subject matter of Andrew Wyeth's works came almost entirely from two localities, the Brandywine Valley around Chadds Ford and the area near his summer home in Cushing, Maine . Wyeth died at the end of his life at his Maine summer home .
 His work displays a strong linear quality, and within his limited palette—consisting mostly of earth tones -- he achieved a subtly extensive range of colour .
 His paintings are precise and detailed, yet he moved them beyond photographic naturalism by imbuing them with a sense of subjective emotion . The paintings are detailed and detailed yet to be photographed .
 Christina’s World is Wyeth's best-known painting . Wyeth knew a disabled woman whom he knew seemed trying to crawl up a hill . Christina's World achieves a note of melancholy .
 This work also exemplifies his use of unusual angles and his mastery of light . This work is also exemplified his work with unusual angles .
 Between 1971 and 1985 Wyeth secretly painted Helga Testorf, his neighbour in Chadds Ford, creating hundreds of images of her, including nudes . Wyeth painted hundreds of nudes of his neighbour, Helga .
 Other important exhibitions included a 1987 show of his “Helga pictures" organized by the National Gallery of American Art in Washington, D.C., and a 2006 retrospective at the Philadelphia Museum of Art in Philadelphia .

 Twelve months after the Great Recession, the worst appeared to have been averted . Twelve months later, what many called the recession showed signs of coming to an end .
 On the whole, private economists applauded the U.S. response to the crisis at hand . But some of the remedies enacted there and in other countries seemed poised to haunt the world economy in years to come .
 Even if the financial crisis did not send the world back to the 1930s, it turned economic growth into contraction in many countries . The crisis slowed expansion practically everywhere else in the world and slowed expansion .
 The ripple effects of the financial crisis ranged far beyond the financial collapse . The ripple effect of the crisis was far beyond financial crisis .
 The Chinese brushed aside pleas for more accommodating human rights and currency valuation policies . The Chinese government has been criticized for its human rights policies .
 Most of the major industrial democracies adopted domestic government programs designed to awaken their slumbering economies . The U.S. package, at $787 billion, was the biggest .
 Most countries began growing again in mid-2009 after recessions that were, for most, the deepest since the Great Depression . The world's economic outlook brightened as the year proceeded, however, however .
 The Bank of England cuts its interest rate from 2% to 1.5%, the lowest since the bank's founding in 1694 . In a rare exception, China escaped the slump; if anything, the global recession burnished .
 Iceland's government falls owing to the collapse of the country's economy . Iceland's economy collapsed in 2008 and the government was forced to step down .
 It is reported that 3. million jobs have been lost in the United States since the recession began in 2007 .

 The project was funded by the $787 billion fiscal stimulus package passed by the United States Congress in February . The project is funded by a $787billion fiscal stimulus bill .

 The United States housing market was the domino that, when it fell, toppled many of the worlds major economies and led the world into recession . The U.S. housing market led to the collapse of the world's major economies .
 For the first half of the decade, aggressive investing by homebuyers, mortgage lenders, lenders . Mortgage lenders have been aggressive in recent years . Mortgage lending has been a big problem for many of the past decade .
 Wall Street investment houses, and insurers had driven up the median price of a single-family home by almost 10% a year . Housing in some parts of the country is escalating even faster .
 When home prices headed back down in 2007, homeowners faced rising adjustable-rate mortgage payments and/or could no longer borrow against a rising home value to finance other expenses . Many of those faced rising mortgage payments .
 By the middle of 2009, the median home price had fallen close to its 2000 level . Median home price was close to the level of 2000 levels .
 Those with heavy investments in housing, including risky mortgage-backed securities, found them all but worthless . Those who invested heavily in housing found their investments worthless . Mortgage-backed investments are now worthless .
 The government stepped in with a massively expensive bailout program in late 2008 and continuing into 2009 . The bailout program was the largest in the country's history .
 The devastation to the U.S. economy spread far beyond housing . The devastation has also spread beyond the United States .
 Even financially secure banks, not trusting potential borrowers to pay them back, stopped lending . Even financial secure banks stopped lending to those who could not afford to repay .
 Small and new businesses could not find the credit that they needed to pay creditors or buy inventory or to pay their own workers, much less to hire new ones . Small businesses were unable to find credit to buy inventory, buy inventory and pay their workers .
 Even short-term interest rates close to zero did not fully thaw credit markets . Credit markets have been hit hard by low interest rates in recent years .
 Businesses that relied on their customers’ ability to secure loans had a rough time . Businesses relying on customers' ability to get loans have a tough time. Businesses relied heavily on loans to make money .
 General Motors and Chrysler both reorganized after brief trips through bankruptcy in 2009 . Automakers GM and Chrysler qualified for bailout money after going through bankruptcy .
 The overall economic slowdown sent stock prices reeling . The benchmark Dow Jones Industrial Average sank by about 54% in the 17 months from the market high in October 2007 to the trough in March 2009 . The market high was October 2007 .
 In the 1930s, national leaders generally pledged allegiance to fiscal policies based on balanced budgets . The 1930s was a period of national leaders pledging allegiance to a balanced budget policy .
 With tax revenue falling in tandem with economic growth, balancing budgets meant cutting spending . Cutting spending just when economies needed to stimulate business expansion and job growth .
 Political leaders poured money into such projects as road construction and schools . This time around, however, political leaders poured it into schools and roads .
 Although some governments were more aggressive than others, just about all countries joined the stimulus parade .
 In 1929 the U.S. Federal Reserve Board instituted a monetary policy of tight money and high interest rates . The policy was intended to restrain a speculative rise in stock prices .
 The Depression officially began that August . The economy predictably contracted, and the Depression began that year .
 The Fed further tightened its grip on the money supply in 1931, adding to the squeeze on the domestic economy . Nevertheless, the Fed continued to tighten its grip in 1931 .
 The Fed and many other foreign counterparts also injected capital into banks and bought their shaky loans . The Fed also bought shaky loans to shore up banks .
 When economies go haywire, there is a natural tendency to close ranks by tightening trade policy and refraining from buying foreign goods . The U.S. has a tendency to tighten trade policy when it is going haywire .
 Smoot-Hawley trade tariffs were introduced in 1930 . Smoot Hawley was introduced by the U.S. Congress in 1930 to protect American imports .
 The result was a decline in world trade volume estimated in late 1932 at about 30% and still growing . The outcome is almost universally seen as having fueled the Great Depression .
 This time there was no such rush to protect industry at home . Global trade actually dropped even more sharply in the current financial crisis than during the Depression .
 The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes at 6547.05, its lowest level of the year . This was not the result of new trade barriers; rather, the faltering global economy sapped the market . The market closed at 65.05 on Friday .
 Chrysler LLC files for bankruptcy protection; after merger with Italy's Fiat, it emerges on June 10 . Chrysler will emerge from bankruptcy after merging with Fiat . Chrysler's merger with Fiat is expected to be completed in June .
 General Motors, once the world's largest corporation, files for bankruptcy . It emerges on July 10 . General Motors was once the largest corporation in the world .
 Japan reports that its econ omy grew by 0.9% in the second quarter; thus, the country is no longer in recession . Japan is now in a recession .
 Enlightened decision making may have blocked another Depression, but it could not prevent a great deal of misery . Enlightened . decision making . may have prevented another Depression but it did not prevent great deal .
 Most of the developed countries had close financial and trade relations with the U.S. Most developed countries have close financial, trade ties with the United States .
 Of the 33 countries that the IMF considered to have ‘advanced economies, only Australia seemed likely to avoid a period of contraction . Australia is one of the only countries considered "advanced" economies in the world .
 The dynamic economies of Asia were well positioned, and three large Asian countries—India, Indonesia, and China—escaped relatively unscathed . The dynamic economy of Asia was well positioned .
 At least in the short run, India benefited from having isolated itself from the crosscurrents of the global economy . India's economy has been hit hard by the economic downturn in recent years .
 Japans economy, the largest in the world after the U.S., was fused to the West’s, and Japan marched alongside the West into recession .
 Japan pulled out of recession in the third quarter of 2009 . With a large economic stimulus package in place, Japan pulled from recession in 2009 .
 The Japanese government proposed weaker limits than those under discussion in Europe and the United States . Europe, with its close financial and trade ties to the U.S., stood in sharp contrast to Asia .
 Even Norway had invested its North Sea oil revenue with considerable prudence while the U.K. was spending its windfall on government programs . Even Norway could not escape recession .
 Norway slipped into a mild slump in late 2008 and emerged early in 2009 . Norway's economy has been in a mild recession since 2008 .
 Many countries approved economic stimulus packages to extricate themselves from recession . U.K., Spain, and others remained in recession for the first nine months of 2009 .
 The stimulus programs in Europe were smaller than those in the U.S. Perhaps more significant, the largesse stopped at national borders . Reflecting fears of future inflation, Europe's stimulus programs were smaller .

 Iceland’s three largest banks, privatized in the early 1990s, failed in 2008 when the financial crisis left them unable to pay a mountain of foreign obligations . The banks had grown fat on securities trading, but they failed when the crisis struck .
 The conservative prime minister resigned in January 2009 and was replaced by a leftist, Johanna Sigurdardottottir . She promptly recapitalized the banks . The leftist prime minister is now a leftist .
 Latvia boasted Europe’s strongest economic growth rate as recently as 2007 . Latvia had boasted Europe's strongest growth rate in 2007 . Latvia's economy had been booming in the past decade . Latvia is now struggling to cope with Latvia's economic woes .
 Latvian economy shrank at doubledigit rates in 2009—possibly the worst performance in Europe . Baltic neighbours, Lithuania and Estonia, were not far behind .
 In January, a street demonstration in Riga turned violent, and a month later the prime minister resigned . In the Latvian capital of Riga, a protest against economic decline turned violent . The prime minister of Latvia resigned a month after the demonstration .
 Greece's budget deficit reached nearly 13% of annual economic output . Fitch, Moody's, and Standard and Poor’s downgraded the country's debt . The budget deficit is even greater than the 11% in the U.S.
 At year's end Greece had the lowest credit rating of the 16 countries in the euro zone . Greece's credit rating is the lowest of 16 countries with a credit rating . Greece has the lowest rating of any euro zone country .
 Greece's debt at 130% of economic output was nearly the highest in Europe . That made it more expensive for Greece to finance its debt, which is 130% economic output . Greece has the highest debt in the European Union and Greece is one of the most indebted countries .
 Spain, whose budget deficit was rocketing toward 11%, was on the same path as Greece, although less far along . Spain's budget deficit is rocketing to 11%, while Greece's is expected to reach 11% .
 Standard and Poor’s also downgraded Spain, which started at a much higher level . Spain's credit rating has also been downgraded . Spain is one of the fastest-growing economies in the world .
 The fiscal problems that put Greece and Spain on a slippery slope were common across Europe . They were common among economies that had grown the most during the heady early years of the decade . Greece, Spain and Spain were among the countries that grew the most in the early years .

 What emerged from the bailout was an extraordinary degree of government involvement in—and sometimes even majority ownership of—the private sector . Government involvement in the private sector was extraordinary, says CNN's John Sutter .
 By late 2009, the government had provided an estimated $4 trillion to keep the financial sector afloat . Altogether, by late 2009 had provided $4 billion to keep banks afloat . The government had given $4 million to keep financial institutions afloat .
 Many of the biggest bailout beneficiaries quickly paid the government back . The ultimate cost of the bailout to taxpayers was estimated at “only"" $1.1 trillion .
 The $787 billion stimulus bill was the first legislative triumph of Barack Obama's month-old presidency . It comprised $288 billion in tax cuts and $499 billion in spending . Most of it was for public-works programs such as school construction and highway repair .
 Budget Office: About three-quarters of $787 billion would be spent in 18 months . Republicans groused that checks for much of the $499 billion bill would be issued too late to do any good . The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office says the tax measures will be spent within months .
 Obama claimed that the bill would create or preserve 3. million jobs . Many of his opponents say that figure is far too optimistic . Obama claimed it would create jobs .
 The U.S. economy grew 3.5% in the third quarter and has emerged from recession . It is reported that the United States economy grew in the last quarter of the year .
 United States unemployment figures show an increase to 10.2% in October, the high for the year and the first doubledigit rate since 1983 . The increase is the first doubling of the unemployment rate in the country since 1983.
 The euro zone is no longer in recession, with a reported 1.6% annualized growth in the third quarter . Eurozone grew by 1% in the last three months of the year .
 Congress also played a role in the bailout of failing financial institutions . Congress played a key role in bailout of banks that failed banks .
 At the end of 2008, Congress enacted the Troubled Asset Relief Program . The Department of the Treasury can invest up to $700 billion by buying unproductive real-estate investments or even becoming part owners .
 The Fed, using authority that it already had, played an even bigger role . The Fed used authority that already had to use to make the decision .
 The central bank invested heavily in foundering institutions and guaranteed the value of their assets . Printing more money when not enough was available, the central bank invests heavily .
 By the end of 2009, the government owned almost 80% of American International Group . The insurer is the country’s biggest insurer, at a cost of $150 billion .
 It initially spent $111 billion to prop up Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac . The companies were sponsored by Congress to buy mortgages from their issuers . The government spent that money to prop them up .
 The government promised to play no role in managing these companies . Government promised to sell its ownership stakes as soon as practical . The government will not be involved in managing the companies .
 TARP provided the Treasury with only a fraction of the funds used for the bailout, however . TARP gave the Treasury the funds needed to bail-out the economy .
 Even the massive AIG rescue was engineered entirely outside the legislated Treasury Department program . The Fed was responsible for the lion’s share, and the AIG was engineered outside the Treasury Department .
 Members of the government expressed outrage that some of the same executives who helped precipitate the financial crisis should make millions of dollars a year in salaries and bonuses .
 Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner appointed a ""special master for executive compensation” to review the compensation packages of top financial executives at firms that received bailouts . The special master will review compensation packages at firms receiving bailouts that received bailout funds .
 Many of the biggest bailout beneficiaries balked at the proposed salary limits . They strove to get out of under them by paying the government back . Many of them are now paying back the bailout money .
 Many members of Congress marched into 2010 with a determination to regulate financial institutions more closely . Financial institutions will be regulated more closely in the wake of the recession .
 The House passed a bill in 2009 that for the first time would bring exotic financial instruments under review by federal regulators . The bill was passed in 2009 .
 The bill would also establish a single agency to protect financial consumers . It would also guarantee shareholders a chance to vote on the compensation packages of corporate executives .
 Despite the yearend sighs of relief over the improving economy, the economic destruction had not necessarily run its course . The economic destruction is not necessarily running its course, says David Cameron .
 Many banks that survived the crisis were badly bruised by the collapse of the housing market . Banks that survived were less willing than before to provide the credit that greases all capitalist economies .
 Government budget deficits loomed like dark clouds on the horizon, threatening inflation and currency devaluations . Huge government budget deficits are designed to facilitate economic growth in the short term, but threaten inflation .
 Low interest rates encouraged immediate business activity, but, like budget deficits, they could ultimately feed inflation . Low rates encouraged by low interest rates, but they could feed inflation, say experts . Low inflation could feed the rate of inflation .
 International trade suffered as countries hunkered down and adopted ""me-first’s policies . International trade held below precrisis levels .
 Nearly one house in four was worth less than what the occupants owed on the mortgage . Similar problems in commercial real estate were mounting mounting .
 DJIA made up half of its losses by year-end 2009 . Stock markets turned robustly upward, with the DJIA making up half .
 Unemployment in the United States reached a peak of 10.2%, its highest level since 1983 . The 2.2% annual growth rate that the economy registered in the third quarter suggested future job growth . The U.S. unemployment rate was 10% in 2013 .

 Just in the nick of time, fellow emirate Abu Dhabi bailed out Dubai with $10 billion . Dubai was bailed out by the emirates of Abu Dhabi and Dubai . Abu Dhabi also bailed out the country .
 Dubai World's default date has been extended beyond its default date . Dubai World proved that not every financial cough would mean pneumonia for the global economy .

 From December 2006 to October 2009, some 14,000 people in Mexico were executed by drug traffickers . More than 3,000 of those deaths occurred during the first half of 2009 alone .
 The Mexican government was at war with a very powerful enemy . The statistics underscored the enormity of the situation, the Mexican government says .
 Drug cartels have been fighting over territories in Mexico since the late 1990s . Domestic consumption of illegal drugs has increased in recent years . Drug cartels are fighting for control of new territories .
 As part of their preparations for war against other cartels, many drug-trafficking organizations hired trained mercenaries . The cartels often hire trained mercenaries to fight off other cartels .
 The Gulf cartel based in the border city of Matamoros recruited a group of former Mexican army commandos called the Zetas . They became known for their efficient use of violence .
 Other cartels recruited members of Central American street gangs, or maras, as well as former Guatemalan elite troops known as the Kaibiles . The cartels recruited Central American gang members and former elite troops .
 Most recent killings resulted from confrontations between the cartels . Most of the recent killings were confrontations with cartel cartels .
 The majority of the victims were policemen and soldiers, some of them probably involved in drug trafficking . The remainder were policemen, soldiers and a small number of civilians .
 The spike in violence between the cartels was one sign of the accelerating fragmentation of these organizations . The spike is one sign that the cartels are becoming more fragmented .
 The big cartels that appeared in the mid-1990s in Mexico did not exist in the same configuration . By 2009, the cartels were no longer the same size as they did in the 1990s .
 New groups emerge to challenge for control over the drug trade . Splits occurred in all of them, with new groups emerging to challenge control .
 This fragmentation along with the growth in the domestic market for illegal drugs led to more executions . This fragmentation has led to the increasing brutality with which killings were carried out . The killings have increased in recent years .
 Many bodies of those executed had been found with messages intended for other drug-trafficking organizations as well as for the Mexican authorities .

 Pakistan was established as a predominantly Muslim but supposedly secular state in the wake of the United Kingdom’s retreat from empire . Pakistan, like India, was the consequence of an outstanding South Asian personality .
 Mohammed Ali Jinnah shared the spotlight with Mohandas K Gandhi in the days leading up to the partition of British India in 1947 . Jinnah assumed the role as Pakistan's first head of state, and it was around him that the government took form .
 Gandhi's assassination soon after the transfer of power did not have the impact on India’s governance . Jinnah's death was hardly a year after Pakistan's independence . Gandhi was assassinated in 1947, but Jinnah died in 1947 .
 His vision of a progressive state could not be institutionalized, and the country drifted from its intended objective to a series of arbitrary maneuvers . The Pakistan army now dominates the political scene in the country .
 From the moment of independence, Pakistan found itself locked in a violent contest with India . Pakistan is one of the most violent countries in the world, with India leading the Taliban .
 Immediately following the transfer of power, India and Pakistan went to war over the northern Kashmir territory . Their conflict set the scene for a bitter relationship in the decades that followed .
 The two countries waged war again in 1965 and most notably in 1971 . The two nations fought again in 1966 and 1971 .
 Kashmir was largely played out in Pakistan’s Bengal province . It could not be kept from spilling over into Kashmir . Kashmir is a major source of conflict between Pakistan and India .

 With the aid of substantial Pakistani resources in men and weapons, the Taliban gained control over most of Afghanistan . With the help of Pakistan's resources in Pakistan, Taliban took control of most of the country in 2001 .

 Pakistan appeared to have achieved its most immediate national security objective . It seemed to gain control over the Pashtun peoples domiciled on both sides of their shared border with Afghanistan .
 The success of the austere Islamists and the formation of a chaste Islamic state in Central Asia drew the attention of Muslims from other parts of the world, among them Osama bin Laden and his al-Qaeda organization .
 The resurrected Afghan emirate is a base of operations ideally suited to press al-Qaeda's worldwide strategy . The latter, bent on forcing American influence from Islamic countries, saw in Afghanistan as a base for its operations .
 The terrorist attacks in the U.S. on Sept. 2001 were quickly traced to Afghanistan, where bin Laden and the Taliban emir had entered into cooperative and intimate association .

 From Recruitment to Reintegration by Michael Wessells, from Mogadishu, Som. Somalia .
 Worldwide, armed forces and nongovernmental armed groups recruit and exploit children . Children are defined under international law as those under 18 years of age .
 At any time, there are estimated to be 250,000 child soldiers, many of whom are girls . Many recruiters hide their actions, and some children lie about their age in order to join political struggles .
 Although most child soldiers are teenagers, recruits also include children as young as six or seven years of age . Most recruits are teenagers but recruits include children aged between six and seven years .
 Lord’s Resistance Army, which abducted many children and fought against the government of Uganda, maintained military camps in southern Sudan . Its leader, Joseph Kony, sired many children who subsequently became soldiers .
 Commanders often select children because they are available in large numbers and can be recruited with impunity . Commanders know they can manipulate children easily by employing terror tactics and offering incentives for bravery and initiative in combat .
 Armed with small lightweight weapons such as AK-47 assault rifles, even young children can be effective fighters . Armed with lightweight weapons, such as small lightweight .
 They may also serve as spies who can slip behind enemy lines without suspicion . They can also be used as spies or spies . They may be able to slip into enemy forces without suspicion.
 Teenagers are often sought for their size and strength, their willingness to take risks that many adults would avoid, and their political consciousness . Teenagers often seek to be larger and stronger than adults in order to take political risks .
 In Sri Lanka the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Elam fought government forces in part by recruiting teenage girls to serve as suicide bombers . The Liberation Tigers recruited teenage girls for suicide bombers in part .
 Child recruitment is contextual and may involve force or decisions made by the child . Child recruitment may be contextualised and involve force and decisions made .
 LRA forcibly recruited as many as 60,000 children by abducting and subjugating them into obedience through a regime of terror . The LRA has been fighting for more than two decades since 2003 .
 To deter escape the LRA forced abducted children to surround recaptured escapees and beat them to death . The LRA was forced to beat children to death to deter escapees from escaping .
 Forced recruitment was also used in Sierra Leone, where the opposition group Revolutionary United Front forced young people at gunpoint to join and often required children to kill members of their own villages .
 Some children decide to join armed groups, but their choices may not be “voluntary,” since they are made in desperate circumstances and involve a mixture of “push” and “pull” factors . Some children join armed forces in desperate situations .
 In Colombia, for example, a boy who has been abused in his home may leave and seek an alternate "family" in the form of an armed group . A boy who is abused in Colombia may leave his home to seek an alternative "family," such as armed men .
 In other countries youths have been lured by propaganda and an ideology of liberation into believing that by becoming soldiers, they will help to liberate their people . In some countries youths are lured into thinking that by . becoming soldiers they will . help their people, they said .
 In Rwanda young Hutu were recruited into a youth militia and were taught that Tutsi had to be eliminated . More than 800,000 people, mostly Tutsis, were killed in the 1994 genocide .
 Other pull factors may include retribution, money, family ties, and power, according to reports .
 In Liberia some children join armed groups in an effort to avenge wrongs, such as the killing of one's parents by government forces . In Liberia, some children joined armed groups to help avenge their parents' deaths .
 Children are eager to earn money that they can send home to support impoverished families . Children may also be eager to work for a living wage to support their impoverished families.
 In northern Afghanistan children frequently joined the Northern Alliance to fight the Taliban . Their fathers, brothers, or uncles were members and because they regarded fighting as a matter of family honour and village protection . Children often joined the alliance because they were members of their families .
 A common myth is that all child soldiers are fighters . Many recruits serve as porters, cooks, bodyguards, and domestics, among other roles .
 Girls were recruited to serve as fighters and sex slaves in Liberia and Sierra Leone . Refusing to provide sex often led to severe punishment or death .
 Child soldiers may themselves become a means of perpetuating violence and armed conflict . Because they have been socialized into lives as soldiers, child soldiers may become a weapon of violence and conflict .
 A key priority has been to demobilize child soldiers and help them transition or reintegrate into civilian life . To break cycles of violence, a key priority is demobilizing child soldiers .
 Typically, this is done through a process of disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration . The U.S. has been involved in Iraq and Afghanistan in the past .
 Child soldiers are demobilized by being stood down from armed groups . Having turned in their weapons (disarmament), child soldiers are stood down . The demobilization process starts at the age of 12 .
 They are reintegrated through rehabilitation and work with families and communities . Families and communities work with them to help them find a place in civilian society .
 Rehabilitation requires attention to mental health issues that cause distress and impede reintegration . Mental health issues are among the issues that need attention to . Rehabilitation is a form of rehabilitation that requires attention .
 As part of her therapy, a female former child soldier in a rehabilitation camp in Bukavu, Dem. Uganda .
 Many former child soldiers developed problems of substance abuse after being plied with drugs by commanders .
 In other countries a minority of former child soldiers develop clinical problems, such as depression, anxiety, and trauma . Post-traumatic stress disorder can arise following extreme events, including exposure to deaths or active engagement .
 Effective treatment of these problems requires specialized supports, such as counseling by well-trained psychologists or psychiatrists, few of whom are available in war zones . Few of these therapists or psychiatrists are available to help the wounded .
 In Angola, former child soldiers were terrified because they believed they were haunted by the unavenged spirits of the people they had killed . Former child soldiers in Angola believed that the spirits of those they killed haunted them .
 The children benefit from the services of a traditional healer, who conducts a cleansing ritual to remove their spiritual pollution . In this case, rather than counseling, the children benefit .
 It is often everyday social issues that cause the greatest distress and the most formidable barriers to reintegration . Social issues are often the biggest barriers to integration, says author .
 To rectify family separation it is essential, when possible, to reunify former recruits with their families and manage family conflicts . It is essential to reunite former recruits .
 Nearly all former child soldiers struggle because they have lost years of education and lack the income needed to start a family . They lack social skills to assume the role of mother or father .
 Some people develop unruly behaviour, while others have difficulty meeting expectations associated with ordinary living . Some people are unruly and unruly, but others are able to cope with ordinary life .
 Many former child soldiers, particularly girls, are stigmatized and called “rebels” or are viewed as aggressive troublemakers . Many former soldiers, especially girls, have been stigmatized by their treatment .
 Effective reintegration is possible through holistic community-based supports . Reintegration can be achieved through holistic support from the community .
 It is important to mobilize communities to support the livelihood, acceptance, and education of former child soldiers . It's important to activate protection mechanisms that guard against rerecruitment or retaliation .
 Reintegration efforts are not sufficient by themselves . Equal efforts should be given to prevention, particularly to ending the impunity that allows recruitment to continue .
 Recognition of the serious nature of enlisting children in warfare was highlighted in 2009 . Thomas Lubanga Dyilo became the first person to be tried by the International Criminal Court .
 UN is at the forefront of strengthening international standards against child recruitment . UN urged governments to ratify the Optional Protocol on the involvement of children in armed conflict .
 The optional protocol was adopted in 2000 to augment the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child . It raises the minimum age of participation in hostilities from 15 to 18 years of age to 18 .
 These efforts will succeed, however, only if all countries agree to abide by the optional protocol and thus safeguard the world’s children .
 Born on the very same day, Feb., 1809, these two icons, one of emancipation and the other of evolution, continue to stir us in the 21st century and remain contemporary .
 "If anything, they are more alive for us now than they were at the moment of their centenary," says David Cameron . "They are still alive now," he says of the centenary .
 A hundred years ago, with civil rights unaccomplished and genetics not yet in place to explain the mechanisms of inheritance, Lincoln was perceived by many as a pious but impotent figure, and Darwinism was a speculative road, largely not taken .
 Barack Obama cites and echoes Lincoln in most of his speeches and many of his actions . Arguments over Lincoln's faith, acts, and attitudes continue to raise temperatures and feelings .
 There is even more dispute about Darwin and his legacy—attempts to use Darwinism to understand not only biology but also art and literature . Counterattacks from the religious-minded arraign Darwin for killing God and favouring eugenics .
 He still lends his name to the tradition that he engendered . Alone among the great scientists, he still lends name to his name .
 Different controversies surrounded both men throughout the bicentennial year . Both men were involved in controversies throughout the year .
 With Lincoln, the most vivid arguments turned on that ‘piety’ and the politics that it produced . Lincoln's "piety" and "politicism" were key to Lincoln's success, says historian John Sutter .
 The Biography of a Writer helps to make the case for Lincoln’s essential ‘literary’ qualities . Lincoln's essential "literary" qualities are evident in the book, which is published in New York .
 Harvard professor Henry Louis Gates, Jr., Jr. wrote a searching book, Lincoln on Race and Slavery . Gates hosted an equally searching public television documentary, Looking for Lincoln .
 Gates: Lincoln's antislavery views were courageous for their time . Gates says Lincoln's views were consistent with a clear vision of equality . He says Lincoln was courageous for his time .

 Others tried to argue, on the whole, that Lincoln was really just a politiciah . Others argued that eloquence and politics are alien to each other .
 To segregate Lincoln’s work as a word maker from his work as politician is historically absurd . In any case, it's historically absurd. Lincoln's word maker is a word-maker, not a politician .
 Lincoln became a plausible candidate for president because of his reputation as an orator . Lincoln's political life and his writing life were one. Lincoln's writing life and political life was one .
 evolutionary theory was part of his abolitionist heritage . The story of life, from first microbe to finished man, is one, he says .
 Darwin rejected those first stirrings of social Darwinism, emphasizing instead the role of culture in fostering humane progress . Darwin, courteous by nature, gave a respectful hearing to his cousin Francis Daltons eugenicist ideas .
 Darwin was certainly a ""Europeanist," who believed that the liberal culture of his time was better than tribal culture . Darwin thought that differences were the result of an increase in the spread of social sympathy rather than something inborn or natural only to one race .
 Darwin and Lincoln emerged from their bicentennial trials as men of their time with the marks of their own time . Darwin emerged as men who, on the whole, grew in moral understanding as they aged and came to embrace Abraham Lincoln's ideas .
 Although the polemics about them are important different, the two men are still worth taking together .
 It is not a simple parallel in life but a common liberal temperament, a modem turn of mind, that melds them together . It is (as I meditated at length in my own long essay Angels and Ages) Not a simple parallels in life in life .
 There was not some kind of secret magic connecting these two very disparate figures but rather a field of new feelings and voices that connected many of the liberal voices of the day, including John Stuart Mill, Ralph Waldo Emerson, and William James .
 One might propose three common elements that gave this temperament a shape . The temperament of this temperament is one of the key elements to the personality of this personality .
 First, they shared a taste for argument from below, rather than insistence from above . First, the pair had a taste of argument from within, not above .
 Darwin and Lincoln both began their great works not with grand principle and moral exhortation, but with simple evocations of homely evidence . Darwin began his great works with simple evidence, not grand principle . Lincoln's great works began with evocation of evidence, rather than principle .
 Darwin had begun his epoch-making Origin of Species not with the ""cosmic question” that he would solve but with an almost absurdly homely description of the breeding of dogs and pigeons . Darwin had written about the breeding and breeding of pigeons and dogs .
 Darwin's argument is more than an analogy—his point is similar to Newton’s contention that a boy throwing a ball and the motions of the planets follow the same rules, even if one is volitional and one is not . Darwin's arguments are similar to that of Newton�
 Lincoln and Darwin practiced the habit, at times exasperating to admirers, of sympathetic summary . Darwin and Lincoln were both famous for their sympathetic summary of their lives .
 The ability to enter into an opponent’s argument without contempt or sarcastic bitterness was common to them both . Both men were able to enter in to an argument without being sarcastic or contempt .
 Darwin did not merely articulate his opponents’ arguments against evolution . He anticipated them and refuted them in advance . Darwin anticipated his opponents' arguments, he refuted them .
 This is not merely instrumental, or a sign of softness, but it is part of the liberal inheritance . Lincoln went to war; Darwin annihilated a thousand years of biblical literalism . Darwin . The liberal inheritance is not just instrumental or soft; it's part of a liberal inheritance
 Charles Darwin and Charles Darwin shared a tragic sense of life that did not paralyze their capacity for moral action . Darwin and Darwin were both men who died in a tragic accident . Darwin died at the hands of a young boy in his native New Zealand .
 Both men rejected organized religion and searched for some other way to understand the presence of pain and suffering in the world . They sought some other model—for Lincoln, a kind of providentialism; for Darwin, a stoical resignation .
 Darwin and Lincoln helped to set the stage for the bicentennial, says historian John Sutter . Sutter: The real event was to see how Darwin, Lincoln helped set them .
 Darwin and Lincoln persist as central figures of liberal civilization . In the politics of the newly inaugurated President Obama and in the efflorescence of evolutionary arguments, evolutionary arguments persist . Science progress and democratic politics are deeply and permanently intertwined .

 The U.S. military fields at least 7,000 robots, which are either remotely guided by a human using a radio link or self-guided by preprogrammed flight plans . The United States military has at least seven,000 of these machines .
 More than 60 manufacturers in at least 40 countries are now servicing a market that is expected to exceed tens of billions of dollars over the next decade . The market is set to grow in the coming decade .
 Quentin Davies predicted in July 2009 that the world is now witnessing the last generation of manned combat aircraft and that by 2030 UAVs will have displaced them . The U.K.’s minister for defense equipment and support, Quentin Davies, the U.S. defense minister for
 UAVs, also called remotely piloted vehicles or unmanned aircraft systems, are aircraft without a pilot onboard . They are also known as remote piloted aircraft systems .
 Fixedwing UAVs resemble “smart weapons"" such as cruise missiles, but they are superior because they return to their base after a mission and can be reused . Fixedwings are superior to cruise missiles because they can return to a base after missions and return to them .
 The current generation of UAVs varies in size from small propeller-driven handlaunched models to jet-powered intercontinental-range craft such as the UQ-4 Global Hawk .
 Prices range from a few hundred thousand dollars for small models to well over $100 million for a Global Hawk .
 UAVs first took to the skies during World War II with radio-controlled target drones . They continued to develop through the Vietnam era when film cameras were mounted onto jet-powered drones for photoreconnaissance missions .
 modem UAVs began to appear over battlefields in the 1980s . Technical advancements made them much more effective in the '80s .
 Advanced composite materials made for lighter, stronger airframes, and improved electronics permitted the development of high-resolution TV and infrared cameras . The composite materials also allowed for lighter airframes and more powerful cameras .
 Full implementation of the Global Positioning System in the 1990s made it possible to navigate UAVs with precision that was previously unattainable . Also, full implementation of global positioning system in the 90s made navigation precision impossible .
 UAVs began to garner media attention during NATO’s intervention in the Yugoslav civil war of the 1990s . NATO intervened in the conflict in Yugoslavia in the early 1980s .
 In 1995 the U.S. Air Force put the RQ-1 Predator into service for airborne surveillance and target acquisition . The Predator was put into service by the Air Force in 1995 .
 Predators flying over Yugoslavia tracked troop movements, monitored refugees, marked targets so that manned aircraft could attack them with laserguided bombs . Predators flew over Yugoslavia, tracking troop movements and monitored refugees .
 The Predator remains the most widely used battlefield UAV operated by the U.S. UAVs. The Predator is the most commonly used UAV to operate in the United States.
 The entire system consists of the vehicle itself (with built-in radar, TV and infrared cameras, and laser designator), a ground-control station, and a communication suite to link the two by satellite .
 Though pilotless, the Predator is operated by approximately 55 personnel, including a pilot operator and a sensor operator .
 The current version, designated the MQ-1, went into service in 2001 armed with two laser-guided AGM-114 Hellfire missiles . The UAV can attack targets as well as identify them .
 The first time a Predator made a confirmed kill was in Yemen in 2002, when one operated by the CIA destroyed a vehicle carrying six members of al Qaeda .
 A turboprop-powered version of the Predator, called the MQ-9 Reaper, is significantly larger and has a greater payload . The Reaper is a larger, more capable of carrying out a larger payload .
 Reaper has been operational since 2007 with U.S. forces and is also used by Britain’s Royal Air Force . Reaper is operational with United States forces and also with Britain's Royal air force .
 Since UAVs are not yet completely autonomous, their operators must display great skill in judging distance and speed when landing, a task made more difficult by a slight delay in signal transmission between the UAV and the ground-control station .
 A Reaper on a combat mission over Afghanistan could no longer be controlled and had to be shot down by U.S. warplanes . There are occasional technical glitches, such as the one that occurred in September 2009 .
 Successful attacks by UAVs depend upon accuracy and timeliness of intelligence . Successful UAV attacks depend upon the accuracy and timing of intelligence, say experts .
 An al-Qaeda military planner was believed to have been killed by an American UAV in September but suddenly appeared in a media interview in October . This principle was demonstrated in 2009 when an al Qaeda military planner appeared in an interview with a media outlet .
 High-tech weapons may win engagements on the battlefield, but they cannot solve political problems . Also, high-tech gadgets may win battles but they may aggravate political problems, CNN's John Sutter says .
 For every militant killed by a UAV in Afghanistan and Pakistan, approximately 10 civilians were also killed, Brookings Institution think tank says . Brookings Institution: For every UAV killed a militant in Afghanistan or Pakistan, about 10 civilians also died .
 Human Rights Watch: Israeli UAVs unlawfully killed at least 29 Palestinian civilians during Gaza incursion in late 2008 and early 2009 . UAV operators allegedly failed to verify that targets were combatants .
 Most UAVs remain dedicated to what the military calls ISTAR—intelligence, surveillance, target acquisition, and reconnaissance . Most of them are dedicated to intelligence, surveillance and target acquisition .
 American UAVs began patrolling off the coast of Somalia in October 2009 in order to provide early warning of pirate vessels approaching merchant ships and to guide naval forces .
 The U.S. Marine Corps awarded contracts to Boeing and a joint venture between Lockheed Martin and Kaman to develop cargo UAVs that would be capable of delivering supplies to troops on the battlefield .
 The goal is to demonstrate how such UAVs could reduce risk and expense in logistics . The goal of the project is to reduce risk in logistics by reducing the cost of logistics .
 Currently it is expensive to operate ground supply convoys on the poor roads and in the back country of Afghanistan . Also, convoys must be heavily guarded, and they continually run risks from roadside bombs and ambushes .
 UAV technology is attracting interest from police forces and other civilian agencies . Besides these military uses, the technology has also attracted interest from other agencies .
 U.S. Customs and Border Patrol has been using the Predator to patrol the MexicoUnited States border since 2005 . Two maritime-patrol variants are scheduled to be operational in 2010 . The Predator has been used in the United States border patrol since early 2009 .
 UAVs are also being developed for use in search-and-rescue operations to help locate survivors and deliver emergency supplies to them . The technology is being developed to help in search and rescue operations .
 UAVs are being evaluated for their potential in assessing damage suffered from disasters such as hurricanes, forest fires, and maritime oil spills .
 As robotic vehicles become more commonplace, UAVs can be expected to be used wherever possible to minimize threats to personnel and to do tasks that exceed human strength .
 If current trends continue, UAVs could one day evacuate casualties from the heat of battle and mount round-theclock surveillance missions for months and maybe even years at a time .
 The pilot and sensor operator of the MQ-1 Predator unmanned aerial vehicle perform function checks at Balad Air Base, Iraq, before handing control of the vehicle to personnel stationed in the United States .

 2009 may come to be seen as a year in which the movement toward electric cars gained momentum . 2009 may be the year that electric vehicles gained momentum in the United States .
 "This sudden gathering of energy actually brought together a number of forces that had begun independently the previous year," says CNN.com's John Defterios .

 Gasoline prices threaten to make sport-utility vehicles and pickup trucks less economically viable for U.S. consumers . Fuel prices have led to a drop in sales of pickup trucks and sport utilities .
 Second was the severe recession that gripped the U.S. and then the rest of the world in 2008 and 2009 . Sales of new automobiles were at their lowest levels in half a century in sales .
 Third was a growing international awareness of the challenges posed by climate change, which led policymakers to seek ways to reduce carbon emissions such as those produced in automobile exhaust .
 The electric car movement has been given a lift by improvements in technology and by government commitments to help develop the infrastructure needed to support electric vehicles .

 Electric motors did not have to be started manually; they were quieter than gasoline engines; and they provided a smoother ride because there were no gears to shift .  The long-awaited results of a monumental effort to reconstruct the skeletal biology, paleoecology, and evolutionary position of Ardipithecus ramidus were published at last in the Oct., 2009, issue of the journal Science .
 The issue featured 11 research articles written by an international team of 47 authors and a number of related stories and online materials . The issue was published in the March issue of the International Economic Journal .
 Over the next year 16 additional specimens were found, including a number of teeth, a mandibular fragment, and parts of four cranial bones, and four arm bones .
 When information about these 4.4-million-year-old hominins was published in 1994, they were considered a new species of Australopithecus . They were more morphologically primitive than the other members of this genus .
 Remains of a spectacular partial skeleton were unearthed at Aramis in November 1994 . The novelty of this new material required a change in generic status from Australopithecus to Ardipithecus .
 It took three entire field seasons of surface crawling to locate and subsequently extract the pieces of Ardi’s skeleton . It took 14 pelvis and 10 cranial reconstructions before the authors were satisfied with the accuracy of their models .
 White, co-director of the Middle Awash Project, had been collecting fossils in this region since 1981 . The project included 70 scientists from 18 countries, including 70 scientists .
 Remains of eight different hominin species spanning almost six million years of evolution were uncovered at the site . Remains were found in the site of the remains of 8 different species of hominoids .
 The A ramidus fossils at Aramis were very securely dated because they occurred between two key layers of volcanic tuff . The fossils were found in the region of Aramis . They were discovered in a crater on the site of a volcano .
 A ramidus represents a lessspecialized grade of hominin organization than the fully bipedal australopithecines . The ramids are a less specialized grade of . hominine organization .
 Ardi walked bipedally when on the ground, although she retained an apelike opposable big toe and also climbed trees . For instance, Ardi’s mosaic-like foot skeleton suggests she walked bipedsally . Ardi also used to climb trees and had an
 In arboreal settings she operated as a monkeylike quadruped while moving on the top of branches and bridging between branches . She operated like a monkey like quadruped .
 Her pelvis structure combined typical features of both hominins and apes . She was found to be a hominin in the form of a chimpanzee .
 A comparison of dentitions from human, Ardipithecus ramidus and chimpanzee all males . Mattermes—Science/AAAS/Reuters/Landov .
 A large very flexible midcarpal joint permitted her to support nearly all of her 50-kg body weight on her palms when clambering along tree branches . She supported nearly all her body weight when she clambered on tree branches using her palms .
 An important evolutionary implication of Ardi’s postcranial material was that the hypothetical common ancestor of humans and chimpanzees was not morphologically or behaviorally similar to modern African apes, as was once envisioned .
 Experts now believe that it was more probably a palmigrade quadrupedal climber that may have resembled some Miocene apes and the earliest hominins in its locomotor adaptations .
 The comparative analysis of Ardipithecus necessitated a complete paradigm shift . The study was conducted by the author of the book, "Ardipithec"

 A baby orangutan laughs in response to a researcher’s tickling, providing evidence that laughter emerged in animals millions of years before humans evolved .
 A number of investigations of nonhuman primates, however, connected these six topics in 2009 . In 2009, a number of probes of non-human primates were connected to the topics .
 Researchers worldwide surveyed the behaviours of nonhuman primates by analyzing the responses of great apes that were tickled . They also monitored the public tantrums of young rhesus macaques and the abilities of long-tailed macaques .
 The origins of human laughter could be traced 10 million to 16 million years ago to the last common ancestor of humans and apes . The researchers also concluded that laughter is a cross-species phenomenon .
 The great apes are not the only nonhuman primates with humanlike displays of expression . They are not only apes, but other non-human primates .
 Infant rhesus macaques were found to be expressive too, especially when they did not get what they wanted . Infants are expressive when they are not getting what they want, researchers found .
 Their mothers were found to be twice as likely to give in to their offspring when the tantrum occurred in the presence of potentially threatening animals .
 This study was considered the first to demonstrate how bystanders could affect the communication between the mother macaque and infant .
 Researchers found that orangutans use unique maneuvers to overcome the safety risks associated with accessing food and crossing gaps in tree crowns . Researchers say the largest habitually arboreal mammal in the world uses these maneuvers .
 The orangutans’ irregular movements include shifting from side to side and using all four limbs at once . The irregular movements cause a minimal disturbance to the trees and facilitate their motion .
 Because orangutans remain on the verge of extinction, it is critical that scientists understand their needs, their movement limitations, and their ability to overcome the environmental challenges posed by humans .
 Such knowledge could form the basis for animal and environmental conservation programs, experts say .

 One zoo became well known for the behavioral study of a bad-tempered primate resident in 2009 . The study was conducted at a zoo in New York City .
 Santino repeatedly gathered stones and concrete chips from his home at the Furuvik Zoo . Santino, an adult male chimpanzee, stockpiled them in scattered areas throughout his habitat .
 Zoo's animal-care staff has removed hundreds of weapon caches . Santino has been accumulating his arsenal for more than 10 years .
 Santino collected objects while he was calm; however, he threw them at zoo visitors a number of hours later during his agitated dominance displays . Santino was observed to collect the objects while his calm state was calm .
 Santino's behaviour indicated that Santino was spontaneously planning for a future mental state . This suggests that chimpanzees have highly developed consciousness, a characteristic many scientists have been reluctant to attribute to nonhuman primates . Santino is a chimpanzee with a history of planning for future mental states .
