 Sakura preferred consonant, or harmonious, sounds to dissonant, sounds . She prefers consonant sounds to discordant sounds . Sakura could indeed appreciate music .
 Sakura consistently preferred to produce consonant music for a longer period of time than dissonant music . During six weekly sessions, Sakura consistently produced consonant songs .
 Study of primates published in 2009 revealed evidence that some monkeys and apes discerned right from wrong . Other studies of primates have found evidence that chimpanzees negotiated with troopmates and constructed mental maps based on geometric coordinates .
 Research with nonhuman primates would continue to provide a portal through which humans might better know and understand themselves . Humans might not be as unique as they once thought, researchers say .
 Young boy in small Gulf-coast town of La Gloria, Veracruz, fell ill with an influenza-like disease of unknown cause . Doctors at the Mexico City Navy Hospital wear protective gear .
 Within weeks nearly 30% of the town’s residents had been affected by a similar sickness . Within weeks people in nearby villages had fallen ill as well .
 The young boy was the only individual from the region to test positive for a new strain of influenza virus . The new strain was named swine influenza, or swine flu, because it contained genetic material from existing swine virus viruses .
 By mid-March a sickness resembling the one from La Gloria had emerged in Mexico City . Not long after, cases of the respiratory illness were reported throughout the country .
 Health officials send more than 50 patient samples to a lab in Canada for analysis . After several infected persons died, the country’s health officials decided to send over 50 samples to the lab .
 The World Health Organization convened an emergency meeting to assess the situation . 16 of the 16 people who tested positive for swine flu turned up positive for the virus .
 The newly identified virus, deemed to have significant pandemic potential (the ability to spread easily over a wide geographic area) owing to the lack of preexisting immunity in humans, appeared in the U.S. in mid-April . The virus is deemed to be a significant pand
 It subsequently spread to Canada and the United Kingdom, to Europe, and to New Zealand .
 Hong Kong flu claimed the lives of more than 750,000 people globally in 1968 . It was the first pandemic to occur since 1968, when more than 700,000 died worldwide .
 The rapid spread of the virus generated significant fear among the public . The majority of individuals who became infected with swine flu experienced only mild symptoms of fever, cough, and runny nose .
 The swine influenza virus at the root of the 2009 pandemic was a newly identified strain of influenza A subtype H1N1 .
 Influenza A viruses are the primary cause of seasonal influenza in humans . They are constantly evolving, and they are the main source of seasonal flu season .
 One mechanism of evolution is viral reassortment, when multiple strains of influenza viruses infect a single host and recombine to give rise to a new strain . Virus reassortment is a form of evolution that occurs when a single virus infects a host .
 Genetic material from humans, birds, and pigs mixed and recombined in a pig host, giving rise to a triple reassortant virus . In the case of the 2009 swine flu virus, genetic material from three organisms—humans, birds and pigs—mixed and . recombined
 Swine flu also was subject to constant evolution through antigenic drift as it circulated between the Northern and Southern hemispheres . Similar to all other influenza viruses, swine flu is subject to continuous evolution .
 As swine flu crossed the globe, strains carrying mutations for drug resistance emerged . The first strain appeared in Denmark in June and demonstrated resistance to Tamiflu .
 Scientists immediately began to search for ways to overcome resistant strains of strains . Scientists are now trying to find new ways to combat resistant strains .
 In laboratory studies, combinations of existing antiviral agents proved promising . Combination of existing anti-viral agents has been shown to be effective .
 The genetic constitution of the reassortant virus rendered it more contagious than typical seasonal influenza . It was transmitted in typical flu fashion—via infectious droplets expelled into the air from infected persons when sneezing or coughing .
 The virus could survive on hard surfaces for 24 hours, providing ample opportunity to spread to another person . It could also spread to other people within 24 hours of exposure .
 The thermal imaging system was used to screen passengers for swine flu under age 5 . Under age 5, persons suffering from chronic illness or with suppressed immunity were screened .
 The name initially given to the virus, “swine influenza,” was fitting in several respects . The virus not only contained genetic segments from two different swine influenza viruses but also appeared to have originated on a pig farm near La Gloria .
 The farm belonged to Granjas Carroll de Mexico, a joint venture operation working in partnership with U.S.-owned Smithfield Foods, Inc. It is a major international producer of pork .
 Countries such as China, Thailand, and Russia temporarily arrested the import of pigs from affected areas . Countries like Thailand, China, Russia and China temporarily suspended pigs imports .
 Egyptian Minister of Health Hatem al-Gabali ordered the slaughter of up to 400,000 of the country’s pigs . There was no evidence that they were infected with the virus .
 The mandate sparked riots and protests from Egyptian farmers who depended on raising and selling pigs as a source of income . The mandate instantly sparked protests and protests .
 WHO changed the name of the virus to influenza Ain late April in an effort to dispel confusion . The virus is now known as influenza .
 When the influenza A virus was discovered in Mexico, it was not considered of international concern . When the flu virus was found in Mexico it was considered not a problem .
 WHO acknowledged that global dispersion was imminent and issued a level 5 pandemic alert . As the disease spread across Mexico City, into the United States and Canada, and overseas to Spain, the United Kingdom, and the Middle East, WHO said it was a pandemic .
 The alert served as a signal to national health agencies to finalize plans for the implementation of control measures . Measures include limiting travel to and from affected regions and distributing face masks to limit disease spread .
 When the pandemic was declared in June, cases had climbed to nearly 30,000 worldwide . The virus had spread to many regions of the world, including Southeast Asia, Scandinavia, the West Indies, and Central America .
 By early September, with the exception of several places, including Greenland, Mongolia, and some areas of Africa, swine flu was established in all parts of the world . The exception was Greenland, Mongolian and some parts of Africa .
 In late December some 622,480 cases and 12,220 deaths were confirmed globally . In late December there were more than 12,000 confirmed cases of HIV-AIDS .
 Not all cases and fatalities could be tracked, however, the actual figures were believed to be far greater . Because not all cases were tracked, it is believed to have been far greater.
 Studies of past pandemics show outbreaks occur in waves, or alternating periods of high and low disease activity in the same region . Each ""wave” represents a period of increased activity, with each ""wave" representing a period .
 In the summer of 2009 in North America, swine flu cases dropped off significantly . In the post peak period of 2009 activity during the summer, 2009, cases of illness dropped significantly .
 WHO issued a warning in late August to prepare for a second pandemic wave . Evidence of that began to emerge in the first week of September in the U.S. Some isolated areas experienced sudden spikes in influenza A activity .
 When the pandemic potential of the virus was first realized in April, scientists set to work on vaccine development .
 In July, just four months after the isolation of the new virus, the first swine flu vaccine for humans entered clinical testing . The vaccine is the first to enter clinical testing for humans .
 The vaccine, however, required two shots, administered three weeks apart, which raised concerns that there was not enough time for full immunity to be established . Vaccine supplies would run out before a second wave hit .
 Just days later, single-dose vaccines emerged, and meeting global vaccine demand appeared feasible once again . Just days before, however, single dose vaccines emerged . Single dose vaccines appeared to be feasible again .
 A singledose vaccine developed by Sinovac Biotech Ltd., a Chinese company, was approved in China in early September . Similar vaccines developed by other pharmaceutical companies worldwide became available shortly thereafter .
 As summer turned to fall in North America, a second pandemic wave, equal to or greater in severity, seemed certain . As summer turns to fall, North America seemed like a second wave of disease was certain .
 U.S. health officials remain confident that the virus could be contained . Despite this, United States health officials remained optimistic .
 The generation of single-dose vaccines, WHO’s effective surveillance program, and existing global mitigation and control measures, were repeatedly strengthened and reevaluated throughout the pandemic .
 Kara Rogers is the Senior Editor of Biomedical Sciences for Encyclopaedia Britannica . She is also a Senior Editor at the Encyclopaedic Britannica.
 Autism is a spectrum condition with varying degrees of severity . Autism is manifested to varying levels of severity and is manifested in various ways .
 At one extreme, a person may have no social skills, no language skills, and major learning difficulties . At another extreme, people may have major social skills and major difficulties .
 Those living with either condition share a strong preference for routines and repetition . They are characterized by an obsessional interest in highly specific topics . Both subgroups are subgroups on the autistic spectrum .
 In the late 1990s the prevalence of autism spectrum conditions was found to have increased substantially relative to previous decades . Data published in 2009 revealed that number of children diagnosed with these conditions was continuing to follow this same trend .
 The study assessed the prevalence of these conditions in eight-year-olds . This represented the age by which most affected U.S. children had been placed under specialist’s care .
 The number of people diagnosed with autism spectrum conditions has increased in the UK in recent years . This figure is representative of an increase in the number of persons diagnosed with autistic conditions .
 It remained unclear whether such increases were due to the conditions’ becoming more widespread or to improved diagnostic procedures used to detect them .
 Information on the incidence of autism spectrum disorders in other countries remained controversial . Information on autism spectrum disorder remains controversial .
 Study published early in 2009 in the Israel Medical Association Journal addressed the incidence of autism spectrum disorders in that country .
 These figures were assessed in terms of the total number of children under age 18 who lived in the country during the time period investigated . The figures were further assessed in . terms of . children under . age 18 .
 Per capita prevalence of autism spectrum disorders in Israel in 2004 was estimated to have been 1.1 per 10,000 children .
 in Israel between 2001 and 2004, the prevalence of autism spectrum disorders was about 36 per 10,000 . This means the incidence of the conditions in the country is closer to estimates of worldwide incidence reported in a study published in 2006 in the journal Lancet .
 Atypical behaviour is a characteristic of people affected by autism spectrum conditions . Autism spectrum conditions are often associated with atypical behavioural patterns .
 Such behaviour has been associated with empathy and systemizing . Such behaviour is associated with two primary psychological aspects, empathy .
 Empathy involves imagining another persons thoughts and feelings and having an appropriate emotional reaction to those feelings . Empathy is a form of empathy that involves imagining a person's thoughts, feelings and responding to them .
 Children and adults with Asperger syndrome show their empathizing difficulties on tests of emotion recognition, theory of mind, and spontaneous empathy .
 Theory of mind is the ability to attribute mental states to oneself or others . It is regarded as the cognitive component of empathy . Theory of Mind is a form of empathy that can be attributed to others .
 Emotion recognition is sometimes regarded as part of theory of mind because emotions are mental states . Emotions are a mental state . Emotional recognition is a form of recognition of a state of mind . Emissions of emotion recognition can be attributed to emotion recognition .
 Often emotion-recognition deficits appear only if complex emotions are tested . In some individuals with autism, the deficit is evident even when basic emotions are examined .
 This deficit can explain the difficulties in social and communicative development and in imagining others’ minds . It can also explain difficulties in the social and social development of children .
 Systemizing is the drive to analyze a system in terms of underlying rules in order to understand and predict its behaviour . Systemizing aims to analyze and predict the behaviour of a system .
 The repetitive behaviour, the desire for routines, and the need for sameness can be interpreted as being the result of a strong drive to systemize . The repetitive behaviours can be seen as a strong desire for routine routines .
 Individuals with autism or Asperger syndrome are relatively fast on tests of attention to detail . Systemizing also requires excellent attention to . Attention to detail also requires .
 Adept systemizing can explain the exceptional mental abilities possessed by some persons affected by these conditions . Adept systemsizing can often explain some of the mental abilities of some people affected by such conditions .
 Anatomical abnormalities have been identified in different brain regions in individuals with autism . Anomalistic abnormalities were identified in the brain regions of autistic individuals .
 These abnormalities are not found in every case, and there are inconsistencies between studies . Sometimes overgrowth or underdevelopment is found in some cases .
 Brain regions that have been reported to be atypical include the cerebellum, corpus callosum, the hippocampus, and the amygdala .
 Epilepsy also occurs in a proportion of individuals with autism spectrum conditions, though the exact rate is not clear . Epileps is a form of epilepsy that occurs in people with autism .
 In classic autism one-third of cases develop epilepsy by adolescence . In Asperger subgroup these rates may be much lower and have not been systematically studied .
 The number of Purkinje cells (large neurons with many branching extensions) in the cerebellar cortex in people with autism is abnormally low . In terms of neuropathology, this is an abnormality low .
 Abnormalities have also been reported in the density of neurons in the hippocampus, the amygdala, and other parts of the limbic system .
 One report also suggested a reduction in the size of cortical minicolumns . The significance of this is unclear .
 Functional neuroimaging studies of autism spectrum conditions show abnormalities in the amygdala and in the orbitofrontal and medial prefrontal cortex, among other areas . Autism spectrum conditions .
 These atypical patterns of neural activity occur in relation to the empathizing deficits . These patterns of activity occur when people empathize with others .
 By age two to four, MRI-based brain volumes are larger than average, study finds . 90% of children diagnosed with autism have larger brain volumes than the average .
 The sibling risk rate for autism has been estimated to be about 5 to 10 times higher than general population rates . In recent years the sibling risk rates have been higher .
 60% of MZ pairs were found to be concordant for autism, meaning that both twins were affected . 60% were concordated for autism - meaning both twins affected .
 Genetic linkage studies have led to the implication of a number of chromosomal regions in autism . Autism has been linked to a range of genetic predispositional factors .
 X chromosome abnormalities have been identified in association with autism, which may explain the sex ratios being markedly biased toward males . In addition, abnormalities affecting the X chromosome have been linked to autism .
 Studies have indicated that levels of fetal testosterone are associated with the number of autistic traits present in an individual . For example, studies have shown that fetal testosterone is associated with autism .
 The hormone also is positively correlated with the emergence of narrow interests, systemizing, and autistic traits . Hormone is also linked to autism, narrow interests and systemizing .
 The higher the levels of the hormone during fetal development, the more likely these features are to appear in early childhood . Thus, the higher the . levels of . fetal development hormone during . fetal . development, more likely to occur in early . childhood .
 The earliest that classic autism has been reliably diagnosed is 18 months of age . Classic autism is a form of autism that can only be diagnosed at 18 months old .
 The Checklist for Autism in Toddlers tests for the absence of ‘joint attention behaviours’ such as pointing and gaze following . This was shown by a screening approach known as the Checklist .
 Children who failed on the CHAT test had an 83.3% chance of developing autism or a related developmental disorder . CHAT was developed by the U.K.-based Autism Research Centre . Children who fail on the test have an 83%.
 The approach, however, has a low level of sensitivity— it detected only two out of every five cases, mostly missing the Asperger subgroup . The approach has been used to detect only two or five cases of autism .
 Autistic children gather around a computer to watch a Lego movie made with Lego toys . Asperger syndrome was found to be a problem for autistic children .
 The most effective interventions for children on the autistic spectrum are special education, such as social skills teaching, and applied behaviour analysis . Special education teaches appropriate skills and behaviours through principles of reinforcement .
 The key ingredients for effective early intervention are that the methods are highly structured, intensive, and individualized . The methods must be highly structured and intensive, according to experts .
 There are ethical issues surrounding the notion of trying to cure autism . Indeed, there are ethical questions surrounding the idea of doing so .
 For many years ‘treatment’ in autism proceeded on the basis of an approach that was tried and tested but without any real rationale for why it should be effective . ‘Treatment’ should be based on an approach to autism that has been tried, tested and tested,
 The principles behind it enable target skills to be broken down into simpler units to be acquired through shaping and mass practice .
 While there is some evidence for the effectiveness of ABA, the methods require external reinforcers or rewards to maintain the child's attention and cooperation . The methods are not as autism-friendly as they could be .
 New interventions have been designed to harness individuals’ areas of strength and their natural interests as a means for building new skills .
 Mind Reading DVD educational software uses the natural interest in lawful, predictable computers and in information's being systematically organized . The domain of emotions is easier to learn about than the domain of emotion .
 A second example is The Transporters DVD animation, which relies on the child’s natural interest in the mechanical, predictable motion of vehicles to help the child attend to the film and to enable implicit learning of emotions .
 A final example is Lego therapy, which exploits the child’s strong interest in systems, to encourage turn taking and social communication . Lego therapy is also a form of therapy to encourage children to take part in systems systems .
 All treatments that are claimed to be useful for children or adults with autism spectrum conditions should be subjected to a scientific evaluation . All treatments should be subject to an evaluation by experts .
 This is to confirm that there are indeed benefits relative to no intervention and that there is no unwanted side effects . This is a confirmation of the benefits of no intervention . The study was carried out to confirm there were indeed benefits .
 Web sites have been developed to help parents and professionals make informed decisions about which treatment option to pursue, given that these are often expensive and that new methods are announced almost annually . Web sites help parents as well as professionals decide which treatment options to pursue .
 Teenagers and adults with Asperger syndrome often suffer from additional mental health problems . The most common is depression .
 The high levels of depression are not surprising if people with Asperger syndrome feel that they do not fit into society and feel rejected by the majority . The high rates of depression is not surprising, say experts .
 For teenagers this may be because the peer group becomes less tolerant of those who do not fit in . Failure to conform in the educational system can also mean underperforming academically . For teenagers, a failure to conform means they are less likely to perform well .
 Such depression may therefore be secondary to the condition and may be preventable with appropriate support . Such depression is secondary to a condition such as depression .
 Such support for teenagers may include special education, a buddy system, social skills training, and organized social groups .
 Support in adulthood may include sheltered employment, mentoring, advocacy, befriending, social groups for Asperger syndrome, and help with housing . Support may also include social groups, sheltered employment and advocacy .
 Autism spectrum conditions are not a disease or disorder but simply an atypical form of neurological development, akin to left-handedness . This is in part intended to convey that one view of autism spectrum conditions is that they are not disease or a disorder .
 Those whose brains develop and work differently need not be judged to be inferior to the majority . This view is less stigmatizing and makes an important political point, says David Frum .
 This view is called the neurodiversity movement . It resembles the civil rights movement that was necessary to gain equal opportunities for ethnic minorities and women . This view resembles the same movement that helped minorities gain equal opportunity .
 The diagnosis is given only if the individual is suffering to some extent, with their autistic traits leading to significant interference in their everyday life . It is important that the disability element is not overlooked in this shift of emphasis .
 This diagnostic criterion is important as a yardstick of severity, since if the features of the condition are very mild, they may not require a diagnosis . The criteria is important to determine the severity of a condition .
 This relates back to the notion of an autistic spectrum, a dimension of autistic traits that runs right through the population . This relates to the idea of an autism spectrum, the author says . Autistic traits that run right through people's lives, he says .
 The current view is that all humans lie somewhere on this spec. trum and that it is only those who are at the extreme end . Those who are experiencing difficulties as a result of their high number of autistic traits will require a diagnosis .
 Not all doctors share this view of autism spectrum conditions’ simply being a case of neurodiversity . Autism spectrum conditions are simply being seen as neurodiverse .
 The American Psychiatric Association retains the term autism spectrum disorder . This group of conditions includes pervasive developmental disorders, which involve varying degrees of impairment .
 Individuals on the autistic spectrum who also have below-average IQs are likely to need special support throughout their lives . Those individuals on the autism spectrum are at risk of broader developmental delays .
 The issues and challenges that low IQ raises are in some respects no different from those raised by low IQs in other individuals (who are not on the autistic spectrum) and are probably best served by learning disability agencies .
 Communities for autistic adults create a living environment that caters to the unique needs of these individuals . Cascina Rossago in Italy is one of the most popular communities in the world .
 Developments in the field of physical anthropology during 2009 included news about the reconstruction and analysis of an extraordinarily complete skeleton of a controversial primate .
 The 47-million-year-old adapiform primate, Darwinius masillae, was announced to the world on May 19 via the most extensive public relations multimedia campaign in the history of primate paleontology . Darwiniusmasillae is the oldest known adap
 The specimen was originally unearthed in 1983 near Messel, Ger. , and was cleaved into two parts that were subsequently sold separately . The specimen is believed to have been discovered in 1983 .
 Her well-preserved digestive tract contents indicated a diet of leaves and fruit . She was probably nocturnal, and her diet was likely to be a low-energy source .
 An agile arboreal quadruped, she inhabited a rainforest and died near a volcanic lake . She was an agile, quadruped who lived near a volcano .
 She possessed a mixture of primitive and advanced morphological traits that led to controversial claims about her taxonomic relationships and phylogenetic position within the order Primates . Her taxonomic position within Primates was controversial .
 Darwinius and other adapiforms placed within lemurlike strepsirhines, not among the haplorhines . Darwinius is thought to be among the lemur like strepsirsines . The consensus favoured by most experts not connected to the research team placed Darwin
 Darwinius was a linking form between lemurlike primates and anthropoids, hence an ancestor of humans . The conjecture was considered to be false by many of the worlds leading paleoanthropologists . Darwinius may have been a link form between anthropoids and primates .
 Cross Altar because he had been in charge of this altar when serving as an unordained canon at the cathedral . He had been serving as a canon in the cathedral when he served as an unordained canister .

 No relatives who could provide a DNA reference sample had been identified . Investigators found a clever substitute source for the DNA sample .

 The strands of hair could be used as a reference sample for his skeletal DNA . The DNA was used to confirm the identification of the skeletal remains as his .

 Statistical analysis indicated 14 ancestral clusters present in the African data set . Analysis indicated that 14 ancestral cluster clusters were present .
 Strong associations between geography, language, and genes reflected the concomitant spread of people, languages, and sometimes culture or ethnicity . Strong associations of geography and genes reflect the spread of languages and culture .
 Genetic diversity was generally highest in African populations and declined with increasing distance from Africa consistent with serial founder effects that resulted from global migrations .
 Modern human migration within Africa may have originated near the coastal border of Namibia and Angola, an area that constitutes the current San homeland . The San homeland is located in the area that is now considered the current homeland .
 The Khoisan speakers, the eastern African Khoisanspeaking Hadza and Sandawe, and the central African Pygmies are all remnants of a widespread proto-KhoisanPygmy population of hunter-gatherers .
 Pygmies were originally Khoisan speakers who, in a rare example of complete language replacement, subsequently adopted the nonclick Niger-Congo languages spoken by their neighbours . According to this intriguing scenario, this is an intriguing scenario of a rare case .

 Shards of pottery recovered from a cave in southern China’s Hunan province were dated to 18,000 years ago . They are the oldest-known examples of clay craft in the world .
 They were found in Yuchanyan Cave among sediments rich in animal bone and charcoal fragments, bone and shell tools, and other artifacts .
 The earliest-known evidence for pottery had come from a suite of Chinese sites in Hunan, Jiangxi, and Guangxi provinces, dating to 10,000-16,000 years ago .

 The manuscripts were discovered during a cave-documentation project . They were transported to a local monastery for conservation and Study .
 Cahokia Mounds are the largest and most complex Native American civilization in North America . Cahokia was the largest of the most complex and largest of North America's ancient mounds . In 2009 archaeological research at the Fisher Mounds Site Complex in southern Wisconsin continued to expand knowledge .
 Cahokians apparently brought pots and chert (fine-grained quartz) tools with them, as there was little evidence from excavated features for the use of local lithic materials and clay sources .
 The Mississippian houses, potsherds, and stone tools recovered from these excavations dated to about 1050 CE . Cahokia’s punctuated regional political consolidation coincided with Cahokia's punctuated political consolidation .
 The absence of a palisade wall at the site indicated that the colony enjoyed a relatively peaceful existence . It indicated that it was a relatively quiet existence .
 Archaeologists uncovered large portions of one of the largest Mississippian mound centres in the eastern U.S. mound centres . The mound centre is one of largest in eastern United States .
 Cahokia excavations fundamentally revised archaeological understandings of Cahokia civilization . Archaeological excavations in Cahokia have fundamentally changed Cahokia history .
 St. Louis mound centre witnessed its peak residential occupation while the nearby site of Cahokia was being depopulated . The mound centre was occupied by Cahokia during the early Cahokia period .
 St. Louis sites experienced their highest population densities contemporaneously . This suggests a larger regional population than previously posited .
 Excavations continued at the Topper site near the Savannah River in South Carolina . Excavation continues at the site .
 Topper was once a Paleo-Indian quarry and habitation site where Clovis points were manufactured . Topper is located in Topper, a site where the points were made by Clovas .
 Work at the site in 2009 recovered more detailed information about the Clovis occupation of the site .
 The presence of blades, cores, and flake tools indicated that manufacturing activities beyond the production of bifacial stone tools occurred at Topper .
 Evidence for this claim consisted of various objects argued to be bend-break unifacial tools . Evidence included various objects arguing to be bent-break tools .
 If this claim was proved accurate, it would overturn most current theories for the peopling of the New World .
 Excavations at the Chimney Rock site near Pagosa Springs, Colo., provided important insight into Southwestern prehistory . Chimney rock site is located near the town of Pagosa, Colorado .
 Lekson believed the site to be directly affiliated with Chacoan society and used as a lunar observatory . Lekson believes the site was used as an observatory by Chacoans elites .
 The elites who lived at Chimney Rock enjoyed a diet of deer and elk, while lower-status residents of the site dined on smaller game, the researchers say .
 Among the significant Mesoamerican archaeological discoveries was that of two large stone sculptures in Mexico City by archaeologist Leonardo Lopez Lujan .
 These works provided additional depth to current understandings of Aztec sacrifice and funeral rituals . These works provide additional depth of the Aztec tradition .
 The first sculpture, a 13-ton monolith, was discovered in October 2006 . It was believed to represent Tlaltecuhtli, a female Aztec deity of the earth, known for her nurturing symbolism .
 Stone representations of this goddess often served as platforms for the cremation rituals of deceased kings . Stone representations were often found in stone representations of the goddess . The goddess is believed to be a Hindu goddess of Hinduism .
 Pigment residues identified on the surface of the sculpture indicated that it would have been decorated in black, red, and blue .
 The second sculpture depicted a large cactus believed to have been used as a platform for rituals involving Aztec sacrifice . This interpretation of the sculptures function was based on an Aztec legend that indicates that sacrificial rituals performed atop cacti confer the gods' favour upon the performers .
 Archaeologist Richard Hansen recently discovered two 8-m -long panels carved in stucco from the preClassic Mayan site of El Mirador, Guat. Guat., that depict aspects of the Popol Vuh, the Mayan origin story .
 Popol Vuh features the Hero Twins, Hunahpu and Xbalanque, who were transformed into, respectively, the Sun and the Moon . In explaining how the Mayan gods created the world, the Mayans explain how the world was created .
 One of the panels depicts the Hero Twins beneath a bird deity . The other panel features a Mayan maize god surrounded by a serpent .
 The panels thus authenticated the earliest written version of the Mayan origin story . It was transcribed in the 1700s by Spanish colonial priest Francisco Ximenez .
 Additional findings at the Classic Maya farming village of Ceren, El Sal., continued to provide major insight into ancient subsistence and food production .
 Ceren was discovered by archaeologist Payson Sheets in 1978 . Ceren, like Pompeii, was buried in volcanic ash, was pivotal in providing amazing detail about Mesoamerican lifeways .
 An eruption 1,400 years ago covered the site in 5 m of ash, preserving houses and adjacent agricultural plots . The eruption covered houses and agricultural plots, preserving the site .
 The use of ground-penetrating radar and limited test excavations during the 2007 field season revealed the presence of this agricultural field . The field is located in an agricultural field in southern California .
 Excavations at the site in 2009 revealed the extent of intensive cassava cultivation in the New World, as evidenced in 18 3 x 3-m excavation blocks .
 The cassava plants had long ago decomposed, their presence was revealed in the ash as hollow spaces that, as in Pompeii, were filled with dental plaster to determine shape and size of the object .
 Cassava, a starchy root crop, is rarely preserved archaeologically . Unlike the more common Mesoamerican triad of maize, beans, and squash, the seeds of which have durable structures that can survive charring . Cassava is a starchy root crop that is
 In tropical and temperate regions, macroscopic plants can remain in preserved form only if they have carbonized in fires . Cassava is composed mostly of sugars, which melt away when burned .
 Manioc often was overlooked in the reconstruction of ancient Mesoamerican foodways . As a result, manioc has been overlooked in many of the foodways of the ancient times .
 Analysis of chili pepper DNA by botanists Seung-Chul Kim, Araceli Aguilar-Melendez, and Mikeal Roose revised previous interpretations .
 Chilies, formerly believed to have been domesticated first in central Mexico, were domesticated independently and from several different wild ancestors in Mesoamerica .

 The American auto industry experienced the BANKRUPTCIES of GM and Chrysler, as well as an increased interest in ELECTRIC CARS and gas-electric hybrids . The U.S. auto industry is experiencing an increase in interest in electric cars .
 In other sectors companies SLASHED inventories, costs, and personnel in the hopes of KEEPING AFLOAT until the economy revived .
 The CEOs of the Big Three automakers appeared before Congress in November 2008 to ask for $25 billion . The CEOs hoped that the cash infusion would help them weather the developing economic downturn . But in the first few months of 2009, car sales collapsed .
 In January automakers sold 656,976 cars and light trucks in the U.S., the lowest total since December 1981 . For the first time in history, auto sales in the United States were lower than in China, where 790,000 cars were sold .
 Obama announced $2.2 billion of his economic stimulus package had been awarded to some 48 automakers or parts manufacturers . The effort is an effort to increase production of electric vehicles . Obama: $2 billion will be spent on electric vehicles and parts production .
 Obama administration imposed strict measures on GM in exchange for continued federal aid . The measures included the resignation of GM CEO Rick Wagoner and a comprehensive restructuring plan .
 GM entered Chapter 11 protection on June 1; it emerged about a month later with a new board and the United States government holding a roughly 60% stake in the company . The U.S. government holds roughly 60 per cent of GM's stake .
 The reorganized GM announced plans to shed more than $79 billion in debt, reduce dealer network by 40%, shutter 14 factories, and cut at least 21,000 jobs . GM also said it will reduce dealer networks by 40% and reduce 14 factories .
 GM pulled out of a deal to sell a majority stake in its European operations Opel and Vauxhall in November . In November GM pulled back on a plan to sell the majority stake of Opel in Europe . GM has been criticized for pulling out of the deal .
 The auto task force nearly voted to let Chrysler collapse by not providing additional financing . The task force voted to not provide additional financing for the company . Chrysler is the largest U.S. auto manufacturer in the world .
 Chrysler entered Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on April 30 . President Obama reportedly decided that the loss of as many as 300,000 jobs would be too much for the already-ailing U.S economy .

 Ford had boosted its U.S. market share to 16.1% for the year . By year's end new vehicle sales had improved slightly, and Ford boosted its United States market share . Ford's market share in the United States was 16.2% .
 Ford surprised analysts with a profit of $834 million in the first half of the year and a $1.1 billion profit for the first nine months . Ford had been targeting a return to profitability by 2011 .
 Toyota Motor Corp. was the world's largest automaker in late 2008 . The global recession wreaked havoc on Toyota’s sales as well .
 The company in May 2009 posted its first annual loss in 59 years . The company said that it was also likely to post a loss in its fiscal year ending March 31, 2010 .
 Other Asian automakers, while struggling for sales in the collapsed North America market, found some balance in the burgeoning Indian, Chinese, and Pacific Rim markets .

 Many European carmakers faced the same formula—declines in Europe and North America countered by gains in Asia . Declines in North America and Europe and Asia offset each other's gains .

 Volkswagen AG's third-quarter earnings were driven by strong sales in China and improved demand in Germany . The company was boosted by an equivalent to the U.S. cash-for-clunkers program .
 Porsche had spent a year battling to purchase a majority stake in Volkswagen . Porsche had a 35% share in Volkswagen in 2008 . It could not raise enough funds, owing to the decline in car sales and tightening of the credit markets .
 In October China announced its annual production had exceeded 10 million cars for the first time in history . China is expected to top 12 million cars by year's end .
 Chinese domestic car sales were up 48% year-on-year in the summer . Many analysts said that China was on pace to become the world’s largest car market .
 Ford especially made a push in late 2009 to boost its presence in India by introducing the Figo, a low-cost car to be built in India and sold to other Asian-Pacific markets . Ford also introduced a low cost car in India in 2009 .
 The American airline industry appeared to stabilize in the second half of 2009 . While much of the automobile sector was in tatters, the airline industry seemed to stabilize .
 International Air Transport Association predicted that its members would lose $9 billion in 2009 . The five largest U.S. airlines all posted losses in the second quarter . None of the airlines went under or required federal bailouts .
 The airline industry has seen a decline in jet fuel costs for much of the year . Jet fuel costs have been a boon for the airline industry .
 Southwest Airlines Co. and United Airlines’ parent UAL Corp. report narrower losses in the third quarter than in late 2008 . Southwest Airlines reported narrower losses than in previous quarter . Southwest and UAL reported narrow losses in third quarter .
 Southwest lost $16 million in third-quarter 2009, compared with $120 million in 2008 . Southwest increased its ridership by lowering its fares, which reduced passenger revenue yield by 12% .
 Delta Air Lines Inc. and United States Airways Group Inc. also posted losses in the third quarter . Delta and U.S. Airways Group both posted losses .
 AMR Corp. registered a third-quarter loss of $359 million, compared with a profit of $31 million in 2008 . AMR showed a record-high load factor (the percentage of available seats filled) as of September 30 .
 The low-cost, smallervolume JetBlue Airways Corp. returned to profitability in late 2009 . JetBlue is a small-scale carrier that operates in the U.S.
 International airlines also faced declining ridership and the subsequent need to reduce flights, costs, and staff . International airlines faced falling ridership in the past .
 Ryanair has aggressively pursued a strategy of reducing fares while increasing customer charges . Ryanair charges to customers of roughly $64 to check in at the airport rather than using Ryanair's Web site .
 Ryanair was rebuffed in its attempt to purchase Aer Lingus, which it owned a 29% stake . Ryanair owns 29% of the Irish airline's network . The budget airline was forced to abandon its bid to buy Irish rival Aer Lingum .
 Aer Lingus expected to lay off up to 17% of its staff and impose salary cuts and caps on much of the remainder of its workforce . Meanwhile, the airline is expected to impose salary caps and salary cuts .
 Deutsche Lufthansa AG slumped by 19% in the quarter ended June 30 . Its purchase of the ailing Austrian Airlines was approved by the EU in August .
 Japan Airlines Corp. lost more than $1 billion in its fiscal quarter ended June 30 . It also continued in joint-venture talks with both Delta and American .
 India's low-cost Jet Airways, which in 2003 had controlled nearly half of India’s domestic market, saw its market share fall to 25%, and by mid-2009 it was posting losses and cutting staff .
 The two largest global aircraft manufacturers had a difficult year, plagued with what seemed to be endless delays in their next-generation aircraft and a great decline in orders . The two biggest global aircraft makers had a tough year .
 As of Sept., 2009, total orders booked by Airbus and Boeing Co. were only 203, compared with the 1,360 orders that the two had booked in the first nine months of 2008 .
 Company analysts said that Boeings decision to outsource much of the Dreamliner's manufacturing to save costs had contributed to bottlenecks in production .
 Boeing posted a $1. billion loss in third-quarter 2009, compared with a $695 million profit in the same quarter in 2008 . Boeing posts a loss of $1 billion in the third quarter of 2009 compared with $695m profit in 2009 .
 Airbus A400M military transport made long-delayed maiden test flight on December 11 . Despite escalating costs and canceled sales, the plane made its first test flight in December .
 Energy producers endured a year marked by extreme price volatility not seen since the energy crisis of the late 1970s . Energy producers had years of record profits due to high oil and natural gas prices .
 Oil prices fell from $145 a barrel in summer 2008 to $33 in December 2008 . Oil prices then soared again to above $80 in late October 2009, before slipping below $80 at year's end .
 The price spikes occurred even though energy demand was low and inventories high, which suggested that they were driven more by market fears of inflation and the reduced prospect of new oil discoveries . The price spike was driven by fears that inflation was more likely to drive the price of oil .
 ExxonMobil was expected to report a 63% drop in profit to $4.94 billion in the third quarter . Britain's BP PLC posted a 53% decline in profit in second-quarter 2009 alone .
 Royal Dutch Shell PLC’s angry shareholders shot down the company's executive-compensation plan in May . Shell's executive compensation plan was shot down by angry shareholders .
 In August 2009 Brazil’s government announced that its national oil company, Petrobras, would control all future development of the deep-sea oil fields found in 2007 . The discovery is considered one of the biggest new oil discoveries in recent years .
 Venezuela bypassed American and Western European firms for its new development . The country signed a $ 16 billion investment deal with China for oil exploration in the Orinoco River region .

 In early December it topped $1,200 per ounce, though it had dropped to about $1.095 by year’s end .

 Silver was up 44% to $ 17 per troy ounce as of mid-October 2009 . Front-month copper had more than doubled, to $2.5290 a pound, in July from December 2008 .
 Aluminum prices, by contrast, slumped in 2009, with prices down 45% year-on-year as of July 2009 . Aluminum prices fell 45% in 2009 .
 Alcoa Inc. posted a $454 million loss in the second quarter and idled 20% of its production by April 2009 . Most of its major markets, including automobile makers, were showing signs of stabilizing . The company reported a third-quarter profit of $77 million .
 Alcoa finished a $750 million construction project on a products factory in Russia . The company also procured Switzerland-based Noble Corp.’s intellectual property rights on welded-aluminum products .
 Steelmakers across the globe contended with bloated inventories, slackened demand, and some heavy losses . Steelmakers in some cases have struggled to cope with high demand and high losses .
 ArcelorMittal, the world’s largest steelmaker, posted a $792 million loss in the second quarter . The steelmaker said it anticipated that the worst of the economic turmoil was over in the first quarter .
 As in other sectors, demand was recovering faster in India, Russia, China, Brazil, and Eastern Europe than in the United States and Western Europe .
 ArcelorMittal’s mills in India were operating at full capacity by mid-year 2009 . Only three of its nine U.S. blast furnaces were operating as of July 30 .

 At the start of the year, the world economy faced the worst recession in modern history, with an increasing number of bankruptcies and rising unemployment . The world economy is facing the worst ever recession in history .
 Firms and individuals are having difficulty accessing operating funds and loans, says the IMF . There was a dramatic slowdown in global production and trade, says IMF .
 In September 2009 the IMF estimated worldwide toxic debt, or subprime assets, at $3.4 trillion . The IMF had previously estimated that toxic debt was $4 trillion, down from its April estimate of $3 trillion .
 Many banks were close to collapse and were rescued by their respective governments . Many banks have been bailed out by their governments .
 In the U.S., 99 banks had been closed down by the end of October . The government's $700 billion Troubled Asset Relief Program fund was used to extend loans to many banks .
 In Ireland the Anglo Irish Bank was Ireland's third largest bank and Europe's most successful during the housing-price ""bubble"" years . In January the bank was nationalized .
 In the U.K., Lloyds Banking Group and the Royal Bank of Scotland were partly and almost completely nationalized, respectively . The banks were nationalized in the 1980s and 1990s .
 In continental Europe casualties included ING, Fortis in Belgium, and Flypo Bank in Germany . ING also suffered in Belgium and Germany .
 In Eastern Europe more than $1.1 trillion had been borrowed, and many banks were in trouble . In 2009 some $400 billion had to be renewed or repaid, mainly to Western banks that were unable to roll over the debt .
 Throughout 2008 central banks around the world had cut interest rates to increase liquidity . Central banks in the world have cut rates to boost liquidity .
 U.K. and U.S. adopted quantitative easing in 2009 to increase lending . Quantitative easing is a form of economic stimulus in the United States and Britain .
 For the first time in 39 years, the 25 leading banks, which accounted for nearly 40% of bank capital and 45% of total assets, suffered losses . The top 5 banks alone lost a combined $95. billion in losses .
 Western banks endured hefty losses, led by the United States with $91 billion . Three American banks—JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, and Citigroup—raised enough funds to head The Banker's list .
 The 27-member European Union sustained a total loss of $16. billion, while the U.K.'s banks lost $51. billion . The U.S. banks also suffered a total of $51 billion .
 10 U.S. banks in June repaid $68 billion to the TARP fund . Bank profits after the first quarter were much better than expected .
 There was growing concern and public anger that the deeply embedded bonus culture persisted in the U.S. and U.K. Bank employees were poised to receive huge bonuses .
 The $9 trillion cost of the bank rescues had fallen on the taxpayers . This was in spite of the fact that the bank rescue costs had been passed on to taxpayers .
 Central banks formulating measures to prevent another banking crisis . Central banks and regulatory bodies formulating new measures to avoid another crisis .
 Capitalization requirements were increased, and there was to be greater transparency .
 In October the U.S. Treasury announced a draft bill that would enable a financial institution to be ordered by the Federal Reserve to sell a risky part of the business or have it seized . The draft bill would allow a bank to sell risky parts of its business .
 In Europe the EU was imposing penalties on all European banks that had been bailed out in the financial crisis, and even more stringent measures were likely . In Europe, the EU is imposing penalties .
 There was ongoing debate on the wisdom and feasibility of dividing banks into a two-tier system of commercial and investment banks . The more risky investment bank activities, such as hedge funds and derivatives, never again had so serious an impact on the retail banking sector .
 BHP Billiton settled iron-ore price negotiations with more than half of its steel industry customers . Many customers agreed to rates 33% below 2008 prices, and others agreed on quarterly price negotiations .
 The more flexible contracts would enable BHP and other miners to respond quickly to spikes in demand . It would also allow steelmakers to cut costs during low-demand periods .
 BHP failed to break through with Chinese steelmaker clients, who were seeking a 50% discount . BHP has failed to find a way to sell the company to Chinese steelmakers .

 Some in the book industry worried about piracy of electronic books via downloads of illegal book copies . Still, some worried about what had already happened to the music industry . The book industry is worried about the possibility of illegal downloads .

 Twitter incorporated features of traditional social networking Web sites, such as MySpace and Facebook . The service worked in some ways like an Internet or mobile telephone instant messaging client . Twitter is now available to buy for free .
 Twitter users (alternatively called Twitterers, Tweeters, or simply Twits) could elect to receive the tweets of other posters or track specific topics, creating a dialogue of sorts . The number of "followers" in a given Twitter feed could reach the millions .
 Ashton Kutcher made the news when he became the first Twitterer to collect more than a million followers in 2009 .
 Twitter users made headlines throughout the year, transforming the service into a news outlet that transcended political borders . The service's users made their own, transforming Twitter from something that was regarded as an idle hobby for an increasingly wired world into an outlet .
 Passenger Janis Krums tweeted that his ferry was going to rescue people from the downed plane . Krums broke the story of the successful water landing of United States Airways Flight 1549 on the Fludson River .
 Twitpic.com crashed as thousands of Twitterers attempted to view the image . Krums's photo was uploaded to the photo-hosting service for Twitter users . The site promptly crashed .

 A massive denialof-service attack in August targeted an economics professor in Georgia, knocking out the entire site for hours . The attack is the latest in a string of attacks targeting celebrities .
 Twitter's iconic 'fail whale' is a cartoon whale being hoisted into the air by a flock of birds, signaling a site outage . Millions of users attempted to log into Twitter only to be greeted by the site's iconic image .
 On hand was astronaut Michael Massimino, who posted the first tweet from space during a shuttle mission in May . The first tweet was posted during a space shuttle mission .
 Twitter's role as an emerging outlet for the dissemination of information more apparent than during the events surrounding the Iranian election in June 2009 . Nowhere was Twitter more visible than in 2009 when the Iranian elections were held .
 Supporters of opposition candidate Mir Hossein Mousavi took to the streets in a series of increasingly violent demonstrations . Mahmoud Ahmadinejad secured an easy victory in the election .
 The topic known as #lranElection became one of the most followed on Twitter . Mousavi supporters coordinated protests and posted live updates of events throughout Tehran .
 On June 15, three days after the election, Twitter delayed a 90-minute maintenance period at the request of the U.S. State Department . Twitter rescheduled it for 1:30 am Tehran time in order to avoid interfering with the flow of information within and from Iran .
 The following day foreign journalists were banned from covering opposition rallies, and Twitter . Twitter, along with other social networking sites, filled the void left by the traditional media .
 Government security officers tried to stanch the flow of information by blocking the Web site . Opposition supporters urged #lranElection followers to change their profile settings to the Tehran time zone .
 Events reached a fever pitch following the shooting of Neda Agha-Soltan as she was leaving a protest on June 20 . Neda was shot by police officers in the face as she left a protest .
 A mobile phone video of the young woman's graphic death was posted on the YouTube video-sharing Web site, and by the following day ""Neda"" was both the rallying cry of the opposition and one of the top trending topics on Twitter .
 The creators of Twitter did not envision such a paradigm shift when they first designed and launched the service in 2006 . Jack Dorsey, Evan Williams, Christopher Isaac Stone, and Jack Drexler created the social networking site .
 Twitter was primarily a free short messaging service with a social networking element . From its inception, Twitter was mainly a free messaging service . Twitter was founded in 2008 .
 The site lacked a clear revenue stream that one could find on sites that derived income from advertising or membership fees . As such, it lacked the clear revenue streams that one can find on other sites .
 Much of the attention in 2009 was focused on Twitter, a social-networking service that allowed people to exchange short messages, or “tweets,"" on any topic via computer or cell phone .
 Twitter was able to raise $100 million in new funding, even though it was a start-up with little or no revenue . Twitter raised the money on the basis of its popularity . Twitter is now a $1 billion-a-year-old company .
 Twitter’s founders sought to expand the reach of the service that they had launched in 2006 without a formal business plan . Twitter was founded by Evan Williams, social-networking expert ""Biz"" Stone, and software engineer Jack Dorsey .
 Text messaging is sending short written messages via bursts of data from one cell phone to another . The activity became controversial when more people began driving and texting at the same time .
 Research into so-called distracted driving found that drivers using cell phones were four times as likely to have a crash as other drivers . Drivers using phones are four times more likely to crash than other drivers, research found .
 U.S. government employees were banned from text messaging while driving government vehicles . Government employees were also banned from texting while driving .
 Another problem of cell-phone texting was the transmission of sexual images or messages, which became known as “sexting,” between teenagers .
 In the United States, the problem posed new issues for schools and courts . In the U.S., the problem poses new issues .
 The Iowa state Supreme Court upheld a misdemeanor conviction of an 18-year-old boy who sent a nude photo of himself to a 14-year old classmate via text messaging . The boy was convicted of a misdemeanor charge of sending the photo to the teen .
 A survey by the National Campaign to Prevent Teen and Unplanned Pregnancy showed that 20% of young Americans between the ages of 13 and 19 had either texted or posted online partially or completely nude pictures or video of themselves .
 Microsoft admitted that users had been disappointed with the Windows Vista OS (introduced in early 2007) Windows 7 was launched in October 2009 .
 Windows 7 was said to address complaints about Vista, software crashes, and software incompatibility issues . Windows 7 is said to keep the underlying Vista architecture of Windows 7 .
 Windows 7 improvements included more efficient use of memory, which caused a PC to start up faster and run more smoothly . Windows 7 also added more efficient memory management .
 Vista's high computing demands meant that it would not run well on many existing computers . Vista was announced in 2007 but has not been widely available on existing computers since then .

 Microsoft reached an agreement on Windows long-running antitrust issues with the European Union in December . In December Microsoft reached a deal with the EU over long-standing antitrust issues .
 The EU reacted favourably to Microsoft’s offer to alter the way that it combined its Internet Explorer Web browser with Windows . The EU responded positively to the offer .
 Microsoft also won a patent victory when a federal judge overturned a $388 million penalty against the company . The penalty was one of the largest amounts ever awarded in a civil patentinfringement lawsuit .
 Software firm Uniloc USA, Inc., Inc., won damages from Microsoft in an earlier jury trial . Software firm won damages on the basis of claims that Microsoft had infringed on Unilloc's security software patents . Microsoft won damages in the earlier trial .
 A federal court in Texas in May ruled in favour of Canadian firm i4i, Inc., which claimed in a lawsuit filed in 2007 that Microsoft’s Word software infringed on an i4I patent . The lawsuit was settled in May .
 In August the court ruled that Microsoft should pay more than $290 million in damages . The court issued an injuction that would prohibit the company from selling versions of the Word program that contained the patented technology .
 i4i told the appeals court that Microsoft had known about Mi’s patent before using the technology and had simply disregarded it . Microsoft obtained a temporary stay of the court's order and told the court that the lower court had erred .
 Microsoft agrees to replace the infringing code in Word 2003 and Word 2007 . Microsoft lost its appeal and agreed to replace it in Word 3 and 2007 .
 The court ruling might force the software company to make technical changes to Word . The next version of Word is planned for release in 2010 . The software company is expected to release the next version in 2011 .
 Under the agreement, Microsoft was to provide Bing’s search technology on Yahoofs Web sites . Under the deal, Bing's search technology was allowed to be used on the sites .
 There were more delays in Google’s settlement with authors and publishers in a 2005 copyright-infringement case over scanned library books that were to appear online . Google settled with authors, publishers in 2005 case over library books .
 Google's original settlement called for Google to pay $125 million to compensate authors and publishers of books that were still protected by copyright . The original settlement was called for the company to compensate copyright holders for out-of-print books .
 The United States Department of Justice raised legal and antitrust objections to the agreement . The U.S. government says the agreement gave Google too much power over copyrighted works .
 A replacement agreement was awaiting court approval at year’s end . The two sides in the copyright case had been negotiating a replacement agreement .
 Google acquired reCAPTCHA, a company that created visual puzzles to ensure that people and not automated hots (short for robots) were signing up for Internet services . In a related matter, Google also acquired re CAPTCHA company, which was created by Google .
 Google sought to adapt the technology to improve optical character recognition for out-of-copyright books that it scanned and offered for downloading . The technology is being used to scan books and offer for download .
 The PC industry waited for signals that the recession was over, but the outlook was not good in the first part of the year . PC industry was waiting for signals of the recession to be over .
 Worldwide PC shipments were down 2.4% in the second quarter from a year earlier, IDC says . The value of PC shipments dropped about 19%, in part because of price discounting .
 It was hoped that the year-end holiday season would signal the return of better economic times . Early indications that could be true, however .
 In the third calendar quarter of the year, all PC companies reported rising sales . PC sales are up in the third quarter of 2014 .
 PC maker Acer replaced Dell as the second-ranked PC market-share holder, with 14% of the worldwide market . Late in the year, according to IDC, Dell replaced Dell with Acer .
 Hewlett-Packard remains number one, with just over 20% of the world PC market . Hewlett Packard remained number one with 20% PC market.
 Apple boosted its U.S. market share with record nonholiday sales in the third quarter . The Macintosh remained a minor player internationally .
 Netbooks were the fastest-growing PC category . Netbooks are seen as bridging the gap between smartphones and laptop computers . Netbook is the fastest growing PC category in the world .
 Netbooks were small notebook computers with slower processors, smaller screens, shrunken keyboards, and smaller screens . They nonetheless could handle Internet browsing and routine computing tasks . Netbooks are small notebooks with smaller screens and smaller keyboards .

 The Epstein Medal for innovation in geochemistry was awarded to John Eiler at the 2009 Goldschmidt Conference in Davos, Switz . The first Epstein Medal was awarded in 2009 .
 This medal celebrates the pioneering research of the late Samuel Epstein, a geochemist . Epstein was perhaps most famous for his calibration of oxygen isotope distributions between carbonates and water .
 These paleotemperature determinations required the estimation of vanished reservoir information such as oxygen isotopes of the ocean from which marine organisms grew .
 Eiler, a geologist from the California Institute of Technology, developed an expanded technique that involved the measurement of ""carbonate clumped isotopes" in carbonate minerals .
 This distribution is temperature-sensitive and independent of the composition of the host medium, such as seawater . The distribution of the distribution of this distribution is also independent .

 A damaging earthquake occurred near the Italian village of L’Aquila on April 6, 2009 . The quake occurred near L'Aquila, Italy .
 The main shock was followed by thousands of aftershocks that were detected and located by a portable network of seismometers . The Instituto Nazionale di Geofisca e Vulcanologia located the quake using a portable seismometer .
 The L’Aquila earthquake resulted from normal faulting on the northwest-southeast-trending Paganica Fault . The earthquake was caused by a normal fault on northwest-southwest-southward fault .
 It and several neighbouring faults are related to extensional tectonic forces associated with the opening of the Tyrrhenian Basin to west .
 Earthquakes that occur deeper than about 50 km have long been enigmatic to seismologists . Seismologists say they are baffled by the depth depth of the deepest quakes .
 At these depths the lithostatic pressure is large enough to inhibit brittle failure, or rock fracturing . At the depths, the pressure is enough to stop brittle failure or fracturing .
 In January a team of geologists from Norway and Germany presented new evidence in favour of a proposed mechanism for generating intermediate-depth earthquakes .
 They analyzed veins of rock that had been formed by flash heating in a Precambrian terrane in Norway . The study was published in the journal Nature Sciencedenceda .
 The pseudotachylytes had initially formed at depths greater than 70 km before being exhumed to the Earth’s surface . In this case, geochemically analysis showed that the pseudotsachylytees had formed in depth at 70 km .
 Using computer modeling, the authors explained their observations by means of a self-localized thermal runaway failure mechanism . The authors used computer modeling to explain their observations .
 This mechanism does not depend on the existence of free fluid in the pore spaces of rocks and therefore provided a distinct alternative to the dehydration embrittlement hypothesis that was favoured as a mechanism for generating intermediatedepth earthquakes .
 Using the laser-flash analysis technique, her research provided insight into how heat behaves as it is conducted through rock enriched with dissolved minerals .
 Discovered in the late 1970s, these features had been extensively studied because they led to distinct biospheres that did not depend on photosynthesis . Discovered by scientists in 1970s .
 Scientists began monitoring the Endeavour segment of the Juan de Fuca Ridge in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Oregon and Washington with a network of eight seismometers buried beneath the seafloor .
 Using high-fidelity seismic data, scientists located several thousand small earthquakes that were associated with an axial magma chamber that drives the hydrothermal, or deep-sea, venting in the region . The scientists located the small earthquakes .
 The scientists concluded that cracking associated with the recharge of the axial magma chamber was the key mechanism for localizing and maintaining black-smoker vent fields .
 The scientists used a new technique known as laser-flash analysis to determine the time that it took for heat to diffuse from one end of a rock sample to the other .
 This technique accounts for biases caused by radiative heat loss and allowed for accurate measurement of the drop in conductivity as the sample was heated . This technique properly accounts for bias caused by heat loss .
 Thermal conductivity was reduced by as much as 50% at the base of the crust compared with previous estimates . The results of these experiments showed that thermal conductivity had been reduced .
 Granitic magmas observed in hot mountain belts such as the Himalayas could be generated without the radioactive heat production in the lower crust increasing . This in turn implied the base of the crust was much hotter than previously thought .
 Heat generated by the localized deformation of the crust may form magmas . Instead, heat generated by local deformation may form the magmas.
 The positive feedback created by temperature-dependent conductivities may have been integral to the differentiation of the Earth into core, mantle, and crust from its original chrondritic (meteorite-derived) composition .
 Scientists studying Earth’s magnetic field reported new constraints on the structure and dynamics of Earth's core . Scientists studying the structure of the core of the Earth's magnetic field .
 Magnetic field fluctuations reflected processes of fluid dynamics that took place in Earth's liquid-iron outer core .
 The fluctuations were created by torsional oscillations that occurred with a cylindrical geometry . The fluctuations are created by the fluctuations of torsion oscillations .
 In contrast to the elastic restoring force responsible for seismic waves from earthquakes, the magnetic restoring force creates these hydromagnetic waves . The waves were created by a magnetic restore force .
 Using methods that seismologists developed to study seismic waves, the scientists modeled the hydromagnetic waves to constrain the structure of the magnetic field in the outer core and the rigidity of the solid inner core .
 The ""core-quakes” that generate the hydromagnetic waves appeared to originate near the equator of the inner core, but their precise source mechanism remained a mystery . The precise source of the waves is unknown .

 An analysis of sightings that had occurred since 1997 near the coast of British Columbia and in the Gulf of Alaska revealed that blue whales in these areas were part of an extant Californian population . This suggests that migration patterns of an eastern North Pacific population may have resumed .
 The California population and the population historically inhabiting the area around the Gulf of Alaska could be one and the same .

 The Fiji petrel ( Pseudobulweria macgillivrayi) is classified by the IUCN as Critically Endangered . It was formerly known from one specimen collected in 1855 on Gau Island .
 In 1984 a single adult was caught on Gau Island, photographed, and released . The adult was photographed and released by the authorities .

 Their decline was linked to inadequate protection of key sites on their migratory routes . Their decline has been blamed on inadequate protection from key sites .
 While wading birds used a network of protected areas in Europe, key sites elsewhere were not adequately protected . Wading birds were not protected in Europe's protected areas, experts say .
 Wetlands along Africa’s west coast, for example, had been affected by the construction of dams that drain wetlands and irrigation schemes that affect water flow .

 Two studies released in September found using a double dose of a cancer drug increased the chance of disease remission for patients with a common form of leukemia .
 The studies examined the treatment of patients with acute myeloid leukemia . The cancer is one of the most common acute forms of the cancer that occurs in adults .
 The studies appeared in The New England Journal of Medicine . The studies examined a man with tuberculosis awaiting free treatment outside a medical facility in Siliguri, a city in northeastern India .
 The dandelion is a plant which propagates by airborne means . In the same way, social action can spread and take root, carried on the winds .
 Of those who took the higher dose, some 71% experienced remission of their disease . Of those patients receiving the normal amount of drug, about 57% entered remission .
 The results also showed that more chemotherapy was associated with improved survival length . Those receiving the larger dose survived 24 months and those receiving the smaller dose survived just 16 months .
 The second study examined patients aged 60 to 83 and found that more than two-thirds had remission of their cancers when given a dose of chemotherapy that was twice the standard amount .
 This was in contrast to remission in about 54% of patients treated with the regular dose of daunorubicin . This was compared to 54% who were treated with regular dose .
 Researchers said that their work could produce a shift in the treatment of adults under 65 .
 The elderly, however, who were at an increased risk of developing acute myeloid leukemia, were not predicted to see any change in the current approach .

 In 2009, for the first time, a person's own heart stem cells were used to help repair tissue damage after a heart attack . The stem cells are now being used to treat tissue damage in the heart .
 In June a team of doctors performed the procedure on a 39-year-old male patient at Cedars-Sinai Heart Institute .
 The tissue was then taken to a lab, where it was cultured, giving rise to heart stem cells . Heart stem cells were then cultured to give rise to stem cells in a lab .
 Millions of cells were grown in order to ensure that there was an adequate supply for the treatment . Millions were grown to ensure there was a sufficient supply of cells for treatment .
 Using a catheter, doctors were able to deliver the stem cells to the patient's heart via the coronary arteries . Using a coronary artery, doctors delivered the stem cell to the person's heart .
 The procedure is part of a Phase 1 clinical trial in which 15 other patients were scheduled to undergo the same treatment . The procedure was part of the Phase 1 trial .

 Statins prevent additional heart attacks and strokes in patients who had already suffered from one or the other . Previous studies had shown that statins can prevent additional strokes and heart attacks in patients .

 About 50% of adverse cardiovascular events occurred in persons who had normal cholesterol levels . About half of those who suffered a heart attack or stroke were people with normal cholesterol .
 Some 20% of these events occurred in persons who had no evidence of cardiovascular disease risk factors . 20% were in persons with no risk factors, including those with no cardiovascular disease .
 The incidence of heart attacks had decreased significantly in places in North America and Europe where smoking bans had been passed .
 Ban on smoking in public and work areas reduces incidence of heart attacks by 17% . Communities that had not taken steps to reduce smoking reported a reduction of 17% in heart attacks .
 Researchers were hopeful that a new drug tested in 2009 could stamp out river blindness, or onchocerciasis . River blindness was primarily in Central and South America and Africa .
 The drug, known as moxidectin, was investigated as part of a clinical trial involving three African countries . The drug was investigated by a group of African countries involved in the trial .
 Africa was the region of the world most affected by river blindness . More than 37 million people worldwide were infected with the causative parasite, Onchocerca volvulus .
 The study was focused mainly on determining moxidectin’s activity against the adult worms of O volvulus .
 The drug was developed as part of a collaboration administered by WHO and Wyeth Pharmaceuticals known as the Special Programme for Research and Training in Tropical Diseases . The drug is available in the UK and Australia .
 Study suggests eliminating onchocerciasis through ivermectin treatment may be possible . Treatment may also be possible in the future, study suggests .

 Promising results were reported in a study examining a new vaccine for advanced melanoma, a deadly form of skin cancer . The vaccine is a form of form of melanoma that can be deadly and aggressive skin cancer.
 A peptide vaccine combined with interleukin-2 stimulates the body's immune cells to attack cancer cells . A study at Anderson Cancer Center in Houston found better response and survival outcomes .
 Among those given the vaccine, 22.1% of patients responded, and for nearly three months, the treated patients' cancers did not progress .
 Those who were not treated with the vaccine experienced an average of about 1.6 months of progression-free survival . Those who didn't receive the vaccine, however, experienced average of 1.5 months of survival .
 The average overall survival time for patients treated with the vaccine was 17. months . The vaccine is a form of formative step-up to a formative form of life .
 In contrast, patients not treated with the vaccine survived only an average of 12. months . Patients not treated for the vaccine survive only 12.6 months .
 The vaccine was also the first to have demonstrated, in a Phase 3 clinical trial, beneficial effects in patients with melanoma . Vaccine was first to demonstrate, in the Phase 3 trial, that beneficial effects were beneficial to patients .
 New hope for cocaine addicts may be on the horizon after an experimental vaccine showed positive results in helping treat their addiction . An experimental vaccine has been shown to help treat cocaine addicts .
 Vaccination with the anticocaine agent reduced cocaine use in 38% of treated patients . Vaccination also reduced the use of cocaine by 38% .
 Clinical trial included patients who were being treated for methadone addiction . The clinical trial received backing from the U.S. National Institute on Drug Abuse .
 The results were published in October in the journal Archives of General Psychiatry .
 The vaccine works by triggering antibody production by the immune system . It is similar to the way in which other vaccines work against infectious diseases .
 In the presence of the anticocaine vaccine, antibodies are produced that bind specifically to cocaine in the blood . Antibodies are produced in the absence of the anti-cocaine vaccines .
 This stops the drug from moving through the blood-brain barrier and thereby prevents the ‘high’ that it normally causes . The drug is then stopped from entering the brain barrier, preventing it from entering into the bloodstream .
 The vaccine Gardasil is widely used to help prevent cervical cancer in women . It is now widely used in men to help fight cervical cancer .

 The United States Department of Justice described the case as being a landmark health care settlement . The settlement is one of the largest of its kind in the country's history .
 The drugs at the centre of the case included the painkiller Bextra . The painkiller had been withdrawn from the market several years earlier .
