 Black colour expressions in wild horses are presumed to have been a consequence of natural selection associated with dense forests following glaciation . The black colour expressions are thought to be a result of natural . selection .
 The investigators concluded that selective breeding of domestic stock is the most parsimonious explanation for the observed changes in horse coat coloration in the Eurasian Steppe .
 The deep ocean is one of the least-explored parts of the planet . The myriad interactions and associations between species in the deep ocean are not well understood .
 Among the population traits that can be critical to the persistence of some communities is the longevity of a keystone species . Keystone species on which other species depend are key to the survival of communities .

 Researchers studying animal behaviour continued to discover patterns that shed light on the ecology and evolution of species . Researchers continued to find patterns of animal behaviour .
 Using a statistical technique called principal components analysis, the investigators determined that choice of foraging microhabitats by juvenile cottonmouths was not random . The cottonmouthmouths are known to be the largest in the world, according to scientists .
 Adults were randomly scattered throughout a diversity of microhabitats . In contrast, adults were randomly dispersed throughout a variety of microhomes . Adults are randomly scattered in microhabits .
 Young cottonmouths were found on land alongside the wetland, typically in a tight coil, in a sit-and-wait foraging posture for ambushing prey .
 Juveniles also occurred in locations hidden from predators, while adults were generally discovered outstretched and actively foraging throughout the wetland . Adults were generally found outstretched .
 Juvenile snakes were able to use caudal luring to attract salamanders and small frogs . The snakes have yellow tails and are able to lure salamander and frogs .
 Developmental changes in coloration and behaviours that affect an animal’s risk of becoming prey can influence foraging strategy and the choice of microhabitat within a predatory species .
 Many social animals gain ecological benefits from living in groups, says behavioral ecologists . The benefits are more effective predator avoidance and an increase in foraging success, or prey capture .
 A third recently identified advantage to larger groups is the development of more effective problem-solving skills in novel situations . A third advantage is the ability to solve problems in new situations .
 Groups of six were found to be 4 times more successful than groups of two at solving the problem of removing the lid and 11 times faster at gaining access to the food .
 A clear conclusion was that larger group size resulted in more rapid problem solving . The study found that larger groups of people solve problems faster than small groups .
 One explanation for the higher success rate was that certain individuals may have had experience in solving similar problems or simply have an aptitude for doing so .
 Research in 2009 also focused on questions related to how animals may respond to shifts in climate . Research also looked at how animals respond to climate shifts in 2009 .
 Two generally accepted responses to global warming are latitudinal or elevational shifts in geographic distribution and changes in the seasonal timing of critical biological events, such as reproduction, migration, or emergence from hibernation .
 Two independent research projects identified components of higher environmental temperatures that affect the body size of animals . The research was conducted by independent research groups .
 Researchers tested the hypothesis that decreased body size among ectothermic, or cold-blooded, aquatic animals will generally become more prevalent with global warming .
 They provided evidence from fish sampled in the Baltic Sea and rivers in France and published data about the North Sea .
 In rivers with more than two decades of gradual increases in water temperature, average fish size decreased . Fish species with smaller body sizes became significantly more prevalent, investigators found .
 North Sea fish communities where warming trends had occurred . The latter observation was also true for North Sea communities .
 This specimen of smooth black coral , which lives in deep water near Hawaii, lived for approximately 4,000 years . In some fish the fish is thought to have lived for more than four millennia .
 Increased water temperature resulted in changes in species composition, individual growth rates, and reproductive patterns of fish and other aquatic ectotherms .
 Similar patterns were found in lab experiments in which a warming environment decreased the size of zooplankton, phytoplankon, and bacteria .
 Arpat Ozgul and Tim Coulson of the Imperial College London examined the causes of decreasing body size among a free-living population of Soay sheep on Hirta, an island in the Saint Kilda archipelago of Scotland .
 The researchers concluded that the shift in size was primarily a consequence of ecological responses to climate change that produced milder winters over the previous two decades .
 More sheep survived milder winters, resulting in greater population densities . This led to greater grazing competition and slower growth rates overall .
 Body size of both fish and sheep changed in under three decades . The results suggest rapid changes in a trait as biologically important as body size can be induced by climate change .
 Important breakthroughs in 2009 were made in 2009 by using genetic engineering to raise the productivity of crop plants .
 Most rice plants die if they are completely submerged in floodwaters for more than a few days . This problem afflicts up to 40% of rice crops in Asia and Africa during their rainy seasons .
 Some rice varieties, however, can survive flooding by rapidly growing their stems upward, some reaching 4 m in height . Some varieties of rice varieties can survive floods by growing stems upward .
 Such plants are typically far less productive than high-yield varieties . High-yielding varieties are typically less productive and less productive .
 As the stems grow, they form hollow structures inside that allow gas exchange with the atmosphere and thus prevent waterlogging . This prevents the plant from getting waterlogged .
 When these genes were introduced into common rice plants, their stems rapidly elongated in deep water and withstood flooding . The stems of these rice plants can also withstand flooding in deep waters .
 A gene helps some types of wild rice fend off rice blast disease, a fungal infection caused by Magnaporthe grisea . The fungus destroys up to 30% of world rice production .
 Previous attempts to breed cultivated rice with resistance to the fungus produced poor-tasting, low-quality rice . Previous attempts have failed to breed resistant rice resistant to fungus .
 The fungus also quickly evolved to overcome the resistance in as little as two years . The fungus quickly evolved in a matter of hours .
 The new work successfully used genetic sequencing to isolate the blast-resistant gene, P121, from a linked stretch of DNA responsible for the bad flavour of the wild varieties of rice .
 The gene increased the plant’s defenses against infection in general, making it harder for the blast fungus to take hold . The gene also increased plant's defense against infection .
 Scientists from Germany, Switzerland, and the United States used another form of plant defense to genetically engineer com plants to fight off a root pest .
 Larvae from a beetle known as the western corn rootworm burrow into the plants’ roots . It had become the most destructive corn pest in the U.S. in the past .
 Some varieties of com, however, fight off D virgifera by releasing a chemical messenger called -beta-caryophyllene . Insecticides are largely controlled with insecticides, but some varieties are resistant .
 Chemical attracts soil-living nematode worms, which attack and kill the beetle larvae . The chemical attracts protective soil living nematodes, killing larvae .
 After decades of breeding, most North American com varieties no longer emitted -beta-caryophyllene and thus had lost the ability to recruit protective nematodes . Most of the com varieties had lost their ability to attract nematode .
 When the gene for the chemical was introduced into the genomes of ordinary corn plants, the plants became far less vulnerable to beetle attacks .
 Plant scientists took a major step forward in their plans to “barcode’s every plant species in the world by using DNA analysis . Plant scientists say they hope to use DNA analysis to identify species of plants .
 The selection of the most appropriate gene for barcoding animals had been achieved several years earlier, but a botanical equivalent proved troublesome . The selection was made after the selection of a gene for animals had already been achieved .
 52 scientists working in 10 countries spent four years discussing which DNA barcode to use . A team of 52 scientists from around the world spent the last four years working on the barcode .
 DNA variations in the DNA give a characteristic signature for plant species . They eventually selected portions of two chloroplast genes, rbcL and matK .
 In 72% of the cases, they immediately determined the correct species of plant . The plant was found in the wild .
 For the remaining specimens, they were able to place each plant within a group of related species . For the rest of the specimens, the researchers placed each plant in a group .
 Researchers in the United States and Belgium identified two species of microbes growing on the inside of roots of poplar trees . The microbes boost the trees’ productivity on barren or contaminated soils .
 Genetic analysis of the two bacterial species revealed that they produce growth-promoting plant hormones . This could stimulate the trees’ growth, according to scientists .
 With fertile farmland in short supply, the notion of adding bacteria to poplar trees to help them grow on marginal land was particularly attractive .
 Trees could be used as feedstock for the production of biofuels and help sequester carbon from the atmosphere . Such trees could also be used to help to feedstock biofuel production .
 Another study revealed a fascinating symbiosis between bacteria and the giant cardon cactus . Pachycereus pringlei allowed the plant to grow on barren rocks in Mexico .
 When the cactus seeds germinated, bacteria contained within the seeds dissolved the rock and released minerals that the seedling roots could absorb . The cactus seedlings can also absorb minerals from the rock .
 Once the cactus was established, its roots grew into the rock and, with the help of the bacteria, eventually produced soil . Once the roots grew in the rock, the bacteria produced soil for soil .
 The bacteria were fed carbon and nitrogen compounds by the cactus . In return for supplying the minerals, the bacteria were given carbon by it .
 Many orchids lure insects to pollinate their flowers by imitating the insects’ sex pheromones . Orchids attract insects to their flowers with imitating their pherms .
 A unique type of mimicry was discovered in Dendrobium sinense, an orchid that grows in China . The orchid is found to mimic mimicry in a Chinese orchid .
 A team of Chinese and German scientists discovered that the orchid produces a chemical that exactly imitates the honeybees’ alarm pheromone Z-l 1-eicosen-l-ol . The chemical is previously unknown in plants and rarely identified even in the insect world
 Hornets typically home in on this pheromone to catch honeybees for food . Hornets typically use the pheramone to attract honeybees to food .
 The hornets are so fooled by the orchid’s scent that they pounce on it and thus pollinate the flower . The orchid is so attracted to hornets that the hornets pounce upon it .
 Microorganisms outnumber the more than 75 trillion cells of the human body by at least 10 to 1 . Every human is host to a microorganism community -- a veritable ecosystem of a diverse array of microbes .
 The majority of microbial populations that inhabit the skin, nose, mouth, gut, gut and other tissues are not simply opportunistic parasites . They are true symbionts vital to human health, and exert previously unappreciated influence on the ability to resist disease .
 Many microbes do not grow well outside of their normal habitat, meaning they cannot be cultured in the lab . One reason that many of these microbes have remained unknown until recently is that they cannot grow well in the wild .
 Available samples of human secretions or tissues contain such a complex array of different species as to be refractory to analysis by traditional means . Human secretions are refractories to analysis using traditional means, scientists say .
 In 2009 scientists made great strides in improving their understanding of the identities and roles of these microbes .
 These research efforts were spearheaded in part by the Human Microbiome Project . The project is sponsored by the National Institutes of Health in the United States .
 Launched in December 2007, the HMP pursued stated goals that included identifying and sequencing the genomes of those microbial species that inhabit the healthy human body .
 One of the first members of the human microbiome to be recognized as beneficial to human health was E coli, which inhabits the large intestine . E coli is one of the most common bacteria in the human body to be beneficial to health .
 The community of microbes inhabiting the gut is startlingly diverse . It became clear, however, that the community was startlingly varied .
 DNA sequence analysis of gene 16S rRNA (ribosomal small subunit RNA), which is unique to each species of microorganism, enabled scientists to identify various microbes in the human gut .
 Studies of the microbial communities in healthy humans and laboratory animals implicate microbial variation as a factor influencing everything from nutrient extraction during digestion, to defense against invading pathogens .
 One of the most compelling connections between gut microbes and health deals with obesity . Gut microbes are linked to obesity .
 Enterococcus faecalis, found in the human gut, is a member of the diverse community of microbial species that constitute the human microbiome . Researchers exploring the distal gut microbes of obese and lean laboratory mice and also of obese human volunteers .
 germ-free mice intentionally colonized with “lean” gut microbes accumulated significantly less total body fat through the course of the experiment . The trait was transferable, according to the study .
 The “obese’s gut microbes also demonstrated an increased ability to extract energy from the diet . Of note, the ‘obese gut microbes’ also demonstrated that they were better at extracting energy .
 While circumstantial, these data clearly implicate the ‘obese’ gut microbes as a contributing factor in human obesity . This may also suggest novel routes of intervention in the battle against obesity .
 One of the least-well-understood aspects of the human microbiome deals with the question of initial colonization of an infant .
 A newborn emerges sterile from the womb, and over the course of the next days to months, he or she must acquire a full complement of “good" microbes .
 One can only wonder whether the most ingrained and natural of all behaviours—that of human parents to nuzzle and kiss their baby, or of a mother mouse to lick her pups—are linked to the need to share not only love but microbes .
 Classic autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder that is evident by age three and that affects four times as many males as females . Classic autism, the most common autism spectrum disorder, affects 4.5% of males and 4% of females . Autism is the most severe form of autism,
 Whether this apparent ""epidemic” of autism reflects a true rise in incidence or is due to changes in diagnostic criteria and ascertainment is a point of some contention . Most experts attribute at least a majority of the apparent increase to ascertainment .
 Even monozygotic twins do not show 100% concordance, sometimes one twin is affected and the other twin is not . The heritability of twins is estimated at greater than 90% . Sometimes twins are affected by the same heritability .
 Even when both twins are affected, the level of severity can differ . Further, the severity of the twins' condition can differ depending on severity .
 The sibling risk is 5-10%, which is 10 times higher than the population risk . The risk of sibling deaths is 5 to 10% .
 ASDs result from a combination of both genetic and environmental factors, say experts . Together these data confirm that ASDs are caused by both genetic or environmental factors .
 Neuroanatomical and neuroimaging studies suggest that affected individuals may experience abnormal neurodevelopment in utero, beginning as early as the first or second trimester of gestation .
 The key environmental influences, therefore, may be prenatal as well as post-natal . Environmental influences, such as prenatal as postnatal influences, may also be prenatal .

 The mouse demonstrated a variety of social and behavioral characteristics reminiscent of the disorder . This is further evidence of a causal relationship between the chromosomal abnormality in patients and their clinical symptoms .

 These advances offered hope that the cause of autism would soon be understood, which may enable future generations to prevent or reverse its course .

 The family Heterodontosauridae represents a very basal group of omithiscian, or ""bird-hipped,” dinosaurs .
 They were small bipedal animals known mainly from the Early Jurassic Period of Africa . The animals were known mainly as small bipedsal animals .

 A new Jurassic ceratosaur from China shed light on the origin of the reduced number of digits in birds .
 Previous studies suggested that the reduction to three digits in theropod dinosaurs occurred by the loss of digits four and five . Previous studies suggest the reduction occurred by losing digits four, five .
 Birds appeared to have lost digits five and one, leaving the three expanded central digits to support the wing . Birds, however, appeared to lose digits five, one and one .
 In the new Chinese ceratosaur, the metacarpal region (an area made up of the bones of the hand proper) shows similarities to digits two, three, and four . While the phalangeal region shows more affinity to digits one, two, and three .
 The authors indicated that this phalangeal anatomy in other theropods may be the reason for the idea that they retain digits 1-3 .
 The authors suggested that it made more sense to assume that the reduced number of fingers in theropods actually represents digits 2-4 . Theropods combined with the hand anatomy of the new ceratosaur, they said .
 A study published in 2008, comparing the clutch volumes of the dinosaurs Troodon, Oviraptor, and Citipati, supported a bird-patemal-care model for the dinosaurs, indicating that the male parent cared for the young .
 Living archosaurs, such as crocodilians, follow the maternal behaviour model, in which the young are cared for by the female . In contrast, living archosaurs such as the crocinos follow the motherly model .
 Epidexipteryx hui, a new avian from the Jurassic of Inner Mongolia, showed a surprising mixture of characteristics from several different theropod groups . Other early bird species seem more aligned with a particular type of coelurosaurian .
 An analysis of pterosaur limb strength indicated that, unlike birds, pterosaurs may have launched into flight by using all four limbs . Unlike birds, birds may have used all four legs to launch into flight .
 The research compared bone strength of three pterosaur species with that of 20 bird species . The research was carried out by a group of 20 birds .
 In heavier birds the leg becomes much thicker than the humerus of the wing, which creates more leg strength for takeoff . The leg of a bird is thicker than that of its wing, making it stronger for takeoff.
 In pterosaurs, forelimbs are much stronger, which suggests that pteros may have used them to aid in takeoff . Forelimbs may have been strong enough to help in flight .

 While fiction of 2009 shot off sparks and sometimes fireworks, the nonfiction books smoldered rather than exploded . Nonfiction books, whether memoir, criticism, history, or a blend of the above, were bestsellers of the year .
 The Death and Life of an American Small Town offered a worrisome piece of book-length reportage of a methamphetamine-saturated American heartland . The book was published by Pulitzer Prize-winning Tom Charity .
 Eula Biss published a collection of eccentric and well-composed personal essays on race in American life in Notes from No Man’s Land .
 Jane Vandenburgh's memoir, A Pocket History of Sex in the Twentieth Century, was built on a wonderful fusion of insight and eccentricity of vision .
 Posthumous The Essays of Leonard Michaels (edited by Katherine Ogden Michaels) Showed off the brilliance of the late story writer in nonfiction prose .
 Alan Cheuse published A Trance After Breakfast, a collection of travel essays that ranged in subject from his native New Jersey to the islands of Bali, Indonesia, and New Zealand .
 Former poet laureate Rita Dove signed in with Sonata Mulattica, a collection of poems about a young African European composer who first won Beethoven's approval and then earned his anger .
 Campbell McGrath turned his attention to the figure of young George Shannon, the youngest member of the Lewis and Clark expedition . Shannon was the Pennsylvaniaborn teenage boy who was the youngest .
 In Shannon he dramatized George’s 16 days of wandering alone across the Great American Desert after becoming separated from the main group of explorers .
 Novelist Richard Bausch went mostly in the direction of lyric in his book These Extremes . The book featured prose to his relatives as well as verse based on historical and literary figures .
 Marilyn Kallet, longtime resident of Tennessee, brought out Packing Light . Marilyn Kallett brought out the light for the first time in her Tennessee home .
 Miguel Algarin is founder of the Nuyorican Poets Cafe . He produced essays and poems in Survival Supervivencia . He has published numerous pieces of poetry, essays and poetry .
 Snodgrass, James Purdy, Harold Norse, Frank McCourt, and William Safire are among the writers behind the scenes .
 Humour and disaster were often uneasy companions in Canadian novels in 2009 . The best Canadian novels of the year were published in 2009 and 2010 .
 Margaret Atwood’s The Year of the Flood was an inventively witty but bleak account of life on Earth after a long-predicted worldwide disaster has occurred . Douglas Coupland's darkly comic Generation A was set in a future in which bees were nearly extinct and only
 Tall tales also informed Michael Crummey’s Galore, set in a remote Newfoundland outport . Galore is set in the province's largest town .
 The true and tragic capsizing of the oil rig Ocean Ranger in 1982 formed the backdrop for Lisa Moores novel February . February is the story of a family surviving the loss of husband, father, and breadwinner .
 Other settings include ancient Macedonia, a World War II-era factory and a post-Khmer Rouge Cambodia .
 Anne Michaels’s compelling love story The Winter Vault took both Egypt and Canada as its setting . Anne Michaels also interweaved flashbacks of historical events in post-World War II Poland and England .
 Barry Callaghan also played with time, present and past in Beside Still Waters . Beside still Waters is a peripatetic search for a lost love .
 Bonnie Burnard’s Suddenly was placed squarely in the centre of a cancer patient's family and friends . In contrast, she was put in the heart of her cancer patients' friends .
 Kate Pullinger reworked the story of a rebellious housemaid and her famous employer, Lucie Duff Gordon . Claire Holden Rothman was not too closely bound by the facts in The Heart Specialist, an account of Maude Abbott, one of Canada’s first female doctors .
 The pitfalls of expediency and morality were examined in Linden MacIntyre's The Bishop’s Man . Colin McAdam's Fall is a portrait of privileged male adolescents at an Ottawa boarding school . Martha Baillie's The Incident Report is a fantastic romp of literary references
 Alice Munro’s latest collection, Too Much Happiness, was published in October 2013 . Munro's short stories include the rewriting of real lives, as well as the final journey of a famous 19th-century Russian mathematician .
 Ali Smith demonstrated the versatility of the short-story form in The First Person, and Other Stories . Deborah Willis and Mavis Gallant once more utilized her talents for observation in Going Ashore .
 Alexandra Leggat’s Animal plumbed the often unrecognized affinities of animals and humans . The stories in the Animal series explore the ways of life in animals and people .
 Curry Is Thicker than Water by Jasmine D’Costa is a deftly witty excursion into tales set in the heart of India . George Bowering’s The Box is a playful riff on Vancouver in the 1960s .
 A common theme in many books of poetry was the differences that both separate and unite individuals . Poems are about the differences and differences that separate individuals .
 Adeena Karasick’s Amuse Bouche served up a word salad of phrases, concepts, metaphor, and wit in wild and tasty juxtapositions . The Amused Bouche is the latest in a series of words from the author's work .
 Marguerite Pigeon’s Inventory examined the interface between subject and object, where the observer and the observed begin and end . Fred Wah considered the relations between word and thing in Is a Door, and Jeanette Lynes contrasted Canadian places and pastimes .
 Douglas Lochhead stayed put and studied his own backyard in Looking into Trees . Lochhead's book was inspired by his backyard experiences .
 Barry Dempster revels in the contrasting vagaries of the human heart in Love Outlandish . The book is based on the same themes of love and marriage .
 David Zieroth meditated on escaping from oneself in The Fly in Autumn . Carmine Starnino in This Way Out looked for exits from modernity . Sina Queyras’s Expressway was a direct route into the heart of other times and places .

 Important works written in English by authors from sub-Saharan Africa, Australia, and New Zealand made a strong showing in 2009 .
 New releases by several of South Africa’s preeminent writers hit bookstores . Much to the delight of readers and critics alike, new releases by South African writers have been released .

 Breytenbach's Notes from the Middle World is one of the year’s most memorable books . The book includes a vast array of aesthetic, social, and cultural commentary .
 Antjie Krog, Nosisi Mpolweni, and Kopano Ratele released their investigative collaboration There Was This Goat . The book is based on the 1996 testimony of a mother who lost her son in a massacre .
 Nigerian fiction writer Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie continued her remarkable success with the publication of her debut collection of short stories, The Thing Around Your Neck .
 Australians heralded the publication of David Malouf’s novel Ransom, his first to appear in more than a decade . Malouf's first novel to be published in over a decade has been published in Australia .
 The work revisited Homer’s Iliad and gained widespread praise for its spare prose and imaginative rendering of ancient Greece . The work is set to be released in 2015 .

 Tim Winton and Christos Tsiolkas received international attention in receiving the Miles Franklin Literary Award and the Commonwealth Writers’ Award . Two other Australians garnered international attention for their work .

 Liberian political leader, short-story writer, novelist, essayist, and translator, died in February . Sankawulo, Sr., was Liberian politician, short story writer, author, translator .
 The authors of a number of the major German-language works of 2009 were born in the communist part of Europe during the Cold War .
 Herta Muller was the winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature . Muller won the prize for her work in Germany . Muller's work was published in Germany in 2007 .
 Muller, who came from a German-speaking village in Banat, Rom., had moved to West Germany in 1987 in order to escape repression and censorship under the dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu . Muller was born in a village in the historic region of Banat in Romania .
 Muller’s novel Atemschaukel, published in August, told the story of a young German-speaking Romanian at the end of World War II and his experiences in Soviet labour camp .
 The novel was about a woman who, like the author herself, loses the ability to speak after a stroke and has to relearn language . The novel is about the woman who loses the language of a stroke .
 Schmidt had published several well-received books in the decade before 2002, when a cerebral hemorrhage forced her to go through that very experience . Schmidt suffered from a stroke that left her with a brain injury .
 Du stirbst nicht dealt with the way that language and identity are interwoven . The novel’s protagonist was, like its author, born in East Germany . It also addressed the final years of the dictatorship and German reunification .
 Hungarian-born Terezia Mora published Der einzige Mann auf dem Kontinent . Mora had moved to Berlin at the beginning of the 1990s .
 The novel’s protagonist, Darius Kopp, lives in a synthetic world of computers and office buildings that is no longer connected to the natural world and its rhythms . The novel's protagonist lives in an artificial world that is not connected to nature .
 The novel explored the fragility of contemporary capitalism and the personality structures associated with it . Written by an author who grew up in the brittle world of socialism in Hungary .
 Rainer Merkel’s novel Lichtjahre entfemt dealt with contemporary sexual relationships . The novel was published in 1998 .
 Norbert Scheuer's novel Uberm Rauschen was also an introspective exploration of personal relationships . This time it was between two brothers and their father, who is dead . Scheuer was also exploring personal relationships with his dead father .
 This novel, unlike the novels of Mora and Merkel, showed the interrelationship between humans and nature . The primary activity of its protagonist, Leo Arimond, as well as of his brother and father, is fishing in a country river near his hometown .
 Stephan Thome’s novel Grenzgang also told a provincial story about life in a small village with its rituals, problems, and interactions with city people . The novel also told the story of a provincial village .
 Swiss novelist Urs Widmer published Herr Adamson, a novel about death and its relationship to life . Widmer's novel is about the relationship between death and life .
 When the novel’s protagonist is eight years old, he meets a man named Adamson . Adamson emerged from the world of the dead, having died at the precise moment when the novel's protagonist was born . The novel's main character is eight when he meets Adamson,
 Adamson can be seen only by the novel’s protagonist, and he can be released completely into the land of the dead only when the protagonist himself dies . Adamson is released from Adamson's body only after the protagonist dies in the novel's final chapter .
 The living and the dead are united by bonds that are only separable only by death . All of life is a preparation for dying, and all of the life is preparing for dying .
 The novel is narrated on the day of the protagonist’s death . Logically, the novel is narrating the death of the main character . The novel was published in 2007 .
 Jens Petersen awarded the Ingeborg Bachmann prize in June for his unfinished novel Bis dass der Tod . Petersen was awarded the prize for the unfinished novel in June .
 Like Herr Adamson, this work explored issues of life and death . The novel’s protagonist, Alex, who cares for his terminally ill and comatose girlfriend, considers the possibility of suicide .
 Judith Hermann’s short-story collection Alice addressed the prominence of death in life . Similarly, the short story collection Alice addresses the prominence in life in life.
 The five stories in the book revolve around one main figure, various men in her life, and her attempts to deal with their deaths . The book is published by Simon Cowell, a British publisher .
 Brigitte Kronauer’s novel Zwei schwarze Jdger was a playful self-referential exploration of literature and the way it reflects and enriches life . On a lighter note, Brigitte's novel was a self-reflective exploration of the way literature
 Rita Palka encounters a number of people with unusual histories in her novel . The novel was written by the writer and is set in New York City, New York .
 Lutz Seiler's sombre short-story collection Die Zeitwaage returned to the problem of life in socialist East Germany and its negative impact on human life .
 The year 2009 showed a marked decrease in the number of works of autobiographical fiction, or ""autofiction,"” a genre in which authors novelize their lives and which had reigned over the past decade of French literature .
 The title of one of 2009’s best-selling works, D’autres vies que la mienne, could be viewed as a literary rallying cry . The title is the title of a 2009 best-seller, one of the best-sellers of the year
 Alain Fleischer subverted autofiction in Moi, Sdndor F by treating biography as autobiography . The prizewinning author subverted the idea of autobiography in the novel .
 Fleischer channeled his uncle, who had been killed by the Nazis during deportation . Fleischer opened a new literary frontier where novel, biography, and autobiography meet and one man's past elucidates another's present .
 Agnes Desarthe’s Le Remplagant was a homage to a dead relative . The author believed herself to have inherited her understanding of storytelling as a weapon against resignation and forgetting .
 The decline of autofiction was matched by a resurgence of traditional fiction, particularly in works exploring the close setting of the family .
 In ParisBrest, Tanguy Viel offered the spectacle of a dysfunctional family in which the narrator, Louis, is trapped between his disgraced, bankrupt father, his domineering mother, and his oppressive grandmother . Louis hopes to gain a fortune that Louis wants to gain for
 Louis attempts a rebellion that is doomed from the outset, in a novel that intertwines humour and despair . Wielding two weapons, he has written to expose his family’s foibles and his friendship for a young hoodlum whom his family despises .
 Philippe Djian published Impardonnables, in which a has-been writer lost his wife and one daughter in a car accident . Djian sees his world crumble again when his other daughter disappears . In a similar vein, the celebrated novelist lost his family in a tragic car crash .
 As his quest to find her estranges him from his new family, he begins to worry whether destiny has chosen him as its special victim and whether forgiveness of oneself can ever be anything but an illusion .
 One subgenre of fiction, historical fiction, also saw a revival in the vacuum left by autofiction . Historical fiction saw a particular revival in its place as a subgenre .
 In Des hommes, Laurent Mauvignier described the ramifications of the Algerian War on a group of French men who witnessed unspeakable horrors . The war was the result of a French draft in Algeria .
 The novel begins 40 years after the war, with the men suffering from psychological problems . The novel culminates in a moving flashback describing their experiences in the Algeria of 1960 .
 Pierre Lartigue completed a historical novel just days before his death . He completed the historical novel days before he died . The novel was published by the French author .

 Three of the four main literary prizes were awarded to autofictions in 2013 . Ironically, in a year marked by pure fiction's triumph over autofiction, three of the main prizes were given to autfiction .
 The Prix Medicis went to Haitian Canadian Dany Laferriere’s L’Enigme du retour, in which the author described his homecoming, after decades of political exile, to Haiti .
 Frederic Beigbeder took the opportunity afforded by his infamous 2008 drug bust to reminisce upon his troubled childhood . Frederic was awarded the Prix Renaudot, Un Roman frangais, for his role in the film .
 Gwenaelle Aubry won the Prix Femina for Personne, her portrait in 26 chapters, one for each letter of the alphabet . Aubry's father was a lifelong manic-depressive who in the end died homeless .
 The Prix Goncourt was awarded to Marie NDiaye’s Trois femmes puissantes . The novel is set in three vividly dysfunctional families, set in a dysfunctional family .
 The second, Fanta, is living in France with her failure of a husband, who envies her and suspects her of having an affair with his boss . Fanta's husband is also in France, but he is not happy with her .
 The third, Khady, is a young widow at the mercy of her in-laws, who hate her for not having given her husband a child before his premature death . Khady is the widow of Khady's husband, who died prematurely .
 Khady remains true to herself in a triumph of the human spirit over adversity . Though subjected to the worst humiliations as she attempts to reach France, she remains poignantly true to her .
 Two fiction titles dominated the literary scene in French Canada in 2009 . French Canada's literary scene was dominated by fiction titles .

 The book won not only the Grand Prix du Livre de Montreal but also France's Prix Medicis . The book is published in Canada and France .

 This was Mavrikakis’s breakout book, though, like her earlier works, it featured a dark and brooding atmosphere . This was her breakout work .

 This was the first time that such a work had been considered for a major prize . The work was considered for the prestigious prize for the work .

 Nelly Arcan's suicide at age 36 shocked Quebec society . The suicide of novelist Arcan shocked society . Arcan committed suicide at 36 .
 Sadly, she did not live to see the publication later in the year of her book Paradis, clef en main, ironically a novel that ultimately argued against suicide . Sadly, there was not the publication of her novel Paradis .
 Tiziano Scarpa's novel Stabat mater, recipient of the 2009 Strega Prize, focuses on the impact of Antonio Vivaldi’s innovative music on his contemporaries . The novel was awarded the award for the best novel in Italy .
 16-year-old Cecilia spends nights writing letters to her unknown mother and conversing with a personification of her own death . Cecilia was abandoned at birth and spends her nights writing her letters to unknown mother .
 Cecilia is Vivaldi's most talented pupil at the Ospedale della Pieta in Venice . Cecilia plays the Red Priest's unconventional scores for the Italian opera company .
 She gradually perceives the revolutionary power of music . Shocked at first, she gradually becomes aware of the power of it .
 In her journey of discovery, writing and music eventually coincide and lead her to pursue her freedom . Her music and writing eventually coincide .
 Edith Bruck’s Quanta Stella c’e nel cielo was recipient of the Viareggio-Repaci Prize for fiction . The protagonist, Anita, is also 16 years old, summons the strength to escape from an oppressive reality .
 After surviving the Auschwitz concentration camp, she finds herself in Czechoslovakia, treated as an object by members of her own family, who, like her, are Jewish, living in a precarious condition, in perpetual wait to leave for Palestine .
 Maternity makes her regain control of herself and her body and gives her the courage to rebel . She begins a journey to reach the Promised Land .
 Elena Lowenthal’s Conta le stelle, se puoi is a family saga told in a “counterhistorical” perspective .
 The author imagines that Mussolini died in 1924 of a stroke and that 1938, instead of being the annus horribilis of racial laws in Italy, was the birth of the state of Israel .
 Their hopes to find their own ""promised land"" seem to burn along with Smyrna (now Izmir, Tur) during the terrible fire that devastated that city in 1922 . Their hopes of finding their own "promise land" seem to have been destroyed by the fire .
 Almeno il cappello by Andrea Vitali brings to life the small intrigues, lies, mysteries, quarrels, and quarrels that animate Bellano, a small town on Lake Como .
 The creation of a brass band in the town exposes the protagonists of this endeavour to petty power games between the podesta and the parish .
 Cesarina Vighy’s L’ultima estate, winner of the Campiello Prize for a first novel, is a caustic coming-of-age narrative told by an internal narrator, who coincides with the author, and partially by an omnis
 Shadows from the internal narrators past populate the limited physical and sensorial space in which she has been confined by illness, and these shadows urge her to make them live through her .
 Antonio Scurati's II bambino che sognava la fine del mondo tells a story inspired by the case of alleged pedophilia at a school in Rignano Flaminio, which received enormous media attention in 2007 .
 Through a complex interplay of fiction and nonfiction, autobiographical fiction and autobiography, the author—a media and communications specialist—reflected on the manner in which the media often amplify collective fears, thereby making the distinction between illusion and reality very thin .
 Roberto Saviano continued to write as an act of resistance, in the obstinate belief that truth ""exists in spite of everything” and is to be found in the proliferation of accounts of “microstories” that are often neglected by the media .

 The protagonists of his novel, Zhuravli i karliki, were the real-life 17th-century adventurer Timofey Ankudinov and a fictional contemporary researcher working on a biography of him .
 A second trend in contemporary Russian prose could be distinguished in Roman Senchin’s novel Yeltyshevy, a dark, naturalistic saga of contemporary peasant life . The novel was stylistically reminiscent of the “country prose” of the late Soviet period .
 Andrey Gelasimov’s novel Stepnyye bogi (2008; ""Gods of the Steppe”) occupied an intermediate zone in that landscape . Aleksandr Terekhov's Kamenny most (""The Stone Bridge"") occupied that zone in

 The novel Okolonolya (""Almost Zero"") provoked something of a sensation as much because of its author as because of the content . The novel was written by the author as much as the content of it .
 The work, a satiric look at circles close to government power, was signed by the pseudonymous author Natan Dubovitsky . The work was satiric take on circles of power in Russia .
 Most suspected the real author to be none other than Vladislav Surkov, one of the most influential figures in the current Russian government . Most suspected Surkov was the author of the book .
 In September a heated discussion about the state of Russian publishing broke out when the poet Olga Martynova published a brief article—in German—in a German newspaper . The poet published the article in September .
 The article was anonymously translated into Russian and posted on the influential Russian Web site Openspace . Soon after, the article was anonymous translated into Russia .
 The article argued that Russia’s dominant publishers ignored aesthetically and intellectually complex works in favour of a kind of mishmash of mass market and “serious” literature that was reminiscent of Soviet literary norms . The article was agreed to expand and write in Russian .
 Martynova criticized a number of Russia’s best-known and most popular writers, including Lyudmila Ulitskaya, Dmitry Bykov, Zakhar Prilepin and Vladimir Sorokin .
 The year saw the publication of new books by Igor Bulatovsky, Ilya Kucherov, Dmitry Grigoryev, Natalya Chernykh, Aleksey Porvin, Aleksandr Mironov, and Vadim Mesyats .
 Although most of the authors in this list were representatives of the Petersburg School, their publishers were Moscow-based, which signaled a healthy openness . The Petersburg School is known for its openness, especially its openness .
 Several young poets whose reputation was based exclusively on Internet publication and who had not yet attempted printed publication. Another highlight of the year was the entry into literature of several young poets .
 This group included 20-year-old poets Vera Polozozkova and Alya Kudryashova . This group of poets included the 20,000-year old poets . The group was formed by a group of young women .
 Although neither had yet produced a masterpiece, their work showed promise . The level of professionalism was considerably higher than that of the ‘Web poets of previous years .
 Many writers died during the year, including acclaimed popular prose writer Vasily Aksyonov and 96-year-old Sergey Mikhalkov . The author of both the Soviet national anthem and the new Russian national anthem was also dead .
 Not since end of World War II and Joseph Stalin’s terror had Russian literature lost so many writers in a single year . Not since the end of WWII and Stalin's terror had such many writers have died .

 In turn lower book prices made books more affordable for the general public . That in turn translated into lower book price and lower book sales .
 New writers traditionally published their first work at their own expense . New writers could not afford to publish their work at the expense of publishers .
 Arab writers were generally dissatisfied with aspects of the cultural life in their countries . Arab writers generally complained about aspects of their countries' culture .
 Complaints abounded about censorship, weak distribution of their works, biased award systems, and what many felt was the undue recognition of writers with strong connections to government publishing houses . Complaints of censorship and censorship abounded .
 Arab writers also showed a growing interest in translation, with some questioning both the quality of the books selected by national translation organizations and the intentions of Western publishers .
 Iraqi writer In'am Kajahjl's work echoed the most pressing problems of the region . His work echoed many of the issues in Iraq and Syria .

 The novel explores the contempt Iraqis feel for their Americanized compatriots, whom they consider traitors . The novel revealed the harsh reality in Iraq, where sectarian and religious divisions destroyed a society that prided itself on religious tolerance .

 The novel paints an atmosphere of fear and secrecy in which the characters are pawns, secretly maneuvered and manipulated . Depicting various Islamic groups as being manipulated by the state .
 Libyan writer Ahmad Ibrahim al-Faqlh explored human interactions with animals and insects . He found compassion on the part of animals toward humans and an absence of compassion in humans' relationships among themselves .
 Muhammad al-Bisatl remained close to his society’s problems with his novel Aswar . Aswar is about life in Egypt being akin to life in a prison .
 The story revolves around a chat room that becomes accessible to new members every Friday . The chat room gives young people the opportunity to discuss their problems freely and anonymously .
 Despite awards for poetry, poetry continued to lose readers to fiction, especially the novel . The Foundation of Abdul Aziz al-Babtain presented the most prestigious poetry awards in Arab world .

 Of some 3,000 new Chinese novels published in print in 2009, few found favour with the critics . Few new novels found favour in print with critics .
 Yi ju ding yiwan ju by Liu Zhenyun was one of the few exceptions to the book . Liu's book was written by a well-known writer, though it had a few detractors .
 Composed of 400,000 Chinese characters, the novel told the story of a peasant, Yang Baishun, who leaves his home in Yanjin (also Liu’s home village) after the death of his adopted daughter .
 Niu Jianguo, who had left the village, returns to it with the same strong desire for personal connection . Decades later the daughter’s son returns to the village in search of personal connection with the village .
 The author probingly examined the concept of friendlessness, which differs from what in English is called loneliness . The author attempted to redefine the meaning of friend . Using a fine, delicate narrative style, the book was written in a fine style .

 The most notable event in 2009 for Japanese literature was the publication of Haruki Murakami’s 1Q84 . The most significant event in the literary world was the release of the novel 1Q85 .
 So many people preordered the two-volume novel that it appeared on best-selling lists as soon as it was released in late May . The novel was released on May 1 .
 Murakami and his publisher kept quiet about the content of the book prior to its publication . Public interest in 1Q84 was only increased by the silence of the publisher and the Japanese media .
 Aomame is a 30-year-old woman who works for a secret agent whose aim is to kill those who hurt others . She is driven by a strong memory of Tengo, a childhood friend, and seeks him out .
 Tengo, who teaches school but aspires to be a novelist, in turn seeks her . She is in a relationship with the author of the novel .
 One day he receives a ghostwriting job from a publisher that had rejected his work, and it is that job that brings him close to Aomame . The job brings him to a close relationship with the publisher .
 Murakami's novel's title is intended as a play on Orwell's dystopian 1984 . The English letter Q and the Japanese word for the number 9 are pronounced identically .
 Murakami also stirred controversy by accepting the Jerusalem Prize for the Freedom of the Individual in Society in early 2009, just after the cessation of hostilities between Hamas and Israel in the Gaza Strip in Gaza .
 Murakami insisted that it would be better to attend the ceremony and deliver his speech than to keep silent . Pro-Palestinian groups had asked him to stay silent, but he refused .
 One of the best-selling books of 2009 was Ken’ichiro Isozaki’s Tsui no sumika . The short novel won the first Akutagawa Prize, normally awarded twice a year .
 The selection committee declined to award the year’s second Akutagawa Prize . The committee has declined to give the second prize .

 During the final battle Tiger leader Velupillai Prabhakaran was killed . During the battle he was killed by the Tiger leader .
 UN Security Council unanimously adopted Resolution 1874, tightening an existing arms embargo against North Korea . Resolution tightened arms embargo on North Korea in response to North Korean nuclear tests .
 Pyongyang conducted its second-ever underground nuclear explosion in May . The action occurred after North Korea conducted a second underground nuclear blast . Pyongyang conducted the explosion after a series of underground nuclear tests .
 A treaty establishing Africa as a nuclear-weapon-free zone came into force in July . Burundi became the 28th African country to ratify the treaty . The treaty establishing the zone was ratified in July by Burundu .
 Treaty of Pelindaba prohibited possession, development, manufacture, testing, or deployment of nuclear weapons on the African continent . Treaty also prohibited the possession of weapons in Africa .
 Barack Obama announced the launch of bilateral talks to succeed the 1991 Strategic Arms Reduction Talks treaty . The talks will follow the 1991 treaty that led to the creation of the treaty .
 START I expired in December 2009 without agreement on a successor to START I . Diplomats had been negotiating a new treaty since April . START I expires December 2009 but diplomats are still negotiating a successor .
 Six-year war between Sudan's pro-government forces and rebels in Darfur effectively ended, UN's military commander in the region says . Except for sporadic violence and banditry, the six-year conflict effectively ended last year .
 Since fighting began, an estimated 300,000 people had died in Darfur . A further 2. million had been displaced, according to reports .
 The Democratic Republic of the Congo continued to be plagued by insecurity and violence . The country has been plagued by violence and insecurity .
 More than 1,000 civilians were killed in the east of the country during joint DRC army-UN operations against the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda . The Rwandan rebel group is linked to the Hutu extremists responsible for the genocide of Rwandan Tutsis .
 Forces from the Ugandan Lord's Resistance Army continued to operate in the DRC’s northeast . A joint offensive by Congolese and Ugandan troops forced most of them into neighbouring Central African Republic .
 Islamist groups and warlords fought for control of much of southern Somalia . Islamist groups battled for control in Somalia's southern Somalia for decades .
 After Ethiopia pulled its troops out of the country in January 2009, al-Shabaab began to dominate the struggle . The extremist Islamic group is thought to have links with the terrorist group al-Qaeda . Ethiopia pulled out of Somalia in 2009 .
 There had been no effective government in Somalia since 1991 . The transitional government, backed by the UN and the African Union, controlled only small parts of the capital .
 Only about half of the 8,000 troops authorized for the African Union Mission to Somalia had been deployed by the end of 2009 .
 The president of Honduras was removed from office by the military and forced into exile in June . Manuel Zelaya was ousted by the Honduran military . Zelaya is now living in exile in Honduras .
 Zelaya managed to secure the support of the Organization of American States and to have himself smuggled into the Brazilian embassy in Tegucigalpa . Neither his supporters nor the OAS was able to prevent an interim government from holding elections to decide on Zelaya's successor .
 Mexico deployed thousands of troops along the country’s northern border to stem violence between gangs supplying illegal drugs to the United States . Thousands of troops are deployed along the border to stop the flow of illegal drugs .
 Such violence in Ciudad Juarez resulted in nearly 2,000 drug-related murders in the first 10 months of 2009 . Such violence has resulted in 2,500 drug murders in Juarez, a city of 1. million people .
 Violence in Iraq fell to its lowest level since the U.S.-led invasion in 2003 . Violence has fallen to lowest level in Iraq since the invasion of Iraq .
 Iraqi forces took control of security in Baghdad’s fortified Green Zone . They assumed more authority over foreign troops based in the country . Iraqi forces take control of the Green Zone in Baghdad .
 British combat operations officially ended in April . U.S. troops withdrew from many towns and cities across the country . British troops were withdrawn from many British cities and towns .
 Saudi Arabian forces and Shi'ite Yemeni rebels clashed along the border between the two countries in November and December . Saudi Arabia and Yemen have been at odds with each other for years .
 During 2009 sporadic fighting between Yemeni security forces and rebels resulted in hundreds of casualties . An estimated 150,000 internal refugees were internally displaced from Yemen .
 Russia declared its nearly decade-old ""counterterrorism operation" against separatist rebels in Chechnya to be over in April . In April Russia declared the operation against rebels in the region over .
 In November a Muslim group from the Caucasus set off a bomb that derailed an express passenger train between St. Petersburg and St. Charles . In November, a bomb was set off by a group of Muslim Muslims from Caucasus .
 The war in Afghanistan grew in intensity and spread to the country’s north . The north had been relatively peaceful since the Taliban were overthrown in 2001 . The war has spread to Afghanistan's north .
 At the end of 2009, there were 71,000 troops (about half from the U.S.) from 43 countries contributing to the NATO-led International Security Assistance Force supporting the Afghan government .
 An additional 36,000 U.S. troops not part of ISAF were also in the country . ISAF is based in Afghanistan and Afghanistan .
 Barack Obama announced that more than 30,000 additional troops would be sent to the country . NATO Secretary-General Anders Rasmussen announced that European members would contribute another 7,000 troops .
 The government of Pakistan launched several offensives during 2009 to wrest control from the Taliban and other militants in northwestern tribal districts bordering Afghanistan . The government has been fighting to regain control of the region since 2009 .
 Affairs claimed that hundreds of militants were killed as well as dozens of security force personnel . Independent verification was impossible, but independent verification is impossible .
 The militants responded with attacks on government and civilian targets across Pakistan . Militants responded to the attacks with attacks against government targets .
 The Ion Tiger is a small unmanned aerial vehicle developed by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory . It flew for more than 26 hours in November .
 The UAV set an unofficial endurance record for fuel-cell powered flight . It was the first time the UAV has set a record for a fuel-fueled flight .
 The U.S. Navy commissioned the amphibious assault ship Makin Island . Makin is the first ship to be commissioned by the United States Navy .
 It was the first navy ship to use a combination of gas-turbine engines and electric drive for propulsion to reduce fuel usage and maintenance costs .
 The United States Air Force Research Laboratory in 2009 test-fired two new laser weapons in flight for the first time . The U.S. Air Force tested the weapons in 2009 . The laser weapons were the first to be fired in flight .
 The Advanced Tactical Laser is designed to destroy ground targets up to 20 km (12 mi) away . It was fired from an NC-130H Hercules aircraft . The laser was fired at a target up to 12 miles away .
 The much larger Airborne Laser, designed to shoot down ballistic missiles, was fired from a converted Boeing 747 . Airborne laser was fired in a converted 747 .
 The U.K.’s Ministry of Defence announced that it was fielding a new generation of lightweight textile-based armour . The new armour is designed to protect vehicles against rocket-propelled grenades . It was announced in March that the new generation was being fielded by the MoD
 Named TARIAN, the new armour is deployed on heavy trucks serving with the British army in Afghanistan . Named TarIAN, it is the latest in a long line of armour deployed by the British military in the country .
 India became the sixth country capable of building its own nuclear-powered submarines . China, France, Russia, the U.K., and the United States are the other countries capable of doing so . France rejoined NATO in March after having left it in 1966 .
 Russia announced plans to set up an Arctic Group of Forces to protect its interests in the far north . Russia has announced plans for the group of forces in the Arctic region .

 The group would coordinate activities of the armed forces, border guard, and coast guard . The group is based in New Zealand .

 The force would also offer assistance in recovery from natural disasters . Force would offer assistance to recovery from disasters .

 In the same month, Israel and the U.S. held their largest-ever joint exercise, simulating the defense of Israel against a ballistic-missile attack . The exercise simulates a ballistic missile attack .
 Approximately 30 ships plus aircraft from 17 countries began operating together in January as Combined Task Force 151 . To combat piracy around the Horn of Africa, approximately 30 ships and aircraft from around 17 countries are operating together .
 Turkey enacted new legislation to give civilian courts authority to try military personnel who threaten national security . Civilian courts will be able to try anyone who threatens national security, Turkey says . Turkey enacted legislation to allow courts to try any military personnel .
 The law also prohibited military courts from prosecuting civilians during peacetime . Military courts were also prohibited from prosecuting civilian civilians .
 UN Human Rights Council backed a report that accused both Israel’s armed forces and Palestinian militants of war crimes that occurred during the 2008-09 Israeli offensive in Gaza . The report was backed by a vote of 25-6 by the UN .
 Around 1,300 Palestinians and 10 Israeli soldiers were killed during the fighting . An estimated 1,000 Palestinians were killed in the fighting, including 10 soldiers .
 A Rwandan man convicted of war crimes committed in 1994 was jailed for life by a Canadian court in October . He was sentenced to life in prison in October after a Rwandan war crimes conviction in 1994 .
 Desire Munyaneza, 42, was found guilty in May in the first court case brought under Canada’s Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act . The case is the first brought under the law under the Crimes Against Human Rights Act and War Crime Act .
 In August the United States Air Force established its first numbered air force dedicated to fighting in cyberspace . The U.S. Air Force is the first to establish a dedicated air force for cyberswarfare .
 The 24th Air Force, based in Texas, is comprised of the 688th Information Operations Wing and the 67th Network Warfare Wing .
 The Japanese government relaxed its long-standing self-imposed ban on arms exports to allow more joint development and production of weapons with other countries . The ban was lifted in order to allow joint development, production and development of weapons .
 Exports to countries that sponsor terrorism, violate human rights, or have inadequate controls over arms sales continued to be outlawed . Arms sales to those who sponsor terrorism or violate human human rights were also banned in the United States .
 The number of suicides in 2009 was set to make it the fifth straight year that such deaths had set a record within the U.S. armed forces .
 U.S. Secretary of Defense Robert Gates ordered a high-level review of military policies . The review follows the death of army psychiatrist Maj. Maj. Gen. Michael Lister . Lister is the son of a psychiatrist who died in 2009 .

 A separate review of the way in which intelligence agencies handled information about Hasan before the killings was ordered by Obama .
 Hasan, a devout Muslim, had expressed misgivings to colleagues about the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan . Hasan, Hasan, was shot dead in a hail of bullets . Hasan had expressed his anger at the wars before the shootings .

 A spate of musicals BOOSTED theatre attendance on Broadway, while 3-D FILMS thrilled moviegoers .
 Classical music, literally, took centre stage at inauguration of U.S. President Barack Obama in 2009 .
 Yo-Yo Ma, Itzhak Perlman, Anthony McGill, and Gabriela Montero performed the debut of Air and Simple Gifts, composed for the event by John Williams .
 The performance went off without a hitch, given that it had actually been prerecorded and was mimed at the event by the illustrious musicians . The performance was actually a prerecorded performance .
 When the deception was revealed days later, a controversy began to stir . The deception was not the first time it was revealed to be a hoax .
 Media made references to Milli Vanilli, the infamous lip-syncing pop duo . The media also made reference to the lip-sync duo .
 The furor subsided quickly, however, when it was reported that the cold had prevented a ""live” performance because of the effect low temperatures have on musical instruments .
 Ma and Perlman had put soap on their bows to dull the sound of their instruments so as not to intrude on the recording . The recording was made the previous Sunday at a Marine barracks in Washington .
 It was that sort of year in classical music, when controversies surrounding the music tended to obscure the music itself . It was a year of controversy surrounding classical music .
 Earlier in January, Israeli conductor Daniel Barenboim canceled performances in Doha, Qatar, and Cairo because of security concerns related to the ongoing fighting between Israeli forces and Hamas .
 The concerts were part of the 10th anniversary tour of Barenboim’s West-Eastern Divan Orchestra . The orchestra was composed of young musicians from Israel, Palestine, and Arab countries .
 In March a West Bank children’s orchestra, the Strings of Freedom, was shuttered by local residents after it performed a concert for Holocaust survivors in Israel .
 An official of the Jenin refugee camp accused the orchestras leader of having exploited the children for political purposes . The event was billed as a Good Deeds Day event organized by an Israeli billionaire . An Israeli billionaire also organized the event .
 Polish pianist Krystian Zimerman created a stir of his own when he announced during a performance at the Walt Disney Concert Hall, Los Angeles, that he would no longer perform in the U.S. because of his objection to foreign policy .
 Cuban government blames U.S. restrictions on travel to Cuba for canceling concerts . Cuban government says it is outraged by the cancellation of the concerts .
 Two opera stars who had previously announced their retirement changed their minds . Meanwhile, two opera stars had previously said they were retiring .
 In August, Dame Kiri Te Kanawa, 65, said that her opera career was coming to an end . Dame Kanawa said in August that she was retiring from opera . In August she said that she would retire from singing .
 Neither singer had ruled out future recital appearances . Both subsequently withdrew any plans to quit the world of opera .
 Placido Domingo, 68, made his debut in a baritone role in a production of Giuseppe Verdi's Simon Boccanegra at the Staatsoper in Berlin in October .
 Bayreuth Festival opened with a children's version of Richard Wagner’s The Flying Dutchman . The opera is a perennial source of familial opera .
 Children were even encouraged to participate in the truncated version of the opera, which was the brainchild of new festival co-directors, Eva Wagner-Pasquier and Katharina Wagner .
 The half-sisters took over the reins of the annual Wagner festival from their father, Wolfgang, who had ruled the festival roost for more than half a century . The half sisters, both great-granddaughters of the composer, took over from Wolfgang .
 The new directors also announced a deal with the Royal Opera House’s Opus Arte production company to release the festival's productions on DVD . On August 9 they offered the performance of Tristan und Isolde live live on the Internet .
 As it had often in recent years, classical music continued to embrace the Internet as a way of extending its outreach and influence .
 The service offered online users the ability to search its database by composer, artist, and individual concert programs . The service was launched in 2009 .
 The Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra pursued a more commercial course with its online concert hall . Performances were made available either live or via reruns on the Internet .
 Classical TV, an online streaming video service, was launched in July . Classical TV offers free and pay-per-view opera, ballet and theatre performances .
 Classical TV also presented broadcasts by the English National Opera, the Royal Shakespeare Company, the Zurich Opera, and others . Metropolitan Opera .
 The price of an online viewing was set at $4.99 or $9.99 per performance . Online viewing of the live performances will cost up to $10.99 .
 Twitter was the star of the show in September at London’s Royal Opera House . The online social network phenomenon was the subject of the opera . Twitter is the latest in a long-running series of musicals from the world .
 The company presented The Twitter Opera, with music by composer Helen Porter and a libretto made up of the site’s signature short messages submitted by the public via the @youropera Twitter feed .
 Twitter was also the focus of a concert by the National Symphony Orchestra in July . Twitter also featured in a concert with the orchestra in July by the orchestra .
 The orchestra was made up of 93 musicians who had been selected from some 3,000 audition videos that had been submitted to the Web site from more than 70 countries . The orchestra is based in Los Angeles, California .
 Fifteen million online visitors voted on the winners, who were led in the debut performance by conductor Michael Tilson Thomas .
 Even as the classical world embraced the future, it was confronted by the disturbing economic realities of the present . The classical world was confronted with the disturbing reality of the future .
 Classical orchestras and opera and ballet companies try to weather the economic storm . Americans for the Arts estimated that 10,000 arts organizations would be out of business in 2009 .
 Both the Met and the Los Angeles Opera cut productions from their seasons and cut salaries . The Met and L.A. Opera laid off 17 people in the process . The Los. Angeles Opera also cut production and salaries .
 The Connecticut Opera closed after 67 seasons, as did the Opera Pacific, Santa Ana, Calif., and the Baltimore Opera . The Baltimore Opera declared bankruptcy last year .
 Budgetary problems forced the San Francisco Opera to cancel a production of Peter Grimes and a revival of Puccini's La Boheme . The opera was also forced to cancel an opera revival and a play of La Bohemme .
 The Bolshoi Theatre was forced to cancel a tour of Mexico and the premiere of its new production of Verdi’s Otello . Russia's Bolshoo Theatre cancelled a tour and premiere of the Verdi production .
 Italy's Maggio Musicale Fiorentino called off productions of Verdi’s Macbeth and Britten's Billy Budd that were to have been featured at the Florence festival . Verdi and Billy Budd were to be featured in the festival .
 South Korea particularly felt the impact when tours to that country by the Radio France Philharmonic Orchestra, the Vienna Symphony, and the Cincinnati Symphony were called off .
 The Guarneri String Quartet called it quits in 2009 after 45 years of playing . The legendary Italian quartet has been a soloist for 45 years .
 Three of the group's members had founded the ensemble at Vermont’s Marlboro Music Festival in 1963 and were in their 70s . The ensemble was founded by three members of the ensemble in 1963 .
 Gustavo Dudamel made his debut as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic in October . Dudamel is 28-year-old Venezuelan conductor .
 In October Rattle reaffirmed his commitment to the Berlin Philharmonic . In October he signed a contract to continue as the artistic director through 2018 .
 The 200th anniversary of the birth of composer Felix Mendelssohn was celebrated in the U.S. and Europe this year .
 Two previously unknown works by Mozart were heard for the first time in August . The International Mozarteum Foundation, based in Salzburg, Austria, unveiled them in a performance by pianist Florian Birsak .
 An opera by popular singer-songwriter Rufus Wainwright debuted in July at the Manchester International Festival .
 The work, Prima Donna, was originally commissioned by the Met, but the company withdrew when Wainwright decided to write the libretto in French . The work was originally intended for the Met but was withdrawn by the company .
 The Cunning Little Vixen received its premiere at the Banff Centre in August . Canadian playwright director John Murrell's English libretto for composer Leos Janacek’s opera received its debut in August at the centre .

 The Met presented its 125th Anniversary Gala in March . The Met was one of the most glittering events of the year .
 The fourhour performance included appearances by Roberto Alagna, Angela Gheorghiu, Domingo, Renee Fleming, Dmitry Hvorostovsky, Natalie Dessay, and a host of others .
 Drucker, 80, was not scheduled to play that night and had not performed the piece since the 1950s . Drucker reportedly did not drop a note .
 It was a delightful and unexpected coda to a career that ended with his retirement in 2009 after 60 years with the orchestra .

 The median age of jazz listeners rose to 46, and the number of young jazz musicians declined . The number of jazz musicians in the United States declined .
 Jazz community was especially sensitive to public perceptions of the art form . Classical audiences were older than jazz audiences and had experienced a comparable decline in their numbers .
 Jazz, a fundamentally African American music, was a comparatively young art without the weight of centuries of tradition . It had been generally accepted as a legitimate art form only since the mid-20th century . Jazz is a fundamentally young art .
 There were few significant jazz institutions with resources equal to those of major-city art museums, symphony orchestras, and opera companies .
 The NEA survey reinforced fear that jazz was a gradually disappearing art . Two of the major living jazz artists turned 79 in 2013 .
 The JVC Jazz Festival, to have been held in June, was canceled by its producer, Festival Network . Festival Network had bought the festival in 2007 from founder George Wein .
 Wein, who founded the Newport Jazz Festival in 1954, rescued that and the Newport Folk Festival for 2009 after Rhode Island had canceled Festival Network’s license to operate those two events . Festival Network's license was canceled in 2009 .
 The 39-year-old monthly did suspend activity in June, but a new owner resumed publication with the old editorial staff in July .

 Unknown Scottish vocalist Susan Boyle exploded onto the global stage with breathtaking performances on the television show Britain’s Got Talent .
 A video clip of her rendition of “I Dreamed a Dream” from Les Miserables made her a YouTube sensation . The video clip led to one of the year’s top-selling albums .
 Geoffrey Gurrumul Yunupingu, a blind Aboriginal singer-songwriter from Australia's Arnhem Land, is a blind Australian . The blind Aboriginal artist is known for his songs and Aboriginal dance .
 It was recorded for an independent label in Darwin, Australia, but became a surprise success across the country . It topped the World Music album charts in Britain .
 Gurrumul’s songs attracted an international audience, thanks to his thoughtful and soulful vocals and melodies . His songs echoed Western gospel and folk themes, and his soulful voice was soulful .
 Australian music was buoyed by the Black Arm Band, a collective of Aboriginal and white performers . The multimedia revue highlighted the ""two worlds of Australia” with stories of Aboriginal suffering and survival .
 From Africa there are also unexpected newcomers who moved from poverty and obscurity to playing in major concert halls .
 Staff Benda Bilili are a group of paraplegic polio victims and abandoned children who lived on the grounds surrounding the zoo in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of the Congo . They survived by performing on the streets .
 Tres tres fort won praise for their debut album . They matched rumba Congolese influences and funk with some extraordinary solos by Roger Landu . Landu constructed an instrument that he called the satonge .
 Mali’s Bassekou Kouyate, the virtuoso exponent of the ancient West African lute, the ngoni, released I Speak Fula . It features veteran singer Kasse Mady Diabate and kora star Toumani Diabates
 Maal was joined onstage by U2 for a memorable set of songs . The set included “One Love” written by reggae legend and Blackwell discovery Bob Marley . U2 was joined by Maal for the performance .
 From Latin America there were further reminders that world music artists are becoming increasingly keen to collaborate and experiment . World music artists from Latin America are keen to experiment .
 On the album Nuevos sonidos afro peruanos, their aim was to transform AfroPeruvian styles, making use of rhythm instruments invented by African slaves whose drums had been banned .
 The growing success of global fusion styles was also demonstrated by American producer Mark Johnson with his Playing for Change album .
 Johnson traveled around the world, recording both street musicians and celebrities playing soul standards . He then mixed the results together to create the album .
 She earned her a Grammy Award nomination for record of the year . She also featured prominently on the sound track of Danny Boyle's hit film Shtmdog Millionaire .

 The death of Michael Jackson and the success of Taylor Swift were the top stories of the American popular music year in 2009 . Taylor Swift's success was the top story of the year in the United States .
 Jackson died of drug-induced cardiac arrest on June 25 . American television networks devoted hundreds of hours to remembering and celebrating his legacy .
 In the two and a half weeks following his death, consumers purchased 2. million Jackson albums, guaranteeing that the late “King of Pop"" would be one of the year’s biggestselling artists .
 Swift's album Fearless overtook Jackson’s compilation Number Ones as the year's best-selling album . Jackson further pushed into third place by the debut album of Scottish singer Susan Boyle .
 Swift sold out Madison Square Garden in one minute . Swift saw her song “Love Story’s top charts internationally . Swift has sold out more than 100,000 fans .
 She also became the object of much public sympathy in September when rapper Kanye West grabbed the microphone from her at the MTV Video Music Awards as she was attempting to accept an award for Best Female Video .
 She capped the year with an impressive showing at the Country Music Association awards in November . She swept all four categories in which she was nominated .
 Sales of physical CDs, digital CDs, and what Nielsen SoundScan termed “track-equivalent albums” declined 8.9% from the first half of 2009 . Digital sales slowed from a 30% increase in growth in 2008 to a 13% rise in 2009 .
 The pop-music market was in free fall for much of the year . Despite some aberrations, sales spike in the wake of Jackson’s death and better-than-expected sales of Beatles albums .
 In January Bruce Springsteen performed on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C., singing through the winter chill at the inauguration of United States Pres. Obama .
 In August rock historians marked the 40th anniversary of the Woodstock Music and Art Fair . Rock historians mark Woodstock 40 years ago .

 The centenary of Russian-born arts patron and impresario Serge Diaghilev’s founding of the Ballets Russes dance company gave the year 2009 a cause for focus and reflection .

 Various companies around the United States as well as around the world have acknowledged Diaghilev’s legacy by presenting works from his era and commissioning works to reflect the innovative thrust of the Ballets Russes .
