 The centenary of the first performances of Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes provided the central theme of the European ballet world in 2009 . Several new works as well as commemorative galas, exhibitions, and film shows were launched .
 In Paris the Theatre du Chatelet hosted a season by the Kremlin Ballet from Moscow, with guest appearances by leading dancers from the Bolshoi and Mariinsky companies . In Paris, the Theatre des Champs-Elysees hosted two evenings of documentary films .
 The program followed a pattern also seen in other cities, combining revivals of original ballets by Diaghilev’s great choreographers . The program included a contemporary reworking of Fokine's Thamar choreographed by Jurius Smoriginas .
 The Paris Opera Ballet waited until December to show a program of works by Leonide Massine and Vaslav Nijinsky . The program included two works by Fokine and Massine .
 John Neumeier’s Hamburg Ballet presented a ballet about Nijinsky, Vaslav, and his own version of Le Pavilion d’Armide . The Hamburg ballet was part of an international gala in October .
 Le Pavilion d’Armide had formed part of the historic debut of Ballets Russes on May 18, 1909 . With its original choreography by Fokine, it had been choreographed by the original choreographer .
 The Hamburg company had already shown a tribute program in its home theatre . The Bavarian State Ballet in Munich, the Rome Opera Ballet, and many others had also shown tribute programs .
 In London the Royal Ballet introduced Sensorium, a new piece by house choreographer Alastair Marriott, into a program otherwise by Fokine . Sensorium is the work of the Ballet's choreographer and choreographer .
 English National Ballet with Faun and Scottish Ballet showed reworkings of Nijinsky’s L'Apres-midi d'un faune .
 ENB’s two Ballets Russes programs brought them some very respectful reviews . Karl Lagerfeld's new costume design for Fokine's The Dying Swan received some publicity .
 Celebrating the present rather than the past, there was new work to be seen in many European theatres . New work was shown in many theatres across Europe .
 The Royal Ballet used its smaller theatre for a new work based on Bach’s Goldberg Variations . The work was choreographed by Kim Brandstrup in close collaboration with principal dancer, Tamara Rojo .
 The major revival of the Royal Ballet’s season was a cut-down version of Kenneth MacMillan's 1981 two-act ballet, Isadora, based on the life of dancer Isadora Duncan . The major revival of the season was the cut-

 Elsewhere in the UK, two companies celebrated their 40th anniversaries . Elsewhere, two of the UK's biggest companies celebrated 40 years .
 The ballets return to the repertory was especially welcome for the memories it evoked of the former company director Christopher Gable, who had created the leading role .
 Scottish Ballet continued its rise in public and critical estimation in its 40th year of existence . Ballet introduced Frederick Ashton's Scenes de Ballet and William Forsythes Workwithinwork to its repertory .
 In France the Paris Opera Ballet gave its first performances of John Cranko’s Onegin . The piece is widely performed elsewhere in Europe .
 The Royal Danish Ballet's year included a visit to Japan, a Jerome Robbins evening featuring the company premieres of Dances at a Gathering and West Side Story Suite, and a Balanchine triple bill including another first for the RDB .

 At the beginning of the year, Yury Burlaka succeeded Aleksey Ratmansky as director of the Bolshoi Ballet . Yury Burlaka  succeeded Ratmansky in January .
 In March, Maria Aleksandrova and Ruslan Skvortsov danced the leading roles on the first night of Sergey Vikharev's reconstruction of Coppelia . In December, Burlaka programed his own new production of La Esmeralda .
 The Bolshoi Theatre's rebuilding project continues to be disrupted by delays . In between, the company toured the U.S. and Spain, while at home the rebuilding project was disrupted .
 The theatre had closed in 2005 and was due to reopen in 2009 . The expected date of reopening was pushed back to 2013 amid reports that the original budget had been overspent .
 The Mariinsky Ballet also toured the U.S. in August . In August the company was in London for two weeks, selling well at the Royal Opera House .
 Opening night devoted to Leonid Lavrovsky’s 1940 version of Romeo and Juliet . Alina Somova making her debut in the leading role . Vladimir Shklyarov had a big success .
 Leonid Yakobson’s Tatar-inspired Shurale was revived in a revival of the original . The White Nights Festival was held in St. Petersburg .
 Leading the cast were Yevgeniya Obraztsova, Aleksandr Sergeyev, and Denis Matvienko . Leading the play was Aleksander Sergeyev and Aleksandra Matvin .
 Legris was chosen to take over as artistic director of the Vienna State Opera Ballet in 2010 . Schandorff moved into a backstage role in Copenhagen . Oaks and Oaks returned to Estonia, where Edur took over as the National Ballet's artistic director .
 The year was marked by the sudden death of choreographer Pina Bausch . She was one of the giants of the dancetheatre movement .
 Her company, Tanztheater Wuppertal, continued with the touring schedule that it had already planned, but there was no announcement about the company’s long-term future .
 Other losses during the year included those of Danish dancer, director, and choreographer Flemming Flindt, ballerinas Ekaterina Maximova and Eva Evdokimova . Two leading male dancers, Andre Prokovsky and David Ashmole, also lost .
 Money itself and the collapse of the world markets became the hot topic of the year in plays by 10 new writers at the small Soho Theatre under the group title Everything Must Go . The group of 10 new plays were created by 10 writers .
 Enron, an epic satiric drama of that company's demise, is produced by Rupert Goold’s touring company, Headlong . It will be staged at the Chichester Festival Theatre and the Royal Court Theatre .
 Samuel West’s outstanding portrayal of Enron's disgraced president, Jeffrey Skilling, assumes the tragic heft of a Shakespearean hero . The play seemed even more timely in its skillful anatomization of the financial shenanigans in the fantasy world of projected profits .
 David Hare’s The Power of Yes is at the National Theatre in an attempt to break through the protective attitude of the bankers . The financial crisis was explored more broadly in the playwright's play .
 Hare spent an intense period of research on his play, and it attracted enormous interest . Hare said in rescuing the banks the British government was replacing capitalism with socialism that bailed out the rich alone .
 The theatre seemed to be catching the mood of the country all year . Big, important plays appeared in rapid succession across the London stages .
 Jez Butterworth returned to the theatre after a long absence with two new plays . Parlour Song and Jerusalem are both new works . Butterworth returns to theatre after long absence from theatre .
 The two were both directed by Ian Rickson and suggested that nature would take revenge on suburban town dwellers .

 The other big play of the year was Simon Stephens's Punk Rock at the Lyric Hammersmith . It was a scintillating comedy of high-school classroom anxieties and friendship culminating in a terrible tragedy .
 The echoes of the Columbine High School massacre were the least of the play's strengths . Spring Awakening covered ground similar to many British plays such as Another Country and Alan Bennett's The History Boys .
 Stephens was a unique and increasingly powerful voice on the British stage . The vigour and perceptiveness of his dialogue as well as the brilliance of the acting in the . cast of mostly unknowns ensured against cliche and banality .

 The latter, which used the old Ted Hughes translation, was directed by Nicholas Hytner and set the action on a sunbaked Mediterranean design by Bob Crowley .
 At year's end, Hytner was awarded a Knighthood in the New Year’s honours list . He was awarded the knighthood at the end of 2013 .
 Phedre was the first NT production to be screened live, as performed onstage, in Britain and abroad . It was the latest move by Hytner to sustain as wide a wide a public interest in the work .
 His own production of Richard Bean’s England People Very Nice was a cartoon resume of immigration to Britain, flaring in a public row over the Muslim section . Antiracism campaigners led the first onstage demonstration of NT's history .
 The theatre stood firm in its commitment to the play, and the furor soon abated . The theatre was forced to stage a play at the end of the play .

 Nunn directed Kevin Spacey and David Troughton in a revival of Inherit the Wind at the Old Vic . Nunn has directed the show for the first time since his directing debut .
 Spacey’s Old Vic also celebrated the 80th birthday of Brian Friel with a gorgeous in-the-round production of Dancing at Lughnasa . Friel was further represented at the Edinburgh International Festival in a trilogy of plays from the Gate Theatre in Dublin .

 Other losses were the actors Dilys Laye, Edward Judd, Harry Towb, and Iain Cuthbertson . The playwrights Tom McGrath and Mike Stott also lost their roles .
 Broadway racked up record profits in 2009 while nonprofit regional theatres coped with shrinking resources, cutbacks, and even closures .
 Some arts pundits speculated that hard times fueled the impulse for escapist entertainment . The bottom-line success of these musicals gave some credence to their thesis .
 Broadway’s sheen was enhanced as well by an eye-catching sales installation . The $19 million TKTS Discount Booth opened in late 2008 on the triangular patch of Times Square in 2008 .
 The booth's ruby-red, 27-stair glass-step design won awards and approbation from the ticket-buying public . The booth won't be available again until 2015 .
 Theatre organizations both large and small watched donations from foundations and corporations shrink or run dry . All-important individual contributions dwindled as well as individual contributions .
 Some major companies have cut staffs and shortened seasons to make ends meet . Some major sports teams have been forced to cut jobs to save money .
 Despite hard times, a spate of newly created and innovatively improved theatre spaces sprang up in the United States during the year .
 Dallas Theater Center moved out of its longtime home designed by Frank Lloyd Wright into a new $354 million performing-arts complex . Ford's Theatre and Museum in Washington, D.C., sported a glistening renovation .
 Lynn Nottage’s Ruined, a humanist expose about the brutalization of women in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, was coproduced by the Manhattan Theatre Club and Chicago's Goodman Theatre . Nottage's play is about a decade of conflict in the Congo .
 Coming Home and Have You Seen Us? a pair of new works by 77-year-old playwright and activist Athol Fugard were both mounted during 2009 by director Gordon Edelstein at New Haven, Conn.’s .
 Sarah Ruhl’s In the Next Room is a sly meditation on Victorian-era relationships and gadgets for women's health . The show moved to Broadway from California's Berkeley Repertory Theatre from California .
 Berkeley company was also the source of a muchtalked-about musical, American Idiot, adapted from a 2004 multiplatinum album by the pop-punk trio Green Day .
 The unusual project, despite mixed critical response, was likely to have a rich future life on American stages .

 Among the major theatre figures moving into new jobs in 2009 were high profile director Mark Lamos and manager Michael Ross . Angels in America director George C Wolfe was hired to help design a museum in Atlanta, slated to open in 2012 as the Center for Civil & Human Rights .
 Bartlett Sher announced that Kate Whoriskey would succeed him as artistic director of Seattle’s Intiman Theatre in 2011 . Sher is at the top of his game thanks to such successes as Lincoln Center Theater's South Pacific revival . Sher: Kate will succeed him in 2011 as artistic
 Kate Warner (formerly of Dad's Garage Theatre Company) and Raelle Myrick-Hodges (the founder of Philadelphia’s Azuka Theatre) took over Massachusetts's New Repertory Theatre and San Francisco's Brava Theater Center .
 Playwright Marsha Norman took up the torch of gender equality in an essay in the November issue of American Theatre magazine .
 Canada’s legitimate theatre scene attempted to hold itself together in the face of canceled shows, soft sales, and slashed prices . The impact of a bleak economy was felt north of the border .
 Buddies in Bad Times, a 30-year-old nonprofit devoted to gay themes and artists, scotched its final mainstage show of the 2008-09 season . The nonprofit was founded in Toronto, Canada, in 1987 .
 Reports leaked out that total sales amounted to only about a third of the seating capacity . Avatar is a science fiction comedy by Morris Panych .
 Even highly publicized commercial musicals were belt-tightening . David Mirvish's Dirty Dancing and the Queen songfest We Will Rock You were hawking reduced-price seats .
 Stratford Shakespeare and Shaw festivals suffered from stalled tourism . Strong reviews and a government marketing initiative helped avert big losses .
 Horton Foote, Tharon Musser, Augusto Boal and Karl Malden among theatre figures who died in 2009 . Horton's Orphan Home Cycle premiered posthumously . Tharon's lighting designer and Brazilian dramatist Boal also died .
 Other losses include playwright Lynne Alvarez, designer Ursula Belden, historian and poet Stefan Brecht, and iconoclastic director Tom O’Horgan .

 Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince was made in England . The film was based on the Harry Potter books .

 Based on the novel “Push” by Sapphire also attracted much attention for its unsparing yet tender story of a pregnant Harlem teenager, an abject victim of parental abuse .

 From Australia, Sarah Watt pondered on the travails of a Melbourne mother recovering from a serious illness in the funny and affecting My Year Without Sex . She ponders on a Melbourne woman's struggle to cope with her illness .

 La teta asustada (The Milk of Sorrow) is Claudia Llosa’s sober but vividly realized drama about a Peruvian housemaid so afraid of being raped that she blocks access to her vagina with a potato .
 The most spectacular Spanish film was Alejandro Amenabar’s Agora (Mists of Time), an emotionally cool but visually succulent epic about love and conflicting beliefs in 4th-century Alexandria .

 In 2009 there was a surge in research on graphene, an atomthick layer of carbon atoms tightly arranged in a honeycomb structure . Graphene is an atom thick layer of graphene that is tightly arranged .
 The exceptional mechanical, structural, and electronic properties of graphene had propelled this form of carbon to the forefront of academic and commercial materials research . Graphene is a type of carbon material that has been used in commercial and industrial applications .
 Graphene conducted electrons faster than any other material at room temperature . Material had great strength and stiffness, stiffness, strength and strength . At room temperature it conducted electrons at faster than other material .
 Crystals of the form of graphite known as graphite had long been described as being composed of multiple layers of graphene . Carbon nanotubes and buckyballs were seen essentially as rolled-up forms and spherical enclosures of graphene, respectively .
 The team had succeeded in isolating graphene by turning to a rudimentary method . The team stuck small specks of graphite onto adhesive tape on adhesive tape .
 In 2009 scientists reported many advances in graphene synthesis, including methods of forming graphene strips by “unzipping” carbon nanotubes chemically and physically .
 Scientists also reported advances in the development of graphene applications, including electrically conductive coatings and polymer composites, ultracapacitors, nanoscale field-effect transistors and ultrafast photodetectors .
 In June 2009 the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry officially recognized a group of scientists led by Sigurd Hofmann of the Institute for Heavy Ion Research in Darmstadt, Ger., as the first to have produced nuclei of element 112 . Hofmann led the group to the Institute
 The research group chose the name copemicium and symbol Cp in honour of Polish astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus . The IUPAC was expected to approve the new name and symbol in early 2010 .
 The Lawrence Berkeley group used high-velocity ions of calcium to bombard a target containing plutonium . The bomb was used to target a target with plutonium .
 Such unfavourable statistics made it especially challenging, yet critically important, to independently confirm heavyelement synthesis results . Heavyelement synthesis synthesis results are especially important to confirm .
 Substances on aromatic rings such as benzene guides incoming substituents to specific ring positions . According to the classic textbook formulation of electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions, the presence of substitutionuents on the aromatic rings guides incoming substitutes to specific rings .
 Amines direct newly arriving reactants to the ortho and para positions (one and three carbon atoms away from the amine group, respectively) on the ring . Amines and other electrondonating groups, such as amine, are electrified by electrifying groups . Amined
 It appeared that these organic-chemistry rules might need to be qualified, however .
 Unusual reaction might lead to new syntheses for valuable products such as pharmaceuticals . The unconventional reaction might be used to synthesise valuable products .
 Study of proteins inside their native cellular environment could provide key insights into the biological mechanisms of diseases . The study of proteins in their native cells could provide insights into disease mechanisms .
 In-cell nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy held promise for carrying out detailed intracellular studies of proteins . Method's application had been limited mainly to probing in-cell protein conformations, dynamic motions, and binding interactions .
 Structure of metal-binding protein TTHA1718 found in bacterial cells differs from structure in vitro . Structure of the protein in vitro is subtle, scientists say .
 The method was previously limited to the study of prokaryotic cells that had been customized to express isotopelabeled proteins at elevated levels for NMR analysis .
 Researchers boosted the time resolution of electron energy loss spectroscopy by a factor of 10 billion . They also pushed the spatial resolution of the technique to the single-atom limit .
 EELS, often used in conjunction with transmission electron microscopy, could be used to reveal the chemical identity of a specimen by measuring element-specific decreases in beam energy caused by interactions between an electron beam and atoms .
 EELS signals were typically recorded on the millisecond scale, but can now be measured with femtosecond resolution . The new method was developed by Ahmed H Zewail and co-workers at the California Institute of Technology .
 Group mapped changes in real time in the chemical bonding and electron distribution of a graphite crystal as it was momentarily compressed by a laser pulse into a diamond crystal .
 In another study a team headed by Kazu Suenaga of Japan’s National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology showed that by finely focusing a TEM beam with devices known as aberration correctors, they were able to pinpoint the location and chemical identity of single impurity
 Converting the chemical building blocks of plant matter into fuels and other useful substances could help alleviate the problems of a dwindling supply of available petroleum resources .
 Major research efforts into green chemistry had largely focused on producing ethanol and other liquid transportation fuels .
 HMF could readily be transformed into various products typically made from petroleum, including solvents, fuels, and monomers for polymer production . Referred to as a platform chemical, HMF is often transformed into other products made of petroleum, such as solants and fuels .
 Research in biomass field was moving in that direction . Methods for converting raw lignocellulose to HMF or other finished chemical products had not yet been demonstrated .
 In the early part of the year, Z Conrad Zhang and co-workers at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, Wash., reported devising a single-step method of making HMF directly from cellulose .
 The conversion was driven by a combination of copper chloride and chromium chloride dissolved in an imidazolium ionic liquid . The conversion is a mixture of copper, chromium and copper chloride .
 The catalytic mixture operated under mild conditions and rapidly depolymerized cellulose . The process is the main bottleneck in the development of a commercial process for the conversion of cellulosic biomass .
 The production of millions of tons of hydrogen peroxide (an oxidizer used as a disinfectant and bleach) each year depended on an indirect chemical process that was based on the sequential hydrogenation and oxidation of organic compounds .
 The direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen would be simpler and potentially less expensive . But it was not employed for the production of bulk quantities of the oxidizer because the catalysts known to drive such a reaction also catalyzed the decomposition of the hydrogen peroxoxox
 The group showed that a goldpalladium alloy catalyst supported on a carbon film pretreated with acid avoided decomposition .
 The team explained that their preparation method formed catalyst particles that were very small (less than 10 nanometres in diameter) and well dispersed .
 The particles guided hydrogen peroxide synthesis selectively and shut down the decomposition pathway . As a result of the particles, the particles guided the synthesis selectively .
 A new generation of logic circuits would be needed for the next generation of computer systems . Physicists focused much work in 2009 on “quantum dots,” tiny collections of atoms that function together as a single atom .
 Spin of a single electron trapped inside a quantum dot can act as a binary digit to store information . For example, the spin of an electron trapped in an electron can be used to store a single binary digit . A quantum dot has been used in quantum computing for decades .
 The information is unfortunately degraded by interactions with the nuclear spins of the atoms that make up the lattice . The information has to be degraded by interaction with the atoms in the surrounding lattices .
 These assemblies can work at room temperature and use very little energy . They can also be used to store energy-efficient devices .
 If electronic systems are going to be built that are nanometres in size, the pieces of those systems will be the size of molecules . The pieces of electronic systems will likely be the sizes of molecules, the researchers say .
 Previously, switching in single-molecule junctions was produced by changing the shape or the charge of the molecule . Now, switching is produced by making the shape of the molecules change or changing the charge .
 Su Ying Quek and co-workers at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Berkeley, Calif., demonstrated switching in a single-molecule junction by merely stretching and compressing the molecule .
 The way in which electrons are transported in semiconductors is determined by the gap between the valence and the conduction energy bands . The gap in the gap means electrons can be transported by electrons travelling through a semiconductor .
 If this bandgap could be tuned, particularly with an external electric field, the design of devices with semiconductors would be much easier .
 Microchips that use light instead of electrons could outperform electronic counterparts . Microchip chips could outperach their electronic counterparts in the future .
 Photonic crystals are periodically arranged structures designed to confine light on subwavelength scales . They could also provide a way to guide light through an optical microchip without losing any of the light’s energy .
 J Hwang and co-workers at the Institute of Technology, Zurich used a single dye molecule as an optical transistor .
 Optical transistor could also be used to manipulate individual photons . An optical transistor of this size could be used in manipulating photons .
 In traditional photoconductors, impinging light causes conductivity to increase . Impinging light makes conductivity increase . In traditional photgraphics, the light impinging on light increases conductivity .
 The interaction between light and matter would be at the heart of any light-based device . Light-based devices could be used in the next generation of devices .
 This demonstrated that several unusual light-matter phenomena could now be tested experimentally . The study was carried out at the University of Cambridge, England .
 Devices that control light with frequencies between 0.0. and 5 THz could be useful in many areas, such as medical imaging, astronomy, and security .
 Y Chassagneux and colleagues at the Universite de Paris-Sud and Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Orsay, France, built electrically pumped lasers that operate between 2.55 and 2.88 THz .
 Devices that can effectively manipulate THz radiation require substantial development . Nevertheless, devices that can . effectively manipulate . radiation require significant development .
 A promising step was made when a two-dimensional device controlled the phase of THz radiation over a narrow frequency band . The device was developed at Los Alamos National Laboratory .
 The device could also modulate THz radiation over a broad frequency band . Alternatively, the device could be modulated over a wide frequency range .
 For the first time, the detailed chemical structure of a single molecule, pentacene, was imaged . The detailed structure of the single molecule was also imaged in a new study .
 An atomic force microscope acts like a tiny tuning fork, with one of the prongs passing incredibly close to the sample . This was accomplished by Leo Gross and colleagues at IBM Research, Zurich .
 When the fork is set vibrating, the prong nearest the sample experiences a minuscule shift in frequency that depends on the molecule’s structure . The prong closest to the sample is vibrating at a very low frequency .
 Understanding structure on the molecular scale could help in the design of drugs and electronics . Understanding structure could help the design and manufacture of electronics .
 Molecules in gases and liquids are always moving, thanks to their thermal energy . Molecules always move thanks to the thermal energy of heat .
 Albert Stolow of the Steacie Institute for Molecular Sciences, Ottawa, and his colleagues did this to a carbon disulphide molecule .
 A Ravasio and co-workers at the Centre d'Etudes de Saclay, France, reported a different method for obtaining images of objects nanometres in size .
 A 20-femtosecond pulse of X-rays generated a diffraction pattern when shone on such an object . The pattern was created by a beam of light that shone on the object .
 Entanglement could someday form the basis of quantum information networks . The concept of entanglement, where two spatially separated systems may have instantaneous correlations, could be the basis for quantum networks .
 These networks would require buffers to control how data moves through such a network . Such networks would need to be controlled by buffers, such as buffers .
 Such buffers would also need to store “quantum images”—that is, pairs of images that are entangled . Such buffers could be used to store single ""quantum bits” and ‘quantum image’
 To be able to control the flow of the quantum image through such a system would mean that one of the images would be slowed down with respect to the other .
 The interaction between the two qubits allowed highly entangled states between them to be created . Highly entangled states were created .
 Much work remained on increasing the power and performance of quantum processors . Despite this success, much work remained to increase the power of the processors .
 Jost’s group at the National Institute of Standards and Technology, Boulder, Colo., took a different approach to entangled states . Jost says entangled states are a form of quantum computing that could be used in the future .
 They took two magnesium-beryllium ion pairs held in different locations and entangled their mechanical vibrational states . The study was published in the journal Astrophysics .
 The researchers entangle the internal states of the beryllium ion with the oscillations of the other ion pair . They also were able to entangle . The study was published in the journal Astrophysics journal Nature Resolutions .
 This work pointed the way for possible future experiments in which the effects of quantum mechanics might be observable in systems larger than the microscopic .
 Pascal Bohi and co-workers cooled rubidium atoms to near absolute zero to form a Bose-Einstein condensation . The state of matter coalesced into a single quantum mechanical entity .
 They were able to entangle the internal atomic states of the atoms, as well as the states relating to their motion . The study was published in The Astronomer's book, The Sun, on Thursday, at 8.30pm .
 This work could lead to future quantum computer systems in which many atoms are entangled . It could also lead to the creation of quantum computers with entangled atoms .
 The Casimir-Lifshitz force exists between two uncharged perfectly conducting plates because of quantum fluctuations, quantum fluctuations . Quantum fluctuations, random tiny amounts of energy, that exist even in a vacuum electromagnetic field .
 For all systems studied experimentally prior to 2009, the C-L force was attractive . The force was found to be attractive for all systems .
 Physicists placed fresh limits on the mass of the Higgs boson . The hypothetical carrier particle is thought to confer mass on other matter . It is the theoretical carrier particle of Higgs field that was thought to give mass to others .
 2009 was designated the International Year of Astronomy by the astronomical community’s professional societies, including the International Astronomical Union . 2009 marked the 400th anniversary of the use of the telescope for astronomical observations .
 The Hubble Space Telescope was repaired in May and then took some of the sharpest images to date of a wide variety of astronomical objects . The telescope's sharpest image was taken in May after it was repaired .
 The year also witnessed the launch of and the first observations with a variety of other space-based astronomical instruments . NASA’s Kepler satellite to search for habitable planets orbiting other stars was launched in 2013 .
 New searches for water on the Moon were conducted in 2009, in part because of proposals to have future astronauts spend long periods of time there . New searches have been conducted since 2009 .
 Astronomers are looking through older space-mission data for evidence of lunar water . This interest also spurred astronomers to look through older data for signs of water on the moon .
 In September it was announced that three different space probes had detected small amounts of water on widespread areas of the surface .
 India's Chandrayaan-1 spacecraft carried NASA’s Moon Mineralogy Mapper and operated in 2008-09 . India's space probe was launched in 2008 and 2009 .
 Scientists analyzing new data from NASA’s Deep Impact/EPOXI probe and 10-year-old data from Cassini spacecraft also found evidence of small amounts of water on the Moon . Scientists analyzing data from Deep Impact and Cassini probes also found signs of surface water .
 The most likely place on the Moon to find extensive quantities of water was thought to be in craters on the far side . Most likely place to find water on the moon is thought to have been craters .
 Water might exist there in the form of ice, since it would be protected from direct exposure to the intense solar radiation . Water could exist in ice, protected from the intense radiation, scientists say .
 In October NASA’s Lunar Crater Observation and Sensing Satellite sent the upper stage of its launch rocket to crash into a crater called Cabeus . The crater lies near the Moon's south pole .
 Nine instruments aboard LCROSS recorded a great deal of data about the impact itself and about the gas and dust kicked up by the collision . The impact produced a small crater some 28 m across and produced a large crater .
 Near the year's end, scientists reported that they had found strong evidence for the presence of significant amounts of water in the material Earth Perihelion .

 Sun, annular , visible along a path beginning in central Africa; extending across eastern Africa, the Indian Ocean, southernmost India, and Myanmar; and ending in eastern China . A partial phase visible in Africa (except the western and southern parts) .
 Sun, total , visible along a path beginning in the southern Pacific Ocean and extending to southernmost Chile and Argentina . Part of the path visible in the Pacific Ocean, with a partial phase visible in southern South America .
 Moon, total , the beginning visible in Europe, western Africa, most of the Atlantic Ocean, North and South America, and the eastern Pacific Ocean . The end visible in the northwestern Atlantic, North America, South America and the Pacific .
 The blue shows the presence of water and hydroxyl molecules excavated from the permanently shadowed lunar impact crater . This is the first time water has been excavated into a lunar crater .
 Another interesting impact within the solar system occurred at the giant gas planet Jupiter . The impact occurred at Jupiter .
 A temporary new atmospheric feature, a debris plume that was the result of an astronomical objects having collided with the planet, was found in Jupiter’s south polar region .
 Australian amateur astronomer Anthony Wesley reported first seeing it on July 19 . Wesley said it was the first time he had seen it .
 Hubble Space Telescope snapped the highest-resolution image yet taken of such an evolving Jovian debris plume . Four days later the revamped Hubble Space telescope snapped the image four days later . The image is the highest resolution ever taken by the Hubble Space Observatory .
 The event could have been caused by either an asteroid or a comet of perhaps several hundred metres across . It could be caused by a comet or asteroid of perhaps hundreds of metres .
 Jupiter sustained a series of hits by debris from the breakup of Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9, which produced many temporary features in the dense Jovian atmosphere . By way of comparison, 15 years earlier, Jupiter had sustained a more massive series of hit by debris .
 These two sightings suggest that solar system impacts are more common than had been previously thought . Together, these two sightings suggested that such solar system impact is more common .
 Since these planets are so dim compared with the stars they orbit, they were very difficult to detect directly . The planets were so dim that they were difficult to see directly .
 Astronomers had found nearly all the known exoplanets by using a variety of indirect means . The most effective was to look for changes in the motion of a star along its line of sight, indicating the presence of orbiting planets .
 The method was used by a group of European astronomers led by Michel Mayor of the Geneva Observatory to detect 32 new exoplanets . It was used to find 32 new planets .
 The discoveries were made with an instrument called the High Accuracy Radial Velocity Planet Searcher . The instrument is attached to the 3.6-m telescope of the European Southern Observatory .
 It was capable of detecting stellar motions as small as 3. km/hr , about the speed of a person walking . It was able to detect stellar motions small enough to reach speeds of 3.km/hr .
 This indicated astronomers were not far from being able to detect planets of about the same mass as Earth . This indicated that astronomers could detect planets that are similar mass to Earth . Astronomers are now close to detecting planets of such mass .
 The object designated CoRoT-7b was discovered in 2009 . It is the most intriguing exoplanet discovery in the history of planet Earth .
 It was the most likely of the known exoplanets to be a solid, rocky body like Earth . The planet is the closest to Earth and is most likely to have a rocky planet .
 Didier Queloz and colleagues from the Geneva Observatory reported that the planet probably has a silicate mantle and an iron core similar to Earth's . The planet is likely to have a silicated mantle and a similar iron core .
 The exoplanet’s orbit is tilted about 77° with respect to the spin axis of its host star, however, which is much different from Earth‘s orbit around the Sun . The planet's orbit around its star is tilted 77°, much different than Earth�
 This planet was found to orbit its star at a distance far less than that between Mercury and the Sun . Unfortunately for the search for life on exoplanets, this planet was not found to have life .
 This meant that liquid water could not exist on the surface of CoRoT-7b, so the possibility of its harbouring life as known on Earth was highly unlikely . Liquid water was found to be extremely low in the solar system .
 Throughout 2009, astronomers reported the detection of a wide range of astronomical objects with the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope . Astronomers have detected a range of objects using the telescope's Gamma-Ray telescope .
 16 previously unknown pulsars have been found on the basis of their gamma-ray emissions . The discovery of 16 new pulsars was the first to find pulsars in existence .
 Thirteen of the detected pulsars coincided with previously detected gamma-ray sources that had not been known to be pulsars . Thirteen such sources have been found in the past .
 Of the 1,800 pulsars discovered to date, the vast majority had been identified first by radio telescopes . The vast majority of pulsars often have gamma-ray luminosity that exceeds their radio power by orders of magnitude .
 Gamma-ray bursts are flashes of gamma rays that last from fractions of a second to minutes . For 40 years, gamma-ray burst bursts had been detected coming from directions all over the globe .
 They were thought to accompany the deaths of massive stars in giant supernova explosions . They are thought to have occurred in supernova supernovations .
 Gamma rays emitted in GRBs are beamed into small solid angles, so they can be detected at great distances . GRBs emit gamma rays that can detect gamma rays at great distance .
 On April 23 NASA’s Swift satellite identified such a burst of gamma rays, now called GRB 090423 for the date of the event . The event is now known as GRB090423 .
 It lasted for about 10 seconds and originated in the direction of the constellation Leo . It originated from the constellation of Leo .
 Ground-based telescopes in Hawaii and Chile determined that this GRB had come from a supernova in a galaxy with a redshift of 8.2, which indicated that it was very distant . GRB was found to be from a galaxy in which it was supernova .
 GRB provided direct evidence that stars had already formed not very long after the big bang . Detection of this GRB provides direct evidence of the formation of stars .
 Gamma-ray observations of 21 very distant galaxies were made with the Hubble Space Telescope's new Wide Field Camera 3 . Infrared observations were made using the telescope's new wide field camera 3 .
 GRB 090423 suggested that galaxies probably did not form at very much earlier times than suggested by GRB090423 . The discovery suggests galaxies probably formed very early in the history of galaxies .
 The colours of the 21 galaxies indicated that they lie between 12. billion and 13.01 billion light-years from Earth . The 21 galaxies lie in between 12 and 13 billion light years from Earth, according to Nasa .
 Galaxy formation was just beginning, but was happening quite rapidly, early in the history of the universe . Taken together, all these observations suggested that galaxy formation was beginning, very early .
 The major issue in manned spaceflight in 2009 was the outcome of hearings on the future of the U.S. space program . In 2009, the major issue was the fate of manned space flight .
 The Review of United States Human Spaceflight Plans Committee, known as the Augustine Commission, was appointed by Pres. Norman Augustine . The Augustine Commission was named after its chairman, Norman Augustine, after his chairman .
 It was chartered to review the future of the United States in space . Former president George W Bush’s plans to return to the Moon and continue to Mars .
 The commission concluded that NASA’s human spaceflight program was “at a tipping point” The commission said the program is at a “tipping point,” primarily due to a mismatch of goals and resources .
 Manned missions in 2009 brought the International Space Station closer to completion . Manned space missions have brought the station closer to the station's completion .
 The ISS could house a crew of six following the addition at the end of 2008 of a bathroom and a urine-distillation processor for recycling water .
 STS-126 returned with the first samples of recycled water from the urine processor, as well as frozen specimens taken from the crew over several months to help measure the long-term effects of low gravity .
 STS-127 completed the assembly of Japan’s Kibo experiment module by installing the exposed platform component . The Kibo module is a Japanese experiment module .
 The shuttle also carried a test model of the DragonEye docking target system that would be used by the commercial SpaceX Dragon spacecraft .
 The STS-128 mission took up the Leonardo Multi-Purpose Logistics Module, containing 6,894 kg of supplies and scientific equipment . The mission was the first to take part in a mission to space .
 The astronauts replaced an ammonia cooling tank and retrieved specimens that had been exposed to space from the exterior of the European Columbus laboratory . The astronauts retrieved specimens from an ammonia cooler tank .
 STS-129 took up an assortment of parts, including gyroscopes and nitrogen tanks, in two ExPRESS Logistics Carriers . The last shuttle mission of the year took up parts of the last shuttle shuttle mission . The mission was the last of 2013 .
 Japan successfully launched the first H-II Transfer Vehicle with the HII rocket on September 11 . A new supply route to the ISS opened when Japan launched the new rocket . The launch was the first of its HII Transfer Vehicles .
 It docked with the ISS on September 18, taking up 4,500 kg of food, computer equipment, and other supplies . The mission to the ISS was the first to dock with the space station .
 In five spacewalks the crews replaced two science instruments, gyroscopes, star sensors, a computer, batteries, and thermal blankets . In five spacewalkers, crews replaced 2 science instruments and repaired two instruments .
 The mission had been delayed by several months from 2008 when Hubble’s primary computer failed . The mission to the Hubble telescope was delayed from 2008 to 2009 .
 This required extra time to pull the spare from storage from storage and requalify it for flight . The spare was needed to be ready for flight.
 The astronauts also opened the Advanced Camera for Surveys instrument and replaced parts at the computer board level . This is something that was never envisioned when Hubble was designed .
 After STS-129, only five shuttle missions remained before the system was retired in 2010 .
 The only interplanetary launch of the year was NASA’s Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter and Lunar Crater Observation and Sensing Satellite on June 18 . The only mission to the lunar surface was the Lunar Observatory on June 4 .
 Most LRO instruments surveyed the lunar surface, searching for evidence of water in permanently shadowed craters . Most of the instruments were instruments used to search for water on the moon .
 LCROSS mission used the Centaur upper stage to strike the Moon . It was overshadowed by the launch vehicle’s Centaur launch vehicle . The mission was the first of its kind to carry out a mission to the moon .
 The LCROSS spacecraft was devised from the Centaur/spacecraft adapter and used commercial parts . It carried cameras and spectrometers to detect materials in the impact plume from Centaur's upper stage .
 The LCROSS ""shepherd” spacecraft separated from the stage on October 8 . The spacecraft is now on its way to the next Mars mission .
 Centaur and LCROSS crashed into a crater near the lunar south pole on October 9 . The Centaur was the closest to the Centaur by about four minutes . The two plowed into the same crater four minutes apart .
 The plume revealed “significant quantities of water,’s water, which would be valuable as a resource for life support and propulsion at a lunar base . The water would be used to fuel a lunar spacecraft .
 India’s Chandrayaan-1 lunar satellite failed on August 28 as a result of key guidance components’ overheating . Chandraya-1 was launched on Oct. 2008 and launched in October 2008 .
 Officials at the Indian Space Research Organisation judged the mission, India’s first interplanetary endeavour, as a success because it discovered water molecules in the lunar surface .
 The major astronomy missions of the year were Russia’s Koronas-Foton on January 30, NASA’�s Kepler on March 6, and Europe's Herschel/Planck spacecraft on May 14 .
 Koronas-Foton was part of the International Living with a Star program . Koronus-Foto is a member of the world's most famous sportswear group .
 It carried instruments to observe the most violent solar activity in the extreme ultraviolet through gamma-ray range of the spectrum . It was carried out by the International Solar System System .
 Space physics instruments monitored the response of Earth's magnetosphere to solar storms . They monitored Earth's response to the latest solar storms in the magnetosphere .
 The telescope was slightly out of focus to help it meet its goal of recording when Earth-size planets transit . Earth-sized planets transit when they cross in front of their stars .
 Light curves are light curves of some 100,000 stars . As such it produced not images or maps but light curves . Light curves were created for the first time in 100 years .
 NASA says it can observe a Jupiter-size exoplanet by its reflected light, as well as by transit . The sensitivity was great enough to detect Jupiter-sized exoplanets by its light .
 Herschel and Planck were launched separately on the same Ariane 5 rocket to orbit separately the L2 gravitational balance point between Earth and the Sun . Planck and Herschel will orbit separately to the same L2 L2 point as Planck .
 It provides an easy place to “park’s telescopes to observe deep space with virtually no radiation input from Earth . It provides a great place to "park” telescopes in space .
 Herschel became the largest space telescope, with a 3.5-m primary mirror, compared with the Hubble Space Telescope’s 2. m . It operated in the far-infrared spectrum to image stars, galaxies, and star-forming regions .
 Planck carries two millimetrewave instruments to map unevenness in the intensity and polarization of the cosmic microwave background radiation left over from the big bang . By comparison, the deepest red that the human eye can perceive is 0.77 Planck instruments .
 North Korea failed in a second alleged attempt to orbit a satellite with the Taepodong-2 launch on April 5 . North Korea has been accused of launching a satellite into orbit in violation of the law .
 North Korea claimed that it was a satellite launch . Western observers believed it was three-stage ballistic missile lofted its payload some 3,800 km .
 On August 25 South Korea also failed to launch a satellite in its first outing with the Naro 1 launch vehicle . The launch vehicle had a Russian-built first stage and a Korean second stage .
 The demonstration version of NASA's new Ares 1 -X vehicle was launched on October 28 . It's the only one in light of the Augustine report, the Ares 1X vehicle .
 The Ares I-X test rocket lifts off Launch Complex 39B at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida, on October 28 . It had succeeded in all static ground firing tests, and a structural model of the second stage and the Constellation spacecraft .
 The flight was a success, although NASA was studying to determine why the second stage and booster slowly jackknifed toward each other after separation . NASA is studying the cause of the problem .
 The recovered booster suffered a major dent in its lower section when two of its parachutes failed after opening . Two of its three parachutes had to be parachuted out of the booster's parachute .
 SpaceX scored its second success out of five attempts with the Falcon 1 vehicle . It flew from Kwajalein Atoll in the Marshall Islands and carried Malaysia’s RazakSAT communications satellite . SpaceX is a private launch company .
 SpaceX had developed and soon will test a larger Falcon 9 vehicle to carry supplies and crews to the ISS in the Dragon capsule . SpaceX also plans to test and launch a larger version of the Falcon 9 that will carry supplies .
 Advanced testing of the Variable Specific Impulse Magnetoplasma Rocket showed great promise for providing a stage capable of taking humans to Mars in less than six weeks . The rocket was developed by Franklin Chang-Diaz .
 VASIMR uses radio waves to heat ionized argon gas, thus accelerating it to high speeds . The radio waves are used to accelerate the gas to a high speed .
 While the thrust was low, it could be continuous, as opposed to chemical rockets that provide high thrust for a few minutes at most . The thrust is low, but it could provide continuous thrust for several minutes .
 Pope Benedict XVI rescinded in January excommunications of four members of the traditionalist Society of St. St. Francis . In an attempt to heal a 20-year-old schism in Roman Catholicism, he rescinded excommunication of four .
 Richard Williamson made statements denying the Nazis’ use of gas chambers to exterminate Jews . Williamson said only up to 300,000 Jews died in concentration camps instead of the generally accepted figure six million .
 The pope's rehabilitation of the bishop was denounced by Jewish leaders around the world and led Israel’s chief rabbinate to sever ties with the Vatican . Israel's chief rabbiinate severed ties with Vatican .
 Benedict said he had not known about the bishop’s views when he lifted the excommunication . The Vatican needs to make greater use of the Internet to prevent such controversies, he said .

 In May the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland voted in Edinburgh to defer action on this issue for two years . Church courts, committees, and ministers are barred from commenting about it publicly .
 In July more than 1,600 members of the Religious Society of Friends in Britain, popularly known as the Quakers, voted to approve marriages for same-sex couples . They voted to ask the government to change the law to recognize such marriages .
 Indonesia's Muslim population, some 13% of the world’s total, is the largest of any country . The country has a Muslim population of some 203 million . Indonesia is home to the largest Muslim population in the world .

 Report found that thousands of students had been systematically beaten and sexually abused by priests, nuns, and other staff members . Thousands of students were abused by staff members, the report found . Report: Thousands had been beaten, sexually abused .

 The Evangelical Lutheran Church in America voted at its biennial assembly to share full communion with the United Methodist Church . The U.S. had previously approved the agreement .
 The accord, which had taken 30 years to reach fruition, meant that the two churches recognized the validity of each other ministers, baptisms, and eucharistic services . The accord was meant to allow each other churches to recognize each other's ministers .

 The French branch of the Church of Scientology was convicted of fraud and fined the equivalent of nearly $900,000 by a Paris court in October . The court also fined the church of Scientology nearly $800,000 .
 Six members of the group, which claimed to have 45,000 adherents in France, were also convicted of fraud . Judges said that no jail sentences were imposed because the church had taken steps to change some practices .

 It ranked Saudi Arabia as the most restrictive country and the Middle East and North Africa as most restrictive regions . Saudi Arabia was ranked as the least restrictive country in the world by the study .

 Button was without a team following the 2008 season after Honda Motor Co. announced that it was pulling out of the sport because of the global economic downturn . His victory was one of the most surprising results in FI history, considering that the 29-year-old Button had no team .
 Brawn GP took over the Honda team a few weeks before the season-opening Australian Grand Prix on March 29 . Button will be competing in his first grand prix since 2008 .
 Button started that race from the pole and came away with the win, just his second since joining FI in 2000 . Button started the race on the pole in Melbourne, Australia, in 2010 .
 Button went on to win the pole and race at the Malaysian Grand Prix one week after his victory in Australia . Button finished the 2008 season in 18th place, finishing 18th in the standings .
 Button is the first British driver to register four straight victories in one season since Nigel Mansell accomplished the feat en route to the 1992 drivers’ title . Button posted wins in the next four races to become the first Briton to achieve the feat since Mansell in 1992 .
 Buttons amazing start in 2009 gave him an almost insurmountable 26-point lead over Brawn GP teammate Rubens Barrichello of Brazil with 10 races remaining .
 Button did not win another race all season, but he did not need to after his dominant start . Button won the first race of the season and the second in a row . Button was the only person to win a race in 2011 to retain his title .

 His victories included the Hambletonian, the Kentucky Futurity, the World Trotting Derby and the Breeders Crown .
 Muscle Hill was touted by many veteran horsemen as the greatest trotter ever, certainly the best in recent decades . Muscle Hill will be the first horse to be retired from the trotting .
 He never seemed to be working hard to win his races but always seemed well within himself . He was always happy to win races but was always within himself even as his rivals were struggling across the finish line .
 His victory in the Hambletonian was timed in 1:50 'Is for the mile' It was the fastest clocking ever in the U.S.'s greatest trotting classic, which was begun in 1926 .
 Muscle Hill won 20 of 21 starts and a total of $3,273,342 in two seasons on the track . In two seasons, Muscle Hill has won $3.273,000 in total in two races .

 At the National Football League annual meeting in March 2009, the competition committee adopted a number of new rules to be put into effect during the 2009-10 season . Football Football Changes the Rules .
 The most talked-about decision was not technically a new rule but rather a clarification of the existing ""roughing the passer'' regulation . The decision was made to clarify the existing regulation of the roughing of the passer .
 The clarification would prohibit a defensive player who is on the ground from lunging at the lower legs of the opposing quarterback, though hand tackles from the position would still be allowed .
 Violation of the revised rule would trigger a 15-yd unsportsmanlike-conduct penalty . Violation would trigger the penalty of 15 yards in a row .
 The adjustment became known in the media as the ""Brady Rule" after New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady famously suffered a torn anterior cruciate ligament and medial collateral ligament in his left knee in the first quarter of the 2008-09 season .
 The loss of Brady, one of the biggest stars in the NFL, hurt both the Patriots and the league . The NFL was determined to further protect its quarterbacks .
 Critics noted that the clarification would make defenders try to act against their natural instinct to pursue the ball . It would be difficult to keep in check during the fast and furious play of a typical NFL game .
 An offensive player may not use his helmet, forearm, or shoulder to deliver a blindside block . Blindside blocks are delivered to someone who does not see it coming to an opponent's head .
 Initial contact may not be made to the head of a defenseless receiver during a tackle . Initial contact must be made with the head at the start of the tackle .
 On a kickoff, the receiving team may not use a blocking wedge (players standing shoulder-to-shoulder who run upfield in front of the kick returner) of more than two players . Kick returner may not be allowed to use blocking wedge .
 During an onside kick, the kicking team cannot have more than five players on one side of the kicker pursuing the ball . The kicking team must have more . than five . players on the side of a kicker pursue the ball.
 Another notable rule change would allow replay officials to review whether a loose ball should be judged a fumble or an incomplete pass . The rule change was not related to player safety .
 This change stemmed from a prominent event of the 2008-09 season, when an apparent fumble by Denver Broncos quarterback Jay Cutler that was recovered by the San Diego Chargers was instead ruled an incomplete pass . This change also stemmed from an incident in which Jay Cutler's apparent fumble was ruled incomplete .
 Denver scored a touchdown and the game-winning two-point conversion soon thereafter . The loss nearly cost the Chargers a play-off spot with 35 seconds remaining .

 The sport of swimming was marred by widespread use of illegal performance-enhancing drugs in the 1990s . In 2009, swimming was again fraught with controversy over the use of swimsuits made from high-tech materials .
 The dispute led to the banning of nontextile swimsuits beginning in 2010 . The dispute overshadowed the performance of the athletes in major meets around the globe . The 13th FINA world championships were held in Rome on July 17-August 2 .
 It forced the incumbent FINA president to abandon his reelection bid and led to serious discussion of a radical revision of FINA’s structure . It also led to a radical discussion of the FINA structure .
 The championships produced no fewer than 43 world records in the 40 events that were contested . The championships were held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil .

 The sport of swimming faced one of its most difficult challenges in 2009 . Athletes, coaches and swimsuit companies squared off over the growing use of performance-enhancing high-tech swimsuits .
 The most radical version of this swimsuit line was a full bodysuit that covered the swimmer from neck to ankles . The most extreme version of the suit was a bodysuits that covered all of the body .
 Swimming had seen full bodysuits before the LZR, most notably when Australia's Ian Thorpe set world records in 2000-02 while wearing Adidas's bodysuit .
 There was no convincing evidence that the suit made anyone faster, and in October 1999 FINA had approved the bodysuits for competition . FINA approved the suit for competition in 1999 .
 Several companies created new bodysuits for the 2000 and 2004 Olympic Games, but post-Olympic analyses cast doubt on any claims of performance enhancement .
 LZR-related world records were set within days of the swimsuit's introduction . It was the first in what became a torrent of increasingly meaningless records . The swimsuit is now the world's most popular swimsuit .
 At the 2009 FINA world championships, 40 events were contested and 43 world records were unceremoniously overthrown . The 2009 world championships were held in Shanghai, China .
 By the end of 2009, the total number of world records broken in those 23 months stood at a staggering 255 .
 Critics claimed that the suits undermined such values as hard work, superb conditioning, and technical mastery . Some coaches and sportswriters claimed that they undermined those values of the past .
 FINA officials dismissed the dissenters as misguided and pointed to innovations that transformed other sports . The fibreglass pole in pole vaulting and the dapskate in speed skating are examples of innovations that have transformed sports .
 High-tech swimsuits kept evolving, especially as more manufacturers entered the fray .
 U.S. delegation offered motion to allow only textile swimsuits, eliminate compression-enhancing features such as zippers . The arms remained uncovered for both sexes, with arms remaining uncovered .
 The ban was to become effective on Jan. 2010, bringing to a close the era of the performanceenhancing high-tech suits . The ban will be effective in 2010 .

 Usain Bolt of Jamaica made the 2009 track and field season his own . He improved his individual sprint world records and won three world championships golds . Bolt won three golds at the 2009 world championships .
 Nine meet records were broken at the International Association of Athletics Federations world championships in 2009 .
 Bolt attributed his early jump to playful competition with his Antiguan training partner, Daniel Bailey, to see who could achieve a faster reaction time . Bolt said the early jump was due to a playful competition between him and Bailey .
 Bolt incurred no penalty, but a new rule to take effect in 2010 would trigger immediate disqualification for any false start . Bolt incur no penalty but new rule will take effect next year . New rule would disqualify Bolt from the 2010 Olympics .

 The victory earned the 27-year-old Bekele a clean sweep of all world and Olympic gold medals in the event since 2003 . It is the first clean sweep in the history of the Ethiopian 5000m steeplechmurders .
 In the 5,000 m, Bekele outkicked defending champion Bernard Lagat of the United States to match his double victory of the Beijing Olympics . He becomes the first man to win the long-distance track double at a world championships .

 A media frenzy began with a leaked report that the IAAF had conducted sex tests on the powerfully built 18-year-old Semenya to determine if she was really a woman . The IAAF has denied that the report was true .
 ASA Pres. Pres. Semenya was suspended from the IAAF after the incident . She was the first woman to be banned from running for more than a year .
 Leonard Chuene angrily denied knowing that sex-verification testing was conducted on Semenya in South Africa before the championships . Chuene said he did not know about the sex-test taking place before the championship .
 The furor grew more heated after press reports alleged that testing had shown Semenya to have an intersex condition . Press reports alleged Semeny had a condition called intersex .
 The unconfirmed accounts claimed that she had internal male genitalia and testosterone levels three times higher than normal for a woman . Levels that could impart an athletic advantage could be attributed to her athletic advantage .
 The IAAF reserved comment on the reports until its council meeting in November . The reports will be made public until November .
 IAAF says medical testing of Semenya was not complete and that the council would not discuss the case until further notice . Two days before that meeting, IAAF issued a statement saying that medical testing had not been completed .
 South Africa’s sports ministry announced that the IAAF had agreed to let Semenya keep her medal and prize money . The IAAF declined to comment on the claim, but the South African sports ministry said it would let her keep the medal .

 Many countries are suffering from the effects of a global recession, many countries are struggling with high unemployment and SHRINKING budgets .
 Germany prepared festivities in remembrance of the fall of the BERLIN WALL 20 years earlier . China marked the 60th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic .
 The United Nations in 2009 continued its efforts to deal with important global issues on many fronts . The U.N. was forced to do so in the context of the continuing global economic and financial crisis .
 It was the UN Year of Climate Change, but little progress toward a comprehensive global climate change agreement emerged . Little progress was made in the UN year of climate change . The United States and the United Kingdom are the world's only two countries .
 The global food crisis persisted, but few new concerted global actions were targeted for dealing with it coherently . Food crisis has been a global problem for years, but little progress has been made in tackling it .
 Afghanistan rose to the top of the global security agenda as insecurity and the death toll there mounted significantly during the year . The death toll in Afghanistan has risen significantly in 2014 .
 Progress toward attainment of the Millennium Development Goals stagnated along with the global economy . Progress toward achieving the goals has stagnated since the 1990s .
 2009 marked the return to greater engagement in multilateral affairs of the United States, led by the new administration of Pres. Barack Obama .
 The wars in Iraq and Afghanistan continued to dominate global peace and security news . CNN's John Defterios reported on the wars in both countries .
 Much of the violence centred on and the follow-up to the presidential elections . The violence occurred in the lead-up and follow up to the elections in 2012 .
 On October 28 five staff members of the UN Assistance Mission in Afghanistan were killed in a suicide attack in Kabul . This fact was highlighted by the attack on October 28, which killed five UN staff members in Afghanistan .
 UNAMA estimated that Afghan civilian deaths exceeded 2,000 during the first 10 months of the year . UNAMA estimates that Afghan civilians died in the last year's fighting .
 The UN Assistance Mission for Iraq continued its work in support of political reconciliation, institution building, and establishment of the rule of law in the country .
 At the end of the year, the UN fielded 17 peace missions with more than 117,000 troops, police, and civilians . The UN fielded a total annual budget of nearly $7. billion .
 The UN Security Council authorized the deployment of 5,500 uniformed personnel to replace the European Union EUFOR military force in January . Highlighting the situation in Africa, the Security Council in January approved the deployment . EUFOR will replace the EUFOR .
 By the end of November 2009, the hybrid U.N./African Union Mission in Darfur had increased to 19,588 uniformed personnel .
 The primary mandate of the force remains the protection of civilians and humanitarian assistance providers . The force is tasked with monitoring the implementation of agreements and the development of political processes .
 As in 2008, UNAMID’s work remained hampered by the lack of transport and aviation assets and logistic support . UNAMid's work was hampered by a lack of transportation and aviation support .
 The UN Mission in the Sudan continued its main mandate to help resolve core issues that stood in the way of implementation of the 2005 Comprehensive Peace Agreement . The mission continues its main mission to help .
 By December UNMIS, with 9,955 uniformed personnel in the field, had nearly reached its authorized level of 10,000 . By December, UNMis had 9,000 uniformed people in the force .
 In November 2008 the Security Council authorized the expansion of the force by 3,000 military and police . 20,255 uniformed personnel were in the field in November 2009 .
 UN Operation in Cote d'Ivoire stood at more than 8,000 in October 2009 . Meanwhile, the UN operation stood at over 8,500 in October .
 At year’s end the Security Council approved sanctions on Eritrea for aiding Somali insurgents and continuing its conflict with Djibouti . Eritrea has been accused of aiding Somalis in Somalia .
 Preventative diplomacy and the use by Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon of special and personal representatives and envoys became ever-increasing tools in the UN’s peace-building efforts . Preventative diplomatic efforts are becoming increasingly important in the United Nations .
 In 2009 such special envoys were actively engaged in more than 30 countries or regions . More than two dozen other UN emissaries were assigned to deal with specific global policy issues .
 The importance placed on postconflict peace building also grew in recent years . The importance of peace building in post-conflict conflict has grown over the years .
 By April 2009 the UN’s Peacebuilding Fund had received more than $300 million in contributions . More than $131 million had been allocated to 12 countries for 65 projects .
 The review process for the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons picked up momentum . A formal review conference was in the works for 2010 .
 Nuclear and conventional weapons proliferation remained an important agenda item, with particular focus on North Korea and Iran . Iran and North Korea were the focus of the meeting .
 Iran conducted a second nuclear test in May 2009 in violation of Security Council resolutions . Concerns have continued over Iran’s evolving nuclear program .
 UN member states agreed to a timetable for negotiating an arms trade treaty by 2012 . UN members of the world agreed to the talks on October 30 . The treaty would be negotiated by the end of 2012 .
 In September 2008 the UN General Assembly renewed its commitment to the Global Counter-Terrorism Strategy that it had adopted two years earlier . The strategy was renewed in September 2008 .
 A UN Counter-Terrorism Implementation Task Force had been established in 2005 . Secretary-General Ban requested to make the necessary institutional changes to enhance the organization’s support of the task force . The task force was organized around eight working groups focusing on cross-cutting themes .
 The UN Security Council passed a U.S.-sponsored resolution to revise the content and process of the UN 1267 Committee’s sanctions list, making it more transparent and fair and providing recourse for individuals and firms wrongly included on the UN sanctions list .
 The primary purpose of the UN list was to serve as a tool for governments to deny terrorists access to funding, weapons, travel, and other resources . The list was created by the UN in 2003 .
 UN humanitarian relief efforts reached near-record levels in 2008, responding to 55 emergencies, including natural disasters, the global food crisis, and civil conflict . UN humanitarian aid efforts responded to 55 crises in 2008 .
 The UN launched a $7.7 billion appeal for contributions for 2010 to assist 48 million people in 25 countries . UN launched the appeal in late November 2009 to help the world's poorest people .
 In addition, another 839,000 individuals filed claims for asylum or refugee status . 827,000 cases awaited determination at the end of the year .
 Nearly half of refugees who were receiving assistance from UNHCR were from Iraq and Afghanistan . Another 20% of refugees were from Africa .
 More than two-thirds of the world's displaced peoples remained inside their own countries . More than 2,000 displaced people remain in their countries .
 The number of internally displaced persons remained around 26 million for the second consecutive year . Around 26 million internally displaced people remain in the country .
 Sudan, Colombia, and Iraq were home to the largest number of internally displaced persons . Nineteen African countries accounted for 11. million IDPs, including Sudan and Colombia .
 The United States sought and won election to the world’s highest human rights body in May 2009 . Reversing the administration policy of former president George W Bush toward the UN .
 President Obama moved to ban the use of torture by the U.S. military . He issued an executive order to close the Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, detention centre within one year .
 A military judge at Guantanamo and later the United States Senate moved to block the order . The U.S. Senate blocked the order, however, and a military judge blocked it .
 The measure would need approval by the United States Congress, however, however .

 The global economic downturn had a significant impact on the MDG process . The MDG is based on the findings of the World Economic Development Council .
 Progress toward achieving the goals was slowed in many areas and even reversed in others . Progress toward the goals were slowed in some areas, even reversed .

 Over the previous decade, assistance to less-developed countries —especially sub-Saharan African countries — had increased substantially . Sub-Saharan Africa is one of the world's poorest countries .
 The world food crisis that had significantly worsened in 2008 remained one of the world’s greatest challenges in 2009 . World food crisis was one of world's greatest challenges .
 Despite a decrease in prices in late 2008, food costs continued to be high . Food costs were high in 2008, according to the USDA .
 A World Food Summit on food security was held in Rome on Nov.-18, 2009 . The summit took place in Rome, Italy .
 The final conference document, while calling on governments to reinforce efforts to meet the MDG target of reducing hunger by half by 2015, contained no new financial commitments for doing so . The conference document was released on Monday .
 The World Bank announced in late November that it had launched a $1.1 billion trust fund to promote agricultural production in poor countries . The fund will be used to promote agriculture in poor nations .
 By year’s end 12,220 deaths had been reported worldwide, and the World Health Organization had declared the pandemic on the decline .
 Deaths from measles dropped 74% from 2000 to 2007 . As a result largely of global and regional immunization campaigns, especially in sub-Saharan Africa, deaths from measles have declined 74% .
 Nearly a million people die annually of malaria annually of the disease . The global campaign against malaria made inroads, but nearly a million died annually .
 Malaria deaths were highly regionalized, with 89% in sub-Saharan Africa in 2008 . The overwhelming majority of those killed were children .
 In December 2009, news broke of a new drug-resistant strain of malaria in the Cambodia-Thailand border region .
 Globally, the number of people living with HIV/AIDS continued to hover around 33 million . Globally there are 33 million people worldwide with the disease .
 In Eastern Europe and Central Asia, HIV prevalence rates had doubled since 2001 . The number of persons living with HIV/AIDS had ballooned from 630,000 in 2001 to 1,600,000 .
 Two-thirds of persons living with HIV were located in sub-Saharan Africa . Most of these were women, most of whom were women . The world's largest number of people with HIV is located in Africa .
 Maternal mortality continues to plague the LDCs worldwide . In 2005 (the year for which the most recent statistics were available), more than half a million women and girls died annually .
 Half of all maternal deaths occurred in sub-Saharan Africa, and another third occurred in South Asia . Half of the deaths were caused by maternal causes, such as death from childbirth .

 The European Union faced a series of daunting challenges as 2009 opened . The EU was the first major institution to enter the continent's borders .
 At the top of the list was how to respond to the global economic crisis . At the time, the most urgent question was how best to deal with the crisis .
 The bloc’s drive to reform its own institutions so they could perform better with an enlarged membership of 27 remained in deep trouble .
 The EU’s Lisbon Treaty was drawn up with the intention of pooling more powers at the European level, in part by creating the new posts of the EU president and a more powerful foreign policy chief .
 The idea was that if Europe could speak as one, rather than as 27, it would be far better able to punch its weight in global negotiations, whether on trade, foreign affairs, or the environment .
 Some member states were determined not to back the deal, arguing that too much power was being transferred from national governments to Europe . Yet some members of the European Parliament say too much of power is being transferred .

 The 47-nation Antarctic Treaty is the managerial mechanism for the region south of latitude 60° S, which includes all of Antarctica . It is managed by the 47 nations that signed the treaty .
 The treaty reserves the area for peaceful purposes, encourages cooperation in science, prescribes environmental protection . It allows inspections to verify adherence, and defers the issue of territorial sovereignty .
 They also agreed to support the International Maritime Organization’s efforts to ensure the safety of Antarctic shipping and to petition the IMO to extend the . Antarctic Special Area northward to the Antarctic Convergence in order to protect the region's marine .

 Antarctica New Zealand was to lead the estimated $6 million project and cover most of the cost as part of its contribution to the shared logistics pool with the U.S. Antarctic Program . The United States Antarctic Program transported most fuel, personnel, and materials to the continent .
 The project would cut fuel consumption by about 463,000 litres every year . Wind-generated electricity would reduce greenhouse gas production by 1,242 tons of carbon dioxide annually . Wind power would reduce carbon dioxide production .
 The wind-generated electricity would supply about 15% of McMurdo’s annual demand . The smaller New Zealand station would draw about 87% of its electricity requirements from the U.S. system .
 The two countries expected the wind farm to be operational in February 2010 .
