 The final phase would be the demolition and removal of the South Pole geodesic dome . The dome would be removed from the site .
 A fire destroyed a building, killed one person, and injured two others at the Russian station Progress, located in East Antarctica . The fire occurred in the 2008-09 austral summer .
 The injured, who were part of a 10-person construction team, were taken to China’s nearby Zhongshan station .
 Kunlun station was China’s third Antarctic station . It was located in East Antarctica at Dome A, about 4,093 m above sea level . It is China's third Antarctic Antarctic station, located in east Antarctica .
 Researchers have found unexpected evidence of a remarkably warm period in Antarctica 15. million years ago . Researchers say they have found unusual evidence of an unusually warm period .
 Evidence found in a sedimentary core, drilled from the seafloor underneath the Ross Ice Shelf, shows that even a slight rise in atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide affected the stability of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet .
 The dynamics of ice sheets were not well understood before this discovery . Discovery improved scientific understanding of the mechanisms that controlled the growth, melting, and movements of ice .
 The authors predicted that seas would rise unevenly because of the shift in a huge mass of ice away from the South Pole would subtly change the strength of gravity locally and the rotation of the Earth .
 In October, NASA scientists reported in the journal Science that over the past seven years ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica appeared to be shrinking faster than originally thought .
 The Arctic Ocean, 14.09 million sq km in area, constitutes about two-thirds of the region . Arctic Ocean constitutes about 2.3 million sqkm in area . The region is about two thirds of the size of the world .
 International organizations concerned with the Arctic include the Arctic Council, Barents Euro-Arctic Council, Inuit Circumpolar Council, and Indigenous Peoples' Secretariat .
 Arctic summer sea ice hit its 2009 annual minimum on September 12 . Sea ice levels hit the 2009 minimum for the first time in the year .
 The 2009 minimum was the third lowest on record, 24% below the 1979 to 2000 average . At 5. million sq km of coverage, the 2009 minimum is the lowest ever minimum .
 The U.S., Canada, Denmark, Norway, and Russia continued their interest in the more open and accessible Arctic Ocean . The countries bordering the Arctic region (U.S. and Canada) continued to interest .
 Much of the ongoing undersea mapping work carried out in 2009 was done jointly by pairs of countries .
 Russia and the United States conducted collaborative research in the Chukchi Sea . The United States and Canada worked together in the Beaufort Sea . Canada and Denmark worked cooperatively in the high Arctic .
 During the year the countries bordering the Arctic continued the process of establishing rights to territory and undersea resources under the aegis of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea .
 In April the UN confirmed Norway’s claim to extend the boundary of its continental shelf, based on undersea mapping submitted in 2006 . The UN confirmed in April that the claim was based on a 2006 undersea map .
 The decision added some 235,000 sq km to Norway's continental shelf area . The decision was made in 2008 .
 Russia’s claim for Arctic undersea rights was submitted in 2007, and the country continued to carry out research to support its claim .
 Canada was expected to submit a claim by 2013, and Denmark was to make its proposal by 2014 . Denmark was also expected to make a claim in 2014 .
 In August the U.S. introduced a moratorium on commercial fishing in its exclusive economic zone off the Arctic coast of Alaska .
 The moratorium was announced to provide time to determine the level of fish stocks, the role of Arctic fish in the ecosystem, and their response to changing sea ice conditions .
 Fishing fleets worldwide had expressed interest in expanding operations into the newly opening waters of the Arctic . Fishing fleets have expressed interest expanding their operations .
 Arctic Council released a major report on Arctic marine traffic in spring 2009 . The Arctic Council report was released by the Arctic Council in 2009 .
 Transport activity is expected to increase from fishing, resource development, tourism, research, and commercial shipping .
 Report made recommendations for search-and-rescue capabilities in the event of accidents and spills . Report: Search and rescue capabilities should be used in accident and spill situations .
 Just weeks before the report was released, a Russian nuclearpowered ice breaker collided with an unladen oil tanker in the Kara Sea . The report comes just weeks before it was released .
 Two German cargo ships successfully completed the transit in September 2009 . Two of the ships completed the transatlantic transit in 2009 .
 The new Russian ice breakers 50 Let Pobedy and Rossia accompanied the ships along the most northerly section of the passage .
 In July the United States introduced bills to build two new ice breakers for use in polar waters . The U.S. also wants to coordinate shipping infrastructure with other Arctic countries .
 Russia also had plans to add another six nuclear-powered ice breakers by 2020 . Russia had also planned to add six more nuclear powered ice-breaking icebreakers .
 In May Russia began construction on the world's first nuclear power plant on an offshore platform . Russia has begun construction of the plant on a platform in an offshore area .
 An additional three offshore nuclear plants are in the plans for coming years . An additional 3 offshore plants are also planned for the future .
 The platforms were intended to have multiple uses, one of which was to supply power for exploration for and development of petroleum and natural-gas reserves . One of the platforms was intended to be used for exploration of and developing natural gas and oil reserves .
 Earlier in the spring, Norway had launched two new offshore semisubmersible rigs designed for harsh environmental conditions and ultradeepwater drilling .
 In 2008 the United States Geological Survey had determined that the Arctic contained 13% of the global oil reserves . The majority of these reserves are located along the Russian continental shelf . U.S. Geological Survey: Arctic contained 30% of global gas reserves .
 Progress was modest in 2009 on two major pipeline projects in North America to connect hydrocarbon reserves in the Arctic to U.S. and Canadian markets . Progress in 2009 was modest, but progress was modest on pipeline projects .
 Interest in northern gas, however, had diminished as a result of technological innovations in drilling, experts say .
 Improvements in steam-extraction technology, known as hydraulic fracturing, were revitalizing natural gas reserves that were closer to markets . Improvements in hydraulic fracturing technology, such as fracking, have revitalized natural gas .
 Methane also exists in the Arctic permafrost, both in the tundra and in the undersea frozen layer of the continental shelf . Methane is the principle component of natural gas .
 New studies in 2009 focused on determining how much methane and carbon dioxide was stored in the Arctic and what quantity of these greenhouse gases might be released as the Arctic warms .
 The concern was that the addition of large amounts of the two gases could create a feedback loop that would accelerate climate change . The concern is that the added gases create a negative feedback loop .
 One study estimated that some 1. trillion tons of carbon dioxide were stored in frozen soils . That figure is twice what had been previously estimated . The study was published by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization .
 Studies in the Arctic and elsewhere conducted into developing technologies that could harvest methane hydrates to use as a fuel .
 methane is 20 to 25 times more potent than carbon dioxide as a greenhouse gas . Methane is a potent greenhouse gas, and could be a significant source of carbon dioxide . The result from such harvesting could be significant .
 A Canadian study revealed that caribou and reindeer herds across the Arctic had declined by some 60% over the previous 30 years . Caribou herds across Arctic have declined by 60% in 30 years, study found .
 Caribou and reindeer were considered a cornerstone species for the subsistence economy of the Arctic’s indigenous peoples . Caribou was considered to be the cornerstone species of the indigenous peoples' subsistence economy .
 Polar bears, also critical to the economy and culture of indigenous peoples, had been under threat from climate change . Polar bears were listed as a threatened species in 2008 by the United States government .
 Indigenous Peoples' Global Summit on Climate Change was hosted by Inuit Circumpolar Council in April 2009 .
 Ban Ki-Moon traveled to the Arctic before attending the World Climate Conference in Geneva in September . The UN SecretaryGeneral traveled to Arctic in the summer . He is scheduled to attend the world climate conference .
 His pronouncements added urgency to the UN Climate Change Conference that convened in December in Copenhagen to negotiate the treaty that would succeed Kyoto Protocol .
 Leaders at the conference were unable to arrive at a treaty to succeed the Kyoto Protocol . But they did reach agreement on an accord that would see negotiations continue in 2010 .
 The war in Afghanistan assumed a higher global profile in 2009 as Taliban attacks inside Pakistan demonstrated the international character of the Islamist insurgency in both countries . Afghan refugees in Pakistan and Iran also include Afghan refugees .
 United States and NATO troop levels in Afghanistan rose above 100,000, most of them American . U.S. and NATO troops in Afghanistan now number more than 100,500 .
 President Obama authorized higher troop levels and replaced NATO’s commander in Afghanistan . He authorized higher levels of troop levels .
 Economic reconstruction and the training of Afghan forces became high priorities in Afghanistan . Economic reconstruction, training and economic reconstruction were high priorities for Afghanistan .
 In recognition of the regional nature of the opposition, U.S. policy would view Taliban activity on both sides of the Afghanistan-Pakistan frontier as a whole . Taliban activity would be viewed as part of the Afghan-Pakistan border .
 The U.S. is reaching out to moderate Taliban, especially to those fighting for money rather than ideology . There was a new willingness on the part of the United States to reach out to moderates .
 Many Western policy makers saw the insurgency in Afghanistan as composed of three groups . The Taliban has been fighting for independence in Afghanistan since 2001 .
 First, the Taliban group led by Mullah Mohammad Omar, was loosely organized and active mostly inside Afghanistan . Mullah Omar's group was active mostly in Afghanistan . The Taliban group was based in Afghanistan and led by Omar .
 Many of this group’s members were Pashtuns who fought for local or tribal issues and might respond to programs addressing their concerns . Many of the members of the group were members of Pashtun .
 A second Taliban group, led by members of the Haqqani family, was credited with having introduced suicide attacks and bombings of public buildings to Afghanistan . The group is said to be connected with both al-Qaeda and elements of Pakistan’s military .
 The group led by the warlord Gulbuddin Hekmatyar remained independent of the Taliban while sharing their Islamist orientation . Finally, the group shared an Islamist orientation with the Taliban . The Taliban was defeated by the Taliban in 2001 .
 It is not known whether Hekmatyar might find common ground with the government of Pres. Assad Assad .
 Throughout the year interest focused on Afghanistan’s second presidential election, in which Karzai stood for reelection . The election was held in Afghanistan's second election, held in 2009 .
 Registration was under way in the winter for a vote anticipated in the spring . The vote is expected to take place in spring 2015 .
 According to Afghanistan's constitution, Karzai’s term would end on May 22 . According to the constitution, the president's term is due to expire on May 23 .
 In January, the Independent Election Commission announced that the election would be delayed until August 20 . Security and weather concerns prompted the delay . The election commission was appointed by President Karzai, appointed by him .
 Many Afghan politicians argued that the decision was illegal . Although it was backed by the UN, the U.S., and other international leaders, many Afghan politicians rejected it .
 The controversy continued until the end of March, when the Supreme Court announced that Karzai could hold office until the August election . Karzai has been in office since March, but the court ruled that he can continue to hold office .
 An Electoral Complaints Commission, which included UN observers as well as Afghans, was charged with investigating and ruling on reported irregularities . An electoral commission was set up by the UN to investigate and rule out irregularities .
 The election provoked thousands of complaints of ballot fraud, and counting continued for two months . Thousands of complaints were made .
 The first count gave Karzai enough votes to avoid a runoff, but several hundred thousand ballots in his favour were eliminated when convincing evidence of mass fraud was brought to light . Karzai won the first count in Afghanistan's first election since 2001 .
 A runoff between Karzai and former foreign minister Abdullah Abdullah was ruled necessary . A runoff was also ruled necessary for the Afghan president .
 Abdullah demanded that officials overseeing the election be replaced to prevent further fraud, but he was ignored . Abdullah demanded the election officials overseeing it be replaced, but they were ignored .
 On November 1 he withdrew his participation, and Karzai was declared the winner without the need for a second vote . Karzai's victory was declared after he withdrew from participating in the vote .
 The president immediately pledged to remove the taint of corruption from his government . President Barack Obama has pledged to do so .
 New strategies could not disguise growing tensions between the Afghan government and its international defenders . Afghan government: New strategies must be used to deal with growing tensions with international forces .
 NATO’s revised rules of engagement, its air strikes continued to cause civilian casualties . NATO air strikes in Afghanistan have caused civilian casualties in the past year . NATO's air strikes continue to cause casualties in Afghanistan .
 Many Afghans have openly criticized foreign troops for not protecting the population . Many Afghans, including Karzai, openly criticized the foreign troops .
 International leaders pointed to the corruption and inefficiency in Afghanistan’s government and demanded reform . International leaders were becoming discouraged by so few signs of success in Afghanistan .
 In March the parliament passed, and Karzai signed, a bill legalizing the traditional family law of the Hazara . Law that was to apply only to this Shi'ite province was to only apply to this Shiite Muslim nation .
 Shi'ite parliamentarians argued that it was legal recognition of Hazara culture . Many inside and outside Afghanistan denounced the law for infringing on women's rights . Shi'ites argue that the law was a recognition of the Hazara religion .
 In July, Karzai enacted a revised version of the Hazara family law . It forbade a woman to work outside the home without her husband’s permission and allowed a man to withhold food from his wife .
 The year saw a shift in attitudes toward NATO shipments to Afghanistan . Russia and Central Asian countries allowed only nonlethal supplies to cross their countries . NATO shipments were allowed to cross the border with arms .
 Several Asian countries voiced new warmth and friendship toward Afghanistan’s government . Afghanistan's government has been criticized for its lack of transparency .
 China offered expanded economic cooperation but remained noncommittal on requests to open the border of Afghanistan’s Vakhan region to trade . China has offered to expand economic cooperation with the Afghan government .
 India too was eager to participate in Afghanistan’s development, and even Japan offered extensive financial aid to the country .
 Afghanistan established its first national park, Band-e-Amir, in April . The park is located in a region renowned for the intense, clear blue of its mountain lakes . Afghanistan's national park was established in March .
 Albania was admitted to NATO at the alliance’s summit in Strasbourg, France, on April 4, 2009, and formally applied for full EU membership on April 28 . Albania is located in Albania's capital, Tirana .
 The EU considered the general elections held on June 28 to be a litmus test of the country’s progress . The European Union considered the elections held in June to be the country's progress .
 By introducing a new electoral system in which seats are allocated proportionally by districts, legislators had significantly diminished the chances of small parties to win seats . New electoral system had introduced a new system which allocates seats proportionally .
 Albania's first coalition government included parties from both the left and the right . This marked a turning point in postcommunist Albania’s polarized political culture .
 In Berisha’s new cabinet, Ilir Meta becomes foreign minister . Meta is the LSI leader in the new government .

 In early 2009 Australia was devastated by bushfires, with many homes in the state of Victoria razed to the ground . Some homeowners were burned alive in their houses .
 The general public rallied behind survivors; appeals for donations were successful . The funds combined with major government assistance to speed up the rebuilding process, which began as soon it was safe to reenter the burned-out zones .
 Kevin Rudd’s government introduced legislation to launch a carbon-trading scheme to tackle global warming . Australia had the highest per capita carbon emissions in the developed world .
 In August Parliament rejected the plan to introduce carbon permits costing $A 10 per ton from July 2011 . Opposition senators defeated the bill by 42 votes to 30 .
 The legislation was defeated a second time in December when it was reintroduced . It was defeated in December after being reintroduced again .
 Rudd was forced to reshuffle his front bench in June after Joel Fitzgibbon resigned as minister of defense amid allegations of misconduct . The reshuffle was prompted by a series of allegations against the former minister .
 UN special rapporteur on indigenous rights criticized Northern Territory intervention . James Anaya criticized the Northern Territory's intervention in August . The Northern Territory is the only Aboriginal community in Australia .
 Experts estimate the number of affected wildlife could climb well into the millions . In addition, more than 2,000 homes were destroyed, and experts say wildlife could also be affected .
 Australia had often suffered from deadly bushfires, most notably the 1939 ""Black Friday"" blaze in Victoria, in which 71 people were killed, and the 1983 ""Ash Wednesday"" fires in Victoria and South Australia, where 75 people perished . With its abundant forests and hot dry climate, Australia
 The scale of the recent fires was unprecedented and left the country in a state of shock . Extreme weather conditions coupled with a severe drought that had created tinder-dry vegetation across the state was unprecedented .
 On February 7, Victorians were told to brace for the ""worst day"" in the state's history . Weather forecasters warned of a record heat wave with temperatures soaring to 46 degrees Fahrenheit .
 That day more than 47 major fires erupted across the state, 14 of them claiming lives or causing significant damage . That day 14 of the 47 fires claimed lives or caused significant damage or were caused by fires .
 The flames quickly jumped a major highway and roared into a forest where they turned into a giant fireball . The flames dwarf the resources of local firefighters who could only flee in its path .
 Aided by steep slopes and powerful winds, this fire raced through a series of townships, including Kinglake (where 38 people died), Strathewen , and St. St. Louis .
 Residents of St. Andrews were surprised by the deaths of 12 people . Many residents were trapped in their homes . Many were trapped inside their homes after the tragedy .
 Some sought to escape by car as the fires approached, but dozens died on the roads as they were overtaken by the fire . Dozens of people are believed to have been killed in the fires in the area .
 Late in the afternoon a sudden change in wind direction pushed the fire to the northeast, bringing new towns into its path . A sudden change of wind direction pushes the fire north of the fire .
 A parallel fire, known as the Murrindindi fire, also blew to the northeast, swallowing the unsuspecting tourist town of Marysville, where 34 people lost their lives . A parallel blaze also swept the town, also killing 34 people, also swept through the town of Mur
 Fire experts said that these two fires alone released energy equivalent to 1,500 Hiroshima-sized atomic bombs . Experts said the two fires released enough energy to release enough power to release Hiroshima-size atomic bombs to release .
 Fires also ravaged other parts of the state, including the eastern region of Gippsland, where 11 people were killed . 11 people died in the fires, including 11 in the eastern part of Victoria .
 In some townships there was no more than a handful of survivors after the fires swept through . Some townships were overrun by the fires, leaving no survivors .
 The township of Flowerdale, 65 km north of Melbourne, was razed to the ground . Flowerdale was the township of the township, 65km north of the Melbourne suburb .
 The government announced that a Royal Commission would be formed to look into the disaster . The government declared that emergency services had done the best that they could in the face of an unprecedented natural phenomenon .
 Country Fire Authority gave inadequate warnings to communities in the fire's path, report says . Public warnings given to communities were inadequate and in some cases nonexistent .
 CFA personnel in charge of managing the fires failed to issue timely warnings, with the result that many people did not know that they were in danger until the fire was upon them . It revealed that the CFA failed to give timely warnings .
 Serious deficiencies were pinpointed in the command and control systems of the emergency services agencies . The problem led to confusion, inertia, and poor decision making at crucial times, officials say .
 Report recommends changes to the ""stay or go" policy . The policy had advised residents to choose between remaining and defending their property against a fire or leaving early .
 Victorian government pledges to implement interim recommendations in time for the 2009-10 fire season . Victorian government pledged to implement all of the Royal Commission's interim recommendations .
 The Commission's final report was expected in July 2010 . Alcohol were discriminatory and breached Australia’s treaty obligations . The Commission was expected to report in July .

 At the beginning of 2009, Australia's national accounts were in a relatively healthy condition, largely because of mineral exports to China . In 2009, the country's national account was in a healthy condition .

 While the BZO remained popular in Carinthia, its support dwindled elsewhere in Austria following the sudden death in October 2008 of its leader, Jorg Haider .
 Austria's economy contracted sharply in 2009, largely owing to a significant fall in investment and exports . Austria's economic growth in 2009 was largely driven by a drop in investment, exports .
 In the first half of the year, investment was severely restrained by a dramatic drop in manufacturing output . Manufacturing output stabilized midyear and began to recover very slowly thereafter .
 Investment also contracted owing to low business confidence and tight credit conditions . Low business consumer confidence also contributed to the drop in investment investment .

 Evo Morales was reelected to a five-year term in December 2009 . His party made major gains in legislative elections, capping a year of major reform .
 The stage for Morales’s victory had been set in January when Bolivians approved a new constitution . Bolivian voters approved the new constitution in January . Morales is the first president of the country to win a presidential election .
 The charter, drafted with the help of Spanish legal scholars, gave sweeping rights to BoAizar Raldes . Leopoldo Fernandez was being held on charges of having orchestrated the killings of several supporters of Bolivian Pres.
 Evo Morales has guaranteed political representation, recognition of communal forms of property, and the right to employ indigenous justice systems . Morales is the leader of Bolivia's indigenous majority .
 The charter won 62% voter approval in a nationwide referendum, but four provinces in the eastern lowlands rejected it . It underscored the division between the economically rich eastern region and the impoverished Indian-dominated highlands .
 The referendum result reaffirmed Morales's popularity and strengthened his hand in Bolivia’s internal political battles . Morales’ popularity has been boosted by the result of the referendum result .
 In April police burst into a hotel in Santa Cruz, shot three men dead, and arrested two others . Police claimed they had thwarted a plot by allies of powerful separatist businessmen in the eastern region to kill Morales .
 The businessmen denied the allegation, saying that Morales was trying to boost his chances of reelection . Morales has been accused of using the affair to help him win re-election .
 One of those killed was a Bolivian Hungarian who had fought in the Balkan wars of the 1990s . The victim had told an interviewer that he was returning to Bolivia to fight for a breakaway state .
 Leopoldo Fernandez, former governor of Pando province, remains in jail . Fernandez is accused of having been involved in the killings of several Morales supporters during opposition protests in 2008 . Fernandez remains behind bars .

 Annual cocaine seizures had doubled between 2006 and 2008, police said . Police raided several clandestine drug laboratories, which they said were among the largest ever discovered .

 New oil discoveries continued to be made by the Brazilian state oil company, Petrobras, and its partners in the ultradeepwater subsalt areas of the Santos basin .
 Multiple discoveries over the previous three years of multibillion-barrel reserves raised Brazil’s profile as a top future oil producer . The discoveries gave impetus to increased investment in ports, shipyards, naval construction, refineries and oil and gas exploration .
 On August 31 Lula unveiled the federal government’s plan for a new regulatory regime to manage this new oil wealth . Lula: "On August 31, Lula unveils the plan for the federal . government”
 He proposed the creation of a new government enterprise, called Petrosal, to manage and oversee the contracts for subsalt exploration and production . The proposal would create a government enterprise to oversee contracts .
 Under this regime Petrobras would be the only operator with a guaranteed stake of 30% in each concession . Under this new regime Petrobasas would have a guaranteed 30% stake of each concession.
 Current royalty distributions would be changed . Social and environmental fund would be created to spread oil revenues to other states outside production areas .
 Producer regions stood to lose revenues from royalties, as well as those who viewed the new regulatory body as a redundant bureaucracy . These provisions caused fiery debate from producer regions, which stood to stand to lose revenue .
 The Growth Acceleration Program aimed to boost the country’s economic growth to 5% annually . The federal government continued its funding of social and educational projects, rural-electrification efforts and housing initiatives .
 The Brazilian Congress was prevented from advancing on any meaningful reforms by a corruption scandal . A corruption scandal that embroiled the Senate for much of the year also prevented progress on reforms .
 Agaciel Maia resigned his post in early March after allegations emerged that he had hidden ownership of a mansion in Brasilia from federal tax authorities . Maia had served as the director general of the Senate since 1995 .
 Maia is linked to the awarding of lucrative patronage jobs and pay raises via hundreds of secret acts passed by the Senate during Maia's tenure as director general .
 Also implicated in the scandal was the president of the Senate, Jose Sarney, accused of having approved the secret acts . Sarney is accused of securing jobs for his family members and political allies .
 Many in Congress called for Sarney's ouster after mounting evidence of corruption . Sarney and others faced mounting evidence .

 Sarney’s son, Fernando, faced allegations of money laundering, won an injunction from a judge in August . O Estado de Sao Paulo newspaper prohibited any reporting of accusations against him by a judge .
 Brazil's Supreme Court ruled against newspaper's appeal of Vieira’s decision . The newspaper sought to overturn this injunction, but the court ruled against it on December 10 . Vieira's decision was overturned by the court .
 By a vote of 10 to 1, the Supreme Court in March ruled in favour of a continuous demarcation of the Raposa Serra do Sol Indian reservation . The reservation is located in northern Roraima state near the Venezuelan and Guyanese borders .
 Brazil also moved forward with infrastructure investments in the country’s Amazon region . Brazil is investing in infrastructure projects in the Amazon region.

 The unexpected shutdown of the nuclear reactor at Chalk River, Ont., on May 14 precipitated a crisis in the medical community, as well as political repercussions . The unexpected shutdown of the reactor at the site precipitates a crisis .
 Canada's 52-year-old nuclear reactor at Chalk River, Ont., experienced a sudden and unexpected shutdown on May 14, 2009, owing to a local power outage . In the early morning of May 15 a leak of heavy water was detected .
 The reactor was originally forecast to be offline for one month . By August officials had revealed that the reactor would not resume production of medicalquality isotopes until the spring of 2010 at the earliest .
 The shutdown resulted in the delay or cancellation of numerous diagnostic appointments as well as other medical imaging procedures that utilize isotopes . The shutdown delayed or canceled many diagnostic appointments .
 Members of the medical community suggested that the temporary loss of the reactor's production was a ""catastrophe,"" as the reactor supplied one-third of the world's supply of medical isotopes .
 Prime Minister Stephen Harper announced on June 10 that the federal government would pull out of the medical-isotope-production industry .

 Michelle Bachelet is the most popular president in Chile's political history . She has been in office for more than four years . She is currently the country's most popular female president .
 Since her election in January 2006, Bachelet had promised to bring an openness and accessibility to the presidency . She has promised to focus public policies on helping the poor and the marginalized .

 Bachelet had to battle a growing sense of political exhaustion among Concertacion supporters . She was the fourth successive president to belong to the centre-left Concertacion coalition .

 On the political right, Sebastian Pinera, who lost to Bachelet in the 2006 runoff election, was vying again for the presidency . On the left, he lost in a runoff election in 2006 . On Sunday, he will be the next president of Chile .
 Pinera had to best Joaquin Lavin to become the right’s candidate against Bachelet . Unlike in his first attempt, he was now the consensus candidate of the right-wing alliance . He waged a campaign that highlighted the need for greater governmental efficiency .
 Pinera has consistently been in first place among the four candidates for president . Polling consistently put him first place in the race among the candidates .
 No candidate gained an absolute majority of more than 50% in the December 13 election . A second round of voting was scheduled to take place on Jan 17, 2010 . As expected, no candidate gained a majority of over 50% .
 The combined vote total for the three centre-left candidates was 56% . It was unclear whether Frei could capture all those votes, especially those that went to Enriquez-Ominami .
 Chile weathered the global recession relatively well, in large part because Bachelet had not bowed to political pressure early in her administration to spend the unexpected financial windfall that had resulted from the high price of copper, one of the country's main exports .
 The value of Chilean exports dropped by 30% during the global downturn . The government saved this revenue and was able to draw on these reserves when the country’s export-driven economy slowed .

 Charter 08 issued in December 2008 after nearly a year of planning . Charter 08 was issued by prominent Chinese dissidents and intellectuals . It foreshadowed the year of dissent in China .
 This manifesto demanded that human rights, democracy, and constitutional government replace the Chinese government’s program of authoritarian modernization . It expressly linked its demands to the approaching 20th anniversary of the 1989 crackdown on Tiananmen Square pro-democracy demonstrators .
 Liu Xiaobo, a well-known writer, was detained around the time of the manifesto’s initial release . He remained in custody throughout 2009, though his formal arrest on charges of subversion was not approved until June . The charter was released in 2009 .

 Air conditioning was rationed to five hours a day; amusement parks and office buildings scaled back their hours of operation . Electric baking ovens and cold storage units were required to be given mandatory power time-outs .

 The Cuban Revolution that brought the regime of Fidel Castro to power marked its 50th anniversary in 2009 .
 Castro led a small band of rebels to triumph during the 1959 revolution that ousted the unpopular and corrupt regime of Fulgencio Batista . A half century had passed since Castro led the small band to triumph in Cuba .
 Castro's embrace of communism and his alliance with the Soviet Union soon provoked conflict with the United States . In response to Castro's actions, United States Pres. George W. Bush ordered the U.S. to arm Castro in Cuba .
 Dwight D Eisenhower imposed economic sanctions on Cuba in 1960 and broke off diplomatic relations with the country in January 1961 . Eisenhower imposed the economic sanctions in 1960 .
 John F Kennedy, backed the Cuban exile-led Bay of Pigs invasion, which backfired badly when Castro's forces easily repelled the assault . The invasion was backed by Castro's Cuban exile forces .
 Kennedy placed a wide-ranging United States embargo on the island in 1962 . The embargo remains the central element of U.S. policy toward Cuba . Kennedy placed the embargo in early 1962 .
 Kennedy learned that Castro had entered into a secret agreement with then Soviet premier Nikita Khrushchev to install nuclear missiles in Cuba . That October the Cuban missile crisis was set in motion when Kennedy learned of the agreement .
 The incident brought the world to the brink of nuclear war before it was peacefully resolved . The incident was the first time the world was at risk of war .
 The dramatic events of the 1960s proved to be only the beginning of decades of tensions in U.S.-Cuban relations . Cuban President Camilo Castro was assassinated in 1961 .
 In the years that followed, the Cuban Revolution reshaped U.S. priorities in Latin America . The Cuban revolution reshaped the United States priorities in the region .
 Castro government promoted wars of liberation in Latin America and Africa during much of the Cold War . Castro government established itself as significant global actor .
 Castro faced off against a succession of U.S. presidents, including Lyndon Johnson, Richard Nixon, and Gerald Ford . Castro was assassinated in 1968 by the Soviet Union .
 Attempts to normalize relations with Cuba failed to bear fruit in the 1980s and 1990s . President Jimmy Carter tried to normalise relations with the island nation .
 Ronald Reagan forcefully embraced sanctions against Cuba as a means of containing communism in Latin America . Reagan embraced sanctions as a way to contain communism in the U.S.
 The collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War appeared to create a brief moment of opportunity in the early 1990s for the U.S. and Cuba to set their relationship on a new path . Cuba's relationship with the United States has been strained for decades .
 By 1992 the Cuban economy was reeling owing to the loss of nearly $4 billion in annual Soviet subsidies, and the country descended into a severe economic crisis . The loss of the Soviet subsidies led to the country's economic collapse .
 The U.S. passed legislation to ratchet up the sanctions against Cuba in 1992 and 1996 . The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Helms-Burton Act of 1996 were passed .
 George W Bush further tightened the embargo on Cuba, and most diplomatic contacts were frozen . Most diplomatic contacts with Cuba were frozen in Cuba .
 Cuba and the U.S. have a history of diplomatic failures . Despite the occasional opportunities to reconcile their estranged relationship, the United States and Cuba never seized on them and instead littered their history with failures .
 Fidel Castro fell ill with a serious stomach ailment in the summer of 2006 . There was ample speculation that his death would pave the way for a restoration of democracy and a rapprochement in U.S.-Cuban relations .
 Fidel Castro lived on, though he was forced to pass power to his brother, Raul Castro, on a provisional basis before formally resigning Cuba's presidency in February 2008 . Instead, Fidel lived on and passed power to Raul, who died in 2008 .
 Fidel's continued presence and his frequent writings on domestic and international topics, however, served to check Raul's power .  Lars Lokke Rasmussen, finance minister in the centreright Liberal-Conservative minority government, took over as prime minister on April 5 . Rasmussen is a former finance minister who has been in charge of the government since 2007 . Rasmussen has been the prime minister of Denmark since 2008 .
 The new prime minister (who was not related to his predecessor) was intent on garnering public support in a country that had been hard hit by the recession .
 The unusually high turnout of 60% was attributed to the inclusion of women on the ballot of a referendum on granting women equal rights in the succession to the Danish throne .
 Danes voted 45% in favour of allowing the monarch’s firstborn child the rights of accession regardless of its gender . The measure passed; Danes vote 45% to allow the monarch's firstborn to accession .
 Danish troops killed in Afghanistan since 2001 have one of the highest per capita death tolls among coalition forces . In June the number of Danish troops died in Afghanistan in June reached 25 .
 Denmark was sharply criticized by both the UN High Commissioner for Refugees and Amnesty International for the government’s plan to forcibly repatriate rejected Iraqi asylum seekers . Denmark has been criticized for forcibly repatriating rejected Iraqi refugees .
 In August police ousted about 20 such Iraqis from the crypt of a Copenhagen church where they had been living for three months . In August 20 Iraqis were removed from a church crypt in the city .
 Violent clashes broke out between protesters and police as Iraqis were arrested and bused to asylum centre, where they faced deportation . Protesters and police clashed as the Iraqis were bused into asylum centre .
 U.S. President Barack Obama makes a rare visit to Copenhagen, Denmark . Obama is the first sitting president to visit Denmark since leaving office in 2009 .
 Barack Obama met in early October with Danish political leaders and the royal family . Obama met with Danish politicians and Danish royals in October .
 Obama was in Denmark during a hectic five-hour stopover while (unsuccessfully) lobbying the International Olympic Committee for Chicago to host the 2016 Games . Obama is in Denmark for five hours during a stopover from a flight .
 East Timor began in April 2008 when Eritrean troops occupied the Ras Doumeira area just over the border in Djibouti . The area was occupied by Eritreans in the area of the region .
 UN Security Council passed Resolution 1862, which ordered both countries to engage in negotiations . Resolution 1862 called for immediate withdrawal of Eritrean troops from Djibouti . Eritreans have been at odds with the UN for more than a decade .
 In late September, Djibouti petitioned the UN Security Council to enforce its earlier resolution . Meanwhile, Eritrea refused to acknowledge that it was encroaching on Djiboutsi land . Eritrea is also refusing to acknowledge the encroachment .
 Djibouti entered into separate agreements with the European Union and Japan to help stave off pirate attacks . The country has been hit hard by pirate attacks in recent years .
 The EU agreement, the Atalanta mission, was mandated by the UN World Food Programme to protect food-aid shipments into Somalia . EU forces would be based in Djibouti .
 Food prices on the continent had spiked, owing in large part to the increased number of pirate attacks on ships off the coast of Djibouti and Somalia . Food prices have also spiked due to an increase in pirate attacks in the region .
 The crisis deepened as a result of continuing drought as well as global increase in food prices . The crisis has deepened due to continuing drought and the global increase of food prices.
 By October more than 23 million people in the Horn of Africa were in need of food assistance, an increase of some 4 million since early in the year . The Horn of African region has seen an increase in food assistance since October .
 The government indicated that it would aim for a target of 3% of GDP, which was not an easy goal to achieve under current conditions . The government said it would be aiming for 3% GDP .
 Opposition parties protested in March in the capital, Roseau, demanding electoral reform . Opposition parties want what they call a "clean" voters list .
 On November 19, however, during Skerrit’s address to the country, he announced that the elections would be held on December 18 . The elections were originally scheduled for December 18, but they were set to be held in New Jersey .
 Dominica and other smaller Caribbean states voted alongside Japan to overturn the International Whaling Commission’s ban on commercial whale hunting . Critics had suggested that Japan was “buying” their vote with aid . Prime Minister Skerrit insisted that he was a convert to environmental preservation
 Dominica had abstained from the vote at the IWC's annual meeting in 2008 . Skerrit announced in March 2009 that Dominica would no longer support Japans efforts to reestablish commercial whaling . Dominica did not support the move in 2009 .
 Inflation closed out the year at 5%, and tourism numbers were resilient . Tourism figures were similar to those in 2007, with figures similar to 2007 .
 Leonel Fernandez was shaken, however, by his perceived failure to address debilitating social and infrastructure crises . Fernandez is shaken by the perceived failure of his government .
 Government commitments to tackle endemic corruption, the erosion of educational standards, increasing drug addiction, and lingering extreme poverty rang hollow .
 A low minimum daily wage of $2.52 in Nicaragua, the second poorest country in the Western Hemisphere, exacerbates labour tensions . Nicaragua's minimum wage is lower by 10 cents than that of Nicaragua, which is second poorest .
 A constitutional reform package negotiated by Fernandez and PRD leader Vargas Maldonado was passed that eliminated consecutive presidential reelection . The reform package was passed by the PRD and Fernandez's government .
 Also in the package was a provision that criminalized abortion, including therapeutic abortions . The measure was considered highly draconian . It included therapeutic abortions in cases of rape or incest or when a pregnancy threatened the life of a mother .
 Dominican Republic's chronically fragile relations with neighbouring Haiti were jarred by strong Haitian reaction to a new Dominican policy . The policy stipulated that children born to Haitian parents residing illegally in the Dominican Republic were not entitled to Dominican citizenship .
 Fernandez demonstrated exceptional skill when he brokered negotiations that cooled an incendiary dispute involving Ecuador, Venezuela, and Colombia . The dispute arose following an attack by the Colombian military on a rebel base located within Ecuador .
 East Timor has one of the lowest per capita crime rates in the world . Mario Carrascalao thanked the international community for creating peace in his country . East Timors have one of world's lowest crime rates .
 Indonesia left East Timor when it left the country . Roads are still in the same condition they were in when Indonesia left the island nation .
 Most of the roughly $8 billion donated to East Timor since independence had been spent on salaries of foreigners and on administration and imports . Only 10% of foreign aid ended up in the local economy, an organization says .
 President Ramos-Horta was equally concerned that too little aid money was going to the people of East Timor . He said too little money would be going to East Timors .
 A ceremony was held in Dili to celebrate the independence anniversary . Ceremony was attended by representatives of East Timor's most important neighbours, Australia and Indonesia .
 Indonesian Foreign Minister Hassan Wirajuda among those at the festivities . Australian Gov.-Gen. Andrew Abbott and Australian Governor-General Andrew MacKinnon were also there .
 President RamosHorta reassured Indonesia of his opposition to the establishment of an international tribunal to bring justice those said to be responsible for human rights abuses during the struggle for independence .
 Ramos-Horta called on the United Nations to disband its serious crimes unit . Ramos-horta calls on the U.N. to disband the unit .
 He also awarded retired Australian general Peter Cosgrove the Order of East Timor in recognition of his leadership of the multinational peacekeeping mission that had kept order in the country at the time of independence .
 Correa expanded programs aimed at improving life for the poor . He challenged foreign resource companies and investors to accept new terms of engagement with Ecuador . Correa has vowed to push ahead with his vision of “21st century socialism”
 A new mining law that imposed minimum royalty rates and limited the scope of exploration concessions was generally welcomed by foreign companies . Some Indian groups opposed it, but some Indian groups oppose it .
 A clash in late September between Shuar Indians and police seeking to break up an antimining road blockade left at least one Indian dead . The Shuar Indian tribe is believed to have been fighting an anti-mining blockade .
 In the petroleum sector, the government seized the assets of French firm Perenco in a dispute over taxes . The government pressed foreign firms to exchange joint production-sharing agreements for service contracts with state-owned Petroecuador .
 Ecuador's output of crude oil, Ecuador’s chief export, declined . As a result, some firms put investment plans on hold, and the output has declined .
 The judge hearing a $27 billion oil-pollution lawsuit against the U.S. multinational corporation Chevron was forced to step aside after the company produced evidence that he had discussed the eventual verdict with government officials . Meanwhile, the judge hearing the lawsuit against Chevron stepped down .
 Ecuador expected economic growth to slow to 2% in 2009, mainly because of weaker oil prices . Weak oil prices and a decline in remittances from Ecuadorans living abroad . Ecuador expected to grow 2% this year .
 To compensate, the government imposed new tariffs and import restrictions . It said it would double the tax on capital outflows, and negotiated advance payments .
 It also repurchased $3 billion in defaulted bonds that it said had been illegally issued under a former administration . The government repurchases at 35 cents on the dollar, at $35 cents .
 Relations with the United States and neighbouring Colombia continued to be strained in 2009 . Colombia's relations with the U.S. and Colombia were strained in the years before .
 Colombia maintained that Ecuador provided tacit support to Colombia . After meeting with Ecuadoran Pres. Guillaillailla, Colombia met with Ecuadorian Pres. Arguillailla . Colombia said that Ecuador had tacit support for the government .
 Indian leaders review draft of a proposed agreement that addressed many of their concerns over new water and mining laws in the country . Rafael Correa in Quito on October 5, India leaders review the draft of the proposed agreement .
 In July Colombian authorities released a video in which a senior FARC commander said that Correas reelection campaign had received funds from the rebel army . In July a video was released by Colombian authorities showing the FARC leader's FARC campaign .
 In September the last U.S. personnel left the military base at Manta on the Pacific coast . Ecuador declined to renew a lease allowing them to conduct antidrug operations . These were then shifted to Colombian bases .
 Two U.S. diplomats were expelled in February after the government said that they had threatened to suspend United States aid in an attempt to influence local police appointments . The government said the diplomats were trying to influence police appointments in the country .
 Despite irritants, the U.S. renewed a longstanding package of duty exemptions and other trade benefits for Ecuador . The United States renewed the longstanding trade benefits .
 The crises were exacerbated by local issues, including strikes, human rights concerns, and disagreement with the Nile River basin countries over the management of water resources .
 There were mass arrests of senior members of the banned Muslim Brotherhood organization . Mass arrests also took place of senior Muslim Brotherhood members in Egypt .
 The impact of the international financial crisis on the Egyptian economy was harshest during the first half of the 2008-09 fiscal year . Egypt's economy was hit hard by the global financial crisis in 2008-2009 .
 Panic struck as cases of H1N1 flu (a respiratory disease caused by an influenza virus) were reported in Egypt . Panic struck after cases of the virus were reported .
 Precautionary measures by the government included the slaughter of the country's estimated 350,000 pig population, a one-week delay in the start of the school year, and the installation of feverdetecting instruments at ports of arrival .
 Egyptian health authorities decided that pilgrims could proceed to Mecca and Medina for the hajj in late November as scheduled . Barring a major global outbreak, however, Egyptian health officials say pilgrims can proceed . The hajj is scheduled to take place in late December .
 By December 20 there were more than 7,300 reported cases of infection and 89 deaths . 89 people were killed by the virus, according to the CDC .
 The former chairman of al-Ghad party, Ayman Nour, was released from jail in June . He pledged to continue his political activism after his release from jail .
 In mid-February, pharmacists, truck drivers, public transport bus operators, real-estate-taxation employees, and other workers initiated strikes or sit-in protests over financial incentives and other grievances . In a wave of protests, drivers, bus operators and real estate workers took part
 In September the government-sponsored National Council for Human Rights delivered its five-year report on Egyptian human rights practices to the Geneva-based UN Human Rights Council .
 The Egyptian council called for reconsideration of the electoral system and its electoral supervisory mechanism in expectation of the 2010 parliamentary elections . The council pointed to irregularities in the past presidential and parliamentary elections that had put into question the integrity of the process .
 It also highlighted the rise in the rates of poverty and called for measures to ensure transparency, combat corruption and strengthen antitorture measures .
 Calls for guarantees to check interference by the executive with the judiciary . Calls for an end to the state of emergency and guarantees of checks on interference by executive .
 It noted improvements in the military justice system that tries civilians under the state of emergency law . The right to appeal was also noted in the report .
 In mid-August some 31 leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood were detained on charges of funding an international organization of the group . 26 Egyptians and other nationals went on trial in August for having organized a cell of Hezbollah to carry out subversive activities in the Suez Canal zone .
 In July ministers of irrigation and water resources of Nile River basin countries met in Alexandria to discuss a legal framework agreement regulating the distribution of water .

 TV journalist Mauricio Funes of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front won the presidential election in El Salvador on March 15, 2009 . El Salvador Area: 21,041 sq km Population : 6,192,000 Capital: San Salvador .
 Funes defeated the National Republican Alliance candidate, Rodrigo Avila, by a margin of 51.3%-48.7%, ending ARENA's long control of the Salvadoran government . Funes was the first FMLN presidential candidate not to have participated in the guerrilla warfare of the
 Funes says he does not want ideological confrontation with the United States . Funes is sympathetic to other leftist governments in the hemisphere, especially that of Lula da Silva in Brazil .
 One of Funes’s first acts upon taking office was to restore relations with Cuba . One of his first acts on Cuba was restoring relations with the U.S.
 Salvadoran government also announced its support for Honduran Pres. Zelizer in July . Salvadoran President Ruben Navarrette is a former President of Honduras .
 In the realm of domestic policy, Funes began implementing dramatic improvements in education and children’s health benefits, especially for the poor . He provided not only free education, but also meals and uniforms for poor publicschool students .
 He also launched new aid programs for the elderly poor and moved against widespread corruption in the government .
 The global recession exacerbated already-serious economic difficulties for the new government . There are widespread unemployment and a sharp decline in exports and imports . The new government has been hit by the global recession .

 In 2009 few outside Equatorial Guinea’s ruling circle celebrated the 30th anniversary of the coup d’etat that brought Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo to power in August 1979 .
 Equatorial Guinea was one of the largest oil producers in sub-Saharan Africa . The majority of the country’s population remained very poor and without access to any social services .
 While Obiang spent a fortune on cars and houses, infant and child mortality increased . Infant and child deaths increased as Obiang's wealth increased .
 A Human Rights Watch report released in July detailed the misappropriation of oil revenue by Obiang .  Ethiopia also earned the distinction of being one of the world's most militarized countries . Ethiopia is also known for being a highly militarized country .

 He attracted scorn at home and abroad as his government detained without trial opposition figures and critics, including politicians and journalists .
 The Afwerki regime also stuck to a strict program of military conscription aimed at maintaining high troop levels at its disputed border with Ethiopia . The regime has also maintained high troop numbers at disputed border .
 Tensions remained high at the frontier, over which the country fought a two-year war with Ethiopia that ended with a shaky cease-fire in 2000 . The country had fought two-and-a-half years of war with neighboring Ethiopia .
 Kenya and Western countries accused Eritrea of having aided Islamist insurgents involved in a civil war in Somalia . Eritrea has been accused of aiding Islamist insurgents in Somalia's civil war .
 In May the African Union asked the U.N. to impose sanctions on Eritrea . The African Union said Eritrea was destabilizing the Horn of Africa .
 UN Security Council voted to impose sanctions on Eritrea in December . Eritrea has been hit with sanctions since it was imposed by the UN in 2012 .
 Nearly 30% of Eritrea's population are living below the international poverty line . Drought and high food prices abroad exacerbated the situation . Eritrea has been hit hard by drought and food prices .
 The dire economic and political situation forced many of its citizens to undertake perilous and sometimes fatal journeys to flee the country . Many of the country's citizens have been forced to flee their homeland .
 In August about 70 refugees perished at sea near the Italian coast when their small boat ran out of fuel and capsized . About 70 such refugees perished near the coast of Italy when their boat capsized in August .
 The European Commission in May allocated about $4.5 million to Eritrea . The European Union has also allocated $4 million to the country . Eritrea is one of the worst countries in Africa .
 The amount was part of about $71.6 million in humanitarian aid that the organization granted to five African countries . The aid is part of a $71 million donation to the African nations .
 In September the European Commission approved about $174 million in development funding for Eritrea for the 2010-13 fiscal years . Eritrea is the only African nation in the region to be granted the most development funding .
 That month the country also completed consultative talks with the International Monetary Fund . That month, the country had also completed consultations with the IMF .
 The organization concluded that the Eritrean economy would continue to be hampered by debt and inflation . Despite some gains from new mining industry construction, some gains were made in the mining industry .
 There was a massive decline in GDP and real-estate values, while unemployment rose to double digits during the first quarter of the year . Unemployment is double digits in the US .
 In addition to state revenue, wages, retail sales, and foreign direct investment all fell considerably . State revenue, wage and retail sales also fell significantly .
 The government sought to take advantage of the drop in inflation to move closer to adoption of the euro, making painful budget cuts . The budget deficit must be below 3% of GDP as required by the EU for euro adoption .

 The Ethiopian economy was expected to grow at a rate of about 6.5% in 2009, down from 8% in 2008 . Most of its exports come from the agricultural sector, particularly coffee, tea, spices, and cereals .
 The decline in global demand for important exports had a negative impact on the Ethiopian economy, as did rising prices for fuel . The decline of global demand had also been a negative effect on Ethiopian economy .
 High inflation and rising food prices meant that urban citizens faced increasing economic hardships in 2009 . Stagnant wages and employment opportunities, decreases in remittances from the diaspora, and increasing internal migration to Ethiopian cities .
 More than 47% of the country’s rural population lived below the poverty line . Meanwhile, more than 47 per cent of the population in rural areas live below the line .
 Power rationing and critical supply shortages in items such as cement were persistent problems . Droughts and food insecurity were also persistent problems, as well as periodic droughts .
 At least 6. million Ethiopians were in urgent need of food assistance during the year . A total of 12. million people in need of some type of food aid .
 A highly controversial law that severely limited the actions of civil society organizations was passed in January . The law was passed by the U.S. Supreme Court in March .
 Foreign organizations prohibited from participating in activities such as conflict resolution and human rights-related work . Foreign organizations that received more than 10% of their funding from foreign sources banned from participating .
 It also empowered a government agency to closely monitor all organizations and impose extremely harsh penalties for violation of the law’s provisions . The law was passed by the U.S. Senate last week .
 Eritrea's border dispute with Eritrea largely remained at a stalemate in 2009 . The border dispute between Eritrea and Eritrea has largely been at stalemate since 2009 .
 Neither country had taken steps to demarcate the border in line with the 2002 ruling of the Eritrea-Ethiopia Boundary Commission, which Ethiopia rejected . Ethiopia had rejected the decision .
 In August the Haguebased Eritrea-Ethiopia Claims Commission ruled that compensation should be paid by each country to the other for damages inflicted during the 1998-2000 war .
 Ethiopia formally withdrew its armed forces from neighbouring Somalia in early 2009 . Ethiopian forces had been serving in support of the Transitional Federal Government of Somalia since December 2006 .
 Ratu Josefa lloilovatu Uluivuda did not have the power to dismiss the previous government in 2007 or install the interim government that had seized power in 2006 . The latter move was therefore invalid, the court ruled .
 President Iloilo abrogated the 1997 constitution, dismissed the judges, and appointed himself head of state with power to rule by decree . The 1997 constitution was abolished in 1997 . Iloillo abrogates the constitution, dismisses the judges and appoints himself president of state .
 With backing of the military, he announced that he would install an interim government for a five-year period . Reforms contained in the People’s Charter for Peace, Change and Progress would be implemented, he said .
 The president reappointed the interim prime minister, Commodore Voreque Bainimarama, who in turn reappointed his interim ministers . The interim ministers were also reappointed by the president .
 The Pacific Islands Forum summit meeting was held in Cairns, Australia, in August . Fiji is one of the most important countries in the world to host the summit .
 Fiji’s membership in the Pacific Islands Forum and Commonwealth was suspended in May . Fiji also suspended from membership of the Commonwealth in September . Fiji's membership in Commonwealth was also suspended in September.
 On July 28, Bainimarama announced that the ailing 88-year-old Iloilo was retiring from office . He was succeeded as acting president by Vice Pres. Iloillo, who was succeeded by Vice President Iloano .
 Tourism, a mainstay of Fiji’s economy, was assisted by a 20% devaluation in the Fijian dollar . The country continued to open new hotels and to attract visitors from Australia and New Zealand .
 Fiji filed claim with the UN for recognition of an extended continental shelf in April . Fiji is hoping to secure rights to seabed minerals in the South Fiji Basin .
 The economy is heavily dependent on exports, which had accounted for 44% of GDP in 2008 . The economy was heavily dependent upon exports, with 44% GDP in 2009 .
 The value of exported goods dropped a historic 35% in the first quarter of 2009 from the same period a year earlier . Exporporations dropped 35% of export value of goods alone .
 Industrial production was at its lowest in 10 years, registering a 37.3% drop in August year-on-year . The drop was the biggest drop in industrial production in the last decade .
 GDP was 9.2% lower in July than it had been a year earlier . Unemployment rate grew to 8.8% in August; inflation dropped to -1% in September . Inflation in September was -1%, inflation was -2% .
 Finns elected five men and eight women to the European Parliament in June . Finns are the only Finns to hold seats in the European parliament .
 Timo Soini, chair of the True Finns, garnered the most votes and secured a seat for his party . Soini's party is sharply critical of immigration, which he says is illegal in Finland .
 The True Finns gained the most proportionately, capturing 9.8% of the vote, up from 0.5% in 2004 . Finns captured the most of Finland's vote in 2004, capturing just 0.6% of its vote .
 2008 scandal over unannounced campaign contributions unraveled further in 2009 . The 2008 scandal was the first of its kind in the country .
 Several stateowned or publicly funded entities chaired by politicians were found to have donated funds to the campaigns of said politicians . The funds were donated to the political candidates .
 The foundation had received funding from the state gambling monopoly RAY . RAY rules prohibit it from giving aid for political purposes .
 The downturn's impact was softened by the French state’s traditionally large role in the economy of spending and providing welfare . The French state has traditionally played a large part in the French economy .
 Many French took part in national street demonstrations to protest the government’s inability to do even more to protect jobs and wages . Yet with only a weak parliamentary opposition to air their complaints, many French take part in demonstrations .
 French model of regulated capitalism was hailed for steering the country clear of the excesses of Anglo-Saxon lending and borrowing . The French model was hailed by the French as a model of capitalism .
 Nicolas Sarkozy discarded the 43-year-old Gaullist model of semidetachment from NATO, however, and brought France fully back into the Atlantic alliance . Sarkozy scrapped the model of semi-separated separation from NATO .
 The popularity of Sarkozy had increased by the beginning of 2009, partly owing to the stabilization of his personal life through his marriage to singer and model Carla Bruni . Sarkozy was elected in 2007 to a five-year presidential term .
 His active governing style invited people to lay the blame for most problems at his door . His very active governing . style invites people to blame most problems on him rather than that of the government of his . Union for a Popular Movement .
 It was the first drop in France’s annual GDP since 1993 . Although this decline was smaller than that of many other countries, it was the biggest drop in the country's annual GDP .
 The government and workers began to adopt unorthodox tactics to stem the unemployment rate . The unemployment rate began to increase toward the 10% mark in 2009 .
 Sarkozy urged Peugeot to close its factories in the Czech Republic or Slovakia rather than in France . Days before authorizing loans to Renault and Peugeet-Citroen to sustain their car businesses, Sarkozy said .
 This caused a minor furor among his European Union partners and led the Czech Republic to convoke a special EU summit . The Czech Republic held the presidency of the EU in the first part of 2009 .
 Some French workers revived the practice of “bosses’s” protest in front of a Sony plant in the French village of Pontonx-sur-lAdour . Sony workers protested in April .
 Gabon detains bosses, usually just overnight, to try to get them to alter settlement deals . Gabon napping, or detaining their bosses, is a term for detaining them overnight .
 About 10 such boss-nappings occurred at plants owned by Molex of the United States and Sony of Japan . Molex plants in the U.S. and Japan are owned by both companies .
 The French economy improved in the second quarter, partly as a result of the French government's small but swift stimulus program of about $33 billion . This practice declined somewhat, however, as the economy improved .
 Sarkozy also planned a “national bond’s issue for investment of more than $50 billion in long-term research projects and the national infrastructure . Sarkozy planned a "national bond" issue .
 The financial issue of the year was the regulation of banks and bankers’ bonuses . Banks and bankers' bonuses were the top financial issues of 2013 .
 Sarkozy took a stand with German Chancellor Angela Merkel in EU and Group of 20 negotiations for tougher international controls on bonuses . Sarkozy has been in talks with Angela Merkel over the issue .
 At home he persuaded French bankers to agree to a code of practice linking bonuses to the longer-term performance of their banks .
 The French government did, however, provide banks with $56 billion in fresh capital and guaranteed $450 billion of their lending . French banks also received $500 billion in new loans .
 Sarkozy was elected on a promise to allow people to work more to earn more . After nearly two years of debate, he persuaded Parliament to pass legislation easing trading laws .
 The new law allowed all retail stores in certain areas to open for business on Sundays . The law was passed in 2010 .
 Lyon, the country's second largest urban area, objected to the plan . It was to take effect in 20 commercial zones around Paris, Lille, and Marseille and hundreds of smaller cities and towns that were often visited by tourists .
 Sarkozy also returned to the issue concerning the veiling of Muslim women . Sarkozy: "The veiling is not a problem. It is a problem for women in the Muslim world."
 In 2004 he had been instrumental in passing a measure forbidding students in French public schools to wear ostentatious religious symbols, such as Muslim head scarves .
 Sarkozy attacked the wearing of burkas by Muslim women as being a symbol of servitude unsuited to a republic dedicated to equal rights . In a June 2009 speech to Parliament, Sarkozy said burkas should not be worn in France .
 In June 7 European Parliament elections, the UMP became the first political party of a sitting French president to win since 1979 . The UMP is the first party to win under President Sark Sarkozy in the European Parliament .
 This result confirmed the splintering of the Socialists that began when Segolene Royal, their presidential candidate in 2007, lost the election to Sarkozy and then lost her bid to become the party’s leader to Martine Aubry, the mayor of Lille .
 Sarkozy continued to foster this splintering by giving cabinet jobs to Socialists, including in 2009 the nephew of Francois Mitterrand, the last Socialist president . Sarkozy's cabinet jobs have been filled with Socialists since 2009 .
 A few months after Frederic Mitterrand was appointed culture minister, a controversy erupted over his confession in a 2005 autobiography to having engaged in sex tourism in Asia . The former French culture minister was appointed in 2005 .
 Dominique de Villepin accused of having slandered Sarkozy in the so-called Clearstream affair . Sarkozy’s rival within the neo-Gaullist movement went on trial in September .
 Former President Jacques Chirac accused of embezzlement for allegedly using payroll to pay national political party operatives . Former mayor of Paris accused of using payroll for political operatives during his time as mayor .
 The trial of Chirac, who had enjoyed immunity from prosecution during his 12 years as president, was expected to take place in 2010 . The trial was due to begin in 2011 .
 Sarkozy started 2009 by attempting to mediate a cease-fire in Israel’s offensive in the Gaza Strip . Sarkozy had a very active EU presidency in 2008, following on the momentum of 2008 .
 France has the biggest Muslim and Jewish communities in Western Europe . In the past, Mideast tensions had reverberated in France .
 During the Gaza conflict, several synagogues and other Jewish sites in France were attacked or vandalized . During the Israel-Gaza conflict, many Jewish sites were vandalized or attacked .
 Sarkozy had no desire to displace the diplomatic role of the U.S., particularly under Pres. Barack Obama . Sarkozy wanted to avoid disinterpreting some of his predecessors' diplomatic posts .
 Charles de Gaulle's 1966 decision to leave NATO's integrated military command was made in 1966 . The French general led the French army to leave the integrated command in 1967 .
 France fully rejoined NATO at the April 2009 NATO summit in Strasbourg, France . France joined the alliance at the end of 2009 .
 France has always sent troops to NATO operations . The immediate military significance of this move was limited . France had always sent soldiers to NATO .
 French acceptance of NATO as a European institution . It ended the long-running ""European" versus ""Atlanticist” political tension in the alliance .

 Year brought success in Germany’s fight against age discrimination in the workplace . On a more positive note, the year brought success for age discrimination .

 Reports in 2009 showed an increase in employment of those aged 50 and above . Employers and unemployment agencies reported a rise in employment .
 The slight increase in the fertility rate in 2007 and 2008 was attributed to a new measure that encouraged fathers as well as mothers to take time off from work to care for their newborns . The measure was introduced in 2007 .
 Statistics released in 2009 indicated that about 20% of new fathers were choosing to remain at home for a time so that the mothers could return to work sooner . Statistics show that 20% are choosing to stay at home .
 This trend was expected to have long-term impacts on the German economy . It was hoped it would increase the likelihood that working women would have children .
 A rise in the number of births would also require the expansion of the day-care system . Day-care is underdeveloped in many German regions, especially in Germany .
 The policy encouraging greater involvement of men in the upbringing of their children was the product of the minister for family matters, Ursula von der Leyen of the Christian Democratic Union .
 All these policies were historically atypical for the conservative CDU and symptomatic of the broad identity struggle that had been occurring within the party for a few years .
 CDU's identity crisis was visible in the election campaign and diminished the CDU’s lead over the other parties in opinion polls . The identity crisis has been visible in Germany's election campaign . The CDU is currently leading the polls in Germany .

 Angela Merkel and her Christian Democrats began the election year anticipating a win . This seemed like good news for Chancellor Angela Merkel, who had hoped to win the election .
 This optimism was shaken on various occasions throughout the following nine months . This optimism continued to be shaken throughout the course of the year .
 Many of the CDU’s policies relating to the economic crisis and to gender and social politics seemed to be more in keeping with the traditional political philosophy of the Social Democrats .
 This led to the impression, among voters as well as parliamentarians, that the Christian Democratic political program was diffuse and undefined, even that close to the election . The Christian Democratic Party's political program is diffuse, undefined, according to the report .

 Atheists and the nonreligious accounted for about 30% of the population by 2009 . Percentage of adherents in the Roman Catholic and Protestant faiths each dropped from about 50% to only some 30% .
