 Arias proposed a plan that would return Zelaya to the presidency but also would require him to form a national unity government and abandon efforts to change the constitution . Arias' proposal failed to pass .
 Zelaya returned to Honduras on September 21, taking refuge in the Brazilian embassy in Tegucigalpa . Zelaya has been living in Brazil since September 21 .
 On December 2, Congress voted against restoring Zelaya to office for the final two months of his term . Zelaya was elected to office in March 2010 .
 Gyurcsany announced in March that he would stand aside as prime minister . Economy Minister Gordon Bajnai became prime minister in mid-April . Bajai is the current prime minister of Hungary .
 Bajnai accepted only a symbolic salary of 1 forint for taking on the crisis-management role . He said he would step down after the general elections in the spring of 2010 .
 Bajnai inherited an economy on the verge of collapse, public debt standing at 77% of GDP, and strict IMF conditions . Public debt is 77% and a set of strict IMF terms .
 The forint had lost 20% of its value against the euro, which made it difficult for the government to service its foreign-currency-denominated debt . The loss of the forint means it will be difficult for Hungary to service foreign-creditorial debt .
 The financial crisis also directly affected the 1.1 million citizens who had taken out foreign-currency mortgages and loans . More than a sixth of the population took out loans and mortgages . The crisis has also affected 1.6 million people .
 A nonparty technocrat himself, Bajnai created a government of experts, cut ministerial salaries by 15%, and announced an austerity program . The austerity program included radical cuts in all areas of public spending and reform of health care, pension, and education systems .
 He overhauled the tax system by cutting personal income tax rates and employers’ social security contributions . He also increased the valueadded tax and excise and business taxes .
 His government also introduced a new “wealth” tax on property and luxury items . His government has also introduced new ‘wealth’ tax on luxury items and property .
 Hungary’s credit ratings were downgraded in the spring, easing investors’ fears about the country’�s prospects for riding out the global financial crisis . Bajnai's achievements later eased investors' fears that the country would ride out the crisis .
 The opposition Fidesz-Hungarian Civic Alliance secured 56% of the vote in June European Parliament elections . The opposition was critical of the new government, but secured a large majority .
 The biggest election surprise was the success of the far-right fringe party Jobbik, which had campaigned on an anti-Jewish and anti-Roma platform . The far right party's success was the result of a wave of support for the far right .
 Jobbik won 15% of the vote and became the most popular extremist party in Hungary since the fall of communism in 1989 . No powerful politicians or public figures were associated with it, even though no powerful politicians were .
 A disconcerting shift toward extremism in Hungary was also indicated by a string of attacks on the country’s Roma community . Growing public support for the Jobbik-allied paramilitary organization known as the Hungarian Guard .
 The black-uniformed group was banned during the summer by a Budapest court . It was later reconstituted under a different name under different name . Budapest court banned the group in the summer .
 In the autumn bilateral relations between Slovakia and Hungary hit rock bottom . The Slovak parliament approved amendments to its state language law that criminalized the use of minority languages, including Hungarian, in public .
 Hungary's parliamentary parties condemned the law, and Bajnai’s government turned to Brussels for help . Hungary's Hungarian-speaking community made up some 10% of the population . The law was passed by Hungary's parliamentarians and the Slovak government .
 The Bajnai government spent more than 3% of GDP on bank bailouts and loan-guarantee programs . Though no banks collapsed, the Bajai government spent 3% GDP on bail-outs .
 Real GDP contracted by an estimated 8-10%, unemployment increased to more than 10%, and the country became heavily indebted abroad . The country is heavily indebted at home and abroad, according to experts .

 Anxiety about the economy compounded by renewed concern about terrorism in the region, sparked by the vicious terrorist attacks in Mumbai in late November 2008 .
 The ruling coalition, the United Progressive Alliance, succeeded in returning to power in the general elections of May 2009 . Despite these problems, the coalition improved its seat tally in the Lok Sabha, the lower house of parliament .
 India's 15th general elections to the lower house of parliament, the Lok Sabha, were conducted over a fourweek period from April 16 to May 13,2009 . The Lok Sabha is India's parliament's lower house .
 No single party had been able since 1984 to secure a majority in the parliament . No single political party had ever secured a majority since 1984 .
 India's oldest and largest party, the Indian National Congress, had led a coalition known as the United Progressive Alliance to form governments since May 2004 . As a result, the country's oldest party had led the coalition since 2004 .
 Pranab Mukherjee continued as leader of the party in the Lok Sabha . Singh was elected to the parliament as a member of the Rajya Sabha, the upper house, the party's seniormost leader .
 Triumvirate of Sonia Gandhi, her son, Rahul, and Manmohan Singh ran the party . The government was headed by Gandhi, Singh, and Mukherjee .
 Mukherjee, a longtime cabinet member, became the finance minister in 2009 . He has remained the government's principal troubleshooter and problem solver .
 More political parties contested the election than in previous years . In most constituencies the battle was fought mainly between three or four major contenders . Some newly founded parties, such as Praja Rajyam registered their presence .
 Mayawati Kumari, Mulayam Singh Yadav and Chandrababu Naidu thought to be the main contenders for the prime ministership . The former Andhra Pradesh chief minister, Chandramadu, is the main contender for the post .
 The ideological platforms of Indian political parties were traditionally trifurcated into left, right, and centre . The ideological platform of Indian parties was traditionally left and right . The party's ideological platforms have traditionally been left or right .
 Parties often adopt diametrically opposite policy platforms while in opposition and in government . Such sharp distinctions based on Western political thought tend to break down in India .
 A growing number of regionaland caste-based parties also tend to adopt shifting platforms .
 In the 2009 elections as well, it was difficult to classify the election manifestos of the three major coalitions neatly along this left, right, and centre axis, however apparent the nature of the political divide .
 The left had a more traditional political platform, echoing its favourite political positions on domestic and global affairs . The left's platform echoed its favourite positions, including that of foreign policy .
 Most opinion polls and several exit polls had forecast a ""hung"" parliament, with no coalition capable of forming a stable government . Most polls and exit polls said no coalition could form a government .
 The BJP and the parties of the left were dealt a severe blow, with the left facing ignominious defeats in West Bengal and Kerala .
 The BJP found itself engaged in a prolonged fratricidal war, with party leader Advani facing severe criticism . Advani's position remained unchallenged, however, owing to internal divisions on the naming of his successor .
 Government failures lay at the root of many of India’s problems with law and order, civil strife, and insurgency . Government reform was not a key issue in the elections, but government failures are key to many of the country's problems .
 Indian economy slowed to a growth rate of 7.1% in 2008-09 and was expected to record an even lower rate of 6.3-6.5% in 2009-10 . After an unprecedented five-year run of a nearly 9% average annual rate of growth,
 An equally important factor was the poor monsoon rains in 2009, the weakest in more than 35 years, which had a negative impact on agricultural output . The poor monsoarsoon rains have also had an impact on agriculture output .
 The Indian banking and financial system had virtually no direct exposure to American subprime-mortgage assets or to the financial institutions in the U.S. that were at the heart of the crisis . The country's financial system has virtually no exposure to subprime mortgage assets .
 The early prudent and risk-averse regulation of the financial system helped to limit the impact of the trans-Atlantic financial crisis on the Indian financial sector . The financial crisis was the biggest financial crisis in the world in the 1980s .
 The economy was negatively affected, however, by various other channels . The economy has been negatively affected by various channels .
 Indian corporations’ access to foreign commercial loans was curtailed . This resulted in the cost of credit going up, since interest rates were higher in India . Second, Indian companies’ . interest rates in India are higher than in other countries .
 Reduced portfolio investment in Indian equities by international institutional investors pushed Indian stock market indexes down . India's stock market index index down .
 To counter the impact of the slowdown, the government unveiled fiscal stimulus packages in late 2008 and early 2009 .
 Additional public spending contributed to an increase in the governments fiscal and budgetary deficits . This additional public spending has contributed to a rise in public spending in the past .
 A liberal fiscal policy along with insufficient monsoon rains and an expected downturn in agricultural production contributed to inflationary pressures . Inflationary pressures are also expected to be seen as a factor in inflationary pressure .
 Managing relations with Pakistan in the aftermath of the 2008 terrorist attacks in Mumbai emerged as a major foreign-policy challenge in 2009 . Managing relations between Pakistan and the U.S. became a major issue in the wake of the Mumbai terror attacks .
 India’s relations with the United States, where a new administration took charge, and with China . Equal attention had to be paid to India's relations with U.S. and China, writes Andrew Hammond .
 India officially accused Pakistan’s chief spy agency of having conspired to stage the terror attacks in Mumbai . India has accused Pakistan of conspiring to carry out the Mumbai terror attacks .
 The Indian government provided information to Pakistan showing links between the terrorists who attacked Mumbai and militants based in Pakistan . Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence agency claimed the terrorists were “clients and creations’’
 Pakistan initially refused to accept any link to the Mumbai attacks . It later conceded that some “nonstate actors” based in Pakistan might have been involved in planning the attacks . Pakistan denied the charge, initially refusing to accept it .
 The action taken against those identified by India and the United States as coconspirators also became a contentious issue . India and U.S. have taken action against some of the alleged conspirators .
 Pakistan had charged India with having aided Baloch rebels, while India maintained that the Baloch nationalist movement was an entirely homegrown resistance movement . Pakistan had accused India of aiding the rebels .

 Simultaneous elections were held in April for the national, provincial, and district legislatures . Those were followed by direct presidential elections in July .
 The elections were largely peaceful and, in the opinion of most observers, reasonably fair, despite some administrative bungles by the Election Commission . The election was largely peaceful, but some observers say it was not fair .

 Indonesia's Islamic parties together gathered just 29% of the vote, down from the roughly 37% that they had received in 1999 and 2004 elections . In their worst-ever election result, Indonesia’s Islamic parties gather just 29%, down from 37% .
 Two new political parties, Gerindra and Hanura, returned vote totals of less than 5%, despite expensive advertising and voter-mobilization campaigns . The parties were led by prominent former generals Prabowo Subianto and Wiranto .
 After trailing Megawati in opinion surveys in mid2008, the president was able to regain the ascendancy . Polls consistently showed him to be by far the most popular and trusted politician in Indonesia .
 SBY's revival was due in large measure to voter approval of his government’s economic policies, which were credited with offsetting the worst effects of the global financial crisis .
 Indonesia had one of the strongest-performing economies in the region, with an annual growth rate of 4.2% that ranked behind only China and India . Indonesia is one of only two countries with a higher growth rate than India and China .
 Robust domestic consumer demand and high export commodity prices were chief drivers of Indonesia’s economic expansion . Robust consumer demand was the key to Indonesia's economic growth in recent years .

 Indonesia experienced its first terrorist attack in almost four years on July 17 . Two suicide bombers struck the luxury JW Marriott and Ritz-Carlton hotels in Jakarta . 9 people were killed and 50 others were injured .
 Responsibility for the bombing was claimed by Noordin Top, a former member of the Jemaah Islamiyah terrorist organization .
 A string of arrests followed, culminating in the shooting of Noordin and several of his top associates at their hideout in Central Java . The suspect was shot dead at his hideout .
 Noordin’s death was a heavy blow for violent jihadism in Indonesia . He had been a key figure in all of the major terrorist bombings in the country since 2003 .
 In late September and early October, several earthquakes struck western Indonesia, causing devastation and heavy loss of life . The Padang region of West Sumatra was hit by the quakes .
 The confirmed death toll exceeded 600, with estimates that more than 1,000 people may have perished . The confirmed deaths are thought to be the result of the earthquake .
 The collapse of many public buildings prompted calls for tighter construction standards . Scientists were warning of more severe quakes over the next two decades .

 The Iraqi Council of Representatives adopted the long-awaited new election law on November 8 . After repeated delays, the law was adopted after repeated delays . Iraq's election law was passed by the Iraqi parliament in November 2013 .
 The law had been held up largely by the explosive dispute over the oil-rich province of Kirkuk . Arabs, Kurds, and Turkmen each claimed a majority in Kirkuk, where Arabs and Kurds claim a majority .
 The parliament agreed to use voter rolls from 2009 and not 2005 . Many displaced Kurds had not yet moved back into the region by that year . The parliament resolved the contention, temporarily, by agreeing to use voters rolls .
 The new election law provided for an open list, rather than a closed list, in which voters would not know the names of individual candidates . Voters could choose candidates by name rather than by name .
 He sought more seats in the parliament for some 2. million Iraqi refugees, most of whom were Sunni . Most of the refugees are Sunni, but most of them are Sunni .

 The date for the 2010 elections was rescheduled from January 16 to March 7 . The 2010 elections were originally scheduled for January 16 .
 Iraq still suffered from a lack of security in the country . However, the year saw an improvement in security compared with previous years .

 In February the government agreed to provide Allied Irish Banks and the Bank of Ireland each approximately $5.25 billion in recapitalization funds . In September it proposed legislation to set up a “bad bank” to absorb nonperforming loans from a number of domestic commercial banks .
 A government advisory committee published a report in July that identified $7.7 billion in possible public spending cuts . The report suggested a 5% reduction in social welfare payments and the elimination of more than 17,000 public-sector jobs .

 Among the more controversial suggestions were cuts in health care spending, the closure of half of all police stations, and sharp reductions in payments to farmers .

 The Commission to Inquire into Child Abuse published its final report in May . It was established in 2000 to investigate abuse of children in Catholic-run residential institutions in Ireland from the 1930s onward .
 The report concluded that beatings and neglect were routine and that sexual abuse was “endemic” in institutions . Church authorities were often aware of the abuse and made efforts to protect offenders from legal charges .
 A separate inquiry into child-abuse allegations against clergy members in Dublin ended in July . The inquiry focused on allegations made against 46 priests between 1975 and 2004 and on how those complaints were handled .
 The inquiry’s findings caused considerable public disquiet over the role of senior churchmen . Churchmen were criticized for not pursuing allegations of child sex abuse by clergy with sufficient vigour .

 Shalit had been held prisoner by Hamas militants since June 2006 . Israeli Defense Forces struck with overwhelming power, sending in ground forces .
 Israel lost only 10 soldiers and 3 civilians during the operation . Hamas fighters launched hundreds of rocket attacks during the raid .
 The disparity between the death tolls and the widespread destruction in Gaza led to claims that the IDF's response had been disproportionate and indiscriminate . Israel's response to the deaths in Gaza was criticized as disproportionate .
 Israel argued that its soldiers had operated strictly within the laws of war and had made strenuous efforts to warn civilians to move out of harm’s way before impending attacks . Israel said its soldiers were fighting militants who were embedded in heavily populated urban areas .

 The commission heard testimony mainly from Palestinians, as Israel refused to cooperate . Israel said the commission's mandate was inherently biased . Israel also said that the commission was biased .

 The United States market was still the destination for approximately four-fifths of all Mexican exports . Mexico had in recent years somewhat reduced its heavy trade dependence on the U.S. market .
 The country's manufacturing sector was badly affected by the sharp decline in U.S. import demand during the year .
 The automobile and auto parts sector is Mexico’s most important source of manufactured exports . The sector suffered because of the broader crisis in the North American automotive industry . The automobile industry is Mexico's biggest source of exports .
 Mexican exports declined by approximately onethird between 2008 and 2009 . Overall, Mexican exports fell by approximately 10% between 2008-2009 .
 The Mexican economy also suffered from a substantial falloff in foreign direct investment flows . Lower prices for petroleum and other (mainly mining) commodity exports also hurt the economy .
 Mexican officials successfully hedged the price of oil and gas exports for the 2008-09 fiscal year at a premium over prevailing international petroleum prices . Lower international prices (though partially offset by a significant devaluation of the peso) had a negative fiscal impact .
 Mexican emigration to the United States slowed by tougher U.S. immigration controls and reduced demand for labour in sectors that typically employed large numbers of immigrant workers, such as construction .
 Flow of migrant remittances to Mexico fell by more than 10% between 2008 and 2009 . Remittances were the country’s largest source of legal export earnings, after petroleum .
 The number of households reporting the receipt of remittances declined by approximately one-fifth between 2005 (when 1.41 million households reported receiving) and 2009 . The decline is one-in-five between 2005 and 2009, according to the OECD .
 Mexico’s economic woes were exacerbated during the year by the outbreak of H1N1 flu in early April . The outbreak of the virus was also blamed for exacerbating the country's economic woes .
 The world’s first confirmed case of the H1N1 virus was reported in the state of Veracruz, Mexico . The virus was first confirmed in the country to be reported in October 2013 .
 In June the World Health Organization declared the H1N1 flu a global pandemic . By late December it had claimed the lives of at least 12,000 people worldwide .
 The Mexican government responded aggressively to the threat by closing schools and universities, sports arenas, cinemas, museums, and churches nationwide . The government also closed all public venues in Mexico City, as well as restaurants and restaurants .
 Some experts judged that public health agencies had been slow in genomically identifying the new virus . Government generally received positive evaluations for its efforts to contain the crisis .

 Dutch government found itself in the midst of controversy over treaties it had made with Belgium in 2005 . In the area of foreign relations, the Dutch government had made treaties with Belgium .
 One of the treaties’ provisions concerned the Western Schelde estuary, which lies within The Netherlands but gives the Belgian city of Antwerp access to the North Sea . The treaty’s provisions also concerned the Eastern Schelde, which is within the Netherlands .
 The 2005 agreement stipulated that the Dutch would deepen the estuary in order to accommodate the largest oceangoing vessels 24 hours a day .
 The Dutch Council of State blocked the start of the work, citing possible environmental consequences . While the Belgian government had agreed to a two-year delay, patience ran thin when the Dutch council of state blocked the work .

 In 2009 Qatar continued its trajectory of economic growth . The country's capital is Doha .

 Press reports made much of occasional signs of tension or disagreement between the president and the prime minister . But in general the tandem appeared to be working smoothly .

 This was the result of an increase in the birth rate, a decline in mortality rates, and an influx of immigrants . The birth rate has increased in the past decade .
 Russia was severely hit by the global financial crisis . Falling oil prices and the general economic slowdown both took their toll . Russia's economy has been hit hard by the fall in recent years .
 Russia entered the crisis with a strong budget, balance of payments, and reserves . The downturn followed a decade of rapid economic growth fueled by high and rising energy prices . Since this downturn followed the downturn, Russia entered this year's crisis .
 Policy makers were able to cover a budget deficit on the order of 8% of GDP, mainly by drawing down the reserve fund that had been built up from oil and gas revenues .
 The scale of the recession in Russia was greater than many had expected . Even so, many had been surprised by the extent of the impact on the economy .
 Many investors, both Russian and foreign, have reacted to the crisis by reducing their investment activity in Russia . They perceived underlying weaknesses in its economic institutions, such as the weak rule of law and the poor protection of property rights, they say .
 Corruption was endemic and, despite a number of high-profile initiatives, showed no sign of decreasing . Corruption is endemic and showed no signs of decreasing, says the BBC .
 There was much hopeful speculation by liberal intellectuals that the economic crisis would force the leadership to liberalize both economically and politically . The economic crisis led to the collapse of the United States .
 The most astute Russian analysts saw little prospect of radical reform that would introduce real competition into either the economy or the political system .
 Fears that the crisis would push leadership toward more interventionist policies proved unfounded . Authorities did not—as many had predicted they would—exploit the crisis to take control of large deeply indebted companies .
 Foreign creditors of cashstrapped Russian energy and metals companies had little appetite for taking assets offered as collateral into their own hands, and they restructured loans on a generous basis .
 This proved advantageous to tycoons such as Oleg Deripaska and Roman Abramovich, who, though relatively impoverished, were not as weakened as originally anticipated . This was not as much as originally thought, but it proved advantageous .
 In October Putin announced that as in previous years, there would be some privatization in 2010 and 2011, partly to pursue the reform agenda . Foreign investors would be able to take part .
 Unemployment rose from less than 6% in the summer of 2008 to 10% in March 2009 . Unemployment in the United States is now 10% . Unemployment is now at a record high .
 First, some workers who had lost their jobs (including a number of previously employed pensioners) dropped out of the workforce altogether . Second, some of those who had been employed in the UK have been found to have dropped out .
 Federal and regional governments pressured employers to halt sackings . Foreign firms operating in Russia, such as Renault, were also pressured to stop sacking . Renault: "It's a job for Russia, not for Russia"
 Regional unemployment data showed that the crisis was affecting the regions in very different ways . Regional unemployment figures show that unemployment rates are rising in some regions .
 Those hardest hit were the so-called metallurgical regions, where industry is dominated by steel and nonferrous-metals production .
 Least hard-hit were the poorest regions that had traditionally relied on the federal centres for financial subsidies, including many parts of the North Caucasus . Least-hard-hit areas were regions that relied heavily on federal centres .
 Many workers suffered wage arrears or shortened workweeks or were forced to take unpaid leave . Many workers were forced into unpaid leave or had to be taken off work weeks . Workers were also forced to go unpaid leave from their jobs .
 There were fears that ""monotowns” (industrial settlements created in the Soviet period around a single industry or factory) would become a locus of social unrest . There were also fears that industrial settlements created around a one industry would be a place of unrest .
 In fact, though there were protests in such towns, they remained small and isolated . The protests in these towns remained small, isolated, isolated .
 By the autumn there were signs that the Russian economy was emerging from recession . Russia's economy was seen to be recovering from the recession .
 Each month's output remained below the level of the corresponding month of 2008 . But the changes from one month to the next became positive in June and remained so in June . The third quarter's output in the third quarter was above that in the second quarter .

 The severity of the economic crisis brought wide—if not universal—acceptance within the elite that economic modernization was an urgent necessity . Economic modernization is an important part of the world's future .
 The elite was sharply divided, however, over what form the reforms should take . The elite is divided on what form of the reforms will take .

 Russia should sit it out and then, when times are better, pursue modernization by investing in cutting-edge technology . Russia should also sit out of the crisis and pursue modernization, says the Russian minister .
 Representatives of this group were believed to include Deputy Prime Minister Igor Sechin and the director general of the Russian Technologies state corporation, Sergey Chemezov .
 As the crisis deepened, he began calling for greater social spending and intervening personally to ward off social unrest .

 Sweden suffered greatly from the global economic downturn in 2009 . As a small, open, and export-oriented economy, Sweden suffered much from the downturn .
 The Finance Ministry estimated that GDP contracted by 5.2%, after having been at a virtual standstill the year before . The finance ministry estimated that the country's GDP was at a standstill last year .
 The production of key Swedish exports, such as cars, trucks, specialty steel, has diminished rapidly . Sweden's key exports, including cars and trucks, have diminished rapidly.
 Many companies, such as truck-making giant Scania, have reduced work hours and salaries to offset falling demand from abroad .
 Employees and unions reluctantly accepted these cuts to avoid job losses . The employees and unions have reluctantly accepted the cuts .
 Unemployment in Sweden was the most alarming feature of the Swedish economic crisis . In Sweden, unemployment was the highest rate of unemployment in the country .
 The unemployment rate rose from 5.8% in July 2008 to more than 8% in the autumn of 2009 . Full employment had been the proud goal of all governments for decades .
 In its budget for 2010, the government projected that unemployment would reach more than 11% that year . In 2010, unemployment was projected to reach 11% for the first time .
 The government responded to the economic downturn by providing a massive fiscal stimulus package . The stimulus package was part of a massive government response .
 The budget bill for 2010 included tax cuts on ordinary incomes as well as subsidies for municipalities and for the education and training of the unemployed .
 The central bank also supported Swedish banks with generous lending facilities . By autumn none of the banks had needed any formal state aid .
 Three of the largest banks, Nordea, SEB, and Swedbank, approved capital increases . Shareholders in three of the biggest banks approve capital increases instead of capital hikes .
 Late in the year some indicators suggested that the worst of the Swedish economic crises was over . The government might even have been overly pessimistic in its assumptions in 2013 .
 Shares on Stockholm stock exchange rose by almost 40% from January to October . Shares on the Stockholm Stock Exchange rose by nearly 40% between January and October . Sweden's economy is the world's largest economy .
 The financial markets started to anticipate rising sales and profits in 2010 and beyond after the ""lost year” of 2009 . Financial markets anticipate rising profits and sales in 2010 .
 Many economists believed that Sweden would be in a favourable position to resume growth once the international economy started to pick up . Sweden's economy is expected to grow again in the coming years .
 Sweden is one of the few European economies to return to a growth of more than 1% in 2010 . IMF predicted that Sweden would be one of only few countries to grow more than a 1% . Sweden's deficit is below the EU average .

 The Daily Telegraph newspaper bought a pirated copy of a computer disk containing previously secret information . The paper devoted much of its news coverage for some weeks to disclosing the details of MPs’ expense claims .
 This showed how many MPs had exploited the expenses system to use public money to make tax-free profits on property dealings . MPs had used public funds to fund spending that had nothing to do with their parliamentary duties .
 Examples included being reimbursed for building a duck house, maintaining a tennis court, and cleaning out a moat .
 The disclosures led to resignations both of government ministers and of Conservative “shadow’s ministers .

 Amid the global recession, the U.K.'s GDP fell by 2.5% in the first quarter of 2009 . The U.S. economy is in a deep recession .
 The recession was the longest since quarterly GDP data were first collected in 1955 . The declines were gentler after that, although the third-quarter slide of 0.2% was the sixth quarterly decline .
 By the end of the year, there were signs that the trough of the recession had been reached, with output 6% below its earlv-2008 peak, and a tentative recovery had begun .

 In 2009, after decades of international economic, military, and political leadership, the U.S. faced serious limits on its ability to control world affairs . President Barack Obama took office in January 2009 .
 Years of fiscal excess exacerbated the effects of a severe global recession, reducing U.S. influence abroad . Less-developed countries, including China, have assumed the role of economic growth in the United States . China is now taking over the role as the world's economic engine .
 Barack Obama started the year with high expectations and ended it with what appeared to be a significant legislative victory . But he also learned the limits of power in a politically divided country .
 The United States struggled through the year under the burden of its most severe economic downturn since the Great Depression . The U.S. suffered the worst year of economic downturn in decades .
 The United States adopted unprecedented stimulus measures aimed at saving jobs and restoring growth . The measures were joined by other major governments, including the United States .
 By year’s end the intervention appeared to have stopped the economic decline . But economists worried that recovery would be slow by historical standards and hindered by excessive government intervention and borrowing .
 The U.S. recession officially started in December 2007 . The slump accelerated as businesses reacted to major financial market turmoil the following year .
 GDP contracted 6.3% in late 2008 and early 2009, the most dismal two quarters for the U.S. economy in more than 60 years . GDP contracted 5.7% in early 2009 and 6.2% in 2008, the worst two quarters in 60 years for the
 In mid-February, Obama signed a $787 billion stimulus spending measure . The measure was signed by Obama in February .
 Financial markets reacted negatively, with stock prices sinking to 1997 levels by early March . Initially, financial markets reacted to financial markets reacting negatively . Stock prices sank by more than 20 per cent in March .
 As more cracks in the economy appeared, the federal government responded with increasing activism . The government responded to the cracks with increasing government activism .
 The Treasury Department was forced to extend a total of $80 billion to two ailing automobile manufacturers . The Treasury took 8% ownership of Chrysler and a 61% stake in General Motors, forcing both companies into temporary bankruptcy .
 Insurance giant AIG took $170 billion in government funds to remain solvent after staggering losses . Insurance giant reinsured numerous mortgage securities that went sour .
 By late spring, financial institutions had begun to stabilize, aided by loans authorized under the 2008 Troubled Assets Relief Program emergency legislation . Financial institutions were stabilized by late spring .
 Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner established “stress tests’s” to make certain remaining banks were adequately capitalized and accurately projecting their losses . The tests were established to make sure remaining banks had adequate capitalized .
 The United States central bank kept interest rates at historic lows to encourage borrowing and economic activity . The U.S. central bank keeps interest rates in historic low levels .
 The target rate for federal funds was pegged at zero to 0.25% for the entire year . That helped keep rates for business loans and mortgages down .
 The Federal Reserve pumped well over $1 trillion into the economy by purchasing Treasury bonds and mortgage instruments . It effectively printed new money to keep interest rates at minimal levels . The Fed has kept interest rates low .
 Unemployment hit 10.2% in October, the highest rate in more than a quarter of a century . Jobless rate eased slightly to 10% in December, but job losses continued in December .
 The upswing erased most of the stock market losses of 2008, which averaged some 40% . But it also produced major inequities in the financial sector .
 By year’s end, the seven largest banks that received TARP funding had repaid the government with dividends and interest . The seven biggest banks that had received the government's TARP funds had repaid it with dividends, interest .
 Financial industry executives were receiving outsized bonuses even as jobs continued to disappear across the country . This meant that some financial industry executives received outsized salaries . This was despite the fact that jobs were disappearing across the U.S.
 GDP finally turned positive in the third quarter, gaining 2.2% and raising hopes that the country was emerging from recession . GDP is expected to recover from recession in the coming months .
 Some economists say the economic growth was made possible only by temporary federal stimulus programs . The stimulus programs include a $3 billion “cash for clunkers” program designed to remove gas cars .
 For the first time in 35 years, Social Security and other pensioners received no inflation adjustment . Consumer price index for the fiscal year ended September 30 actually dropped . The consumer price index actually dropped for fiscal year .
 Energy and food prices began climbing again late in the year, signaling an imminent return to modest inflation of recent years . Even so, energy, food prices are climbing again, signaling a return of modest inflation .
 The recession erased most remaining traces of fiscal responsibility in Washington . The recession wiped most of the nation's fiscal responsibility out of control .
 Stimulative policies helped balloon the U.S. federal deficit to $1.42 trillion for the fiscal year . The deficit was three times the previous record set a year earlier . Stimulus policies helped boost the deficit to three times previous record .
 A similar deficit was forecast for fiscal year 2010, part of a deficit projection of $9 trillion for the next decade . The deficit is forecast for the fiscal year of 2010 . The U.S. is projected to have a deficit of nearly $10 trillion in 2010 .
 Fiscal imbalance helped depress the value of the U.S. dollar against foreign currencies in 2013 . Low interest rates, low interest rates also contributed to the drop in the dollar value .
 Obama entered office vowing to reduce partisanship in Washington, but he made little progress in his first year . Like his predecessor, he entered office with a pledge of reducing partisanship .
 With Democrats holding majorities in both houses of Congress, Obama allowed Congress to shape legislation . Obama allowed congressional leaders to shape important legislation . Democrats hold substantial majorities in Congress .
 Republicans were largely excluded from substantive negotiations on key bills . Republicans were able to slow progress on several of Obama’s legislative priorities .
 In the president’s first month in office, Democrats pushed three major bills through Congress with minimal or no Republican support . In the first month of Obama's presidency, the president's first major bill was pushed through Congress without GOP support .
 The second bill was a reauthorization and expansion of the State Children's Health Insurance Program . The measure had been vetoed twice by former president George W Bush as fiscally irresponsible .
 The House of Representatives passed a third bill without any Republican votes . The $787 billion stimulus spending measure was passed without any GOP votes .
 The partisan actions helped solidify the Republican caucus, particularly in the Senate, where 60 votes are required for most legislative action .
 The president was able to accomplish numerous changes through executive order in early 2009 . The president's executive order was passed by executive order .
 In January Obama rescinded the “Mexico City policy”— which had been reinstated by Bush in 2001— to allow the resumption of U.S. foreign aid funding for international family planning groups .
 In March he removed restrictions on federal funding for stem cell research that had been established by Bush administration . The Bush administration had established the restrictions eight years earlier .
 Obama’s overall job-approval rating, as measured by public opinion polls, topped 65% in early 2009 but dropped steadily to around 50% in late December . The president's overall job approval rating is now 50% .
 His rating was weighed down by rising unemployment, perceived federal overreaching, and hard decisions that he had to make on his legislative and policy agendas .
 Obama renominated Ben Bemanke for a second term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board . The nomination was quickly bogged down amid congressional demands for more transparency and added control over the Fed .
 In June, Obama proposed a sweeping increase in federal authority over the country’s financial institutions . Obama declared that the subprime mortgage crisis had been caused by ""insufficient regulation”
 By December the House had approved legislation that cracked down on hedge funds and credit-rating agencies . The legislation also increased congressional scrutiny of Fed monetary policy .
 Later in June the House approved a controversial Obama administration energy and environmental protection bill . The bill was approved on a largely party-line vote .
 The “capand-trade’s” legislation would establish a system of buying and selling pollution permits to meet emissions limits . The legislation aimed to slash greenhouse-gas emissions to 17% below 2005 levels by 2020 .
 Opponents say the legislation would hamstring American industry and cause major increases in taxes and the cost of American goods . Opponents said it would hamstring U.S. industry .
 The Senate failed to take up cap-and-trade legislation during 2009 as opposition mounted . Several analysts declared the cap and trade concept dead, and several analysts declared it dead .
 At year's end Obama obtained a major victory on his top domestic policy priority . Both chambers of Congress approved national health care reform bills after contentious legislative bargaining .
 Both bills would extend access to health insurance to an additional 30 million Americans . They would prohibit denial of coverage by insurers, require most Americans to obtain insurance or face financial penalties .
 The bills would pay for expanded care in part through tax increases on higher-income earners and reductions in payments to providers of Medicare and Medicaid services .
 Democrats were optimistic that Obama would eventually get a final bill to sign, but serious problems remained . Democrats are optimistic that the bill will eventually be signed, but there are still many problems .
 Critics complained that the legislation would raise revenues quickly but delay benefits . Critics called into question its estimated $900 billion price tag over 10 years . Critics say it would raise revenue quickly, delay benefits and raise costs .
 No GOP member voted for either health care reform bill or a government takeover of health care . It's hot good enough for U.S.
 The Senate dropped a provision setting up a government-run insurance option to compete with private firms, angering liberal Democrats . The Senate also watered down a strict House measure prohibiting public funds from being spent on abortion services .
 At year's end, support for the legislation dropped markedly amid allegations that some Senate votes had been effectively bought via special-interest provisions . The legislation was passed in the Senate in December .
 The apparent breakthrough on health care provided an upbeat ending to a difficult first year for the new administration . Even so, the apparent breakthrough provides an upbeat end to a tough first year .
 President Obama moved quickly in departing from Bush administration efforts to combat Islamist terrorism and extremism . President Obama left the Bush administration behind efforts to fight Islamist terrorism .
 Obama signed executive orders that banned the use of harsh interrogation techniques on captured terrorist suspects . He also called for closing the United States military detention facility at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba .
 The Guantanamo deadline was especially controversial and proved overly ambitious . It was especially ambitious and proved over ambitious .
 Few countries were interested in taking high-risk prisoners . Federal trials of detainees posed some enormous procedural and security problems . Terrorism recidivism was high among released prisoners .

 The defendants, all of whom had been captured abroad, will receive most of the constitutional protections and process rights afforded U.S. citizens .  Another idea: Transferring prisoners to Yemen was widely discredited after concerns raised over al-Qaeda activity in that country . Another idea was to transfer prisoners to the U.S. to Yemen, but concerns were raised .

 In his presidential campaign, Obama had criticized U.S. involvement in Iraq and suggested Afghanistan pacification efforts were wrongly shortchanged as a result .
 As security conditions in Iraq continued to improve, the new administration began slowly removing U.S. military personnel . The goal of ending combat operations by mid-2010 and exiting the country entirely by late 2011 was announced in January .
 The military outlook in Afghanistan deteriorated rapidly, however, as Taliban insurgents regrouped and stepped up attacks on U.S. and NATO forces . The Taliban insurgents have stepped up their attacks on United States and NATO troops .
 In February Obama announced plans to send 17,000 additional U.S. troops to Afghanistan, bringing the total troop commitment to 68,000 . The total commitment to Afghanistan currently stands at 68,500 .
 President Obama has ordered a comprehensive review of the United States mission in Afghanistan . He has also ordered a review into the U.S. mission in the country .
 His military appointees concluded their review in August and asked for the deployment of up to 40,000 more troops . The review was part of a review by the US government .
 The request comes as evidence of fraud nearly overturned the Afghan national election . The request came as evidence nearly overturned an election nearly overturned .
 U.S. troop fatalities doubled in 2009 compared with the previous year . Antiwar activists were raising the spectre of another Vietnamlike disaster for the United States military .

 The new administration worked to project a more cooperative image of the U.S. abroad during 2009 . It acknowledged past errors and sought to repair strained relations in many parts of the world .
 In April Obama sought a ""fresh start” with Russia, telling Russian Pres. Vladimir Putin to get a "fresh start" with the U.S. President .
 This diplomatic outreach was well received internationally, but tangible results on specific major international controversies were almost nonexistent .
 Some world leaders applauded the approach as helpful toward restoring the vitality of U.S. diplomacy . Critics suggested that the United States was instead pandering, projecting weakness, and abandoning leadership .
 Joe Biden declared that Russia was a nation in decline, Russia allowed the U.S. to use its airspace to resupply allied military forces in Afghanistan . Russia also promised a new nuclear arms reduction agreement by year’s end . Joe Biden declares that Russia is in decline .
 In September, the United States dramatically abandoned elements of its long-standing European missile shield project . The U.S. abandoned elements in Poland and a radar site in the Czech Republic .
 The Strategic Arms Reduction Talks I treaty was allowed to expire in December without a replacement . Russia pressed for additional concessions by threatening to restart development of new offensive weaponry .
 Efforts to thwart the nuclear ambitions of North Korea and Iran again went nowhere in 2009 . Efforts in 2009 failed to thwart North Korea's nuclear ambitions .

 The United States ultimately urged recognition of the balloting results, which removed Zelaya’s party from control . The development was widely viewed as a sign of declining United States influence in Latin America .

 U.S. state governments faced tough economic times in 2009 . The economy dominated the priorities of state governments in the United States . The state's economic woes were the result of a long-running recession .
 Almost all states were constitutionally required to balance their budgets . Officials took drastic measures to reduce costs and increase revenue . Almost all of the nation's budgets were met with deficit projections .
 The fiscal crisis, termed the most severe for states since the Great Depression, discouraged creation of new legislative programs, prompted major tax increases during economic hard times . It also caused unusual tensions in the relationship between states and federal government .
 Several lower-tax states with energy-based economies were able to weather the downturn relatively easily . Several states used federal stimulus funds to avoid significant trims to state services . The stimulus funds will be used to offset significant cuts to services .
 While the economy showed signs of recovery by midyear, state finances were slow to stabilize . State finances are slow to stabilise after a year of recession .

 In many cases, this aid came with strings attached, imposing federal policies on unenthusiastic state governments . In some instances, the aid was aimed at countering state efforts to reduce social services spending .

 Federal efforts to improve homeland security prompted another face-off over the 2005 Real ID Act . The act required states to tighten standards on the issuance of state driver's licenses as well as ID cards .
 Washington warned that residents of states unable to comply by the December 31 deadline could not use existing licenses as identification to board airplanes or enter federal buildings . The deadline expires on December 31 .
 With only a small minority of states on track to meet the deadline, the government granted an extension until May 2011 .
 The fiscal crisis preoccupied state governments throughout the year . It led to a second consecutive year of reduced general fund spending . State governments reduced their budgets in 2014 .
 Revenue from all major state tax sources diminished by more than 10% as the national economy languished . Required expenditures for unemployment, health care, and other programs rose dramatically . State revenue from state taxes diminished by 10% .
 Stimulus funds were used to shore up state expenditures for social services, infrastructure programs, public schools, and general economic stabilization . Stimulus money was used in the wake of the financial crisis .
 The aid also allowed a few, mostly smaller, states to balance their budgets without dramatic legislative adjustments . 13 states drained their rainy-day funds in order to resolve budget problems .
 22 states laid off government workers and 23 made acrossthe-board reductions in agency budgets . To reduce costs, 22 states made cuts to their budgets .

 Idaho, Kansas, Utah, Nevada, and Washington trimmed spending on public schools . Florida, Kansas and Washington reduced higher-education support in higher education .
 The crisis overcame traditional reluctance to raise taxes during economic downturns . It overcame traditional legislative reluctance to do so during the downturn .

 Hugo Chavez scored a decisive victory on Feb., 2009, when voters approved a referendum to remove term limits for all elected officials . Chavez won the vote in 2009, and thus enabled him to run for reelection in 2012 .
 This measure won the support of 54.4% of the voters and restored to Chavez the political momentum that he had lost after voters defeated his first attempt to scrap term limits in December 2007 .
 On July 25 he opined that he would not object to being given powers to eliminate all “counterrevolutionary” laws by the end of the year . He said he wouldn't object if he was given the power to eliminate "counter-revolutionary" laws .
 More than 80% of the deputies in the National Assembly were loyal to Chavez, but they declined to give him those powers . Chavez's government has been in turmoil since his government began in 2009 .
 Deputies passed legislation that moved Venezuela closer to the Cuban model . Still, the deputies passed important legislation that moves Venezuela closer .
 Noteworthy were laws that increased government control over police forces, education, and the expropriation of land . Noteworthy in this regard were laws increased police forces and education .
 Community councils received new powers to determine the manner of expropriation property could be used . Community councils were also given new powers in order to determine how expropriated property was used .
 Vietnam provision of false information that harmed the state . Conviction for this offense could bring a prison sentence of up to four years . If convicted of this offense, the sentence could be up to 4 years .
 The National Electoral Council oversaw the PSUV’s internal elections for delegates to the First Extraordinary Congress, which took place over three weeks beginning on November 21 . The PSUV's internal elections took place in the first three weeks .
 There is concern in the PSUV that the opposition could win the one-third of National Assembly seats necessary to block fundamental changes to the state's administrative structure .
 Chavez-controlled CNE gave the power to arbitrarily redraw electoral districts until just prior to the 2010 elections . Thus, the government introduced legislation that downsized the representation of party coalitions and gave the CNE power .
 Venezuela’s economy remained dependent on revenue from petroleum sales . Venezuela's economy is dependent on revenues from oil sales .
 In November the Ministry of Finance projected that oil revenues for 2009 would amount to $18.33 billion . In November 2009 oil revenues were projected to amount to more than $18 billion .
 Non-oil revenues were expected to total $39.07 billion, and debt was likely to reach $16.42 billion . Non-Oil revenues were also expected to top $39 billion .
 Inflation approached 30%, real wages fell, and distribution programs sustained large cuts in their budgets . Distribution programs suffered large cuts, with inflation approaching 30% and real wages falling .
 One study found that food consumption among poorer Venezuelans was declining despite discounts of up to 40% at Mercal, the state-owned grocery chain . The study also found that Venezuelans are less likely to buy more food than they would otherwise .
 Many units of the government’s primary-care health network, Barrio Adentro, closed . Despite being staffed by thousands of Cuban doctors, many units closed despite being staffed .
 The Foreign Exchange Administration Commission reported that the government authorized $29.7 billion for imports through September . That figure is a 47% decrease compared with 2008 . The government is authorized to import $29 billion through September 2013 .
 Chavez sought to strengthen the Bolivarian Alternative for the Americas . He described the alliance as an “anti-imperialist military alliance” and to develop the Union of South American Nations into an institution .
 Venezuela’s admission was cast into doubt on November 8 when Chavez told his people to “prepare for war” with Colombia . Colombia is one of Mercosur's five associate members . Venezuela's admission has been under scrutiny since Chavez's comments .
 Alvaro Uribe’s decision to allow the U.S. to use military installations in Colombia as bases from which to hunt down drug traffickers . The Colombian president has been criticized for his actions .
 It adopted a resolution calling for measures to prevent recession, reduce inflation, and stabilize the macroeconomy . The resolution was adopted by the House of Representatives on Tuesday .
 Long-simmering discontent over the government’s decision to approve bauxite mining in the Central Highlands erupted in public . Controversy erupted over the decision to award the contract to a Chinese company .
 A loose coalition of environmental scientists, academics, and retired officials opposed the government . The government has been criticized by environmental groups .
 General Vo Nguyen Giap, a national military hero, wrote three letters to party and state leaders urging reconsideration on environmental and national security grounds . Giap: "I'm a national hero. I'm not afraid of the environment"
 Bauxite mining concerns were echoed at a government seminar in April to review mining . Concerns were raised on the floor of the National Assembly in May .
 The government was forced to revise its plans and address the impact on the environment and ethnic minority community . The government eventually agreed to revise the plans and addressed the impact .
 At midyear the Central Committee held its 10th plenum, which initiated preparations for the 11th national congress, scheduled for January 2011 . The 11th congress will be held in January 2011.
 The meeting reviewed draft socioeconomic plans for 2011-20, proposed alterations to the party’s 1991 platform . The meeting also appointed three subcommittees to deal with administrative matters, leadership selection, and leadership selection .
 Beijing unilaterally declared a moratorium on fishing in the South China Sea from May 16 to August 1, the height of Vietnam’s fishing season . Relations with China became a domestic issue when Beijing declared the moratorium on May 16 .
 Chinese fishery vessels aggressively chased Vietnamese fishermen out of the area by seizing catches and detaining and fining boat crews .
 In July the Roman Catholic Church became involved in a major dispute over ownership of land that once belonged to the Tam Toa church in the Vinh diocese in the city of Dong Hoi . In July, the church became embroiled in a dispute over the land .
 Tens of thousands of parishioners held public prayer vigils and mass rallies to protest police brutality . Parishioners called for land confiscated by the state to be returned to the church .
 Riot police and bulldozers leveled the site in August, and in November authorities returned to remove a statue of the Virgin Mary from the Catholic cemetery there .
 Security authorities continue to arrest and detain prominent pro-democracy activists . Security authorities continued to arrest, detain and arrest prominent activists . Pro-democracy protesters continue to be detained .
 In October, Vietnam tried and convicted six persons for their role in 2008 in hanging banners in Haiphong calling for political freedom . Vietnam's political freedom movement has been rocked by anti-government protests in recent years .
 In December former army officer Tran Anh Kim, one of five dissidents arrested in June, was convicted and sentenced to more than five years in prison for subversion . In December ex-army officer was convicted of subversion for subverting .
 The other four, notably U.S.-educated human rights lawyer Le Cong Dinh, were expected to be tried in 2010 . They were also expected to face charges related to human rights abuses .
 In October the Central Committee held its 11th plenum to discuss future economic plans . Draft political report to be presented to the 11th congress .
 The plenum concluded that Vietnam had begun its recovery from the global financial crisis with a GDP growth rate of 5.2% for the year . Vietnam's GDP growth is projected to be at 5.3% this year .
 Later the government announced that it would extend until March 2010 portions of the economic stimulus package that it had enacted . The stimulus package was enacted by the government .
 Vietnamese leaders crisscrossed the globe in 2009 to promote Vietnam’s interests . Vietnamese leaders visited the globe to promote their country's interests .
 Vietnamese President Nguyen Minh Triet addressed the UN General Assembly and Security Council Summit on Nuclear Nonproliferation and Nuclear Disarmament in September . Triet then flew to Cuba to attend the UN summit .
 In November he visited Venezuela and Singapore, and in December he travelled to Italy, the Vatican, Spain, and Slovakia .
 Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs Pham Gia Khiem made a separate trip to Washington to promote trade and educational cooperation . Deputy PM and minister of foreign affairs made separate trip .
 Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung visited China twice in October to attend a trade and investment conference in Chengdu . Prime Minister visited China in April and October to participate in the Boao Forum for Asia .
 He attended the 15th Association of Southeast Asian Nations summit in Thailand in October .
 During 2009 Vietnam hosted visits by the presidents of Laos, South Korea, and Sri Lanka . The prime ministers of Thailand, France, and Finland also visited Vietnam .
 Yemeni Prime Minister AN Muhammad Mujawar was prime minister of the country in 2009 . The Yemeni government faced two important challenges in 2009.
 The second was an armed uprising of the alHouthis along the mountainous northern border with Saudi Arabia . The uprising was an uprising by the al Houthis in a mountainous region .
 Antigovemment demonstrators rally in the southern Yemeni city of Habileen on October 14 .
 The Zaydi monarchy was toppled by a coup d’etat in 1962 .
 Al-Houthi elements made an incursion into Saudi Arabia in early November . In early November al-Qaeda elements made incursions into the kingdom .
 Yemen and the Saudis accuse Iran of supporting the Shi'ite al-Houthis . Yemen and Saudi Arabia have accused Iran of fuelling tensions in the region . Iran has been accused of supporting al-Qaeda in Yemen .
 By December armed conflicts with the al-Houthis had left thousands dead or wounded . By December some 150,000 civilians had fled the area .
 Both the U.S. and Saudi Arabia feared that alQaeda would take advantage of the weak government and instability to expand its influence in Yemen . The United States, which had a presence in Yemen, had a close relationship with al Qaeda .
 At year end there were indications that the al-Houthis were willing to pursue peace talks with Saudi Arabia . At year's end, indications that there were also indications that they would pursue peace negotiations .
 Yemen remained a country with high unemployment and shortages of water, electricity, and municipal services . Yemen remains a country that has high unemployment, shortages of electricity and water .
 Yemeni government was trying to attract foreign investment to stimulate the economy . The Yemeni government is trying to encourage foreign investment in the country .
 It also sought entrance into a partnership with the Gulf Cooperation Council to help its economy and provide employment .
 He complained about uncooperative members within his own ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy and malicious media attacks . He also complained about members of his own party's own ruling party .
 A dispute arose over the timing of a national convention to elect party officers . Shortly afterward, a dispute arose within the MMD leadership about the timing .
 President Banda and his supporters contained the dissent by dissolving the provincial branch executive that had been opposing them . The action only buttressed allegations of autocratic behaviour and lack of transparency .
 In August former president Frederick Chiluba was acquitted of corruption charges after a long trial . This was the first time that an African former head of state had undergone a credible trial in his own country .
 In 2007 the U.K.’s High Court had determined that the former president had bilked the Zambian government of some $46 million . Earlier in the year his wife, Regina, was imprisoned for having received stolen funds during his term of office .
 In 2009, he was accused of having embezzled half a million dollars during his 10-year presidency . But the judge ruled that the prosecution had not established that the funds in question could be traced to government money .
 Susan Tsvangirai died in a head-on automobile collision in which her husband was also injured . Her death prompted speculation of an assassination attempt . She was involved in fighting corruption in Africa .
 The effects of the global recession on Zambia’s economy were mitigated by high copper prices, which were driven by strong demand from China . China is the world's largest consumer of copper, and Zambia is a major copper producer .
 Global electronics manufacturers also sustained demand and investment in mining . Mining also sustained investment in the mining industry .
 World Bank and other agencies urged Zambia to develop alternative sources of revenue, including tourism and agriculture . The mining sector supplied most of the country’s foreign earnings . Zambia has been heavily dependent on mining .
 Although poverty continued to be a serious problem, the economy had strengthened . The economy was characterized by a stable currency and increasing trade . The country's poverty rate remained high .
 Inflation topped 12%, growth was anticipated to exceed 5% in 2009-10 . Although inflation topped 12% in 2008-2009, growth was expected to exceed the expected 5% growth .
 Zambia had become a model country in malaria-reduction policy . The prevalence of the malaria parasite in children under age five had decreased by more than 50% since 2006 .
 Mortality rates in this age group had also been reduced by 29% from 2002 to 2007 . Health professionals largely attributed to the success of the country’s new malaria policy .
 From the beginning, political analysts expected that the new government was a fragile, uneasy power-sharing arrangement . The SADC had strongarmed the parties into accepting the deal .
 Tsvangirai was cast as the junior partner to his archrival, Pres. Mugabe . He has been accused of being a weak leader in Zimbabwe . Mugabe is now the prime minister of Zimbabwe .
 On March 6, the prime minister was injured in a head-on automobile collision in which his wife, Susan, was killed . Suspicion about ZANU-PF objectives deepened when the prime minster was injured .
 Many MDC-T officials and supporters believed that this accident was an assassination attempt . Tsvangirai had survived a previous attempt on his life and several brutal beatings at the hands of his political opponents .
 In his inaugural speech Tsvangirai advocated a policy for democratic reconstruction; however, Pres. Elias says he is not interested in a return to the streets .
 Mugabe’s intransigence and unyielding control over home affairs, the military, and the security forces blocked any reform . Mugabe's control over the military and home affairs blocked reform, he says .
 Throughout the year Tsvangirai complained about continued harassment and manhandling of MDC-T members, including legislators and ministers, some of whom faced criminal charges . Some of the charges were brought against some of the party members .
 Mugabe refused to accept nomination of Roy Bennett as deputy minister of agriculture . Bennett's nomination as agriculture deputy minister was rejected by Mugabe .
 Bennett, a white farmer and MDC-T treasurer, was detained on charges of alleged antigovernment activities . Bennett was detained two days after the unity government came into effect . He was arrested on charges related to alleged anti-government activities .
 Bennett's case highlighted the issue of Mugabe’s blocking the appointment of top government officials . In mid-October, the MDC-T's boycott of cabinet meetings with the president culminated in the party boycotting cabinet meetings . The case highlighted issue of the president blocking appointment of
 Tsvangirai agreed to lift the three-week boycott on the understanding that the power-sharing agreement would be implemented fully within 30 days . After intervention by SADC leaders, the agreement was lifted on the basis of the agreement being fully implemented .
 Despite the tense political scene, the new government managed to turn around the economy . Despite the political turmoil, the economy has remained strong .
 On February 2, the government devalued the Zimbabwe dollar—as it had six months earlier—dropping 12 zeros to make Z$1 trillion of the old currency redenominated to $1.00 . The Zimbabwe dollar was devalued six months ago . The old currency was red
 In April the unity government suspended the Zimbabwean dollar for at least a year . The new unity government opted to allow the use of selected foreign currencies, notably the South African rand and the United States dollar .
 By August the month-on-month inflation rate had fallen to 0.4%, and by year’s end GDP was projected to grow by about 6-7% in 2010 . By August, inflation rate was expected to be at 0.3% .
 The agricultural and mining sectors began to improve as restructuring programs were established and investment began to return . The agricultural sector is now in the middle of a recession .
 Zimbabwe's $1.1 billion debt to the IMF, World Bank, and African Development Bank was unable to repay . The policies of the new prime minister and his financial officials won a considerable amount of international support, which resulted in rescheduled loan repayments .

 No part of this work may be reproduced or . utilized in any form or by any means, electronic or mechanical, including photocopying, recording, or by . any information storage and retrieval system, without permission .
 Britannica World Data is intended as structured support for many of Britannica’s other reference works . Updated annually, it's intended as a level of detail that their editorial style or design don’t permit .
 Statistics possess their own inherent editorial virtues and weaknesses . Like the textual, graphic, or cartographic modes of expression of these other products, statistics possess its own editorial virtues . Statistics are a form of expression that can be written in print or online .
 Two principal goals in the creation of Britannica World Data were up-to-dateness and comparability . Each possible to maximize separately, but not always possible to combine .
 Comparability, however, also resides in the meaning of the numbers compiled, which may differ greatly from country to country . Comparability is also a factor in comparing numbers compiled .
 The headnotes to the thematic tables explain many of these methodological problems . The Glossary also serves the same purpose for the country statistical pages .
 Published data do not always provide a neat, unambiguous choice between a datum compiled on two different bases . One of which is wanted and the other not .
 Published data on a particular subject may be complete and final but impossible to summarize in a simple manner . Finally, published data may be incomplete and final and impossible to summarise .
 The education system of a single country may include public and private sectors; local, state, or national systems; varying grades, tracks, or forms within a single system; or opportunities for double-counting or fractional counting .
 When no recent official data exist, or they exist, the tables may show unofficial estimates, a range , analogous data, or no data at all . The tables are based on unofficial estimates and ranges .
 The published basis of the information compiled is the statistical collections of Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc., some of the principal elements of which are enumerated in the Bibliography .
 Further information is received in a variety of formats: telephone, letter, fax, microfilm and microfiche . Further information can be received in electronic formats such as computer disks, CD-ROMs, and the Internet .
 The Internet has added uniform resource locators to the great majority of country pages and a number of the CNS tables . It was decided to apprise the reader of the possibility and means to access current information year-round .
 Sites will usually be updated year-round, expanded as opportunity permits, and lead on to related sites, such as parliamentary offices, information offices, diplomatic and consular sites, news agencies and news agencies .
 These URLs were correct and current at the time of writing . They may be subject to change .
 The great majority of the social, economic, and financial data contained in this work should not be interpreted in isolation . The social and economic data should be taken to account for the fact that it is not just a single study .
 Britannica World Data will supply up-to-date geographic, demographic, and economic detail . Britannica will be used to help students learn more about the world of the world .
 Those italicized terms that are used regularly in the country compilations to introduce specific categories of information appear in this glossary in italic boldface type . A description of the precise kind of information being offered and how it has been edited and presented .
 Many terms have quite specific meanings in statistical reporting, and they are so defined here . Statistics is based on data from the National Statistical Statistical Statistical Center .
 Other terms have less specific application as they are used by different countries or organizations . Other terms are used to refer to different countries and organizations .
 Data in the country compilations based on definitions markedly different from those below will usually be footnoted . The data is based on the definition of the country's nationalities .
 Terms that appear in small capitals in certain definitions are themselves defined at their respective alphabetical locations . Terms are defined at the respective alphabetically locations .
 When substantial numbers of persons do not know, or state, their exact age, distributions may not total 100.0%. aquatic plants production, the weight of aquatic plants harvested in freshwater or marine areas; the share harvested by farming is aquaculture production . Area, the total surface area
 Land area is usually calculated from “mean low water” on a “plane table,” or flat, basis . Area and population is tabulation usually including the first-order administrative subdivisions of the country .
 Balance of trade is the net value of all international goods trade of a country, usually excluding reexports (goods received only for transshipment) and the percentage that this net represents of total trade . Detail of national law as to what constitutes a transaction, the basis of its
 Balance of trade refers only to the ‘visible’ international trade of goods as recorded by customs authorities . Balance of Trade is a segment of a country’s BALANCE OF PAYMENTS .
 A country has a favourable, or positive, balance of trade when the value of exports exceeds that of imports and negative when imports exceed exports . A barrel barrel is a unit of liquid measure .
 The number of barrels of crude petroleum per metric ton, ranging typically from 6.20 to 8.13, depends upon the specific gravity of the petroleum . It is typically between 6 and 8.20 barrels per ton, depending on the type of crude .
 The world average is roughly 7.33 barrels per ton. birth rate is about 7.3 barrels a ton . World's birth rate, the number of live births annually per 1,000 of mid-year population, is around 7.30 barrels a year .
