 When both a recurrent and a capital budget exist for a single country, the budget is funded entirely from national resources that would recur (be generated by economic activity) every year . The capital budget is the budget funded by national resources .
 It funds the most basic governmental services, those least able to suffer interruption . The funds are used to provide basic services to those least at risk .
 Capital budget is usually funded by external aid and may change its size considerably from year to year . Capital is usually the actual seat of government and administration of a state, usually the capital .
 When more than one capital exists, each is identified by kind . When interim arrangements exist during the creation or movement of a national capital, the de facto situation is described .
 This principle, the “underlying cause of death,” is the basis of the medical judgment as to cause . The statistical classification system according to which these causes are grouped and named is the International List of Causes of Death .
 When data on actual causes of death are unavailable, information on morbidity, or illness rate, usually given as reported cases per 100,000 of infectious diseases, may be substituted .
 In general usage, the chief of state is the formal head of a national state . Chief of state in general usage is the head of the country's chief government . In general use, the title is the title of state .
 The primary responsibilities of the chief of state may range from ceremonial to the exercise of complete national executive authority . Chief of state can also exercise national executive power .
 The head of government, when this function exists separately, is the officer nominally charged (by the constitution) with the majority of actual executive powers . This may not in practice be exercised, especially in military or single-party regimes in which effective power may reside entirely outside the executive governmental
 A prime minister, usually the actual head of government, may in practice exercise only Cabinet-level authority . In practice, a prime minister in practice exercises only Cabinet level authority .
 Communications communications are the means available for the public transmission of information within a country . Examples include the Commonwealth (composed of independent states [from 1931 onward] Puerto Rico since 1952, and the Northern Marianas since 1979 .
 For each, a rate per 1,000 persons is given, constant prices, an adjustment to the members of a financial time series to eliminate the effect of inflation year by year . For each of the members, a time series is based on inflation year-by-year .
 Consumer price index is a series of index numbers assigned to the price of a selected “basket,” or assortment, of basic consumer goods and services in a country, region, city, city or type of household . It consists of referring all data in the series to a
 Items included in the CPI are ordinarily determined by governmental surveys of typical household expenditures . Items included are assigned weights relative to their proportion of those expenditures .
 Death rates for individual countries may be compared with the estimated world annual average of 8.2 deaths per 1,000 population in 2005 . The average death rate is 8.6 deaths per person per year .
 Special adjustment is made for large areas of inland water, desert, or other uninhabitable areas . Dependentions, dependency, an area annexed to, or controlled by, an independent state but not an integral part of it .
 A crown dependency is a dependency originally chartered by the British government . Direct taxes, taxes levied directly on firms and individuals, such as taxes on income, profits, and capital gains .
 It is most commonly reported for wages paid on a daily, weekly, or monthly basis . Annual figures may represent total income or averages of these shorter periods .
 Index for each country applies to all wage earners in a designated group . Index takes into account basic wages, bonuses, cost-of-time allowances, and contributions toward social security . Index is based on wages and contributions to social security in each country .
 Contributions toward social security by employers are usually excluded, as are social security benefits received by wage earners, see population economically active population . Contributions by employers and wage earners are also excluded .
 Rates given usually refer to free market values when currency has no restrictions on its convertibility into other currencies . Currency has no, or very limited, restrictions on converting currency into other . currencies .
 Valuation of goods exported is free on board unless otherwise specified . Valuation on board is free for all goods exported .
 The value of goods exported and importedo.b. is calculated from the cost of production . It excludes cost of transport, external debt, public and publicly . guaranteed debt with a maturity of more than one year owed to nonnationals .

 Fisheries production is the live-weight equivalent of the aquatic animals (including fish, crustaceans, mollusks, and other aquatic mammals) caught in freshwater or marine areas by national fleets . For BALANCE OF PAYMENTS, the origin in terms of component balance of trade items
 The share of fisheries production that is harvested by farming is aquaculture production . Foreign direct investment is a long-term investment with a significant degree of control by a business entity .
 FDI comprises three components—equity capital, reinvested earnings, and intra-company loans . FDI consists of three components: equity capital, earnings, inter-company loan, and investments. FDI is a key component of FDI .
 The net balance of the three FDI components is often volatile from one year to the next . FDI is a key component of the country's economic growth .
 If negative for a particular time period, the balance of the three components is called a reverse investment, or disinvestment . form of government/political status, the type of administration provided for by a country’s constitution, the number of members for each legislative house, and the
 Unless otherwise noted, the value is given in current prices of the year indicated . The value of the items is shown in the chart below .
 The System of National Accounts (SNA) provides a framework for international comparability in classifying domestic accounting aggregates and international transactions . Net factor income from abroad is the measure that distinguishes GDP and GNP . Gross national income is the total value of final goods and services produced both from
 A family household is one composed principally of individuals related by blood or marriage . The average size of a household is by number of individuals and median household income .
 Sources of income and expenditures for major items of consumption are given as percentages . Sources of Income and Expenditure are shown as percentages of the income and expenditure .
 In general, household income is the amount of funds, usually measured in monetary units, received by the members of a household in a given time period . Household income is generally measured by monetary units .
 The income can be derived from wages or salaries, nonfarm or farm SELF-EMPLOYMENT, transfer payments, such as pensions, public assistance, unemployment benefits, etc. and other income, including interest and dividends, rent, royalties, etc .
 The income of a household is expressed as a gross amount before deductions for taxes . A household's income is expressed in terms of its gross amount of income before deductions .
 Data on expenditure refer to consumption of personal or household goods and services . They normally exclude savings, taxes, and insurance . Exclusion of credit purchases differs markedly markedly .
 The principal alternate basis for valuation of goods in international trade is that of cost, insurance, and freight . Its use is restricted to imports, as it comprises the principal charges needed to bring the goods to the customs house in the country of destination .
 Because it inflates the value of imports relative to exports, more countries have started estimating imports on ano.b. basis as well .
 The date usually refers to the date from which the country was in effective control of these affairs within its present boundaries, rather than the date independence was proclaimed or recognized as a de jure act .
 Total infant mortality includes neonatal mortality, which is deaths of children within one month of birth . Labour force, portion of the POPULATION ECONOMICALLY ACTIVE comprising those most fully employed or attached to the labour market .
 In the “gross domestic product and labour force” table, the majority of the labour data provided refer to population economically active . PEA represents the longer-term view of working population and subsumes more of the marginal workers .
 National capitals are almost always given, regardless of size; fewer cities/towns may be listed if there are fewer urban localities in the country .

 The powers of the monarch may range from absolute through various degrees of limitation of authority to nominal, as in a constitutional monarchy .  The rate of natural increase is the difference between the BIRTH RATE and the DEATH RATE of a given population . Natural growth is the excess of births over deaths in a population . See also exchange rate .
 The estimated world average during 2005 was 11.3% per 1,000 population, or 1.35% annually . The world average is 11.7% per person, or 11.5% per year .
 Other languages may have local protection, may be permitted in parliamentary debate or legal action . They may be “national languages” for the protection of which special provisions have been made, but these are not official .
 The United States does not yet formally identify English as ‘official,” though it uses it for virtually all official purposes . English is the official form, short or long, of a country’s legal name taken from its constitution or other documents .
 The English-language form is usually the protocol form in use by the country, the United States Department of State and the United Nations . Official religion is generally a religion prescribed or given special status or protection by the constitution or legal system of a country .
 Identification as such is not confined to constitutional documents utilizing the term explicitly . Overseas territories have some degree of self-government and having a special status above that of a colony .
 Population given are DE FACTO, referring to those actually present, rather than DE JURE, those legally resident but not necessarily present on the referent date . Unless otherwise specified, populations given are De FACTO or DE Jure .
 National practices vary as regards the treatment of such groups as armed forces, inmates of institutions, persons seeking their first job, unpaid family workers, seasonal workers and persons engaged in part-time economic activities .
 In some countries, all or part of these groups may be included among the economically active, while in other countries they may be treated as inactive . In other countries, the same groups may not be considered as economically active .
 In general, however, the data on economically active population do not include students, persons occupied solely in family or household work, retired persons and retired persons .
 The labour force is based on the country’s own projections wherever possible . See also labour force. population projection .
 Estimates of the future size of a population are usually based on assumed levels of fertility, mortality, and migration . Estimates are based on assumptions about fertility and mortality levels and migration levels .
 When a single consistent measure of value, such as VALUE ADDED, can be obtained, this is given, ranked by value . Otherwise, and more usually, quantity of production is given .
 For countries that report debt under the World Bank Debtor Reporting System, figures for outstanding, long-term EXTERNAL DEBT are given .
 Britannica World Data publishes only purchasing power parity rates as calculated by the World Bank method . Quality of working life is a group of measures including weekly hours of work (including overtime) and weekly commuting patterns .
 Length-of-track figures include all mainline and spurline running track but exclude switching sidings and yard track . Length of track figures are based on length of all mainline, spurline and spur line running track .
 Route length, when given, does not compound multiple running tracks laid on the same trackbed . Route length is given when given; see budget for recurrent budget .
 This usually assigns to children the religion of their parents . Remittances are amount of a migrant’s earnings sent from the migration destination to the place of origin . This usually includes remittances, amount of earnings sent .
 Remittance data is compiled somewhat differently from one country source to another but usually include cash transfers of long-term legal migrants . Remittances data are compiled by different sources in different countries .
 Cash transfers of short-term (“for less than one year of residence”) legal migrants or the cash transfers of illegal migrants and refugees are also often included with remittances . Cash transfers are often included in payments to migrants .
 The standard sources used in BWD for national remittances are the latest editions of World Bank publications and UNCTAD Handbook of Statistics . BWD is based on the latest edition of the World Bank's publications .
 Republic, a state with elected leaders and a centralized presidential form of government, local subdivisions being subordinate to the national government . These two sources may also include net wages and salaries of all nonresident migrants and approximate the value of migrants’ transfers of household .
 A federal republic is a republic in which power is divided between the central government and the constituent subnational administrative divisions (g., states, provinces, or cantons) Power is defined in a written constitution and jurisdictional disputes usually settled in a court .
 Unitary republic (as distinguished from a federal republic) is a republic in which power originates in a central authority and is not derived from constituent subdivisions . A unitary republic is also a unitary state of power .
 A people’s republic, in the dialectics of Communism, is the first stage of development toward a communist state, the second stage being a socialist republic . The second stage is a socialist state, a people's republic .
 An Islamic republic is structured around social, ethical, legal, and religious precepts central to the Islamic faith . Islamic republic structured around ethical precepts . Retail price index is based on retail sales and service enterprises .
 The term is sometimes limited in meaning to fully independent and internationally recognized states . The more general sense of an entity possessing a preponderance of these characteristics is intended here .
 It is, thus, also a first-order civil administrative subdivision, especially of a federated union . It is also a civil administrative subdivater .
 An associated state is an autonomous state in free association with another that conducts its external affairs and defense . The association may be terminated in full independence at the instance of the autonomous state .
 External territory is a territory situated outside the area of the country . An external territory is an external territory located outside the country's borders .
 An organized territory is an organized territory for which a system of laws and a settled government have been provided by an act of the United States Congress . The U.S. Congress has provided an order of law and settled government for organized territory .
 An overseas territory is an overseas subdivision of the French Republic with elected representation in the French Parliament, having individual statutes, laws, and internal organization adapted to local conditions . ton-miles, or ton-kilometres, is aggregate measure of freight hauled by a specified means of transportation
 The distinction is usually based on the country’s own definition of urban, which may depend only upon the size (population) of a place or upon factors like employment, employment, administrative status, density of housing, etc. value added .
 Value added is the portion of the sales value or gross output value that is actually created by the firm or industry . Value added refers to a portion of sales value that actually creates a product that is added to the firm's product .
 Value added generally includes labour costs, administrative costs, and operating profits . Value added is defined as labour costs and administrative costs . It includes administrative costs and profits .

 In this table “date of independence” may refer to a variety of circumstances . ‘Date of Independence’ is a date of independence . “Date ofindependence” is a number of circumstances in which independence was declared .
 In the case of the newest countries, the date given is usually just what is implied by the heading . The date is usually when the country, within its present borders, attained full sovereignty over both its internal and external affairs .
 In the case of longer established countries, the choice of a single date may be somewhat more complicated, and grounds for the use of several different dates often exist .
 The reader should refer to appropriate Britannica articles on national histories and relevant historical acts .
 The date of the current, or last, constitution is in some ways a less complicated question . Governments sometimes do not adhere to existing constitutional forms or trouble to terminate the previous document and legitimize themselves by replacing it .
 Often, however, the desire to legitimize extraconstitutional political activity by associating it with existing forms of long precedent leads to partial or incomplete modification, suspension, or abrogation of a constitution . The actual day-to-day conduct of government may be largely unrelated to
 When a date in this column is given in italics, it refers to a document that has been suspended, abolished by extraconstitutional action, or modified extensively .
 The characterizations adopted under “type of government” represent a compromise between the national constitution and the more pragmatic language that a political scientist might adopt to describe these same systems . The type of government is a compromise of the forms provided for the constitution .
 For an explanation of the application of these terms in the Britannica World Data, see the Glossary at page 501 .
 The positions denoted by the terms “chief of state” and “head of government” are usually those identified with those functions by the constitution . The positions are usually identified with the functions of the constitution by the president .
 The duties of the chief of state may range from largely ceremonial responsibilities to complete executive authority as the effective head of government . Chief of state is the head of state with little or no authority over the day-to-day conduct of government, but is also the most powerful person in the
 In certain countries, an individual outside the constitutional structure may exercise the powers of both positions . In some countries, a person outside the country's constitutional structure can exercise the role of both .
 Membership in the legislative house of each country as given here includes all elected or appointed members, as well as those who by virtue of some other office or title .
 The legislature of a country with a unicameral system is shown as the upper house in this table . The upper house is shown in the table as a state legislature .
 The number of administrative subdivisions for each country is listed down to the second level . Each country has a second level of administrative divisions .
 In the second half of the table are listed the memberships each country maintains in the principal international intergovernmental organizations of the world . Finally, in the second . half, are listed each country's memberships .
 This part of the table may also be used to provide a complete membership list for each of these organizations as of Dec. 2009 . The membership list is also available for use in the future .
 Constitutions whose dates are in italic type had been wholly or substantially suspended or abolished as of late 2009 . Constituencies whose dates were in bold or bold are suspended, abolished or abolished . The dates are shown to indicate that the dates have been changed in accordance with the Constitution

 The data represent the latest published and unpublished data for both the surveyed area of the countries and their populations, the latter as of a single recent year . The data are presented as of the recent census to provide the fullest comparison of certain demographic measures that are not always available .
 The 2008 Revision, the United States Bureau of the Census International Data Base, databases of other international organizations, and Encyclopaedia Britannica’s own estimates .
 Statistics are estimates of varying, and some of suspect, accuracy, even when they contain a very full enumeration . One principal point to bear in mind is that all of them, whatever degree of precision, are estimates .
 The United States is unable to determine within 1.2% its total population nationally . The U.S. has a long tradition both of census taking and of the use of the most sophisticated analytical tools in processing the data .
 The accuracy of the enumerated count may be off as much as 3.1% at a state level and by a greater percent for a single city . In states and larger cities, where enumeration of particular populations, including illegal, is more difficult, accuracy is off .
 The accuracy attained by census operations in China may approach 0.25% of rigorously maintained civil population registers . The accuracy of China's census operations may be less than 1% of the accuracy achieved .
 Other national census operations not so based, however, are inherently less accurate . Census data is based on the fact that national census data is not based on census data .
 Ethiopia’s first-ever census in 1984 resulted in figures that were 30% or more above prevailing estimates . For example, the first census of Ethiopia in 1984 ended up 30% higher than expected figures .
 An undercount of 2-8% is more typical, but even census operations offering results of 30% or more above or below prevailing estimates can still represent well-founded benchmarks from which future planning may proceed .
 The editors have tried to take account of the range of variation and accuracy in published data . It is difficult to establish a value for many sources of inaccuracy, but it is difficult .
 Afghanistan 249,347 645,807 41 28,150,000 people live in Afghanistan . Afghanistan is the largest country in the world . Afghanistan has the largest population in the country . Afghanistan's population is estimated to be at least 250,000 .
 The sources of these data are censuses, national population registers and sample surveys to establish demographic conditions; and the like. Census data are collected periodically and periodically .
 The statistics provided for area and population by country are ranked . The population densities based on those values are also provided .
 The population densities, for purposes of comparison within this table, are calculated on the bases of the 2009 midyear population estimate as shown and of the total area of the country .
 The data in this section conclude with the estimated average annual growth rate for the country during the five-year period 2004-2009 . The data is based on the growth rate of the country in 2004-2008 .
 In the section containing census data, information supplied includes the census total (more often de facto) the population actually present, rather than de jure, the population legally resident, who might be anywhere . The proportion that is urban (usually according to the country’s own definition)
 Young, fast-growing nations show a high proportion of people under 30 . Many countries in sub-Saharan Africa have about 40% of their population under 15 years . Sweden suffered no age-group losses in World War II .
 The projections for 2010, 2020, and 2030 represent the best fit of available data through late summer 2009 . The projections are based on available data from 2009 to 2010 .
 The evidence of the last 30 years with respect to similar estimates published about 1970, however, shows how cloudy is the glass through which these numbers are read . The evidence shows that this is not the case, however .
 In 1970 no respectable Western analyst would have imagined proposing that mainland China could achieve the degree of birth control that it apparently has since then . On the other hand, even the Chinese admit that their methods have been somewhat Draconian .

 2005 estimate for both the West Bank and the Gaza Strip . iExcludes 305,000 Israeli Jews in West Bank . Excludes East Jerusalem . 2005 estimate includes 305,00 Israeli Jews .
 Most of the populations given refer to a so-called city proper, that is a legally defined, incorporated, or chartered area defined by administrative boundaries and by national or state law . Most of these populations are referred to the city proper .
 In some instances, where cities proper do not exist or are not strictly demarcated, populations of locally defined urban areas may be used . In some cases, the population of people living in such areas may also be used in the United States .
 In a few cases, data refer to the municipality, or commune, similar to the medieval city-state in that the city is governed together with its immediately adjoining, economically dependent areas, whether urban or rural .
 Some countries define no other demographic or legal entities within such communes or municipalities . Many identify a centre, seat, head, head or locality that corresponds to the most densely populated, compact, contiguous core of the municipality .
 Populations for urban agglomerations as defined by the United Nations are occasionally inset beneath the populations of cities proper . Populations are sometimes inset under the population of cities in some areas .
 Urban agglomeration populations are at least three times the size of cities proper . That is when the urban agglomation population is three times that size of the city proper .
 For certain countries, more than one form of the name of the city is given, usually to permit recognition of recent place-name changes or of forms likely to be encountered in press stories . The title of the entry in the Encyclopedia Britannica is spelled according to a different romanization
 Chinese names for China are usually given in their Pinyin spelling, the official Chinese system encountered in official documents and maps . Chinese names are given in the official system of the Chinese language .
 Sources for this data were often national censuses and statistical abstracts of the countries concerned, supplemented by Internet sources .

 St. Paul 277,251 Barcelona 328,000 Beaumont 109,579 Jacksonville, Jacksonville 805,605 St. Augustine, Florida, is the largest city in the world .
 The countries, and the principal languages represented in each of each, are listed alphabetically . The countries are listed in alphabetically.
 The sum of the estimates equals the 2003 population of the country given in the “Area and population” table . The sum is the population estimates .
 Many countries do not collect any official data whatever on language use, and published estimates not based on census or survey data usually span a substantial range of uncertainty .
 The editors have adopted the best-founded distribution in the published literature (indicating uncertainty by the degree of rounding shown) but have also adjusted or interpolated using data not part of the base estimate . The editors use this distribution of data to make their point of view .
 Such adjustments have not been made to account for largescale refugee movements, as these are of a temporary nature . Such adjustments are not expected to be made, as such as largescales refugee movements .
 A variety of approaches have been used to approximate mother-tongue distribution when census data were unavailable . The census data was not available when the census was unavailable .
 Some countries collect data on ethnic or “national” groups only . For such countries ethnic distribution often had to be assumed to conform roughly to the distribution of language communities .
 Minority population not always free to educate its children in its own language . Better economic opportunities often draw minority group members into majority-language community . This approach should be viewed with caution .
 For some countries, a given individual may be visible in national statistics only as a passport-holder of a foreign country . However, however long he may remain resident, he may not remain resident in the country .
 Such persons, often guest workers, have sometimes had to be assumed to be speakers of the principal language of their home country . Such persons have sometimes been assumed to speak of their native language .
 For some countries in the Americas, so few speakers of any single indigenous language remain that it was necessary to combine these groups as Amerindian so as to give a fair impression of their aggregate size .
 No systematic attempt has been made to account for populations that may legitimately be described as bilingual, unless the country itself collects data on that basis, such as Bolivia or the Comoros, for example .
 Speakers of the language as a second tongue are shown in italics, even though very few may speak it as a mother tongue . The language is a nonindigenous official or excolonial language .
 Lingua franca figures that are both italicized and indented are not included in population totals . Lingua-Franca figures are also not included into population total .
 No comprehensive effort has been made to distinguish between dialect communities usually classified as belonging to the same language . Such distinctions were possible for some countries— g., between French and Occitan or among various dialects of Chinese .
 Parenthetical alternatives are given for a number of languages that differ markedly from the name of the people speaking them or that may be combined with other groups .
 French is the universal language throughout France . Traditional dialects and minority languages are retained regionally in the approximate numbers shown . 2000 population estimate is 233,000 . lOData reflect multilingualism .
 An assessment was made for each country of the available data on distribution of religious communities within the total population . The best available figures, whether originating as census data, membership figures of the churches concerned, were applied as percentages to the estimated 2001 midyear population .
 Several concepts govern the nature of the available data, each useful separately but none the basis of any standard of international practice in the collection of such data .
 The word “affiliation” was used above to describe the nature of the relationship joining the religious bodies named and the populations shown .
 This term implies some sort of formal, usually documentary, connection between the religion and the individual . It says nothing about the nature of the individual’s personal religious practice, in that the individual may have lapsed or joined another religion .
 The nature of affiliation differs greatly from country to country, but the social context of religious practice does also . The user of these statistics should be careful to note that not only does the nature of the affiliation differ greatly .
 A country in which a single religion has long been predominant will often show more than 90% of its population to be affiliated . No more than 10% of the population may actually practice that religion on a regular basis . A country often shows 90% is affiliated with one religion .
 Such a situation often leads to undercounting of minority religions, blurring of distinctions seen to be significant elsewhere . Double-counting in countries where an individual may practice more than one ‘religion’ at a time .
 Communist countries had for long consciously attempted to ignore, suppress, or render invisible religious practice within their borders . Until 1989 communist countries had tried to ignore or suppress religious practice in their own country .
 Countries with large numbers of adherents of traditional, often animist, religions and belief systems usually have little or no formal methodology for defining the nature of local religious practice .
 On the other hand, countries with strong missionary traditions, or good census organizations, may have very good, detailed, and meaningful data .

 The accuracy of these data depends on the effectiveness of each respective national system for registering vital and civil events (birth, death, marriage, etc.) and on the sophistication of the analysis that can be brought to bear upon the data so compiled .
 Even in a developed country such identifications are often left to nonmedical personnel . In developing countries there will be too few physicians to perform autopsies to assess accurately the cause of death after the fact .
 Calculating natural increase, which at its most basic is simply the difference between the birth and death rates, may be affected by the differing degrees of completeness of birth registration .
 The total fertility rate may be understood as the average number of children that would be borne per woman if all childbearing women lived to the end of their childbearing years and bore children at each age at the average rate for that age .
 Data for causes of death are difficult to obtain, since many countries are not well equipped to collect the data . Many countries are also difficult to collect, as their accuracy may be suspect and their meaning may be subject to varying interpretation .
 Statistics on causes of death seek to identify the ‘underlying’ cause (that which sets the final train of events leading to death in motion) Statistics often must settle for the most proximate cause or symptom .
 Even this kind of analysis may be misleading for those charged with interpreting the data with a view to ordering health-care priorities for a particular country . The data is based on the national level of health care in the United States .
 The eight groups of causes of death utilized here include most, but not all, of the detailed causes classified by the World Health Organization . This would not, thus, aggregate to the country’s crude death rate for the same year .
 Expectation of life is probably the most accurate single measure of the quality of life in a given society . Expectation is probably most accurate measure of a society's quality, the author says .
 It summarizes in a single number all of the natural and social stresses that operate upon individuals in that society . The number is a simple list of the stresses that affect individuals .
 The number may range from as few as 40 years of life in the least developed countries to as much as 80 years for women in the most developed nations .
 The lost potential in the years separating the two numbers is prodigious, regardless of how the loss arises . The loss is due to poor public health services, or poor individual health practice in matters of nutrition, exercise, stress management .
 Available data usually include both first marriages and remarriages after annulment, divorce, widowhood, or the like . The available data usually includes both first marriage and second marriage .
 Well-defined family data are not collected as part of a country’s national census or vital statistics surveys . Data for households have been substituted on the assumption that most households worldwide represent families in some conventional sense .
 Increasing numbers of census programs are making more adequate provision for distinguishing nontraditional, often nonfamily households . Even in developing countries, even in developing nations, such as China, are making adequate provision .
 Each of these measures represents an aggregate value of goods and services produced by a specific country .
 GDP is a measure of the total value of goods and services produced entirely within a given country . GDP, the more basic of these, is the GDP of the country's economy .
 The GNI, the more comprehensive value, is composed of both domestic production and net income from current transactions with other countries . GNI is made up of domestic production, net income and current transactions from other countries. GNI includes both domestic and current net income .
 In the first section of the table, data are presented for the nominal GNI, the nominal GDP per capita, and the GNI purchasing power parity per capita . In the second section, the data are shown for GNI per capita and GNI Purchasing Power Parity .
 Purchasing power parity is an economic theory used to determine the number of units in a country’s currency that are required to buy the same amount of goods and services in another country . Purchasing price parity is a theory that determines the units needed to buy same amount in a currency
 PPP is expressed in a common currency, usually United States dollars, and as such it is often used to compare the standards of living between countries . PPP has been used in the past to compare living standards of countries .
 PPPs per capita in this table are nearly always calculated by the World Bank . The World Bank values are based on the World's PPP per capita values .
 "Real" GDP figures are adjusted to eliminate the effect of recent inflation or, occasionally, of deflation between two given dates . Average annual population growth rates for the same span of years are shown .
 GDP/GNI values allow comparison of the relative size of national economies, but further information is provided when these aggregates are analyzed according to their industrial sectors of origin and component kinds of expenditure . GDP/ GNI values are used to indicate the size of the national economies .
 Secondary sector is composed of manufacturing, construction, and public utilities . Secondary sector composed of construction, manufacturing, and construction .
 GDP agrimining manuconpublic transp., trade finanother governpower parity GDP lation per capita culture facturstrucutilcommucial Svcs. ment <%) <%> ing tion ities nications Svcs .
 The tertiary sector, which includes transportation and communications, trade, financial services, other services, and government services, is the most important sector .
 The category “other” contains adjustments such as import duties and bank service charges that are not distributed by sector . The category "other" contains adjustments that do not distribute by sector or sector .
 The majority of the world’s countries are in the less developed bloc . Data are given for outstanding external public and publicly guaranteed long-term debt rather than for total public debt, which is the major concern in developed countries .
 External account records the sum of all economic transactions of a current nature between one country and the rest of the world . The external account records all of the economic transactions between the countries .
 The account shows a country’s net of overseas receipts and obligations, including not only the trade of goods and merchandise, but also such invisible items as services, interest and dividends, investments, tourism, transfers to or from overseas residents, etc.
 Each transaction gives rise to a foreign claim for payment, recorded as a deficit (g ., from imports, capital outflows) or a foreign obligation to pay . The transactions give rise to either a deficit or a domestic claim on another country . Each transaction is recorded as either a surplus
 Any international transaction automatically creates a deficit in the balance of payments of one country and a surplus in that of another . This is a result of an international transaction creating a deficit of payments .
 The data is taken from International Financial Statistics published by the International Monetary Fund .
 Net income or expenditure from tourism is often a significant element in a country’s balance of payments . Tourism is a significant part of a country's balance of payability .
 Receipts from foreign nationals reflect payments for goods and services from foreign currency resources by tourists in the given country . The receipts reflect payments by foreign nationals from foreign citizens .
 Expenditures by nationals abroad are also payments for goods and services, but in this case made by the residents of the given country as tourists abroad . Residents of a given country spend money on goods and other services .
 The table focuses on the concept of “economically active population,” which the International Labour Organisation defines as persons of all ages who are either employed or looking for work .
 In general, the economically active population does not include students, retired persons and retired persons . Students, persons occupied solely in domestic duties are not considered economically active .
 Persons engaged in illegal economic activities also fall outside the ILO definition . Illegal economic activities include prostitutes, drug dealers, bootleggers, black marketeers and others .
 Countries differ markedly in their treatment, as part of the labour force, of such groups as members of the armed forces, inmates of institutions, the unemployed (both persons seeking their first job and those previously employed) and the unemployed .
 Some countries include all or most of these groups among the economically active, while others may treat the same groups as inactive . Some countries may include the same group as inactive, while some may treat them as economically active .
 Each of these measures indicates certain characteristics in a given national labour market . None should be interpreted in isolation, however, as the meaning of each is influenced by a variety of factors . Demographic structure and change, social or religious customs, educational opportunity, educational opportunities, sexual differentiation in employment
 Low activity and participation rates might be characteristic of a country having a young population with poor employment possibilities or of a good job market distorted by the presence of large numbers of ‘guest’ or contract workers who are not part of the labour force .
 Loss of working-age men to war, civil violence, or emigration for job opportunities may also affect the structure of a particular labour market . Loss of workers to war or emigrations may affect a particular job market .
 This occurs because the countries involved have poor, largely agrarian economies . The average worker is a farmer who tills his own small plot of land . This is because of the fact that the average worker in these countries is a small farmer .
 In countries with well-developed economies, “employees” will usually constitute the largest portion of the economically active . “Employees’s” are usually the largest part of the economy .
 Caution should be exercised when using the economically active data to make intercountry comparisons . Countries often differ in their choices of classification schemes, definitions, and coverage of groups .
 The population base containing the economically active population may range, in developing countries, from age 9 or 10 with no upper limit to, in developed countries, age 18 or 19 upward to a usual retirement age of from 55 to 65 . In developed countries the average retirement age is 55-65
 Data on female labour-force participation, particular, often lack comparability . Data on women's participation in the labour force often lack comparisonable data .
 Cultural bias favouring traditional roles for women results in the undercounting of economically active women . In many less developed countries, particularly those dominated by the Islamic faith .
 In other less developed countries, the role of women may be overstated . In other countries, particularly those in which subsistence workers are deemed economically active, women may not be economically active .
 The second major section of the table provides data on the distribution by economic sector of the economically active population . The table includes the distribution of economic activity by economic activity .
 The data usually include such groups as unpaid family workers, members of the armed forces, and the unemployed . The data is distributed by industry as far as possible .
 The categorization of industrial sectors is based on the divisions listed in the International Standard Industrial Classification of All Economic Activities . The sectors are based on a number of industrial activities .
 The ‘other’ category includes persons whose activities were not adequately defined and the unemployed who were not distributable by industrial sector . The “other” category includes those whose activities have not been adequately defined .
 A substantial part of the data presented in this table is summarized from the online database of the ILO . The ILO compiles its statistics both from official publications and from information submitted directly by national census and labour authorities .

 The FAO depends largely on questionnaires supplied to each country for its statistics . FAO makes estimates, using incomplete, unofficial, or other similarly limited data .
 FAO provides standardized guidelines upon which many nations have organized their data collection systems and methods . But persistent, often traditional, variations in standards in standards of coverage, methodology, and reporting periods reduce the comparability of statistics that can be supplied on such forms .
 FAO data are based on calendar-year periods; that is, that is the calendar year in which the harvest occurred . FAo data for any particular crop refer to the year of the harvest . FAO figures are published by the World Organization of Agriculture .
 World's agricultural production is probably more often underreported than overreported . Food shortages have been blamed for some of the world's most tragic food shortages .
 Some countries report only crops that are sold commercially and ignore subsistence crops produced for family or communal consumption . Others limit reporting to production for export only, to holdings above a certain size, or represent a sampling only .
 Methodological problems attach to much smaller elements of the agricultural whole, however, however . Methodological issues attach to some of the biggest problems in agriculture, such as agriculture .
 Some countries collect basic data they report to the FAO on sown or cultivated areas instead and calculate production statistics from estimates of yield . Some countries, however, collect the basic data and use it for production statistics .
 Millet and sorghum used primarily as livestock or poultry feed in many countries . Some countries use the same grains for human consumption and report them as cereals . Others use them as animal fodder only .
 FAO statistics include vegetables and melons grown for human consumption only . FAO vegetable statistics are based on vegetable and melon consumption only.
 Smallscale production may account for 20 to 40 percent of total output in certain countries . Some countries do not make this distinction in their reports . Some exclude the production of kitchen gardens and small family plots .
 Livestock statistics may be distorted by the timing of country reports . The timing of the country reports is often affected by the country's timing .
 Ireland, for example, takes a livestock enumeration in December that appears low against data for otherwise comparable countries because of slaughter and export of animals at the close of grazing season .
 It balances this, however, with a June enumeration, when numbers tend to be high . The June census is a good time to count the dead .
 Milk production as defined by the FAO includes whole fresh milk, excluding milk sucked by young animals . It includes amounts fed by farmers or ranchers to livestock but national practices vary .
 Certain countries do not distinguish between milk cows and other cattle, so that yield per dairy cow must be estimated .
 Some countries do not report egg production statistics . External estimates must be based on the numbers of chickens and reported or assumed egg-laying rates .
 Other countries report egg production by number, and this must be converted to weight . Conversion factors are specific to the makeup by species of national poultry flocks .
 Notes that follow, keyed by references in the table headings, provide further definitional information . Table headings provide further definitions of the events in the book .
 Most of the data and concepts used in this table are adapted from the United Nations’ Energy Statistics Yearbook . The table is based on the U.N.’s energy statistics yearbook .
 Total installed electrical power capacity comprises the sum of the rated power capacities of all main and auxiliary generators in a country . Total installed electricity power capacity is the total power capacity of a country with rated power capacity .
 Production of electricity comprises the total gross production of electricity by publicly or privately owned enterprises and also that generated by industrial establishments for their own use . Production excludes consumption by the utility itself .
 Annual production of electricity ranges generally between 50% and 60% of total production capacity . Measured in millions of kilowatt-hours (kWhr), annual production is generally 50% of the capacity .
 The great majority of the world’s electrical and other energy needs are met by the burning of fossil hydrocarbon solids, liquids, and gases, either for thermal generation of electricity or in . internal combustion engines .
 Many renewable and nontraditional sources of energy are still negligible in the world’s total energy consumption . Wood, biogenic gases and liquids, tidal, wave, and wind power are being developed worldwide .
 For this reason only hydroelectric and nuclear generation is considered separately with fossil fuels . Hydroelectric, nuclear generation are considered separately separately .
 Trade in electrical energy refers to the transfer of generated electrical output via an international grid . Trade in electricity is a transfer of electricity via the international grid to the power grid .
 Total electricity consumption (residential and nonresidential) is equal to total electricity requirements less transformation and distribution losses . Total electricity needs equal to the amount of electricity consumption less transformation, distribution losses less transformed and transformed .
 In this table, coal comprises all grades of anthracite, bituminous, subbituminous and lignite that have acquired or may in the future, by reason of new technology or changed market prices, acquire economic value .
 Coal may be differentiated according to heat content and content of impurities . These types of coal may be different from others depending on heat content .
 Most coal reserve data is based on proven recoverable recoverable reserves only, of all grades of coal . Most coal reserves are based on proved recoverable coal reserves .
 Exceptions are footnoted, with proven in-place reserves reported only when recoverable reserves are unknown . Exceptions only occur when recoveredable reserve is unknown .
 Production figures include deposits removed from both surface and underground workings as well as quantities used by the producers themselves or issued to miners .
 Wastes from mines or nearby preparation plants are excluded from production figures . Wastes recovered from mines and nearby plants are not included in the figures .
 This term refers to any combustible gas (usually chiefly methane) of natural origin from underground sources . Methane gas is a form of methane that is produced by underground sources in the United States .
 The data for production cover, to the extent possible, gas obtained from gas fields, petroleum fields, or coal mines that are actually collected and marketed . The data is based on data from the gas field, petroleum field and coal mines .
 Manufactured gas is generally a by-product of industrial operations such as refineries, gasworks, coke ovens, and blast furnaces . Manufactured natural gas is a mixture of natural gas and natural gas .
 It is usually burned at the point of production and rarely enters the marketplace . Rarely enters the market, it is often burned at point-of-production .
 Crude petroleum is the liquid product obtained from oil wells . The term also includes shale oil, tar sand extract, and field or lease condensate . Crude oil is a form of crude oil .
 Production and consumption and consumption per capita data in the table refer, so far as possible, to the same year so that the relationship between national production and consumption patterns can be clearly seen . Data are given in barrels.
 The published proven reserve figures do not necessarily reflect the true reserves of a country . Government authorities or corporations often have political or economic motives for withholding or altering such data .
 Estimated exhaustion rate of petroleum reserves is an extrapolated ratio of published proven reserves to the current rate of withdrawal/ production . The estimated exhaustion rate is based on published proven proven reserves .
 Present world published proven reserves will last about 40 to 45 years at the present rate of withdrawal, but there are large countryto-country variations above or below the average . The world's published proven proven reserves are estimated to last 40-45 years .
 Data on petroleum and gas pipelines are provided because of the great importance to both domestic and international energy markets of this means of bringing these energy sources from their production or transportation points to refineries, refineries and distribution points .
 The pipeline length for petroleum includes the combined total length for both crude and refined petroleum pipelines . Pipeline length for natural gas, condensate, and liquefied petroleum gas pipelines is included in the pipeline length .
 The source for these data was the latest edition of the CIA World Factbook . The data is based on the CIA's latest edition, the World Economic Forum's new book .
 Jamaica 1,469 11,808 7,217 98. H 791H 46,426H 348,982H 6,029H 3411 98H 24,289n Jamaica .
 The availability of information about these services often runs behind the capabilities of the services themselves . Unfortunately, the availability of this information is often limited to the capability of these services .
 Certain countries publish no official information; others publish data analyzed according to a variety of fiscal, calendar, religious, or other years . Still others, while they possess such data almost simultaneously with the end of the business or calendar year, may not see them published .
 Even when such data are published in national statistical summaries, it may be only after a delay of up to several years . The data may be published only after several years of publication .
 The figures include government publications, school texts, offprints, series works, and illustrated works, even those consisting principally of illustrations .
 A book is defined as a work of 49 or more pages . A work published simultaneously in more than one country is counted as having been published in each country .
 A periodical is a publication issued at regular or stated intervals and, in Unesco’s usage, directed to the general public . A periodico is a periodical published at regular intervals and directed to a public .
 Newspapers continually are founded, cease publication, merge, or change frequency of publication . Newspapers worldwide are founded and cease publication .
 Data on circulation are often incomplete, slow to be aggregated at the national level, or regarded as proprietary . Data is often incomplete or slow to collect at national level .
 Post office statistics are compiled mainly from the Universal Postal Union’s annual summary Statistique des services postaux .
 Some countries do not enumerate domestic traffic or may record only international traffic requiring handling charges . Some countries may not record domestic traffic .
 Data on mail traffic includes the number of copies of newspapers and excludes advertising material and ordinary money orders . Data is based on data from the U.S. Census Bureau, which shows that mail traffic is declining .
 Data for some kinds of telecommunications apparatus are relatively easy to collect . Telephones, for example, must be installed, and service recorded so that it may be charged .
 In most countries the other types of apparatus mentioned above may be purchased by anyone and used whenever desired . But in most countries it is not possible to buy such equipment .
 Data on distribution and use of these types of apparatus may be collected in a variety of ways . The data is collected on the basis of numbers of subscribers, licenses issued, sample surveys, trade data, census or housing surveys .
 Data on telephones refer to ‘main lines’ or the lines connecting a subscriber’s apparatus (fixed or mobile) to the public, switched net . Data on phones refers to “main lines,” or lines connecting subscribers’ apparatus to public .
 The Statistical Yearbook of Unesco contains extensive data on book, periodical, and newspaper publishing, and on television broadcasting that have been collected from standardized questionnaires .
 The quality and recency of its data, however, depend on the completion and timely return of each questionnaire by national authorities . The quality of the data is dependent on the accuracy and accuracy of each question .
 The commercially published annual World Radio TV Handbook is a valuable source of information on broadcast media and has complete and timely coverage . It is published by commercially published annually .
 It depends on data received from broadcasters, but some do not respond . Local correspondents and monitors are used in many countries . Unconfirmed or unofficial data is included as estimates .
 This table summarizes the basic indicators of health personnel, hospitals, by kind and utilization . It includes mortality rates that are most indicative of general health services . External controls on health (adequacy of food supply and availability of safe drinking water) Sources and amounts of expenditure on health care .
 Each datum refers more or less directly to the availability or use of a particular health service in a country . While each may be a representative measure at a national level, each may also conceal considerable differences in availability of the particular service to different segments of a population or regions of a country
 Limited financial resources at the national or local level may leave facilities underserved . Lack of good transportation may prevent those most in need from reaching a clinic or hospital .
 Definitions and limits of data have been made as consistent as possible in the compilation of this table .
 Organizations such as the World Health Organization try to maintain more specific international standards for training and qualification . For example, despite wide variation worldwide in the nature of the qualifying or certifying process that permits an individual to represent himself as a physician .
 Statistics for health personnel in this table uniformly include all those actually working in the health service field, whether in the actual provision of services or in teaching, administration, research, or other tasks . Statistics include those who work in the service field .
 Midwives are perhaps the largest and most important category of health auxiliary worldwide . Midwives represent, after nurses, perhaps the most important health auxiliary in the world .
 Hospitals worldwide differ considerably in terms of staffing and services . Hospitals also differ considerably worldwide in which they are different from hospitals .
 In this tabulation, the term hospital refers generally to a permanent facility offering inpatient services and/or nursing care and staffed by at least one physician . The term hospital is generally used to refer to permanent facilities that offer inpatient care and nursing care .
 Establishments offering only outpatient or custodial care are excluded from the list of establishments .
 These statistics are broken down into data for general hospitals, specialized facilities, local medical centres, and rural health-care centres . The last two generally refer to institutions that provide a more limited range of medical or nursing care, often less than full-time .
 Statistics on number of beds refer to beds that are maintained and staffed on a full-time basis for a succession of inpatients to whom care is provided . Inpatients are in the care of a number of patients at the hospital .
 Admission and discharge are the two principal points at which statistics are normally collected . Statistics are the basis for the data on the amount of care by kind of facility .
 The data on numbers of patients exclude babies born during a maternal confinement . The data includes persons who die before being discharged from the hospital . Data on numbers excludes babies born in maternal confinement, but include persons who are discharged .
 The bed-occupancy and average length-of-stay statistics depend on the concept of a “patient-day,” which is the annual total of daily censuses of inpatients . The average patient-day is a ‘patient day,’ which is
 The bed-occupancy rate is the ratio of total patient days to potential days based on the number of beds . The average lengthof-stay rate is based on total patient-days to total admissions . The length of a stay is the average length of stay rate .
 Bed-occupancy rates may exceed 100% because stays of partial days are counted as full days . Bed occupancy rates may be higher than 100% .
 Two measures that give health planners an excellent indication of the level of ordinary health care are those for mortality of children under age five and for maternal mortality . Two measures are important indicators of the quality of health care in the United States .
 The latter refers to deaths attributable to delivery or complications of pregnancy, childbirth, the puerperium , or abortion .
 Levels of nutrition and access to safe drinking water are two of the most basic limitations imposed by the physical environment in which health-care activities take place . Levels of food and water can be a limiting factor for health care workers .
 The nutritional data are based on reported levels of food supply, referred to the recommendations of the United Nations’ Food and Agriculture Organization . Fewer calories are needed in a hot climate to remain in average good health .
 The range of deficiency is less dramatic numerically but far more critical to the countries in which deficiencies are chronic . The deficiencies lead to overall poor health (raising health service needs and costs), to decreased productivity in nearly every area of national economic life .
 By “safe” water is meant only water that has no substantial quantities of chemical or biological pollutants . By "safe" water, it means no significant quantities of pollutants sufficient to cause “immediate” health problems .
 Data refer to proportion of persons having “reasonable access to an “adequate” supply of water within a “convenient” distance of the person’s dwelling, as these concepts are interpreted locally . Data refers to the proportion of people having ‘reasonable
 The data were excerpted from a joint effort by the WHO and the World Bank to create better analytical tools by which the interrelations among health policy, health care delivery systems, and human health might be examined against the more general frameworks of government operations .
 Expenditures were tabulated for direct preventative and curative activities and for public health and public education programs having direct impact on health status . But not more indirect programs like environmental, waste removal, or relief activities .
 Public, parastatal , international aid, and household expenditure reports and surveys were used to build up a comprehensive picture of national, regional, and world patterns of health care expenditures and investment .
 For reasons of space, public and parastatal are combined as the former . Public and public are combined for space reasons of the former, for the first time in a row .
 A principal source for expenditures was the World Bank Group Statistical Database, which includes national statistics, UN databases, and World Bank surveys .

 Zimbabwe includes Gaza Strip . Number of pharmacies includes pharmacies . Central Hospital only . Central hospital only .
 No well-accepted or well-documented body of statistical comparisons exists in international convention to permit objective assessment of any of these subjects, either from the perspective of a single country .
 The data provided within any single subject area do not represent the most consistent approach to problems of international comparison found in the published literature for that field .
 The provision of social security programs to answer specific social needs, for example, is summarized simply in terms of the existence or nonexistence of a specific type of benefit program . The complexity of national programs is the result of the great complexity of programs, such as eligibility, coverage, term,
 Activities connected to a particular type of benefit often take place at more than one governmental level . Activities connected with a particular kind of benefit may take place through more than a single agency at the same level .
 A bullet symbol indicates that a country has at least one program within the defined area . A circle indicates data is for 2007; in some cases it may have several programs . The bullet symbol is a bullet symbol .
 A blank space indicates that no program existed providing the benefit shown; . ellipses indicate that no information was available as to whether a program existed . ellipasses indicate no program was available for use .
 Data given for social security expenditure as a percentage of total central governmental expenditure are taken from the International Monetary Fund’s Government Finance Statistics Yearbook . The most comparable analytic series is based on the consolidated accounts of central governments .
 Data on the finances of social security programs are taken in large part from the International Labour Office’s The Cost of Social Security (triennial), supplemented by national data sources .
 Statistics are usually based on the number of offenses reported to police, not the amount of offenders apprehended or tried in courts . Statistics are often based on police reports, not on arrests or convictions .
 A person identified as having committed multiple offenses is counted only under the most serious offense . A person who commits multiple offenses can be counted as a person with multiple offenses .
 Murder refers to all acts involving the voluntary taking of life, including infanticide, but excluding abortion, or involuntary acts such as those normally classified as manslaughter . Infanticide is the most common form of murder in the world .
 Assault includes “serious,” or aggravated, assault involving injury, endangering life, or perpetrated with the use of a dangerous instrument . Assault includes serious, or aggravated assault, that involving injury or endangerment of life .
 Interpol statistics are reported as “breaking and entering,” but national data may not always distinguish cases of forcible entry . Burglary involves theft from the premises of another .
 Automobile theft excludes brief use of a car without the owner’s Social protection country social security programs available, 2007 or 2008 expendifinances . Afghanistan • • • 4.5% of the country's social security funds are from the U.S.
 Criminal offense data for certain countries refer to cases disposed of in court, rather than to complaints . Criminal offenses in certain countries are recorded in court cases, not in complaints .
 Police manpower figures refer to full-time, paid professional staff, excluding clerical support and volunteer staff . Figures refer, for the most part, to full time, paid professionals .
 Personnel in military service who perform police functions are presumed to be employed in their principal activity, military service . Personnel in the military service perform police duties in the UK .
 The figures for military manpower refer to full-time, active-duty military service and exclude reserve, militia, paramilitary, and similar organizations . The figures are based on full time, active duty military service .
 The data on military expenditures are from the SIPRI Military Expenditure Database and the IMF’s Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and country statistical publications .
 Programs providing cash payments for each of the three types of longterm benefit indicated to persons exceeding a specified working age who are qualified by a term of covered employment . Qualified by their status as spouse, cohabitant, or dependent minor of a qualified person who dies . Qualifying by
 Programs providing cash or medical services to employment-qualified persons who become temporarily or permanently incapacitated (fully or partially) by work-related injury or illness .
 Programs providing cash payments to families or mothers to mitigate the cost of raising children and to encourage the formation of larger families .
 A police officer is a full-time, paid professional, performing domestic security functions . Police officers perform domestic security duties in the United States .
 Data include administrative staff but exclude clerical employees, volunteers, and members of paramilitary groups . Data include clerical staff but excludes clerical workers, volunteers and paramilitary members .
 Includes active-duty personnel, regular and conscript, performing national security functions . Includes all active and regular military personnel, including conscripts and reservists . Includes active duty personnel and regular service members .
 Excludes reserves, paramilitary forces, border patrols, and gendarmeries . Crime and law enforcement military protection country offenses reported to police per population manpower, 2008 h expenditure, 2007 arms trade .

 As of November 2008 United States and allied coalition forces numbered 143,000 and 6,500, respectively . United States military aid of U.S.$2 billion annually .
 Whenever possible, data referring to preprimary education programs have been excluded from this compilation . Preprimary education data has been excluded .
 These data are supplemented at each level by a figure for enrollment ratio, an indicator of each country’s achieved capability to educate the total number of children potentially educable in the age group .
 At the first and second levels this is given as a net enrollment ratio and at the third level as a gross enrollment ratio . At the second level this is based on the enrollment ratio of students in the United States .
 Data in this last group are confined to those who have completed their education and are no longer in school . Data is confined as far as possible to those with completed education .
 At each level of education, differences in national statistical practice, in national educational structure, public-private institutional mix, training and deployment of teachers contribute to the problems of comparability among national educational systems .
 Reporting the number of schools in a country is not simply a matter of counting permanent red-brick buildings with classrooms in them . It's not simply counting permanent buildings with classroom spaces, it's counting buildings in them.
 The resources of a less developed country are such that temporary or outdoor facilities are all that can be afforded, while in a developed but sparsely settled country students might have to travel 80 km a day to find a classroom with 20 students of the same age .
 Many at any level must work part-time, or that institutions in which they work may perform a mixture of functions that do not break down into a tidy categories . Such difficulties also limit the comparability of statistics on numbers of teachers, with the further complications that many at any levels must
 In certain countries teacher training is confined to higher education, in others as a vocational form of secondary training, and so on . In some countries it is a form of training that is limited to secondary education .
 For purposes of this table, teacher training at the secondary level has been treated as vocational education . For purposes, this table includes vocational education at secondary level .
 At the higher level, teacher training is classified as one more specialization in higher education itself . At the highest level, it is considered a teacher training specialization in education .
 Many countries have a primary system composed of grades 1 through 6 that passes students on to some kind of postprimary education . Many countries do, indeed, have primary systems that pass students through grade 6 .
 The difficulties are compounded when a country has instruction in more than one language or when its educational establishment is so small that higher, sometimes even secondary, education cannot take place within the country .
 Enrollment figures in this table may, therefore, include students enrolled outside the country . Students enrolled outside of the country may also be students in the UK .
 Student-teacher ratio usually provides a good measure of the ratio of trained educators to the enrolled educationable . Student teacher-student ratio is one of the highest in the country's schools .
 In general, primary and secondary students have been counted on the basis of full-time enrollment or employment . tertiary students and teachers have been . counted on . basis of both fulltime and part-time enrollments and employment .
 It is not always, however, the best indication of utilization of teaching staff and facilities .
 Utilization, provided here for higher education only, is best seen in gross enrollment ratio . Gross enrollment ratio compares total enrollment to population within the normal age limits for that level of college .
 Literacy data provided here have been compiled as far as possible from data for the population age 15 and over for the best comparability internationally . Literacy statistics provided here are compiled as well as possible .
 Standards as to what constitutes literacy may also differ markedly . Sometimes completion of a certain number of years of school is taken to constitute literacy . Others it may mean only the ability to read or write at a minimal level .
 When a country reports an official 100% literacy rate, it should usually be viewed with caution . Separate studies of ‘functional’ literacy for such a country may indicate 10%, 20%, or even higher rates of inability to read or write .
 UNESCO literacy estimates have been used for some of the least developed countries . UNESCO estimates are used in some countries where literacy is no longer perceived as a problem, thus no longer needed monitoring .
 Data provided for public expenditure on education are complete in that they include all levels of public expenditure (national, state, local) but incomplete for certain countries . In some countries this fraction of the educational establishment may be of a significant size .
 Occasionally data for external aid to education may be included in addition to domestic expenditure .

 The following list indicates the principal documentary sources used in the compilation of Britannica World Data . The list of documentary sources is compiled by Britannica's World Data database .

 Many sites exist that are narrower in coverage or less official and that may also serve the reader (on-line newspapers; full texts of national constitutions; business and bank sites) but space permitted for the top national and intergovernmental sites .
 Sites that are wholly or predominantly in a language other than English are identified . Sites that use English are so identified are identified by their language .

 References that appear with page number but without a year are references for the current yearbook . Other references that appear without page number are references to current yearbooks .
 Indented entries under a topic refer by page number to some other places in the yearbook text where the topic is discussed . Indented entry under topic refers to some of the topics discussed in the book . Indenting entries under topic refer to other places where the book was written .
